DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Rape Suspect They Say Fell Asleep on Victim's Bed
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager who fell asleep on the bed of a woman he raped was arrested after the woman escaped with his clothes and called police, a detective said. ``He had been drinking prior to breaking into the house,'' said Nashville Sex Abuse Detective Brad Worthington. He said the suspect broke in through a front window, carried a knife and robbed and raped the woman. The woman, in her late 20s, waited until her attacker fell asleep, then ran from the room with his clothing, Worthington said. ``He was still sound asleep when patrol arrived,'' Worthington said. James E. Winston, 18, who police said was from North Carolina, was charged with aggravated rape, aggravated robbery and aggravated burglary. He denied he was involved in the crime.

DOC.HEAD: Where Buffaloes Roam, Residents Complain
DOC.TEXT: A roaming buffalo herd has trampled farm land and frightened schoolchildren in this central New York town. The worst damage was reported at John and Dawn Krewson's tree farm, where the buffaloes last week destroyed 241 evergreen trees worth more than $10,000. ``They reduced them to toothpicks. It looks like a hurricane or tornado came through,'' Dawn Krewson said. About 10 buffaloes were spotted Thursday walking in the road toward children waiting for a school bus. The herd wandered into woods by the time Onondaga County sheriff's deputies arrived, sheriff's spokesman Robert Burns said. He said the herd apparently belongs to the Onondaga Indian Nation, and Chief Leon Shenandoah was leading a search for the animals. There was no answer at Shenandoah's telephone number Thursday. ``It's very dangerous,'' said Peggy Holm, who encountered about 15 of the beasts while driving Thursday morning in Lafayette, about 15 miles south of Syracuse. ``I herded them down the road with my car.''

DOC.HEAD: Interior Minister Calls For Amnesty of Prisoners on Unity Day
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's interior minister has asked for an amnesty to give prisoners a fresh start in a united Germany next month. Prisoners demanding amnesty have protested in several jails in recent days, saying they were unfairly jailed under the previous Communist regime. Pieter-Michael Diestel said Thursday in a statement together with Vera Wollenberger of the left-leaning Buendnis 90 that the amnesty should be linked to German unity slated for Oct. 3. The appeal to the East German Parliament said the amnesty should cover prisoners convicted of minor crimes and that those jailed for major crimes should have their sentences reduced. Ms. Wollenberger read the statement to Parliament and cited a letter from a prisoner asking for the chance to ``attempt a new beginning in freedom.''

DOC.HEAD: Births in 1989 Lowest Since World War II
DOC.TEXT: The number of babies born in Japan last year fell by 67,204 from a year earlier to a record low 1,246,802, the Health and Welfare Ministry said. The previous low was 1,314,006 in 1988, said a ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Earlier, the ministry said that in 1989, the average Japanese woman had 1.57 children. The official said the average bridegroom was 28.5 years old in 1989, compared with 28.4 years old in 1988, while the average bride was 25.8 years old, unchanged from 1988. The Home Affairs Ministry said last month Japan's population was 122.74 million at the end of March. It attributed recent low population growth to the increasing role of women in the work place and the high cost of educating children.

DOC.HEAD: Lang Unveils Franco-American Agreement
DOC.TEXT: French and U.S. film directors will be able to work more easily in each others' countries under an agreement with the Motion Picture and Entertainment Association, Culture Minister Jack Lang says. The agreement, negotiated by Lang and association president Jack Valenti, is likely to ease the concerns of many French filmmakers and other artists. They have depicted recently tightened visa requirements for foreign artists as a sign of increasing American cultural protectionism. ``The idea is to work towards establishing automatic filming permits, with a minimum of red tape,'' Lang said Thursday after meeting with Valenti. Valenti said the reciprocity agreement was now in the hands of U.S. unions and signing could take place this fall. Lang announced he would visit the United States in November to attend the French Film Festival in Sarasota, Fla. and inaugurate the French Music Office in New York.

DOC.HEAD: New Democrats Win Majority in Ontario Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with breakdown of seats won by various parties, comments by Rae, Peterson's resignation; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Ontario's 6 million voters elected the province's first socialist majority government Thursday, ousting the Liberals from power, according to early returns. The new government will be the first east of Manitoba led by the New Democratic Party. The only other NDP government currently in power is in the Yukon. New Democrat Marion Boyd, who runs a women's shelter, defeated Premier David Peterson, a Liberal, in the district of London Center. The Liberals lost more than 50 seats to the New Democrats, prompting Peterson to announce he would step down as Liberal leader. The New Democrats' leader, Bob Rae, won easily in his Toronto district of York South. ``Ours is not a party that is exactly accustomed to winning elections in Ontario,'' Rae told cheering campaign workers as his wife, Arlene Perly, stood next to him. ``My heart is full of great love and great emotion tonight. I say to you that I will simply do the best I can.'' The New Democrats won 74 seats to the Liberals' 35 seats and the Conservatives' 20. One race was too close to call with a few polls still left to report. A minimum of 66 seats is needed to form a majority government. Going into the election, the Liberals held a huge majority of 93 seats to the NDP's 18, giving them official Opposition status, and the Tories 17. There were two vacancies. Public opinion polls released in the final week of the campaign suggested a dramatic shift away from the Liberals and indicated the New Democrats had the opportunity to form their first government ever in the province. Rae made the Liberal government's integrity a main campaign issue, and the Liberals focused on constitutional reform. Ontario contains one-fourth of Canada's 25 million residents.

DOC.HEAD: The Associated Press Names Four Photo Executives
DOC.TEXT: Four members of The Associated Press photography staff have been named to executive positions. ``These changes are part of the department's restructuring as we approach PhotoStream and the high-speed, digital delivery of the AP's picture report,'' Vincent Alabiso, the AP's executive photo editor, said Thursday. ``This management team will work to produce a more diverse selection of photos tailored to every member's needs and deadlines.'' Tom Stathis has been named senior photo editor for North America, based in New York. His primary responsibility will be to oversee the AP's newsphoto report from the United States and Canada. George Mikulec has been named senior photo editor for administration and will manage the department's business-related matters. Based in New York, he also will oversee the operation of AP's extensive photo library and the New York darkroom. Mike Feldman has been named senior photo editor-news in Europe, Africa and the Middle East. He will be based in London, where he joins Horst Faas, who becomes senior photo editor-operations in the same region. Faas will help plan and implement the AP's expanding photo technology and the continuing growth of photo services in the region. Stathis, 36, is a native of New York's Long Island and a graduate of the University of South Florida. He worked for newspapers in Tampa and Clearwater, Fla., before joining the AP in New York in 1981. Mikulec, 58, is a native of Herkimer, N.Y., who joined the AP in New York in 1957. He worked in the photo library before becoming a photo editor and has been deputy news photo editor since 1982. Feldman, 43, worked overseas for Reuters as an assistant European photo editor and for United Press International as a photo manager in Philadelphia before joining the AP in New York in 1988. He is a graduate of Temple University. Faas, 57, a native of Berlin, joined the AP in Bonn in 1956. He worked in Singapore, Frankfurt and Saigon, where he earned a Pulitzer Prize in 1966 for his coverage of the Vietnam War. He earned a second Pulitzer in 1972 for photos from Bangladesh. Faas has been based in London since 1974.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Frigate Intercepts About 10 Vessels a Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.DATELINE: ABOARD USS ROBERT G. BRADLEY IN THE PERSIAN GULF (AP)
DOC.TEXT: Voices interject anti-American slogans as the guided missile frigate USS Robert G. Bradley and its two helicopters intercept vessels in the Persian Gulf. The frigate's skipper, Cmdr. Kevin J. Cosgriff of Binghamton, N.Y., told The Associated Press his ship was challenging an average of 10 tankers and freighters a day to enforce the blockade on Iraq, which invaded Kuwait nealry five weeks ago. Its helicopters check out almost as many vessels. As he spoke, the Greek-flag 52,000-ton tanker Filoxenia appeared on the horizon. The American warship questioned by radio the other vessel's last port of call, destination and type of cargo. ``We come from Jubail, Saudi Arabia, on our way to (the Saudi port of) Yanbu with a shipment of gas oil,'' the captain answered. ``We left Jubail on September 5 and we'll arrive in Yanbu on September 13.'' Cmdr. Cosgriff signaled the radio officer to thank the Greek and wish him a nice trip. Minutes later, helicopter pilot Lt. Rick Groenenboon reported he had intercepted six outbound tankers from sunrise to midday. Groenenboon of Augusta, Ga., identified the intercepted ships as two Norwegian, two Iranian, one Belgian and one Japanese. Speaking to reporters flown from Manama, Bahrain, to the ship, he said that radio stations often ``cut in with very impolite words, sometimes obscene.'' ``They also say things like Yanks go home. ... Stop this war,'' he added. ``Otherwise the radio exchanges with the (intercepted) ships are very polite.'' Cosgriff said this was his third tour of the gulf, having served twice in the region during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. He participated in escorting U.S.-flagged Kuwaiti tankers in the gulf at the height of the so-called tanker war. He judged the crisis after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait as ``more serious, and I am concerned about aircraft, mines, and missile capable boats.'' The frigate has so far not encountered any Iraqi warplanes, he said, but that ``we are occasionally subjected to reconnaissance flights by Iranian planes.'' The 453-foot-long, 3,800-ton Robert G. Bradley is one of nine U.S. warships involved in interdiction operations to enforce the U.N. blockade against Iraq. Its 200 crewmen would not answer political questions. Those interviewed said they were carrying out military orders and did not give much thought to whether the decision to send them to the gulf was right or wrong. They displayed to reporters anti-chemical weapons outfits and gas masks.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Needs Makes New Deals with Old Enemies To Survive Siege
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON5,LON7 Aug. 6.
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein's best hope of breaking the stranglehold of U.N. economic sanctions depends on reaching new terms with old enemies, Western analysts say. The embargo is slowly choking Iraq, effectively cut off by geography and Western warships from life-giving access to the sea. Western diplomats and military analysts, speaking on condition of anonymity, contend that short of war, surrender or compromise, Saddam's only possible moves are toward Syria and Iran. He has been locked in an often bloody ideological feud with Syrian President Hafez Assad for more than a decade. He fought a grueling war with Iran between 1980 and 1988, in which an estimated 1 million people were killed. ``It's like a chess game. You have to think two, three, four moves ahead. To see his options, you only have to look at a map,'' one Western diplomat said. The U.S.-led naval quarantine denies Iraq the use of its only two ports, which are at the northern end of the narrow Persian Gulf. Saddam's only hope of breaking the sanctions is via the coasts of Syria and Iran and through convoys of trucks hauling supplies across their long borders with Iraq, the analysts contend. That strategy is complicated by Iraq's relations with Iran and Syria, which has sent troops to Saudi Arabia to help confront Saddam's legions. Saddam has sought desperately to move closer to Iran. Iraqi Minister Tariq Aziz will fly to Tehran on Sunday, the first such visit by an Iraqi official since the outbreak of the Iran-Iraq war. Saddam ``has shaken hands with Iran, made peace, giving back territory paid for with Iraqi blood,'' said another Western diplomat. The Iraqi leader proclaimed the gulf war a great Iraqi victory, even though it was pretty much a draw brought about by mutual exhaustion. Some Iraqis now ask privately why it was fought. Western diplomats and military analysts contend Saddam had no choice but to make concessions to Iran. They say even if he persuaded other countries to break sanctions, no significant quantity of supplies could slip past the gulf barricade and that he needed to have border openings with Iraq. The analysts predict that Saddam has six months, perhaps a year, before Iraq crumbles under the weight of the sanctions. That estimate ignores the effect of any food shortages. The Americans ``have got him by the throat. And they don't have to tighten their grip,'' one military analyst said. Saddam has tried to rally support in the Arab and Islamic world. While he has wide popularity with the average Arab, most governments oppose him. In a statement released Wednesday, he called for a holy war against U.S. forces in the gulf, for the overthrow of governments that collaborate with the Americans, and for Arab and Islamic solidarity with Iraq. His religious crusade is a marked departure from the secular ideology of Iraq's ruling Arab Baath Socialist Party and is aimed in part at moving Iran and Syria. A change in Syrian policy toward Iraq is unlikely. Saudi Arabia is the bankroller for Syria, which has little to gain by ending its feud with Iraq. Syria and Iraq are ruled by rival wings of the Baath and have been at loggerheads since Saddam took office in 1979. Some diplomats argue Saddam's best hope left is his old enemy Iran, a country with 50 million people, many of whom harbor fierce anti-Western sentiment. ``Iran already has defied the West,'' one diplomat said. ``And who would ever ask Iran why it is importing so much wheat?'' An Iranian newspaper suggested in an editorial Thursday that Tehran might send food and medicine to Iraq despite the sanctions. The Tehran Times, which is close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani, said: ``Iran is certainly able to solve almost all food and medicine problems the 16 million population of Iraq is presently facing.'' It added: ``The reason lies in the treacherous approach of the West to Iran during the war.''

DOC.HEAD: Who Owns East Germany? Carving Up the Socialist State
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Large and handsome homes line every shady block in this township southwest of Berlin. To many residents, it would be difficult to move away. Many fear they may have to. Officials say up to 70 percent of the property here has been claimed by West Germans who once lived in its quiet neighborhoods. With German unification less than a month away, the day is drawing nearer when those claims _ and up to 1 million others _ will be decided by local committees in scores of towns. Such claims are only one aspect of the broader question of how to decide who owns land that was until recently under the strict Communist control and, before that, part of prewar Germany. The puzzle over property has been blamed for the reluctance of many businesses to immediately invest in East Germany, which is scheduled to merge with its capitalist neighbor Oct. 3. Billions of dollars in land and buildings are also in the hands of former Communists, and a special committee has been trying to track down the property before the old guard strikes it rich on the real estate market. Klein Machnow is one of the prize pieces of residential real estate in the nation, as well as a favorite of the former elite. It borders an expensive section of suburban West Berlin and is only a 25-minute drive from the bustling center of the reunifying city. The Berlin Wall still runs along two sides of the township. So far, only a few openings have been made to connect the asphalt streets of the West with their cobblestone counterparts in the East. Many West Germans have been driving through those gaps to look at the land their parents left them years ago. Gerhard Hollman recalled a visit from a West German woman who claimed her family once own his home in Klein Machnow. ``She said, `My family lived here for 20 years.' I said `I've lived here for 25,''' he said. Hollmann, his wife and three children are one of two families who occupy a sturdy two-story building four doors from the Berlin Wall. He works in a nearby electronics firm struggling to survive and pays a subsidized rent of $57 a month. If his home were just a block away, it might cost 20 times that amount. ``You go up and down this street and it is the same,'' he said. ``Some West Germans come here and act very aggressively, and say, `Get out.' Others are nice and say, ``Don't worry, I won't want it back for perhaps 10 years.' Either way, there is a lot of reason to worry.'' The German states have agreed West Germans who once owned East German land will be allowed to reclaim it, but that no East Germans will be forced to leave their homes or pay significantly higher rents. There are many unresolved issues, including whether West Germans can take possession of property in future years or if some compensation will be available to West Germans claiming land. Some East German tenant groups say once West Germans have control of their old property, East Germans will face increasing pressure to move out or pay rents they cannot afford. The deadline for filing property claims is Oct. 13. Local communities will then begin determining who gets what. The rush by West Germans has shortened tempers. In Pritzwalk, an East German was hospitalized with burns after he snipped an electrical cord of a West German's recreational vehicle, an Interior Ministry spokesman said. The cord had been surreptitiously plugged into the East German's home. West Germans comprise the largest group of people claiming land, but by no means the only group. A group of East Germans in the city of Schwerin, about 110 miles northwest of Berlin, is trying to reclaim farmland on what is now the border between the two nations. A number of German Jews also have filed claims on property they were forced to sell at low prices during the Nazi regime. Scores of corporations, both German and foreign, also are eyeing land and buildings left behind when the Communists nationalized the nation's industry. A treaty signed by the German states Aug. 31 gave businesses some protection, guaranteeing that land purchased for development cannot be lost to a previous owner's claim. Officials say most of the property being reclaimed is some of the best. The largest number is in the Berlin area, where there are 40,000 claims. Buildings Ministry spokesman Hans Zillig said 40 percent of the East Berlin's homes have been claimed. But Manfred Melzer, a West Berlin economist and specialist in East German property, said there are still too many unsettled areas. Property now is being priced too high by an inexperienced bureaucracy with limited knowledge of the free market, he said. After the hard-line government fell last year, the reform Communist caretaker government that followed began selling a lot of property under the table to Communist loyalists at cheap prices. Now, many current and former functionaries are believed to be sitting on real estate goldmines. Renate Oeckert and her husband, who works at the former state petroleum company, said she bought a Klein Machnow home from the government during the frantic days following the democratic revolution. The red-brick home came complete with a Berlin Wall in the backyard. ``We have no plans to sell it,'' she said. ``We only wanted a nice place to live. We just hope nobody comes and says it isn't ours anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Orphans Draw Romanian Princess Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
Eds: Alexandra is cq for mother and daughter.
DOC.TEXT: A princess who fled Romania 42 years ago and became a nun is ministering in her beleaguered homeland to AIDS-infected orphans who sleep three in a bed and die paupers' deaths. ``As always, it is the innocent who suffer,'' said the former Princess Ileana, now known as the Rev. Mother Alexandra at the western Pennsylvania monastery she founded in 1967. On Monday, the 81-year-old exile and her daughter, Alexandra, started a weeklong tour of Romania's orphanages, where an estimated 14,000 children were abandoned. An archaic practice of giving blood transfusions to sickly newborns has resulted in at least 687 AIDS cases among Romanian children, and the World Health Organization estimates thousands more may be infected with the virus that causes AIDS. ``My interest is to arrange something so that the children who are dying of AIDS should die a humane death,'' said Mother Alexandra, who has six children of her own. ``They deserve more than putting them all in one bed and pulling them out one at a time as they die.'' Mother Alexandra, the great-granddaughter of England's Queen Victoria and Czar Alexander II of Russia, fled the family's palace in the capital of Bucharest just after New Year's Day 1948, about a week after Communists forced her nephew, King Michael, to abdicate. In 1967, she founded the Orthodox Monastery of the Transfiguration, starting only with a mobile home in Ellwood City about 50 miles northwest of Pittsburgh. The monastery complex now has 12 buildings. In a recent interview at her monastery home among paintings of her family and relics of its rule, Mother Alexandra said she watched with interest last year's overthrow of Romania's Communist government and the execution of its feared dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu. Ceausescu made AIDS a state secret. His wife, Eleana, who also was killed by a firing squad last Christmas, was the enforcer of a ban on contraception and abortions in the nation of 23 million. The Ceausescus hoped to make the country more powerful by having 30 million people by the year 2000. ``The pro-choice people are making a great story out of it,'' Mother Alexandra said. ``There was no family planning, no pill. The women were forced to have more children than they could feed.'' Mother Alexandra was invited to Romania by Christiana, a fledgling relief organization founded by the country's doctors and priests. After her return, she plans to meet with directors of American charities to gather support for relief efforts. ``We need to be able to say, `This is what we need, this is what we have and this is how we can dispose of it,' '' she said. ``I have a lot of good will and a lot of faith. I hope to be able to move others to help.'' Mother Alexandra speculated an international adoption network would help some children. She said, however, that such a program could not place children in the United States, which blocks immigration of people infected with HIV. Mother Alexandra retains a following in Romania in part because for 30 years she made twice-yearly broadcasts over Radio Free Europe. She said she plans a low-profile visit to avoid the fray between the government of President Ion Iliescu, which granted her entry, and the political opposition. She's also wary of seeing the many changes that Communist rule wrought on Romanian landmarks. ``I want to remember it the way it was, as my home,'' she said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: The space shuttle Columbia, prevented from lifting off early Thursday, holds the record for the most launch delays. It is also the oldest ship in the fleet. Columbia set the mark when it was delayed seven times before a satellite delivery mission that finally made it off the ground in January 1986, two weeks before the Challenger accident. So far in 1990 only three shuttle missions have lifted off and with three more scheduled, NASA will fail to meet its goal of nine flights for the year. On Jan. 9, Columbia was launched on a satellite delivery run. It had been scheduled for liftoff on Dec. 18, but its launch pad was being refurbished and not ready. A rescheduled launch Jan. 8 was delayed by bad weather. Atlantis was launched Feb. 28 on a secret military mission. It was originally scheduled for Feb. 22 but was postponed successively to Feb. 23, 24 and 25 because commander John Creighton had a cold. On Feb. 25, with the crew in the cockpit, a malfunction in the range safety computer forced a scrub. The following day there was another postponement because of bad weather. On April 24, Discovery went aloft to place the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. The liftoff, originally scheduled for April 18, was actually moved ahead to April 10. But that attempt was halted with four minutes to go because of a faulty valve in a hydraulic power unit. Columbia, which flew first on April 12, 1981, was to go on its 10th trip into space on May 17, carrying the Astro observatory. But that date was changed to May 30 because of the Hubble mission was late. On launch day, engineers found a massive leak of hydrogen fuel and spent the next three months searching for a cause. On Aug. 29, while readying the ship for a Sept. 1 flight, launch control found it had no communications with one of the telescopes aboard the shuttle. The mission was rescheduled for Sept. 6, but the leak reappeared during fueling the night before and caused a third delay.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Has A Cow; Talk Show Host Milks It; Scouts Honored
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Eagle Scouts be prepared: If you want to collect letters of recognition from the governors of all 50 states don't expect much cooperation from Gov. Roy Romer. Colorado's governor is standing firm for postal parsimony despite being taunted by a radio show host as ``Stingy Roy.'' Jane Nelson, a Romer spokeswoman, said Thursday that the governor still believes his office cannot afford to send congratulatory letters to everyone who asks. But it will not be caught again sending letters explaining that it cannot send letters. Now, ``if we respond in a negative fashion to a request, we will simply send postcards, because they are less costly and more efficient timewise,'' Nelson said. Romer's postage policy took a licking when the parents of scouts Douglas Baker, 14, of New Milford, N.J., and Derek Kahill, 17, of Oradell, N.J., solicited letters of recognition from the 50 governors. The boys had become Eagle Scouts, the highest honor for Boy Scouts. Governors from 49 states complied, as did President Bush. Romer's staff sent letters explaining its no-letter policy. The boys' families were upset, and George Weber, host of a KOA radio show called ``The Flip Side,'' took up their cause. Weber interviewed the scouts on the air last week and urged listeners to write to ``Stingy Roy.'' Romer, who was listening, called in to Weber's program and took the talk-show host to task in a 20-minute tirade. Romer also lectured the boys on government responsibility. Weber responded: ``Take a sedative, governor.'' The exchange spurred newspaper editorials and cartoons. Columnists compared Romer with his predecessor, Richard Lamm, who was governor from 1974-1986. Although both are Democrats, Romer _ characteristically an upbeat cheerleader for the state _ is not usually compared to Lamm, who was nicknamed ``Gov. Gloom.'' Lamm attracted notoriety for his criticism of the use of expensive technology to keep terminally ill old people alive _ his 1984 ``we've got a duty to die...'' comment. While Romer's outburst at Weber lacked such life-and-death gravity, it did cause enough fallout that he felt obliged to pen Baker and Kahill an apologetic, five-page letter. ``I am writing to you personally so that you may understand my attitude and feelings about your personal achievement of becoming Eagle Scouts and about the way my office handled the issue,'' he wrote. Weber claimed victory. But Nelson said the governor's office letter-writing policy has only been altered slightly as a result of the episode.

DOC.HEAD: Crisis Provides Boost for Fort That Had Faced `Mothballs'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Not too long ago, the future of Fort Dix appeared bleak. But the Persian Gulf crisis has brought a renewed sense of purpose at the sprawling army base. Base personnel and critics of a plan to scale back operations at Fort Dix are feeling just a bit smug now that the base is playing a major role in mobilizing Army reserve units for deployment in Operation Desert Shield. ``It shows the military importance of Fort Dix,'' said Rep. James Saxton, R-N.J. ``If we are to have a large mobilization of National Guard or Army Reserve forces, Fort Dix is just the base for that. ``This is the kind of thing that we said over and over again that Fort Dix would be important for,'' Saxton said. The hatchet fell on Fort Dix last year when Congress approved a massive cost-cutting plan. A federal commission recommended closing 86 military bases and scaling back five more, including central New Jersey's Fort Dix, about 30 miles east of Philadelphia. An Army spokesman, Lt. Col. Joseph Allread, said the increased activity resulting from Operation Desert Shield will not alter the ultimate fate of the targeted bases. ``It doesn't change the base closure mandate which we have,'' Allread said. ``When we come through this current situation, they will still be moved towards closure.'' The plans call for the elimination of basic training operations _ boot camp _ for Army recruits at the fort by October 1992. The base's 3,800 civilian work force was expected to be trimmed by about one-third by the cutbacks. The base also employs about 8,900 members of the military. New Jersey politicians attempted, unsuccessfully, to derail the plan. And the base's role in the Persian Gulf crisis isn't likely to change the plan. But it has provided a validation of the base's importance, at least in the minds of those laboring there. Capt. Dwayne Lacewell, who commands an engineer battalion placed on alert, said the mood at Fort Dix is noticeably more upbeat these days. ``I think it should bring to light that Fort Dix has a viable mission in the force structure,'' Lacewell said. ``Obviously Fort Dix is an integral element in providing soldiers to the force.'' The arrival of reservists at Fort Dix last week was widely publicized, and that, said base spokeswoman Rebecca Wriggle, puffed out the chests of more than a few soldiers and civilian workers. ``Having a chance to do something that you prepare every day to do is a good feeling,'' Wriggle said last week. Fort Dix, which was established in 1917, will remain an active center for reserve and National Guard training, Wriggle said, and maintain its function of processing soldiers whose term of duty is completed. ``There are a number of things that will continue,'' Wriggle said. ``The major thing that is changing is that we will lose our initial army entry training function.'' And Fort Dix will continue as a mobilization center for Army reserve units. However, Wriggle said no one was kidding themselves that the recent reserve activity would somehow save the fort's boot camp. ``It is a stretch to think that it will affect the future of Fort Dix,'' she said. ``The realignment is a matter of public law now.''

DOC.HEAD: Charlie Sheen Completing Rehab at Drug-Alcohol Center
DOC.TEXT: Charlie Sheen, ending a month of rehabilitation in a drug and alcohol abuse center today, says drugs are the ``proverbial toboggan ride to hell.'' Sheen, 25, checked himself into the rehabilitation center, which wasn't identified, on Aug. 9 for what his publicist, Jeff Ballard, called ``severe exhaustion due to an arduous filming schedule of four features back-to-back.'' Now, Ballard said, ``He's fine.'' The son of actor Martin Sheen and brother of actor Emilio Estevez hasn't identified what substances he was abusing. He said on CBS-TV's ``Face to Face With Connie Chung'' that he had ``tasted the fruits. I gnawed some beef, as it were.'' He also told Chung drugs are the ``proverbial toboggan ride to hell.'' Sheen's recent movie appearances include ``Navy SEALS,'' ``Men at Work,'' ``Cadence'' and ``The Rookie.''

DOC.HEAD: Incumbents Head for Desert to Drum Up Votes Back Home
DOC.TEXT: One of the most popular stops on the campaign trail this year is the Saudi Arabian desert. Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., showcased his chairmanship of the Foreign Relations Committee by leading a delegation to the Persian Gulf last weekend. Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., was seen on local television interviewing home-state soldiers in the gulf. And Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., greeted voters in a USS Wisconsin hat upon his return. With the country in the grip of a Middle East crisis, candidates are racing to demonstrate their patriotism and support for the U.S. military. The themes are traditionally Republican and would appear to favor that party's candidates. But the unstable international situation makes voters less apt to throw out incumbents _ most of whom are Democrats. At least one GOP incumbent stands to gain from the gulf confrontation _ Helms, a diehard conservative facing a tough challenge from Democrat Harvey Gantt, the black former mayor of Charlotte, N.C. Gantt champions education and environmental concerns, and criticizes Helms for opposing spending in those areas. The gulf situation allows Helms to divert attention to the kind of federal spending he does support _ defense. In a new Helms ad, a narrator talks about Iraq's Saddam Hussein, his chemical weapons and the U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. ``Should we cut defense $300 billion?'' the voice asks. Helms says no, Gantt says yes, the narrator explains. Gantt made the proposal long before Iraq invaded Kuwait and says he still believes the money can be saved over the next five to eight years or longer. But he adds, ``I think the voters understand very clearly that Harvey Gantt stands behind the president and stands behind our troops.'' Gantt is not the only candidate who has been forced on the defensive by the gulf crisis. Many who have promoted Pentagon cuts or voiced reservations about the U.S. role in the gulf are finding themselves vulnerable to attack. In Oregon, for example, GOP Rep. Denny Smith is accusing his Democratic challenger, Mike Kopetski, of ``cozying up to Saddam Hussein'' and promoting appeasement tactics that didn't stop Hitler. Kopetski, who nearly toppled Smith in 1988, did say he opposed military action and hoped the Iraqi aggression ``wouldn't go any further than Kuwait.'' However, the remarks were made the same day as the invasion and Kopetski has since said he supports President Bush's moves. Smith's strategy could backfire in the end. Editorial writers across Oregon are criticizing him for opportunist and offensive campaign tactics. The gulf crisis has become a significant factor in other races as well _ including Senate contests in Iowa, Michigan, Illinois and Nebraska, where three Republican representatives and a former congressman are trying to oust four Democratic incumbents. In Nebraska, former Rep. Hal Daub pounced on Sen. James Exon for expressing reluctance to engage U.S. troops in combat in the gulf region. In Iowa, meanwhile, Rep. Tom Tauke said Sen. Tom Harkin's questions about whether Bush needed to call up the reserves were ``either tragically misinformed or blatant opportunism.'' Rep. Lynn Martin ridiculed Illinois' dovish Sen. Paul Simon as ``an election-year macho man'' for urging last month that Iraqi oil pipelines be bombed. And in Michigan, Rep. Bill Schuette has attacked Levin for past votes against conventional weapons. But the senators are fighting back with trips to the Persian Gulf, news clips of them with the troops, talk show appearances, op-ed newspaper pieces and emphasis on any relevant positions of authority _ in Levin's case, his chairmanship of the conventional forces and alliance defense subcommittee. The crisis would seem to be a windfall for Pell, who is facing a spirited challenge from Rep. Claudine Schneider in Rhode Island. In his role as Foreign Relations Committee chairman, Pell has been on television and op-ed pages and he led a delegation to Saudi Arabia just before Congress reconvened. But his flurry of activity came only after Schneider's campaign had needled him for weeks about his failure to respond quickly to the gulf crisis. ``It's interesting that nearly a month went by and you did not see him really sought after or showing up on CNN or the networks or major papers as a voice. Why aren't people asking him?'' said Wendy Burnley, a spokeswoman for the National Republican Senatorial Committee. Anita Dunn, Burnley's counterpart at the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, scoffed at such criticism. The Schneider campaign's ``test of whether Pell is an effective Foreign Relations chairman is how many times he's seen on TV nationally. That's not the best, most valid test,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: 57 Hanged And 700 Arrested In Anti-Drugs Sweep In Iran
DOC.TEXT: Iran hanged 57 alleged drug traffickers and arrested 700 suspected smugglers and addicts in a five-day nationwide sweep, Iran's Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said Thursday that nine men were hanged in western Hamedan province and 48 were executed in the city of Mashhad in northeastern Iran. IRNA said law enforcement agents seized 1 ton of narcotics in the sweep that began Saturday. Some of those executed were charged with possessing as little an ounce of heroin. The state-run Iranian media have reported more than 1,500 drug-related executions since December 1988 and arrests of over 50,000 addicts. Iranian opposition groups allege that drug-related executions are used to mask killings of political opponents.

DOC.HEAD: NASA to Replace Fuel Pump in Hopes of Solving Hydrogen Leak
With PM-Space Shuttle-Delays
DOC.TEXT: NASA plans to replace a softball-sized fuel pump this weekend to get shuttle Columbia ready for a fourth try at carrying an astronomical observatory into space in mid-September. ``This has been a troublesome and vexing summer for me and for NASA,'' Richard Truly, NASA's administrator, said Thursday. ``But let me just remind everybody that running the space program ... is not an ordinary business. We push the boundaries of human activity, flying in space, and it's a hard job.'' The new target date for the thrice-scrubbed launch will be early in the week of Sept. 17. That, Truly said, will let the Astro mission proceed without affecting the next flight, which must begin between Oct. 5 and Oct. 23. Space engineers, following a vapor trail of clues, said the pump was the leading suspect for the hydrogen leaks that canceled Thursday's scheduled launch. They will not be sure until they open the aft compartment of the shuttle on Saturday and remove a ``package'' that includes three of the pumps, one for each engine. The swap itself will take only two days, according to officials, but retesting and all the other steps required before a countdown can begin will take up the rest of the week. All along, NASA has said that Columbia must be on its way before Sept. 14, so that launch crews can turn their attention to Discovery, sitting on a neighboring launch pad. But the officials say now that was a ``soft'' date, subject to change. In any event, the Discovery flight is likely to be delayed several days because of a problem in its cooling system. Discovery will carry into orbit a space probe that then will be launched toward the sun, with a velocity boost gained by flying past the planet Jupiter. Only in the 19-day period will the alignment of Earth and Jupiter permit that boost. Columbia's leak problem first surfaced on May 29 while the shuttle was being fueled for the first attempt to launch the $150 million Astro observatory. After scrubbing the flight, engineers thought the hydrogen leaked from a plumbing connector between the orbiter and its fuel tank. Hydrogen also was detected in the aft compartment. William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program, said engineers concluded at the time ``that perhaps half that leak was drawn into the aft compartment and the other part went external.'' He said engineers found no separate cause for the leak in the compartment, which houses a maze of pipes, valves and pumps, ``but we could not conclusively say we did not have yet a second leak that was in the aft compartment.'' On Wednesday evening, however, engineers found the opposite to be true. Columbia had two leaks in May, and only one had been fixed, the one around the plumbing connection.

DOC.HEAD: Clamor For More Emergency Aid For Gulf Refugee Camps
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Countries are pledging millions of dollars to buy food and otherwise ease conditions in Jordan's overcrowded refugee camps, but relief agencies say more is needed and those stranded must be repatriated. Since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait 605,300 evacuees have crossed into Jordan, the official Jordanian news agency Petra reported. The majority have left Jordan, but relief officials estimate more than 100,000 Bangladeshis, Pakistanis, Indians, Sri Lankans, Thais and Filipinos remain. Japan today announced an additional $12 million to help Asian evacuees. Britain on Thursday earmarked $3.8 million more in refugee aid. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told the House of Commons the grant brought the British government contribution to $10 million. Sweden, Denmark and Norway have together pledged $14 million in relief aid. Finland has pledged $2.5 million and Italy $3.4 million. European Community foreign ministers meeting in Rome today planned to consider emergency aid to Jordan, the Italian Foreign Ministry said. The United Nations has sent more than 3,000 tons of food and supplies to Jordan and received $19 million in aid, mainly from Japan and Sweden, said Robert Souria, a U.N. relief official. ``The international community needs to send more,'' Souria said. The European Commission on Wednesday authorized about $19 million for relief, mostly for chartering aircraft. Humanitarian agencies applauded the donations but said the top priority was to send home the refugees fleeing Kuwait and Iraq. ``The aid agencies have said that there are ways of getting foreign nationals out. Scheduled flights are leaving Amman with empty seats on them,'' Martin Cottingham, spokesman for Christian Aid, said Thursday in London. Oxfam press officer Anna Feuchtwang said the agency has provided $475,000 worth of aid. ``I think we are doing as much as we can. The problem is, what Oxfam can do, what any charitable organization can do, is really not enough. ``What really needs to happen is for governments to help people to get out of Jordan, out of the refugee camps,'' Ms. Feuchtwang said. Richard Wright, a senior official with the International Red Cross in Geneva, said they are concerned that developing countries may not be able to absorb the large number of nationals fleeing the region. ``We can't afford to have another Hong Kong, where the `temporary' camps built 10 years ago to house Vietnamese boat people are still full,'' Wright said. The first of 10 flights organized by the government of Bangladesh returned to Dhaka on Thursday with 160 Bangladeshis. The flights are carrying a total of 1,200 tons of rice to Jordan, Bangladesh said. About 110,000 Bangladeshis were working in Iraq and Kuwait when the invasion took place. A British Airways jet left London Thursday with tents and 200 bales of blankets for Jordan, Christian Aid said. The Foreign Office said it was expected to pick up Britons evacuated by Kuwait. The International Organization for Migration said it would begin a 72-flight airlift to evacuate 19,000 stranded people on Thursday. The Geneva-based intergovernmental organization said the airflift would cost about $12 million.

DOC.HEAD: President Appealing Directly to Iraqi People to End Crisis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is appealing directly to the Iraqi people for support to end the Persian Gulf crisis as he renews a blistering attack on their president and prepares for a weekend superpower summit. ``We Americans should make something very clear _ our argument is not with the people of Iraq,'' Bush told a Republican rally in Tallahassee, Fla., on Thursday night. ``Rather it is with Iraq's dictator who uses innocent travelers as shields, who now, in direct contravention of international law, holds hostage civilians from many countries.'' He said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``must know that our policy ... will not be altered by this brazen blackmail'' and that the United States will maintain its military buildup in the region and enforcement of the international economic sanctions against Iraq. However, Bush told reporters traveling with him on a one-day political trip that he was glad for Saddam's offer of airtime to televise a message to the Iraqi people. The president called it ``a real opportunity.'' He has previously voiced a desire to take his case to the Iraqi people, as Saddam has done to Americans, with hours of his speeches and appearances broadcast live on U.S. news programs. White House officials said Bush will tape a message of about 10 minutes, probably next Wednesday after his address Tuesday to a joint session of Congress on the Persian Gulf situation. Press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the White House would put together the tape and then have a State Department translation made. ``We'll do the whole thing ourselves,'' he said in reference to the Iraqi offer of a TV crew to travel to Washington and interview Bush. Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat said that ``of course'' Iraqi TV would air Bush's message ``in its entirety without editing. Here you edit, in Iraq we do not edit.'' Bush will explain on the tape why the United States has sent thousands of troops and air and sea power to the gulf in the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, officials said. The president's statements Thursday about having no quarrel with Iraqis were reminiscent of the language he used in remarks about Panama before the December U.S. invasion to oust dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. Bush leaves tonight for Helsinki, Finland, to discuss the Persian Gulf and other matters with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Sunday. He also will press the Soviet leader for a quick resolution to strategic arms reduction talks that have been going on for eight years. Preparing for the summit, Bush consulted Thursday morning with Syrian President Hafez al-Assad, Turkish President Turgut Ozal, French President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Fitzwater said. The president also met Thursday with Israel's visiting foreign minister, David Levy before embarking on a day of politicking in Florida and Kansas. He used the political swing to issue a rallying cry for his Middle East policy as well as raise money for Republican candidates and praise U.S.-Soviet cooperation, which he said can deepen with this Sunday's summit. ``The world is united against this aggression,'' by Iraq, Bush told the Florida rally for Rep. Bill Grant. ``And I'm glad the Soviet Union is on our side on this one.'' ``And there is no substitute for the support of the American people,'' he said. ``I need you support and I hope I have it as we continue to stand up against aggression in the Middle East.'' Earlier he told a Kansas luncheon for Gov. Mike Hayden that the United States will see through its goal of forcing Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. ``There is nothing I want more than for our American servicemen and women to come home _ and they will once we've completed a mission that does right by America, and the world,'' Bush said. Bush's trip Thursday marked his first flight on the new Air Force One, a specially equipped Boeing 747 that replaced his aging Boeing 707.

DOC.HEAD: Schoolyard Gun Ban Urged in Congress
DOC.TEXT: Gun control supporters are calling for a nationwide ban on bringing firearms within 1,000 feet of schools, but federal officials say it would be virtually impossible to enforce. ``Passage of this bill will enable our children and their teachers to travel to and from ... schools without an overriding fear for their personal safety,'' Cleveland police Chief Edward P. Kovacic said Thursday. He urged the House Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on crime to approve the bill, which is similar to provisions included in an omnibus crime package already approved by the Senate. Bringing a gun within 1,000 yards of a schoolyard would be punishable by a maximum five-year sentence under the measure. The bill reflects growing concern over gun incidents on school grounds in recent years, including multiple slayings of youngsters by deranged individuals in Stockton, Calif., and Winnetka, Ill. ``Those incidents, while celebrated, are not isolated,'' said Rep. Edward F. Feighan, D-Ohio, bill's sponsor. On Thursday, at the same time the congressional hearing was taking place, an armed high school sophomore held nine classmates hostage for more than five hours at a school in Cumming, Ga. He surrendered after growing dizzy, and no one was injured. The bill would provide exceptions for weapons on private property, licensed by the state after a background check of the owner, unloaded and kept in a locked container in a vehicle or carried by a school guard. Concern that the bill could not be enforced, however, was expressed by Richard Cook, chief of the firearms division in the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. He said the bureau has 1,800 special agents nationwide to enforce scores of laws under its jurisdiction. ``Our firearms enforcement activities are focused on violent criminals and illegal drug traffickers,'' he said. ``As you can see from these numbers and the law enforcement demands placed upon us, ATF could not provide direct protection to all of the nation's schools and could not be expected to be the first line of defense against guns and violence in schools,'' Cook added. Local police should take the lead in enforcing gun laws around schools with support from the bureau, he said. Subcommittee Chairman William J. Hughes, D-N.J. also expressed some doubts on whether the bureau would have sufficient agents to enforce such a measure. ``We're lucky if we can inspect a firearms dealer once in 15 years at this point,'' Hughes said. ``I'm just curious what this bill adds to your arsenal other than a lot of problems at this point,'' said Rep. Chuck Douglas, R-N.H. He said the ``answer is a metal detector and not some law that can't be enforced anyway.'' According to a report distributed at the hearing by the Center to Prevent Handgun Violence, at least 71 people have been killed with guns at school nationwide over the last four years. The report said six were employees and the rest were students. The report said 201 individuals were severely wounded and 242 held hostage at gunpoint. It said gang disputes were responsible for 18 percent of gun violence in the schools, romantic disagreements for 12 percent, ``longstanding arguments'' for 15 percent, fights over material possessions for 10 percent and accidents for 13 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Farmer Battles Senator's Name Recognition in State Race
DOC.TEXT: Gordon Humphrey, who was unbeatable as a U.S. senator, may have trouble getting elected to the New Hampshire Senate. The popular Humphrey, who opposes abortion, faces state Rep. Jack Sherburne in Tuesday's Republican primary and some say an upset is a genuine possibility. ``I think (Sherburne) has a shot at this, which is amazing,'' says Peg Dobbie, state director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, which supports the pro-choice Sherburne. The election ``could go either way'' and likely will be decided by political and abortion activists if the turnout is as low as expected, says Republican Executive Councilor Peter Spaulding. Two years ago, 4,444 people voted in the Republican primary. Sherburne believes at least 2,000 more will vote because of the media attention given the race. The Republican incumbent, William Johnson, who is pro-choice, is running for Congress. But Humphrey, 49, of Chichester, has the enormous advantage of nearly universal name recognition in the state after 12 years in Washington. In an unusual move, he gave up almost certain re-election because he believes senators should be limited to two terms. By contrast, Sherburne, 67, a retired Air Force fighter pilot, is little known outside his hometown of Deerfield. In 1970, he retired to his farm where he grows corn, apples and Christmas trees, raises chickens and sells firewood. He served 12 years as a selectman and eight in the Legislature. Last year, he championed an ethics bill opposed by Republican legislative leaders. Humphrey is trying to cash in on his name recognition with bold blue and white campaign signs that read: ``Senator Humphrey.'' ``He's not particularly experienced in state politics, but there's this idea that he's somehow more deserving as a U.S. senator,'' Sherburne said. ``We realized when we started that name recognition was going to be the big thing,'' Sherburne added. ``We're still out there fighting.'' To combat Humphrey's advantage, NARAL, Dobbie's pro-choice organization, has set up a telephone bank to contact voters who haven't heard of Sherburne. To counter spending by abortion rights forces, Humphrey spearheaded formation of an anti-abortion political action committee, Heartbeat New Hampshire. It raised $24,000 by early September _ all but $1,000 from out-of-state contributors. Humphrey said the group is contacting voters in other Senate districts as well as his. NARAL raised $20,000 to spend on all races, $5,000 from out of state. Sherburne and Humphrey each has raised about $14,000. But Humphrey, unlike Sherburne, has refused to be bound by the $15,000 voluntary state spending limit for the primary, saying late spending by abortion-rights advocates could force him to respond. Sherburne has placed ads in weekly newspapers questioning why Humphrey would give up a federal seat with a salary of $98,400 to run for a $100-a-year, largely volunteer job. ``Why does he think we need a self-appointed savior from out of state?'' the ad asks. It then cites Sherburne's service as a legislator and selectman, and his position on abortion. Humphrey has said he'd like to run for governor, but not while his friend, Republican Judd Gregg, holds the office. He also says the state's ``conservative character is being eroded'' and needs conservatives like himself to rebuild it. While acknowledging that name recognition helps, Humphrey said he's taking nothing for granted. He's campaigned everywhere from dumps on Saturday mornings to judging a cow-chip bingo contest for charity. Humphrey also is trying to capitalize on his skinflint reputation in the U.S. Senate to win support from unhappy property owners who've seen their taxes skyrocket in the past decade. He proposes letting communities disregard some state regulations that add to property taxes and letting towns give tax credits to parents who send children to private schools. Sherburne agrees that property taxes can be eased by eliminating some education requirements, but he said Humphrey goes too far. ``All he says is fight taxes. That's too simplistic.'' The mostly rural district is comprised of 14 small towns between Concord and the densely populated seacoast. Voters interviewed at random in the district Monday were more worried about the Middle East crisis than the Senate race. Many were unaware of the race, and others were paying little attention to it. The few who knew how they would vote cited personal ties rather than issues. ``I think people are going to back Jack because they know him. I know he'll listen. I know I can get to him and that counts,'' said Deerfield librarian Evelyn Cronyn.

DOC.HEAD: New Corporation Promises World's Largest Oil Spill Cleanup Operation
DOC.TEXT: A new corporation is promising to become the world's largest oil spill cleanup operation. Marine Spill Response Corp. President John D. Costello announced Thursday his company will spend an estimated $800 million over the next five years to set up and operate a system to clean up U.S. waters and scour beaches around the Atlantic and Pacific oceans and the Gulf of Mexico as well as areas around outlying islands in the event of major oil spills. The non-profit company is to be funded by the oil industry, but it will operate independently, and spills will have to pay for its services, Costello said at a news conference. The cost is three times the original estimate of a petroleum industry task force that set up the corporation. Costello said increases in the estimates were necessary to do the job. The company plans to construct five regional centers in areas where major oil spills are most likely to occur: the New York-New Jersey area; Port Everglades, Fla., north of Miami; Lake Charles, La., near the Texas border; Port Hueneme, Calif., north of Los Angeles, and Seattle, Wash. Missing from the list is Alaska, where the nation's worst spill occurred March 24, 1989. Costello said the vastly improved spill response capability in Alaska is now greater than it will be at any of the corporation's regional centers. However, he said Marine Spill Response is negotiating to work out what role it might play in Alaska. In addition to the regional centers, the corporation will have vessels at about nine other sites, said Costello, a retired Coast Guard vice admiral. ``We're excited by the prospect of creating the world's largest, best-equipped and best-trained oil spill cleanup organization,'' he said. Each regional center will have the ability to handle a spill roughly as large as the record 11-million-gallon spill of crude oil from the Exxon Valdez in Alaska's Prince William Sound, he said. Regional centers can combine forces to handle even larger spills. The corporation expects to spend $315 million on initial equipment, including ships, trucks, booms, skimmers, dispersants and tools for dealing with wildlife and damaged shorelines. The company, with about 400 employees, will administer spill response but will contract most of the work out to scores of other companies, Costello said. The company was set up to fulfill the terms of federal oil spill legislation signed by President Bush last month. The law gives oil companies until February 1993 to show they can contain and clean up a worst-case oil spill. Costello said the new company would be fully operational by then and could provide some limited response even earlier. The oil spill law also increased the liability of shippers from a ceiling of $150 per gross ton of the tanker to $1,200 per gross ton. Costello said liability laws in some states should be changed to allow for a quick response to oil spills. He said that although his company would have no problem, because it is a non-profit corporation, its subcontractors might be inhibited.

DOC.HEAD: US-Soviet Security Join Forces To Safeguard Summit
DOC.TEXT: Finnish police say they were caught off guard when they were told less than a week ago to prepare for Sunday's superpower summit, but U.S. and Soviet security agencies have joined forces to help them. Police Chief Olli Urponen said the summit, while a surprise, was made easier by the experience of other recent visits to Helsinki by U.S. and Soviet leaders. ``Of course it's been a great help to have worked with the Americans and Soviets before on similar occasions,'' he said. In 1988, Finnish police worked with U.S. Secret Service agents when President Reagan made a brief stopover on his way to a Moscow summit with Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Eleven months ago, they joined forces with Gorbachev's KGB agents during the Soviet leader's three-day official visit. ``President Gorbachev's visit and President Reagan's visit form a basis for the security arrangements of this (summit),'' Urponen said. ``But each event is absolutely its own ... and we have to make security arrangements accordingly.'' On Thursday, Soviet and U.S. security agents met at the President's Palace, site of Sunday's one-day summit meeting. Urponen said Finnish, American and Soviet security agents have held several meetings during the week of summit preparations. He refused to comment on details of the U.S.-Soviet security cooperation. U.S. and Soviet summit advance team personnel refused to discuss questions related to the summit security arrangements. Seppo Tiitinen, Chief of Security Police, who is in charge of joint operations, said there were no hierarchy problems and that Finnish police would ``play the coordinating role.'' ``No direct threats have been made against this summit. There is no threat ... apart from the general threat of terrorism,'' Tiitinen said. Both Urponen and Tiitinen declined to speculate on whether Finnish President Mauno Koivisto's criticism of Iraq on Wednesday increased the danger of a terrorist attack. Koivisto, in a pre-summit interview, accused Iraq of wasting natural resources on weapons for war instead of helping the poor. It is unusual for a Finnish president to speak out on such issues. He said police officers, cars and equipment had been called into use from other cities and all able-bodied Helsinki police have been placed on duty for the weekend. In 1975, 35 world leaders met in the Finnish capital to sign the Helsinki Final Act of the Conference On Security and Cooperation in Europe. Urponen said the security job would be easier if police had the special powers Finland's parliament granted them temporarily during that 1975 meeting. The powers allowed police to stop people on the street and search houses if they suspected any danger for those attending the meeting. The special powers were criticized on constitutional grounds. They required a two-thirds majority of Finland's parliament, which is not in session this week.

DOC.HEAD: D'Amato: Soviets Wouldn't Object if U.S. Used Force in Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev will not condone the use of force to solve the gulf crisis but probably would ``reluctantly look the other way'' if President Bush decided that was the only answer, Sen. Alfonse D'Amato says. D'Amato, the New York Republican, made the prediction Thursday, a day after meeting with Soviet leader. D'Amato has for weeks expressed doubt that the Persian Gulf crisis will be resolved without the use of force and has advocated the ouster of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein by bombing him ``off the face of the Earth.'' D'Amato was part of a seven-member Senate delegation that traveled to the Middle East, Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. The meeting with Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders covered a number of topics, including the Soviet Union's economic future and the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, D'Amato said. ``I don't believe that we're ever going to see the Soviets call for the use (of force), unless extraordinary developments take place, such as Soviet hostage-taking of their citizens, etc.,'' D'Amato said. ``However, at a certain point in time, if the president feels it is absolutely essential, then Gorbachev will reluctantly look the other way.'' On the question of U.S. aid, D'Amato said Gorbachev mentioned his desire for ``most-favored nation'' trading status and technical assistance from the United States. However, D'Amato said, Sen. Connie Mack, R-Fla., asked Gorbachev how the United States could justify such assistance when the Soviets are sending $3 billion to $5 billion a year to Cuba and billions more to Vietnam. ``He (Gorbachev) said, `Our relations are undergoing change _ Cuba, Afghanistan, Vietnam,''' D'Amato recalled. ``He said, `In the future we will be talking about trade and considering financial aid within the context of trade, not aid.''' Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, was even more direct, D'Amato said. ``He said, `There is no way that we can or should be providing economic aid to other countries when we are in such dire straits.''' Gorbachev has condemned Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait and cut off Soviet arms shipments to Iraq. But he has balked at joining a naval blockade to enforce a U.N. economic embargo on Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Learning the Soldier's Bible
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for possible duty in Saudi Arabia. National Writer Fred Bayles is following the 14 Guardsmen as they prepare for deployment overseas.

``The Soldiers Manual of Common Tasks'' is the Army's camouflage-covered bible, a compendium of instruction on everything from digging a foxhole to knocking out a tank. While it doesn't offer much in the way of plot, it is the book the 265th Quartermaster Detachment is reading these days. It is studied while waiting for chow, while resting in the barracks, while riding in the canvas-backed pickup trucks. The 14 members of the South Carolina National Guard water purification unit are studying hard for their final exam: deployment to the Mideast. No one seems to mind the homework. ``I'm glad for the training,'' said Spec. Bobby Youmans, 29. ``You can't give me too much. The more we train, the more we're ready.'' All this education suits Youmans, an officer at the Allendale Correctional Facility who has been in the Guard 11 years. Youmans has been to several National Guard schools, studying things like field telephone systems and refrigeration. ``I'm a jack-of-all-trades and a master of none,'' he said. His education is just part of the benefits of his guard membership. He not only learns a trade, he is paid for attending the school. Before his call-up, he planned to go to college with the help of the Guard's college program. ``You have to take advantage of what you can to improve yourself,'' he said. For now, self-improvement takes the form of classes in radio operations, compass reading, chemical warfare and small arms. Even the classes' location fits the curriculum. The men spend the afternoon in the humid heat of an open field to prepare bodies for desert temperatures. The first aid class is working on a life-size rubber mannequin with moveable simulated wounds. Rubberized arms and legs are swathed in different combinations of dressings and gauze as the instructor offers comment. ``Keep talking to him,'' he says, referring to the dummy. ``Tell him he's going to be all right. Get him mad. Tell him if he doesn't make it, you're going to get to know his girlfriend. You want to get him angry.'' ``But make sure you get his M-16 and pistol first,'' says Sgt. Hullie Cohen. The instructor tells a first aid story about his basic training when a soldier threw himself out a high window. The man survived with cuts and a broken leg. Instead of getting a discharge, the man was sent through basic again. ``The commander said he didn't want to lose anybody crazy enough to jump out a third floor window,'' the instructor explains. Further down the field another squad of men strip down their new M-16 rifles. The men sweat heavily and the instructor stops class often for the men to drink from canteens _ another lesson harped on constantly. As has happened throughout the day, the instructor suddenly calls ``Gas,'' and the men drop the weapons and pull on gas masks. Next comes a field problem: How do the men know when it's safe to take the masks off? ``Use your M256,'' say the men, referring to a small test kit that detects poison gas. ``You don't have one,'' says the instructor. ``You ask for a volunteer,'' says Sgt. Bill Bostick, reciting the next step. ``Before you ask for a volunteer, you better make sure your weapon is locked and loaded so if the man you ask to volunteer doesn't want to you can shoot him,'' said the instructor. ``It sounds hard but you've got to think of the rest of the unit.'' So Bostick, a brick mason, ``asks'' Henry Harris, the retired school teacher, to volunteer. Harris tentatively unseals. There is, of course, nothing wrong with the air other than a swarm of gnats. The men practice waiting the prescribed 10 minutes and when Harris doesn't fall over, they too remove their masks. ``We'll make sure we got plenty M256s,'' Bostick tells Harris.
