DOC.HEAD: Countries Line Up Behind Egypt for Debt Forgiveness
DOC.TEXT: Poland has at least as strong a claim for forgiveness of its U.S. debts as Egypt, which President Bush wants to reward for its help in the Persian Gulf, a senior member of Congress contends. The Poles are throwing off the shackles of communism imposed, with U.S. acquiescence, after World War II, said Rep. David Obey, D-Wis. They are suffering hardship while they seek to establish a market economy, a reform whose success is crucial to the outcome of Eastern Europe's dramatic changes. Before going along with Bush's plan to let Egypt off the hook for $7 billion in past military loans, ``I want to know what's happening with respect to Poland,'' which owes the United States some $3 billion, Obey said in an interview. Analysts say other countries are lining up for similar treatment at a time when wiping away debts, even uncollectable ones, will make more difficult the task of struggling U.S. budget negotiators. ``In reality, everyone else who owes money already is calling for similar treatment,'' said Robert Hunter, an analyst at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. Lawmakers fear opening a door they may not be able to close again quickly, and the White House has yet to offer a detailed explanation of why Egypt deserves help that should be denied to other allies. ``I am not about to support at this point making a single exception for one country without knowing what the rest of the game plan is going to be,'' said Obey, whose Appropriations foreign aid subcommittee will be a central player in the debate over forgiving Egypt's debt. Of the total official foreign debt owed the United States, nearly $20 billion is for past sales of military equipment. Much of that amount also is owed by countries who can claim that, like Egypt, they have bee helpful in the Persian Gulf crisis or have crippling debt burdens. Others might make the claim on a simple ``me, too'' basis. ``I want to know the administration's plans with respect to Israel, and to Pakistan ...,'' Obey said, naming some of those considered most likely to line up behind Egypt. Sen. Patrick Leahy, Obey's Senate counterpart, named Turkey, Greece, Morocco and the Philippines as other major debtors that might seek relief, and expressed alarm over the lack of a clear policy from the administration. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater has asserted that Egypt is ``a special case, and it's not open season on this kind of request.'' But there has been no detailed public explanation to back up that assertion. Egypt is the largest single debtor in the category of U.S. military loans, with an outstanding debt of $6.7 billion. Second on the list is Israel, which has $4 billion in unrefinanced debt. An additional $4.5 billion in high-interest military loans was recently refinanced under a program that offered U.S. guarantees and yielded an immediate saving to Israel of about $1.8 billion. Other top military debtors include Turkey, which owes $3.4 billion, a portion of which has been refinanced; Greece, $1.9 billion; and Pakistan, $1.3 billion. Further down the list is Jordan, which could argue that economic hardship stemming from the U.N. trade embargo with Iraq could justify forgiving its nearly $400 million in military debt. And there is no reason the list will stop at those who owe the United States for past weapons purchases. Poland's debt is primarily for food purchases from the United States, and Obey has included in the emerging 1991 foreign aid bill a provision that would let Bush forgive most of it. Carrying the loans on the books means some countries take the aid they receive from the United States, intended to help build their economies, and in effect sign the checks back over to the Treasury in repayment of their debts. Egypt, for example, owes principal and interest totalling more than $1 billion this year, more than the $815 million in economic aid it got from the United States. The situation, says Obey, is an ``absurdity.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Saudi Defense No Free Lunch for U.S. Allies
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. allies who depend on Saudi Arabian oil must realize that sending more than 100,000 U.S. military men and women to the Persian Gulf ``is no free lunch,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says. ``We need to have some of our friends step up to the counter and contribute more than some of them have indicated that they are prepared to contribute,'' Cheney said Thursday. The Pentagon chief's blunt remarks came as Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady continued their global search for cash to help pay for Operation Desert Shield. Cheney, in a speech to the Institute for Strategic Studies in Hot Springs, Va., chided those nations whose economies benefit from the guarantee of a free flow of oil, but haven't offered to help foot the bill. ``There's no free lunch here,'' he said. Except for lauding the military contributions of Britain, France, and the Arab nations who have come to Saudi Arabia's defense, Cheney mentioned no nations by name. Key Arab allies are planning to boost their forces, The Washington Post reported in today's editions. The newspaper, quoting unidentified officials in Saudi Arabia and Washington, said Egypt had agreed to expand its force of 2,000 soldiers to 30,000 and Syria had separately agreed to boost its 3,200-man contingent by 20,000. Cheney cited ``ample opportunities'' to help _ such as sending troops, aiding the transportation of troops or refugees, or even offering economic assistance to nations such as Jordan or Turkey that have been economically strapped by the U.N. trade embargo against Iraq. In his first public comment about the numbers involved in the U.S. buildup, Cheney said there are more than 100,000 U.S. armed forces in the Persian Gulf region. But is ``too soon as yet'' to halt the flow of troops and weaponry, he added. Since U.S. forces were dispatched to Saudi Arabia and gulf waters after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, Pentagon officials have been publicly silent about the exact number of forces or weaponry. However, it had been widely reported that some 60,000 ground troops and airmen had reached Saudi soil, while tens of thousands of sailors were on the dozens of U.S. Navy ships in the Persian Gulf and the Red Sea. ``The worst sin of all would be for us to deploy forces out there sufficient enough to get into trouble, but not strong enough to deal with any eventuality that may arise,'' Cheney said. He said the U.S. deployment of ground troops had reached a ``significant'' size, since the heavy tanks of the Army's 24th Infantry Division (Mechanized) and two Marine expeditionary brigades had joined elements of the 82nd and the 101st Airborne divisions. Members of the 1st Cavalry Division from Fort Hood, Texas, were on their way as well, Cheney said.

DOC.HEAD: Baptist Leader Decries Racism; Opposes Combat Role in Persian Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No lead expected
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the nation's largest black church says racism in America is worse now than it was during the civil rights struggles of the 1950s and '60s. Former President Reagan and his appointments to the Supreme Court are a large part of the problem, the Rev. T.J. Jemison said Thursday at the 110th annual meeting of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A. Inc. ``He (Reagan) will be remembered not because he didn't have a memory, but he will be remembered because he gave respectability to racism,'' he said. Jemison, who led one of the first successful boycotts of segregated busing in Baton Rouge, La., in 1953, said race relations stand at a criticial point in the nation's history. He said he thought the battle to condemn racism had been won during the civil rights struggle, but ``it's worse now than it's ever been.'' In his presidential address, Jemison also called for a negotiated settlement to the crisis in the Persian Gulf. He said that while he supported President Bush's decison to send troops to the Middle East, ``this convention does not condone war that takes the lives of our best young men and women, black and white, because of oil.'' The convention was expected to act today on a resolution on the gulf crisis. With 7.8 million members, the Baptist convention is not only the nation's largest black church body, but claims to be the largest black organization in the world. In the highly hierarchical convention, the presidential address offers a blueprint of where the denomination stands on social issues. The Baptist leader singled out Reagan's appointments to the Supreme Court for criticism, saying blacks will feel the impact of his conservative movement for three decades. ``They call themselves strict constructionists, but I call them strict segregationists,'' Jemison said. Addressing internal church issues, Jemison appealed to National Baptists to support their own institutions, including the $10 million World Baptist Center. The center has caused some grumbling about whether the denomination is more concerned with architectural monuments than the social needs of black Americans. Jemison said there must be fewer pastors and churches dropping only $100 in the convention's bucket. ``Isn't that a disgrace,'' Jemison said as he urged the 11,000 delegates to give more to both church programs and the world center in Nashville, the first headquarters building for the denomination. But the emphasis on fund-raising for the center rankled some delegates. Delegate Al Lipscomb of Dallas said in an interview Thursday the center is a ``Tower of Babel'' that reflects the denomination's lack of a social agenda. ``This really saddens me to see $10 million in the glorification of a center versus all the nation crying out for help,'' Lipscomb said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Seek More International Help in Saudi Arabia
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress bringing words of support to U.S. troops in the Saudi desert are seeking more support from America's allies for the military action. Several members of the 11-man delegation urged allies Thursday to send troops to join the Americans on Saudi soil and to help pay the costs of the continuing American buildup. The delegation's visit was to continue today, with stops at several other units before an evening flight to Jiddah for a meeting with Saudi King Fahd. Saudi Arabia on Thursday pledged billions to underwrite U.S. military operations in the Arabian desert, but European allies have yet to field ground troops in the region. ``I'm dissatisfied with the lack of burden-sharing generally so far,'' Rep. Les Aucoin, D-Ore., said Thursday during a visit with the 82nd Airborne Division's 1st Brigade in the Saudi desert. ``My constituents are looking for good-faith efforts on the part of our allies.'' Echoing that theme was Rep. Bill Hefner, D-N.C., who said he expected more European allies to support the Saudi defense effort because they ``depend far more on energy supplies from this area than we do.'' For the troops, the delegation brought promises that Congress and the American people support the deployment. ``You have averted a war to this point,'' Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa., chairman of the House Defense Appropriations subcommittee told the paratroopers. ``I don't know if you will down the road but you have to this point.'' Several lawmakers said they came away from military briefings with the impression Iraq's Saddam Hussein would be foolish to attack Saudi Arabia because of the growing American force. ``I think that every day that goes by the risk of a shooting war is less and less,'' Hefner said. Murtha concurred but added the caution: ``Anytime you have a potential enemy as fanatical as (Saddam) Hussein is, you have to believe there could be a war,'' he said. ``But if he has any professional ability at all, he will see that he will pay a high price.'' Murtha said he envisioned a long U.S. military presence in the region if Saddam stays in power as part of any resolution of the current crisis. ``We would have to have a substantial presence in the Middle East,'' Murtha said. He said it was unclear whether U.S. forces would be invited to remain on Saudi soil, but added: ``I don't think the Saudis will want us to leave any time in the near future.'' For now, he said, the U.S. deployment was ``open-ended'' and has the support of Congress and the American people. Several members of the delegation said the Middle East crisis would force a rethinking of American defense policy to respond to the first major military challenge of the post-Cold War era. They said expensive missile systems are likely to face cuts and more will be spent on faster sealift and air transport capacity. Manpower cuts also will be deferred, the lawmakers said. ``We're going to have to shift some priorities,'' said Hefner.

DOC.HEAD: Military Teachings Focus on Lessons of Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: The military's command schools are preparing officers for conflicts such as the Persian Gulf crisis by teaching the hard lessons once learned in Vietnam. Military educators told a congressional panel on Thursday that from the Marine Corps classrooms in Quantico, Va., to the Air Force's school in Maxwell Field, Ala., officers are taught that the focus is no longer on a superpower showdown. ``It's not the world environment in which we live,'' Brig. Gen. John Miller, deputy commandant of the U.S. Army Command and General Staff College, told the House Armed Services subcommittee on professional military education. It was an obvious acknowledgment of the U.S. invasion of Panama in December and the current massing of troops in Saudi Arabia to thwart Iraqi aggression. Students also are exposed to the painful lessons from the Vietnam War and the rancorous issues that emerged from that conflict, including the massacre at My Lai, inflated body counts and unauthorized bombings. ``The good, the bad and the ugly,'' said Brig. Gen. Phillip J. Ford, commandant of the Air Command and Staff College. Miller said many of the instructors are Vietnam War veterans who saw battles from the company to the command level. ``We bring to our task of educating tomorrow's leaders the realization that we did not fully understand the essential linkages between a clear statement of national objectives, the development of a national strategy, a military strategy and an operational campaign level,'' Miller said. ``We have no intention of watching that happen again,'' he said. Capt. Elizabeth Wylie, dean of academics at the Naval War College in Rhode Island, said the goal was ``not to have a school solution but a lively discussion.'' During the past academic year, a policy and strategy symposium at the Marine Corps facility included presentations from Gen. William Westmoreland, the former U.S. commander during the Vietnam War, and Roger Hilsman, a top official in the Kennedy administration who argued against U.S. involvement in Vietnam. Among the titles on the reading list for Marine Corps officers are ``A Bright, Shining Lie,'' Neil Sheehan's account of the life of John Paul Vann, an acclaimed military leader in Vietnam, and Stanley Karnow's best-seller, ``Vietnam: A History.'' The books detail both the United States' successes and failures in Southeast Asia. ``We're obligated to provide varying points of view. It's left for students to draw personal lessons,'' said Col. David A. Vetter, director of the Marine Corps Command and Staff College. Military educators noted that most of their students have never been in a war and from a historic perspective, the most recent lengthy conflict they recall is the Vietnam War. The hearing, chaired by Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo., was prompted by his conversations with military officials in which he learned that the Indian wars weren't being taught to students at Fort Leavenworth. Skelton said he was pleased to hear that the service colleges were taking ``low- and mid-intensity conflicts seriously'' as well as addressing the thorny issues from the Vietnam War. However, he expressed dismay that none of the schools had invited retired Col. David Hackworth to speak. The highly decorated soldier recently wrote a book harshly critical of the U.S. role in Vietnam.

DOC.HEAD: Marine General Says Air Power Can Destroy Saddam At Outset
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: If war erupts in the Persian Gulf, a U.S. Marine general says American air power could quickly smash Iraq's defenses. Maj. Gen. Royal N. Moore Jr. said Thursday that the stronger, technologically superior U.S. and Arab forces arrayed in Saudi Arabia along the border with Iraq would ultimately triumph over an offensive by Saddam Hussein's army. ``We want about three to five minutes, and we're going to give them the most violent three to five minutes they've ever seen,'' said Moore, speaking to reporters at a display of Marine Corps aircraft. ``That's all we want.'' Earlier Thursday, Saudi Arabia's defense minister, Prince Sultan, was quoted as warning Iraq that if Saddam carried out his threat to use chemical weapons, Saudis would respond with ``lethal'' Chinese-made CSS-2 ballistic missiles that can hit anywhere in Iraq. Although President Bush said Aug. 5 that Iraq's armed takeover of Kuwait Aug. 2 ``will not stand,'' senior U.S. officers have carefully avoided suggesting that any offensive is planned. They stress that U.S. forces are in Saudi Arabia only to protect it from further aggression. But should war break out, Moore said his strategy would be to immediately gain air superiority by destroying Iraq's anti-aircraft guns, missile batteries and air force ``within hours.'' Iraqis' air defenses ``are lined up fairly heavy on the coast,'' he conceded. But, said Moore, ``There's always a back door. You can't defend everything.'' Thus, he said, the multinational force would aim for Iraq's vulnerable points. U.S. and allied air strength in the region, including carrier-based aircraft and other superior U.S. and British artillery, is well in excess of 700. Iraq has an estimated 500-plus combat aircraft. Moore described a classic operation in which Marine air strikes, Naval gunfire and artillery would ``soften up'' a target. Assault troops would then move in by helicopter, go ``around it or over it'' or ``come in with the amphibious landing,'' deploying assault troops from seaborne transports. ``The country and the area of operations are so small that it'll be easy for me to cover ... any amphibious landing that we desire to make,'' he said. But Moore, who commands the 3rd Marine Air Wing at El Toro, Calif., conceded that the struggle for air supremacy probably would cause casualties on the U.S. side. ``I'm not going to ever predict that it's going to be a cakewalk,'' Moore said. ``If we do it right, the casualties will be light, we hope.'' He said that even if the U.S. forces seized control of the skies, the final struggle likely would be on the ground. ``I'm not saying that all that air's going to win it,'' said Moore. ``Air can't do everything. It's the tank-on-tank that probably cleans it all up.'' Moore declined to say whether the allied forces were strong enough yet to seize Kuwait back from the Iraqis. But he said that ``if the force level continues, there will be a period in time that we have enough combat power on the ground to do that.'' Moore said ``trolling'' probes by U.S. reconnaissance planes had revealed a formidable array of Iraqi anti-aircraft defenses along the coast to the north of the troops' location. The Iraqis have set their Soviet-made SA-2 and SA-3 missiles to track U.S. aircraft at 80-100 miles off the coast. The SA-2s have a range of about 11 miles and the SA-3s eight miles.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: No Obsession With Hostages This Time
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III issued a comprehensive statement on the Persian Gulf crisis the other day that barely mentioned American hostages in Kuwait and Iraq. In a curious way, Baker was speaking volumes about Bush administration policy on the issue: American hostages are not going to be an obsession of this administration, in contrast with its predecessors. Hostage crises produced the darkest hours for the last two presidents. Of Ronald Reagan's eight years in office, none was more trying than the late 1986-87 period when his efforts to obtain the release of the American hostages in Lebanon degenerated into the Iran-Contra affair. President Bush and Baker, both top lieutenants of Reagan, had bird's eye views of the political costs of the blunders Reagan committed in his eagerness to get the hostages home. And memories are still fresh of how President Carter was virtually chained to the White House for months on end in 1979-80, trying to devise a strategy for liberating the 52 American hostages in Iran. In his re-election bid, Carter carried six states. Some might say the current administration is being cold-hearted in not giving the Americans in Kuwait and Iraq its highest priority. After all, there are about 50 times more Americans held on Saddam Hussein's turf than there were in Tehran a decade ago. But that ignores the efforts the administration has made on behalf of the hostages, many of which have received little attention. The U.S. Embassy in Iraq makes daily appeals to the Iraqi Foreign Ministry for their release. The main reason the American Embassy in Kuwait remains open _ under appalling conditions _ in defiance of Iraqi orders is so that U.S. diplomats there can try to help the 2,200 or so Americans trapped in Kuwait. There are also tales of American diplomats loitering sometimes for days on end at the Iraqi border with Turkey, Jordan or Saudi Arabia, awaiting the possibility that a stray American in need of assistance might turn up. When an American appeared at the Saudi border the other day, she was received by a lonesome U.S. diplomat who had been staked out there for eight days. But there is a distinct let's-do-it-differently-from-Carter-and-Reagan image being projected by the administration concerning this hostage crisis. Bush refuses to allow the dust-up to imprison him in the White House; he spent much of August frolicking at his Maine vacation retreat. Baker has spent part of the crisis at his Wyoming ranch, receiving from a London newspaper the sobriquet ``the invisible man.'' The families of some hostages object to what they regard as the cavalier attitude of Bush and Baker toward the captives. ``If it was the president's son, he would not go on vacation,'' said Florence Culbertson, wife of a former hostage who returned to his Texas home this week. The administration is operating under the assumption that the best way to obtain freedom for the hostages is to devalue them, make their captors believe they will gain nothing by continuing to hold them. Bush said last week he will not be deterred from taking military action by Iraqi threats to the hostages. Baker spoke in a similar vein this week to the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ``We stand at a critical juncture in our history,'' Baker said, calling the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait ``one of the defining moments of a new era.'' Decisive action, he said, is required to confront a ``dictator who acting alone and unchallenged could strangle the global economic order, determining by fiat whether we all enter a recession or even the darkness of a depression.'' Baker's between the lines message is that this worst-case scenario could come about if the fate of the hostages _ and not national security interests _ becomes the issue that drives U.S. policy.
DOC.HEAD: EDITOR'S NOTE: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for The
DOC.TEXT: Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: 3 to Enter Pleas in Capitol Bombing
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Will be topped; court proceeding scheduled for 9 a.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Three leftist radicals could receive 15-year sentences under a deal with prosecutors in which they agreed to admit participating in a conspiracy to bomb the U.S. Capitol and seven other locations. Marilyn J. Buck, Linda S. Evans and Laura J. Whitehorn are scheduled to appear today in U.S. District Court to plead guilty to participating in a two-year conspiracy of ``armed propaganda'' to detonate bombs in government buildings and private offices, according to court documents. Prosecutors have agreed to drop charges against three co-defendants, according to court papers. The three women also agreed to plead guilty to setting of a bomb that blew a hole in a wall outside the U.S. Senate chamber late Nov. 7, 1983. The conspiracy count carries a five-year prison term while the charge of causing malicious damage to the Capitol carries a maximum 10-year term. The blast, which occurred after Congress had recessed for the night, damaged five paintings and blew the door off its hinges outside the office of Democratic leader Robert Byrd. None of the bombings in New York and Washington between 1983 and 1985 caused any injuries. The group, calling itself the Armed Resistance Unit, the Revolutionary Fighting Group or the Red Guerrilla Resistance, claimed responsibility for the bombings in communiques to news organizations. The underground organization is linked to a series of other crimes, including the $1.6 million armed holdup of an armored car near Nyack, N.Y., in 1981 in which two policemen and a guard were killed. Buck, 42, is serving a 50-year prison sentence for participating in the armed holdup and four others. She was also convicted of racketeering for helping convicted murderer Joanne Chesimard escape from a New Jersey state prison in 1979. Evans, 43, is already serving a 40-year prison term for illegally purchasing firearms. Whitehorn, 45, the only defendant not already serving another prison term, could face an additional five-year sentence if she pleads guilty to fraud in connection with possession of fake identification documents. The plea agreement signed by the defendants and prosecutors said the government will dismiss charges against Timothy Blunk, Susan Rosenberg and Alan Berkman. Attorneys familiar with the case said that a Supreme Court ruling on the issue of double jeopardy that was issued in May influenced the government's decision to drop the case against Blunk, Rosenberg and Berkman. Another factor was the lengthy sentences being served by all but one of the six defendants, said the attorneys, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Blunk, 33, and Rosenberg, 34, are serving 58-year sentences for possessing a 600-pound arsenal of dynamite, blasting caps, and other explosives. Berkman, a physician, is serving a 10-year sentence for possession of explosives, firearms and fake identification cards.

DOC.HEAD: Banks' Performance Is `Mixed Bag', FDIC Chief Says
With PM-Banks-States list
DOC.TEXT: The financial performance of banks in the Midwest, South and West showed improvement in the second quarter, while loan problems continued to grow in the Northeast and Southeast, government figures show. Nationwide, commercial banks earned $5.3 billion from April through June of this year, down 24 percent from the same period in 1989, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. reported Thursday. The FDIC said banks in the Northeast dragged down profits for the entire industry, which had earned a record $7 billion in the second quarter of 1989. ``It's not great, but it's not terrible,'' said Robert Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, a Washington research group. ``It's continued sogginess, basically.'' At a news conference, FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman said the latest banking results are ``very much a mixed bag.'' Banks in the West appear strong, while ``New England is having ... a real recession,'' he said. Seidman conceded that the outlook for banks and the economy has been complicated by the Persian Gulf crisis and the resulting increase in oil prices. Higher oil prices should help Texas and the Southwest, but that ``certainly is not going to be helpful to New England,'' he said. ``They're making a bad situation worse for a lot of banks that already had problems,'' Litan said, noting that the inflationary effect of rising oil prices tends to make banks more cautious about making new loans. Banks in the Northeast had a total net income of $1.026 billion in the second quarter, down a steep 62.9 percent from the same period last year. Real estate values have fallen sharply in the region. Nearly all of the banking industry's $2 billion increase in provisions against future loan losses was accounted for by banks in the Northeast, where those provisions rose by $1.9 billion. That was more than twice the amount set aside for future losses by Northeast banks in the second quarter of 1989, the FDIC said. ``The real estate problems of the Northeast have spread to the mid-Atlantic states, and signs of real estate weakness have appeared in several Southeastern states,'' the agency said. Banks in Maryland, Georgia and the District of Columbia showed a sharp increase in delinquent real estate loans during the quarter, the FDIC said. Banks in 22 other states had some rise in the delinquency rate of those loans. Six states registered a strong decline in delinquent real estate loans: Utah, Illinois, Wyoming, Kansas, Montana and North Dakota. Eighteen others showed some decrease. Most of the growth in real estate loans overall came from banks in the West, where they increased 7.25 percent during the second quarter. Home mortgages in California banks _ which jumped more than $5 billion, or 11 percent _ accounted for most of the growth in real estate loans in the West. Construction loans by Western banks rose by almost $1 billion during the period, including $881 million in California, while they decreased overall for the industry. Despite the progress in some regions, ``the quality of the banking industry's real estate loans is continuing to decline,'' the FDIC said. Nationwide, delinquent real estate loans increased by $3.2 billion in the second quarter, a rise of 13 percent from a year earlier. Most of the latest increase, $3.05 billion, came from banks in the Northeast. Analysts have said it would take a downturn at only a few large commercial banks to cause trouble for the deposit insurance fund, which posted losses in 1988 and 1989, even if most of the industry is healthy. Separately, the Office of Thrift Supervision reported last week that the financial conditions of more than 200 savings and loans have worsened since the agency made its last report in May. At least 246 S&Ls are expected to fail and are likely candidates for government takeover, the office said.

DOC.HEAD: Women Should Stand Up for Themselves, Griffiths Says
DOC.TEXT: Women must become more aggressive and outspoken in the face of indifference to their struggle for equality, says Lt. Gov. Martha Griffiths, who complained loudly about being pushed off the Democratic ticket in Michigan. ``Women are too modest and too quiet,'' Griffiths told the National Press Club. ``It's partly their own fault that they don't get promoted. They should be indispensable. They should be so good at the job that you can't get anybody else.'' The former state legislator and congresswoman sponsored the Equal Rights Amendment and an amendment to the 1964 Civil Rights Act that outlawed discrimination on the basis of sex as well as race. Her appearance came in the wake of Gov. James Blanchard's decision last month against retaining Griffiths as his running mate in his campaign for a third term. Blanchard, a Democrat, said he needed someone who could assume his job at a moment's notice. He said Griffiths, 78, had declined to release her medical records. She reacted bitterly to the decision but said Thursday she would support Blanchard's re-election because ``he has been a good governor and I know the other guy,'' a reference to GOP nominee John Engler.
DOC.HEAD: Black Editor Resigns To Protest Exclusion Of White Candidate
DOC.TEXT: Profile

An editor at the Washington Afro-American resigned after saying the minority-owned weekly newspaper refused to profile a mayoral candidate because he is white. Robyn Denise Yourse, who is black, said Thursday she submitted her resignation to publisher Frances Murphy after Murphy refused to include a story on City Council Chairman David Clarke in a 36-page issue of the paper. ``I felt that the reasons given for yanking the profile were racially biased,'' said Yourse. ``It was a decision in all good conscience I could not agree with.'' Yourse declined to elaborate on her discussion with the publisher, who also is black. Murphy denied that Clarke was excluded because of his race, claiming that other candidates who did not receive the paper's endorsement were not given full-length feature articles.
DOC.HEAD: Cal Poll Shows Big Green and Alcohol Tax Propositions Popular with
DOC.TEXT: Voters

The Big Green and alcohol tax ballot initiatives are popular with California voters, though only a minority had heard of the environmental measure, a poll shows. Proposition 134, the nickel-a-drink alcohol tax measure, would raise funds for alcohol and drug abuse programs, emergency medical care and other programs. It led 69 percent to 24 percent, according to the statewide California Poll of 468 people conducted between Aug. 17-27. Proposition 128, the environmental protection measure known as the Big Green, trailed among the voters who had heard of it before they were given the survey, with 12 percent supporting and 16 percent against. Once a summary of the measure was read to all those polled, the measure led 58 percent to 26 percent. The measure would phase out pesticides linked to cancer, ban oil drilling in state waters, curb ocean pollution, mandate big cuts in ``greenhouse'' gases and raise $200 million to save old-growth trees. It also would create the elected position of environmental advocate to prosecute violators. Pollster Mervin Field said Wednesday that heavy advertising campaigns aimed at both measures may narrow the gap by the time the initiatives are voted on in November. The margin of error in the poll was 4.8 percent.

DOC.HEAD: President is High on New Official Airplane
With PM-Gulf-Bush Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife Barbara will fly to the superpower summit in Helsinki tonight aboard the new Air Force One jumbo jet that a delighted president calls ``marvelous in every way.'' Bush took his maiden flight Thursday in the gleaming, regally appointed Boeing 747 that replaced an 18-year-old Boeing 707 that had carried every president since Richard Nixon. On cross-country hops to political rallies in Topeka, Kan., and Tallahassee, Fla., Bush pronounced himself well pleased with the whale-shaped aircraft, one of two jumbos that Congress and President Reagan commissioned in 1986 at a cost of more than a quarter-billion dollars. It can fly 7,140 miles without refueling _ 1,400 miles farther than the old Air Force One _ and could even be refueled aloft in a pinch. ``Have plane, will travel,'' the peripatetic president quipped when reporters jokingly asked if he planned any day trips to the Persian Gulf to visit U.S. troops. ``It's marvelous in every way _ the latest in technology and certainly very, very comfortable,'' Bush said after getting his first look inside the jet. It is painted in the same striking colors of white, royal blue and robin's egg blue with a gold stripe that John F. Kennedy chose for the first presidential jet 28 years ago. Kennedy's plane until now has still been used as the backup to the regular Air Force One. When a second jumbo jet is delivered by next June, both the 707s will be relegated to ferrying lesser government VIPs. The creature comforts range from a shower-equipped presidential lavatory to an airborne office with a large wooden desk to a fully decked conference room that could accommodate more than half the Cabinet. Bush and his wife will share a cabin in the nose of the plane decorated in soothing wood tones, with his-and-hers leather armchairs and twin sofas that fold out into twin beds. An upholstered wall mural depicts a rustic sunset in soft hues. There's even a medical room where the White House physician could perform emergency surgery atop a stretcher that latches onto a reclining chair. There are televisions galore, 85 telephones, computers, memory typewriters, facsimile machines, a paper shredder, two galleys with ovens and microwaves and enough freezer space to feed almost 100 people for a week. The new plane boasts separate cabins for guests, Bush's senior staff and other aides as well as for Secret Service agents and media representatives. The jumbo seats 70 passengers and 23 crew members, half again as many as the old plane. It can carry a media pool of 13 members, two more than before. The passengers on the maiden flight had nine movies to choose from, viewed on overhead televisions with the sound over stereo headsets. Thursday's offerings included ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'' and ``Young Einstein.'' Veteran flight attendant Becky Schulz said it will be more work running around the larger plane, but ``a lot less stress.'' ``You won't be stepping over people's feet all the time,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Targets 6 Bran Claims for Reduced Cholesterol
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration is targeting six companies for its first action to enforce a policy barring food makers from labeling their products with cholesterol-lowering claims. In letters to the six released Thursday, the agency said the claims for bran products are not backed by scientific evidence and must be removed from the product labels. The food-labeling policy, proposed last February but being enforced as an interim rule until one is formally adopted, allows companies to make only limited health claims about their products. Linking bran's dietary fiber to lower cholesterol is not among the permitted claims. But an official of one of the companies warned says the claim is scientifically legitimate. ``We feel the excellent studies that have been done more than qualify these products'' to make cholesterol-lowering claims, said Curt Rocca, chairman of Pacific Rice Products of Woodland, Calif. Officials of his company plan to discuss the studies with the FDA in hopes of persuading the agency to allow claims that eating ``Vita Fiber Rice Bran'' daily can reduce cholesterol levels in the blood. In its letter to Pacific Rice, the FDA said the claims were ``false and misleading in that they are not supported by ... the 1988 Surgeon General's Report on Nutrition and Health and the 1989 National Academy of Sciences Report on Diet and Health.'' Similar warning letters were sent to Ralston Purina Co. of St. Louis for ``Oat Chex'' cereal and Continental Baking Co. of St. Louis for ``Oatmeal Goodness Bread Wheat Oatmeal.'' Letters also went to J & J Snack Foods Corp. of Vernon, Calif., for ``Toasted Oat Bran Shake;'' Health Valley Foods Inc. of Irwindale, Calif., for ``Oat Bran Fruit Jumbo Cookies;'' and Select Origins Inc. of Yaphank, N.Y., for ``Rice Bran Oil.'' In its letter to Ralston Purina, the FDA said labeling of ``Oat Chex'' was ``false and misleading'' because the claims ``suggest that a serving of the product provides a nutritionally significant amount of fiber, and particularly soluble fiber, which is contrary to fact.'' Patrick Farrell, spokesman for Ralston and Continental Baking, a Ralston subsidiary, said, ``It's our belief that all of our products comply with regulations concerning label requirements.'' The companies have 10 days to respond to the FDA's warning. The FDA's draft policy allows specific health messages on products if they fall within a narrow range of claims regarding relationships between diet and health benefits that are outlined in the recent reports by the U.S. surgeon general and the National Academy of Sciences. Those areas have been limited to calcium and osteoporosis, sodium and hypertension, fats and cardiovascular disease, fats and cancer, dietary fiber and cancer, and fiber and cardiovascular disease. The FDA had said that if other links between diet and health are scientifically shown, they could be added to the list. Because there have been conflicting scientific reports as to whether dietary fiber reduces cholesterol, the FDA is not allowing that claim to be made on food products. The FDA told the companies that if corrective action is not taken, it could seek court action to remove the products from stores.

DOC.HEAD: FTC Wants To Make More College Football Games Available on Television
DOC.TEXT: In some cities, a college football fan might have access to a dozen televised games on a Saturday. The Federal Trade Commission doesn't think that's enough. Asserting that television viewers aren't getting a full selection of games because of restraints on competition, the FTC said Thursday it will try to change the system. The College Football Association and Capital Cities, which owns ABC and ESPN, are unhappy about it and are set to fight the FTC's administrative complaint. ``We want to have the marketplace ... determine what games are shown and when,'' said Kevin Arquit, director of the FTC Bureau of Competition. ``We think the system is operating to the benefit of consumers,'' said Lewis Engman, the CFA's lawyer and former FTC chairman. ``CFA is not a cartel. We are not interested in restricting output. We are trying to get more and more games on TV.'' The CFA was created as a bargaining agent for the major football schools and began marketing games in 1984, after the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that the NCAA violated antitrust law by selling national TV contracts for the games. But Arquit said the current system, with the CFA negotiating a network contract for its 64 member schools, is not in the best interests of consumers, schools or television networks. He argued that the Supreme Court ruled that restrictions aren't necessary and the same reasoning holds for the CFA practices. But Engman said the circumstances are different because the NCAA would not let individual schools sell television rights to their games and the CFA does. ``That's a far cry from the present situation,'' Engman said. ``Every (CFA) member school has the right to sell every one of its games, if it wishes.'' Notre Dame, for instance, sold rights to its home games, beginning in 1991, to NBC, eliminating those games from the CFA-ABC package that is to start next season. Engman called the proceeding ``a royal waste of taxpayer's money. I'm not aware of anyone complaining that there's not enough football on television.'' He said any CFA member can sell television rights to its games to local, cable or syndicated stations. But schools can't sell to national networks or, on cable, to ESPN, which is 80 percent owned by Capital Cities and with which the CFA also has an exclusive deal. Stations that purchase games on their own may not show them late Saturday afternoon when the network is showing the game to which it has exclusive rights. Arquit said the FTC also is concerned about contractual limits on the number of times certain schools can appear on television. An administrative law judge will rule on the allegations of anti-competitive practices after a hearing Nov. 13. The decision can be appealed to the five FTC commissioners and ultimately to the U.S. Court of Appeals. This year's contracts will not be affected. If the FTC charges are upheld, Arquit said, existing contracts could be rescinded and future anti-competitive contracts would be barred. Asked if each school would have to negotiate TV contracts on its own in that case, Arquit said he didn't know. In a statement, ABC Sports said the arrangement with CFA is ``entirely lawful and in the public interest. The agreement is designed to offer a broad selection of college football games to the widest possible audience. The number and quality of games available to viewers will benefit viewers, advertisers and college football.'' Right now, ABC has a contract with the Big Ten and Pacific-10, which are not part of the CFA. The CFA's $64-million, four-year contract with CBS expires after this season and ABC has a five-year, $210 million deal with the organization. Arquit said the FTC's investigation began two years ago but refused to say what triggered it. Usually such probes are spurred by a consumer complaint or a congressional inquiry. Engman said no CFA member had complained and said he did not believe any networks had approached the FTC.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Share Prices Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed sharply lower against the Japanese yen on Friday, while prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rose slightly. The dollar closed at 140.25 yen, down 1.40 yen from Thursday's close of 141.65 yen. The low for the day's trading was 140.00 and the high was 141.00. It was the lowest closing value for the dollar since 141.55 yen on Oct. 25, 1989. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues recovered to close at 23,962.07, up 150.16 points, or 0.63 percent. Estimated volume of trading for first-section shares was 440 million shares. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds finished the day almost even with Thursday's level, closing at 8.250 percent, up slightly from Thursday's close of 8.245 percent. The price stood at 82.46 points, down from 82.48. Currency dealers said the dollar's low opening followed its overnight downswing in New York over speculation that U.S. monetary authorities might push interest rates lower. But short-covering pulled the dollar back from the brink of the psychological barrier of 140 yen to the dollar, said Tadashi Sazaki, assistant general manager of the foreign exchange and international treasury division of the Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Analysts said the market's attention is focused on the U.S. Labor Department's release Friday of unemployment statistics for August on the assumption that the Federal Reserve Board, the nation's central bank, will respond by pushing interest rates lower to give the economy a boost. Kan Sugita, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, said the early dollar trading was brisk in both buying and selling. ``But I don't think the dollar will soon move below the 140-yen level'' before the release of the unemployment data, Sugita said. The stock market started slowly with mixed small-lot buying and selling in a favorable reaction to the yen's appreciation against the dollar, though some investors remained cautious against rising oil prices and an overnight decline on Wall Street, dealers said. ``Every investor is very, very negative,'' said Hidetada Yoshida of Kidder Peabody. Traders are worried about what kind of a deal might be cut at the weekend summit of President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. ``If the ceremony fails to get agreement, the market will be disappointed,'' he said. Arbitrage trading and the rapid fall on the bond market, heralding higher interest rates, also drove the market down, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Acquaintances of Suspect Pay Graffiti Tribute to Utah Slay Victim
DOC.TEXT: A Utah tourist slain while defending his mother against subway robbers is memorialized with graffiti in a schoolyard where the teen-ager accused of stabbing him once taught youngsters handball. The name Brian Watkins, spray-painted in bright red, orange, purple and blue, towers over the courtyard behind Junior High School 189 in the city's Queens borough. ``I gave that tribute to him,'' said Papo Love. ``I feel sorry for him because he lost his life for defending his mom.'' Love and other youths who knew murder suspect Yull Gary Morales, 19, of Queens, gathered by the decorated wall Thursday and talked about the penalty Morales should face if convicted of second-degree murder. Police say Morales alleged that Watkins ``ran into'' his knife Sunday night in a Manhattan subway station. After his father was robbed of $200 and his mother was knocked to the ground, Watkins, 22, fought back and was stabbed. Morales, known as ``Rocstar'' on the street, and seven other youths were charged Monday with killing Watkins as they tried to raise money to go dancing. Next to Love's tribute to Watkins, someone spray painted ``Rocstar, be cool man.'' Also written was ``Rest in peace,'' ``May God be with you'' and a peace symbol. The Watkins family came to New York from Provo for the U.S. Open tennis tournament, held in the same area of Flushing, Queens, where members of the street gang Morales co-founded, FTS, often hang out. The youths charged in the killing all were members of FTS, a posse _ a menacing gang or a group of friendly youths who like to dance and scrawl graffiti, depending on who describes them. Some locals said FTS was an obscene acronym; others said it stands for ``Flushing Top Society.'' A member of another street group, The Sanford Boys, who refused to identify himself, said of Morales: ``He's our friend. We don't believe he did it intentionally, but he did it and he's wrong.'' The graffiti tribute was praised by 10-year-old John Zambrano, who said Morales used to teach him and his friends how to play handball behind the school. ``He used to be a nice quiet kid,'' Zambrano said. ``He used to write poetry to his girlfriend.'' The ethnic mix of Flushing is evident the moment one walks into Junior High School 189 and sees flags from 79 different nations in the main corridor. Eight other flags have been stolen. The school's principal, Jay R. Littman, said more than 30 languages and dialects are spoken by the school's nearly 1,300 students. ``It's a pretty solid community,'' Littman said. ``Something we work on very hard is to get the students to respect people's rights to their property.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Find Genes Underlying Heart Disease in Young Athletes
DOC.TEXT: The discovery of two genes that cause dangerous thickening of the heart should help doctors spot youngsters who inherit the defect and risk death during strenuous exercise. The research, conducted at Harvard Medical School and published today, reveals the precise genetic error that underlies familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, the leading cause of sudden death among young athletes. Loyola Marymount basketball star Hank Gathers, who collapsed and died during a game in March, had cardiomyopathy, although doctors are unsure whether it resulted from the newly discovered genetic mixup. The research marks the first time scientists have pinpointed the precise genes responsible for an inherited abnormality of the heart itself. The scientists found that the condition is passed through families when errors occur in two side-by-side genes that oversee the production of an essential heart protein. Victims are prone to suffer heart failure or heart rhythm problems that can lead to cardiac arrest. Cardiomyopathy causes thickening of the walls of the heart. While familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is rare _ affecting about three in 100,000 people _ other forms of the condition are common side effects of a variety of diseases, including high blood pressure. By untangling the precise cause of the inherited form of the disease, experts also hope they will shed light on the mysterious origins of the far more common varieties of cardiomyopathy, and help scientists design treatments. ``It has significance far beyond this relatively rare disease,'' said Dr. Christine Seidman. ``We'll gain significant insights in the secondary causes of hypertrophy (thickening), which is a very common phenomenon.'' Seidman is senior author of the research, which is being published in the journal Cell. Parents with cardiomyopathy have a 50 percent chance of passing it on to their children. The Harvard researchers studied two families with the disorder and found that it was caused by genes that make proteins called myosin heavy chain polypeptides, which are essential for muscle contraction. Each gene contains about 30,000 bits of information. In one family, the disease resulted from a mistake in just one of those bits of code. In the other family, people with the disease inherited an extra gene that was a hybrid of the two heart protein genes. Seidman said defects in these genes are responsible for some, but not all, inherited cases of the ailment. Other research suggests that mixups in genes elsewhere in the body's genetic library can also trigger the condition. Tracking down the genes that underlie common conditions has become a highly competitive area of medical research. Just this week, other teams announced the discovery of one faulty gene that can cause some cases of arthritis and another that results in Creutzfelt-Jakob disease, an illness marked by rapid mental deterioration. Finding the genes that cause inherited cardiomyopathy has been a goal of researchers at several labs in the United States and Canada for several years. ``The work is extremely important,'' said Dr. Neal Epstein, who had been working on the disease at the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute in Bethesda, Md. He noted that some people who carry one of the faulty genes show no outward signs of their condition, even though they may suffer its consequences. Knowing the precise genetic defect should enable physicians to determine whether or not they are at risk. It also can help parents who are unsure whether more than one of their children also have the disease. ``If you had a child die suddenly while running to catch a bus, this can cause tremendous emotional strain,'' said Seidman. ``Do you let your other children run or play sports?''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Seeks Aid From Ousted Kuwaitis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Leads with 5 grafs to ADD Kuwaiti emir's pledge of monetary support for U.S. military presence; picks up 3rd graf pvs bgng Later today.
DOC.TEXT: The ousted Kuwaiti government joined Saudi Arabia today in pledging to help the United States bear the cost of the military buildup set up since Iraq invaded its country more than a month ago. Secretary of State James A. Baker III flew to this royal mountain retreat to see Kuwait's exiled monarch, Jabir al-Sabah, whose regime already has pledged to compensate Turkey for losses of up to $2 billion from the shutdown of an Iraqi oil pipeline. Al-Sabah said his government would contribute to the cost of the American military buildup in the Persian Gulf region ``in order to restore my country to what it was before.'' Speaking through an interpreter, the exiled Kuwaiti leader said, ``We will not spare any amount or any value. We will give whatever is necessary.'' The emir, asked when he would return to his homeland, said he could not predict. Baker interjected, however, ``The sooner the better.'' Later today Baker goes to Abu Dhabi for a meeting with President Zayid of the United Arab Emirates. U.S. warplanes are deployed in the Persian Gulf country to shield that country from Iraqi attack as well. ``We are facing the first real crisis of the post-Cold War world,'' Baker told reporters as he left Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, with a multibillion dollar commitment from the wealthy monarchy that is hosting 60,000 U.S. military men and women. Senior State Department officials said they were confident all the allied gulf countries would participate in what Baker calls a ``responsibility-sharing'' operation. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady is also seeking financial support from South Korea and Tokyo, but has yet received no firm commitments. Saudi Arabia promised several billion dollars Thursday toward defraying the staggering cost of the U.S. forces protecting the kingdom's oil fields from Iraqi aggression, U.S. and Saudi officials announced. The commitment came in response to a direct appeal by Baker. ``There was a meeting of the minds,'' a senior Saudi official told reporters after Baker met twice with Prince Saud, the foreign minister, and, for two hours, with King Fahd. Clearly pleased U.S. officials said the Saudis would, at the minimum, pick up all fuel, water and transportation costs for the American troops now stationed in Saudi Arabia. Earlier this week, Baker told Congress the U.S. presence, which also involves some 40,000 forces at sea, would cost about $6 billion by year's end. Both U.S. and Saudi officials declined to provide a specific price tag for the commitment, but the senior Saudi diplomat said, ``The United States will not be disappointed in what Saudi Arabia is willing to do.'' Other Persian Gulf countries and Japan also are expected to pitch in, providing assistance along with Saudi Arabia to poorer Arab and other countries feeling the bite of the U.S.-led economic boycott of Iraq. At a joint news conference today in Jiddah, both Baker and Saud ruled out compromise with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``There is really nothing to compromise,'' Baker said of the U.S. demand for Iraq to reverse its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and to restore the Kuwaiti emir to power. Compromise is ``not the word to use,'' he said. Still, Baker said, ``Our desire and wish is to find a peaceful way'' out of the Persian Gulf crisis. ``We cannot rule out any options.'' However, he offered no prescription to accomplish that goal. Baker acknowledged ``there has been some small leakage in imports to Iraq,'' but he said the U.S.-led embargo on exports was holding firm. Baker attributed the breach to a dispute on whether the Aug. 6 embargo approved by the U.N. Security Council permits food and medicine to get through to the Iraqis. Baker said a U.N. sanctions committee was weighing the issue. But he said there should be no exemption for commercial food sales to Iraq. Earlier, a senior U.S. official said the Saudis were reaping what could be considered a windfall from expanded oil production following a decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to partially make up for oil from Iraq and Kuwait. Since Iraq conquered Kuwait and the United Nations placed an embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti petroleum, Saudi oil production has been boosted an estimated 2 million barrels a day to about 7.7 million barrels, giving the Saudis nearly $100 million a day in additional revenues. From the outset of the crisis, the Bush administration has shied away from publicizing how much it seeks from its allies to offset U.S. military defense costs and to assist other nations hard pressed by honoring the boycott. Informed estimates of what the administration seeks run to about $500 million a month to help finance the deployment of tens of thousands of U.S. troops and the naval armada offshore and $4 billion over 12 months for nations suffering from the economic blockade of Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Nothing Compares 2 Sinead in MTV Awards
With PM-MTV Awards-List
LaserPhoto LA3
DOC.TEXT: Irish pop singer Sinead O'Connor breezed past American bombshell Madonna for top honors at the seventh annual MTV Music Video Awards, in a ceremony marked by a protest against censorship. The outspoken O'Connor took video of the year, best female video and best postmodern video for her stark ``Nothing Compares 2 U'' during the three-hour ceremony broadcast live Thursday night. Madonna's ``Vogue'' video won for direction, cinematography and editing. Madonna, dressed in an 18th century French costume bursting at the bust, performed a racy version of the video during the awards show. Ex-Eagle Don Henley beat Billy Idol and M.C. Hammer in the best male video category for ``End of the Innocence.'' But Hammer's ``U Can't Touch This'' won in rap and dance categories. O'Connor's closely cropped head as she sings ``Nothing Compares 2 U'' predominates the winning video. Even when she starts crying, the camera angle doesn't change. O'Connor caused a flap last month when she threatened to walk out on an audience of 9,000 at the Garden State Arts Center in New Jersey if the state-owned amphitheater played the national anthem before her show. ``I'd like to say I had a great respect for people of all countries, including American people,'' she told the sellout MTV crowd, which gave her a standing ovation. ``I don't see aesthetically what national anthems have to do with any country,'' she said after the ceremony. She said the incident taught her to be ``much more conscious of other people's feelings and not so obsessed with my own.'' The rap group 2 Live Crew performed ``Banned in the USA,'' a version of Bruce Springsteen's ``Born in the USA.'' The performance sparked a dance-fest by audience members who waved bumpers stickers reading, ``Censorship is UnAmerican.'' The rappers decried the banning of their explicit ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' album from some record stores. ``It's a damn shame. It's racist,'' said lead singer Luther Campbell. It was a disappointing night for last year's big winner, Laker Girl-turned-megastar Paula Abdul, whose ``Opposites Attract'' video was shut out, despite six nominations. Last year, Abdul won for best female, dance, editing and choreography for her ``Straight Up'' video. Michael Penn walked away with the new artist award for his densely written ``No Myth'' and two older groups enjoying new success also picked up awards: the B-52's for best group and art direction for their exuberant ``Love Shack'' and Aerosmith for metal-hard rock for ``Janie's Got a Gun.'' Janet Jackson, sister of pop icon Michael Jackson, was named in advance as the recipient of the 1990 Video Vanguard award, MTV's highest honor. Noted more for onstage drawing power than historical significance, the MTV Awards were broadcast live on the Music Television cable channel from the Universal Amphitheater. Emceed by late-night talk-show host Arsenio Hall, the show's lineup also included on-stage performances by Aerosmith, Jackson, World Party, O'Connor and a one-time reunion of New Edition. Last year, comedian Andrew Dice Clay was forever banned from MTV for delivering a routine laden with obscene and unprintable poems about sex and overweight women during the video awards show.

DOC.HEAD: Judge's Ruling Setback for Defense
DOC.TEXT: A judge's ruling has made it more difficult for an art gallery and its director to fight obscenity charges for displaying Robert Mapplethorpe's sexually graphic photographs, a defense lawyer says. Hamilton County Municipal Judge David J. Albanese on Thursday ordered the Contemporary Arts Center and director Dennis Barrie to stand trial Sept. 24 on one misdemeanor count each of pandering obscenity. Defense lawyers contend the 175-picture Mapplethorpe exhibition _ mostly portraits and pictures of flowers _ isn't obscene when viewed as a whole. But Albanese granted a prosecution request to let a jury see only the five pictures that depict sex acts. ``I'm disappointed but I'm not surprised,'' Barrie's lawyer, H. Louis Sirkin, said after the hearing. ``It certainly doesn't help us.'' Albanese said in a 12-page ruling that each photograph is a separate work. He said prosecutors will only have to prove that one is obscene to obtain a conviction. ``The court believes the retrospective is a vehicle for displaying the five S&M photographs,'' said Albanese, referring to the shots as sadomasochistic. Barrie did not attend the hearing. He was at a Washington fund-raiser to help pay the gallery's legal bills. He and the gallery already were scheduled for trial Sept. 24 on charges of using children in material involving nudity. Albanese said the combined trial could last 10 days. The child nudity charge is based on separate photographs in the exhibition of a boy and a girl with their genitals exposed. Each charge carries a maximum penalty of six months in jail and a $1,000 fine for Barrie, and a $5,000 fine for the gallery. Albanese rejected a defense argument to dismiss the obscenity charge on the grounds that state obscenity law exempts legitimate art displays. The charges were filed April 7, the day the exhibition opened to the public. The exhibition attracted 81,000 people before closing May 26. The Mapplethorpe exhibition opened Aug. 1 at the Institute for Contemporary Art in Boston. On Wednesday, a court clerk in that city refused a request to file obscenity charges. Defense lawyer Marc Mezibov asked Albanese whether he was aware of the Boston ruling. Mezibov said it indicated the pictures have artistic value that makes them immune from obscenity charges. Albanese said he had not read the ruling. But he noted that Massachusetts obscenity law differs from Ohio law, and said the Boston decision would have no bearing on the Cincinnati case. ``For all I know, the photographs may be in a different arrangement, a different order. They may even be different photographs,'' the judge said.

DOC.HEAD: New Options to be Studied in Spotted Owl Plan
DOC.TEXT: Members of a White House task force have been asked to explore ``new options'' in their efforts to devise a plan to balance protection of the northern spotted owl and timber jobs in the Pacific Northwest. ``Clearly the principals are not satisfied that they have come up with the best solution,'' Steve Goldstein, spokesman for Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan, said Thursday night. He said task force leaders told the panel's working members in a meeting this week ``to begin exploring new options.'' ``Secretary Lujan believes there are better options,'' Goldstein said. Goldstein denied a report in today's Washington Post that the task force had tentatively agreed to back a controversial proposal by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas and other government scientists to ban logging on millions of acres of old-growth forest inhabited by the owl. ``Coming back with the Jack Ward Thomas plan would mean they (members of the task force) did not fulfill their mandate,'' Goldstein said. Goldstein declined to say more about the new options being explored. Kelly Shipp, spokeswoman for Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, has also denied that any decision had been reached. Shipp said working members of the task force ``have made several recommendations through the entire process, but a decision has not been made yet.'' She said she hoped the plan would be fully formed sometime next week. The Interior and Agriculture departments are the government's two forest-management departments. Most of the land involved is managed by the Agriculture Department's Forest Service; some is managed by Interior's Bureau of Land Management. A congressional aide who spoke on the condition of anonymity said White House Chief of Staff John Sununu told Yeutter Wednesday night that the Thomas report is ``simply unacceptable'' because of its economic impact. The source said Sununu wants the panel to come up with an owl protection plan similar to the one being implemented by the Bureau of Land Management _ a plan that would have less economic impact but which is opposed by environmentalists. Another congressional source said Thursday night the task force is leaning toward adopting the Thomas report as an interim measure and would recommend that President Bush and Congress work out a permanent plan over the next year. An administration source who asked not to be identified said the task force has concluded it will be more difficult to save timber jobs than the task force originally had hoped. The Thomas plan called for setting aside large tracts of old-growth forest where logging would be banned. Logging interests argued that this would cost 150,000 jobs. The government, however, estimates the Thomas plan, along with other industry changes, would cost 20,000 jobs by the year 2000.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Who Held Classmates Hostage Sent to Psychiatric Hospital
LaserPhotos AX1,2
DOC.TEXT: A high school sophomore who held nine classmates hostage at gunpoint for five hours surrendered and was taken to a psychiatric hospital. No one was injured during the ordeal. ``I just wanted to leave the country,'' a smiling Randy Floyd Addis, 17, said as authorities led him away Thursday from the South Forsyth high school and middle school. Addis had demanded $3,000 before becoming dizzy and giving up the siege. He was taken to Central State Hospital in Milledgeville for evaluation. Sheriff Wesley Walraven of Forsyth County said Addis was charged as an adult with kidnapping and weapons violations. Addis has a juvenile arrest record, and suffers from epilepsy, among other health problems, he said. Addis entered the school about 40 miles north of Atlanta with a 30.06 semiautomatic deer rifle, a single-shot 12-gauge shotgun, a .25 caliber automatic pistol and black powder concealed in a duffel bag as a science project. Walraven said Addis fired the rifle over the heads of students in a civics class shortly before 8:30 a.m. A teacher wrestled the rifle away, but Addis pulled a pistol and held about 40 students at gunpoint. Addis periodically released all but nine hostages. Most of the school's 1,200 students were evacuated and released to parents. About 1:45 p.m., Addis became dizzy and officers moved in to take his weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Willing to Send Forces to Gulf Under Joint Command
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union would be willing to provide troops for a U.N. peacekeeping force in the Persian Gulf if they were under a joint command that included Soviet generals, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. A joint U.S.-Soviet military force under a United Nations banner would be a historic first for the superpowers, who have been on opposing sides of nearly every other global crisis since World War II. U.S.-Soviet cooperation in the gulf crisis will be topic No. 1 on Sunday when Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev hold a hastily arranged summit in Helsinki, Finland, spokesman for both sides say. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said the U.N. Security Council should revive article 47 of the United Nations charter, which provides for a military staff committee comprising representatives of the five permanent council members. ``We must put life into the military staff committee,'' Gerasimov said in an interview. ``The committee would be made up of the five permanent members, and not by one member.'' ``This committee will have military forces at its disposal. And of course we will be ready to participate,'' he said. Asked whether one purpose of the proposal was to make sure Soviet generals were in command of Soviet troops, to prevent unilateral military action by the United States, Gerasimov said ``yes.'' In the past, however, the United States and Britain have said they would not place their troops under U.N. command. The military staff committee, inactive since 1946, consists of senior officers from the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France. The Soviet Union voted with the United States on Security Council resolutions condemning Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, ordering economic sanctions against Baghdad and authorizing military means to enforce them. The Soviet Union has two warships in the gulf region, but they are not playing a direct role in the U.S.-led naval interdiction of ships carrying goods to and from Iraq. In Tokyo today, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze urged U.S. troops not to take unilateral action in the gulf, saying the superpower summit will seek ways to resolve the crisis peacefully. ``I don't think that U.S. troops would be well advised to take some unilateral, one-sided punitive action,'' he said. Shevardnadze also confirmed there were about 180 Soviet military advisors in Iraq, but he said the contingent is being reduced. In recent years, United Nations troops have been deployed only to separate warring sides, monitor cease-fire lines and try to keep the peace. Not since the Korean War of 1950-53 and Congo Rebellion of 1960-64 have U.N. soldiers undertaken a ``police action'' to reverse aggression or put down a civil war. And in the Congo and Korea, at the height of the Cold War, the United States and the Soviet Union were fiercely antagonistic. Gerasimov dismissed a proposal by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to link the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait to Israel's pullback from occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Once Bustling Port Now Near Paralyzed
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: One month after the U.N. embargo of Iraq, the once- bustling shipping business in the port of Aqaba is in the doldrums and the thriving tourist trade has disappeared from the palm-dotted shores. Much of the trade through Aqaba has been blocked by sanctions against Iraq, heavily dependent on trade through Jordan, but most people interviewed in the port expressed loyalty to Iraq's President Saddam Hussein. They blamed Washington for the embargo that threatens the livelihood of workers in the port that is Jordan's only outlet to the sea. ``What about the human rights you are always talking about?'' one shopkeeper Eid Al-Sharari asked an American visitor. ``You are going to murder me by stopping all the food from coming in.'' Jordan has appealed for international aid to save its strapped economy, further stretched by the U.N. embargo and the thousands of Arab and Asian refugees crossing the border from Iraq. Al-Sharari said many prices have doubled since the embargo began a month ago and supplies of rice, sugar and other staples were running low. Tourists have been frightened away from Aqaba, a stopoff point for the ancient ruins of Petra, 65 miles away and a preferred skin diving spot. Tensions in the Middle East have emptied hotels. ``We had calls from Italy with people saying, `Why are you still there? We heard Aqaba was occupied by the Americans,' '' said Mohammed Zghoul, an assistant desk manager of one hotel. The port at the head of the Gulf of Aqaba, a finger of the Red Sea between Arabia and the Sinai Peninsula, is an outlet for Iraq as well as for Jordan. Since U.S. warships began monitoring vessels in the Persian Gulf, traffic has dropped from more than six ships a day to two or three, said Awad al-Tal, the port director. Insurance rates have shot up and now include a $1,400 surcharge on each 40-foot cargo container and $35 per ton of cargo as of Aug. 25. With so few ships calling on the port, there are not enough to carry goods out. Phosphate is a major export to Asian markets but is now being stored in Aqaba, al-Tal said. Only half the monthly average of 650,000 tons was exported in August, he said. There are 2,400 permanent employees and 1,000 to 1,500 who work on a daily basis, the port director said. ``We haven't fired anyone yet,'' he said. But the overtime that supplied much of the income here has been eliminated, and al-Tal said there might be layoffs soon. The port was expected to handle 18 to 19 million tons of cargo this year, al-Tal said. Of that, 30 percent was exports of phosphate, potash, concrete, and other material, while 40 percent was imported goods such as meat, sugar, grain, electronics and automobiles. The remainder, al-Tal said, was transit trade, mostly to and from Iraq, but also Saudi Arabia and Jordan's tariff-free zone. The director, port employees and residents of Aqaba say no Iraqi goods are being transported now, in accordance with King Hussein's decision to abide by the U.N. embargo. There were no evident violations of the sanctions. Western diplomatic sources said that if severe violations were discovered, Western support for aid to Jordan could erode. They said minor violations were inevitable. For truck driver Mohammed Ali, trade had almost stopped. ``Since this started, nothing has come into my pocket,'' said Ali, who has nine children and was expecting $45 for his first load in a month. Stopped beside the narrow asphalt strip through the desert that connects Aqaba to Amman, he prepared a lunch of lamb's liver in the shade of a rig belonging to a friend, Said Khaleed. Khaleed's truck was broken and he was fixing it himself, an all-day job, because he had no money to pay a mechanic. Both men spoke of their hostility toward the U.S. government and fierce loyalty to Hussein. ``We're looking for death as you're looking for life,'' said Ali. ``We're praying to Allah that nothing happens, but if it does, we don't care.''

DOC.HEAD: Famed Pony's Offspring Sold, Bound for Pennsylvania
DOC.TEXT: A Pennsylvania man has bought four descendants of the famed miniature pony Misty and will move them from their Chincoteague Island home, prompting an outcry from their keeper. ``They're just saying nothing matters, no tradition, no Misty,'' Ruth Calvo said Thursday. ``What I care about is the history. It's being destroyed.'' Misty was made famous in the 1947 children's classic ``Misty of Chincoteague'' by Marguerite Henry. The book was the first of a series of tales she wrote about the herd of wild ponies that live on the island in the Atlantic Ocean off Virginia's Eastern Shore. Each year, the horses are forced to complete a swim of 10 to 15 minutes across a quarter-mile-wide channel for auction on the shore. Thousands of people gather to watch. Michael Pryor of Blue Ridge Summit, Penn., said Thursday he bought Misty's descendants from Paul Merritt, who owns the Misty Museum and Pony Farm, which Ms. Calvo manages. Pryor planned to move the four ponies to Pennsylvania as soon as today. He would not disclose the purchase price. Pryor said he already owns eight of Misty's descendants. He also is leasing Stormy, Misty's daughter, and the stuffed carcass of Misty. ``I know that we upset some people in taking the ponies off the island of Chincoteague,'' Pryor said. ``The ponies will be there during tourist season. That's where they should be.'' ``I live in Pennsylvania, but I'm a Chincoteaguean at heart,'' he said. He said he travels with his horses to state fairs, schools for handicapped children, hospitals, shopping malls and craft shows. None of the horses travel more than once a week, Pryor said. Pryor, who said he also owns a restaurant, said he runs a non-profit organization with the ponies _ Mike Pryor's Pony Outreach. The money raised pays veterinarian bills and buys food for the horses, with the rest going to handicapped children, he said. Ms. Calvo said she hated to see the four ponies taken away. She once owned the Misty site, but has not been able to make payments since April so now manages it for Merritt. ``Pennsylvania is a nice state. I have nothing against it, but it isn't Chincoteague,'' she said. Ms. Calvo also disputed ownership of two of the ponies. She said she owns one, Wings of Mist, because he was born while she still owned the museum-farm. Ms. Calvo said she gave the other pony to a plumber who did extensive work for her and that he asked her to keep him at the farm. Merritt said he owned all four horses. No one is sure how the herds of wild ponies got to the island. The most commonly accepted theory is that they are descendants of horses hidden on the island by early settlers who wanted to avoid paying taxes on the animals. Another theory has the ponies washing ashore from shipwrecks during Colonial times.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Sharply Down, Shares Up
DOC.TEXT: Pessimism about the U.S. economy pushed the dollar sharply down against the Japanese yen today, while rumors about the removal of Saddam Hussein buoyed the Tokyo Stock Exchange, up after four straight days of losses. The dollar closed at 140.25 yen, down 1.40 yen from Thursday's 141.65 yen. The low for the day's trading was 140.00 and the high was 141.00. It was the lowest closing value for the dollar since 141.55 yen on Oct. 25, 1989. Dollar sales by life insurance companies drove the dollar down, one trader said on condition of anonymity. Short-covering kept the dollar from sinking below the psychologically important 140-yen level in the morning. And a rumor that Hussein had fled to Libya unleashed sharp selling in the afternoon. ``But nobody took a long-dollar position,'' said the trader. Traders said the currency could drop below the 140-yen barrier next week, reflecting wide pessimism about the U.S. economy.
