The trend could accelerate, especially if U.S. unemployment figures for August, scheduled for release tonight Tokyo time, show a rise in joblessness, pushing interest rates down. ``I expect the dollar to trade between 138.50 and 141.50 next week,'' said Yoshikazu Kuroda, a currency trader at Fuji Bank. On the Tokyo Stock Market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues recovered from the lowest intraday trading of the year to close at 23,962.07, up 150.16 points, or 0.63 percent. An estimated 440 million first-section shares traded hands in moderate trading. Rising oil prices and the overnight decline in Wall Street dampened morning optimism centering around the yen's appreciation against the dollar, dealers said. The price of benchmark Brent Crude for October delivery opened in London at between $31.10 and $31.30 a barrel today. Dealers were also worried about the outcome of the weekend summit between President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Helsinki. Arbitrage trading and the rapid fall on the bond market, which heralded higher interest rates, also drove the market down, traders said. Several rumors, mostly unfounded, shook the jittery afternoon market, they said. ``In the afternoon, one rumor said that Hussein had fled. There was another rumor of a coup d'etat, followed by a sharp rally,'' according to Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst at Nomura Securities. Both rumors were unfounded. The market mood also improved on speculation that the Nihon Keizai newspaper would review the list of industries represented in the 225-stock index to reflect changes in the economy, and a new average would curb price volatility. The newspaper did announce, after the markets closed, that it was forming a committee to study the makeup of the average and hoped to introduce a more accurate average next summer. Other stories circulating on the trading floor suggested that the Ministry of Finance might be moving to boost the market, and that a major brokerage house was going to lay off traders because of recent market losses. Neither rumor has been confirmed. ``Brokers and institutional investors feel anxiety about the direction of the market,''said Isao Takahashi, a trader for James Capel Pacific. Some felt the market needed support as it headed toward 23,000, inspiring a small technical rebound effect. Still, he said, ``most brokerages and dealers are very bearish.'' In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds finished the day almost even with Thursday's level, closing at 8.250 percent, up slightly from Thursday's close of 8.245 percent. The price stood at 82.46 points, down from 82.48.

DOC.HEAD: State Says Doctors Overprescribed Drugs to Elizabeth Taylor
DOC.TEXT: State prosecutors have filed a complaint charging three doctors with overprescribing addictive drugs to Elizabeth Taylor, a television station reported. During a five-year period the doctors wrote for Miss Taylor more than 1,000 prescriptions for 28 controlled substances, including sleeping pills, pain killers and tranquilizers, KCBS-TV reported Thursday. ``I think it goes beyond simple negligence,'' Earl R. Plowman, deputy attorney general, told KCBS. ``With the kind of situation that's been created, the patient could just as easily have killed herself.'' Named in the complaint were Drs. Michael J. Roth, William F. Skinner and Michael S. Gottlieb. If the complaint is substantiated, the State Medical Quality Assurance Board could suspend or revoke their licenses. Roth is a longtime friend of Miss Taylor and has been her physician for a decade. Skinner is medical director of the chemical dependency center at St. John's hospital in Santa Monica. Gottlieb is the immunologist who reported the first AIDS cases in the United States is Roth's former partner. In a statement, Skinner defended his conduct and objected to the inquiry by the state medical board. ``I used good professional judgment treating a complex set of problems,'' he said. A message left at Roth's office after business hours was not returned. There was no Los Angeles listing for Gottlieb. In 1983, Miss Taylor acknowledged a 35-year addiction to sleeping pills and painkillers prescribed for health problems. She went into treatment for alcohol and drug abuse that year at Skinner's behest. An after-hours message left with Miss Taylor's publicist in New York was not returned.

DOC.HEAD: Americans In Saudi Desert Suffer From Diarrhea, Heat Rash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 23rd graf `Before coming...' with 1 graf to fix typo in `hepatitis'; Pickup 24th graf `The environment...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Without a shooting war, most GI casualties in the Saudi desert have been due to diarrhea, heat rash and other ailments common to Americans moving to a foreign country. But the U.S. military has been building more than a dozen hospitals in case the shooting began. Military doctors said in interviews that few of the 100,000-odd U.S. troops have suffered from training accidents or illnesses caused by the harsh desert environment. ``We've had some colds, some gastroenteritis,'' said Lt. Col. Jim Mattis, who commands a Marine brigade encamped in the desert. Nevertheless, the U.S. military is erecting a sophisticated network of medical facilities, including 15 hospitals capable of providing virtually any type of surgery and care to injured Americans should combat break out. ``We are fully capable of providing the best medical care in the world,'' said Capt. Richard Mayo, head of a 500-bed Navy field hospital housed in 24 air conditioned tents, each about 20 feet by 100 feet. Hundreds of doctors and nurses _ Mayo's hospital will have 800 medical personnel alone _ are either here or are on their way from the United States. Their skills are so varied and the equipment is so sophisticated that they will be able to perform neurosurgery, heart surgery and orthopedic surgery. Field hospitals have laboratories, X-ray facilities, operating rooms, dental clinics and psychiatric units. All supplies, from narcotics to hospital beds, have been sent from the United States. U.S. military officials say troops in the oil-rich kingdom are in a defensive posture, but the range of medical technology sent to the Saudi desert underscores the degree to which officials want to prepare for combat injuries. For the time being, doctors have been preoccupied with treating training injuries and lesser medical complaints. Army officials said 14 people have been evacuated for medical reasons, including three people who broke bones and two who experienced psychological problems. But Maj. Jack Wright of Fayettville, N.C., a physician with the 44th Medical Brigade that controls hospitals for the Army, said most complaints have been less serious. ``It's usually run of the mill kinds of thing,'' Wright said. He sees about 40 people a day at an Army clinic. The most prevalent complaint is diarrhea, usually brought on by a change in the water or the food. The Army regularly tests the water to make sure it is safe to drink, he said. The stomach problem usually lasts about 24 hours and is treatable with over-the-counter drugs. Colds and heat rashes are also common, medical authorities said. Despite scorching temperatures, few soldiers have come down with dehydration, partly because the military has drilled into them the importance of drinking enough water. Some men drink up to four gallons a day. Fever is particularly dangerous in a hot climate so when soldiers get one they are often given liquid intravenously to prevent dehydration. In the desert, the big problems are sanitation and sand, Mattis said. ``We have to keep the food out of the sand,'' he said. ``And we have a wash rack built so people can wash their hands.'' Before coming to Saudi Arabia, soldiers were given shots to prevent cholera, meningitis and hepatitis. The environment also plays havoc with medical supplies, according to Maj. Mike Calder, chief nurse at the 28th combat support hospital. The 200-bed ``bubble'' facility _ blown-up rubberized tubes that look like giant caterpillars _ is being set up in the desert. The heat tends to shorten the shelf-life of drugs, meaning it is unlikely that unused medical supplies will be taken back to the United States when Operation Desert Shield ends.

DOC.HEAD: F.W. de Klerk To Meet Bush Sept. 24
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk will meet President Bush on Sept. 24 in the first U.S. visit by a South African leader in decades, a government official said today. De Klerk, who has launched wide-ranging reforms since assuming power a year ago, was scheduled to meet Bush in June. But the visit was canceled after anti-apartheid groups in the United States protested, saying Bush should first hold talks with African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela. Mandela, who saw Bush in June, said it did not matter who met first with the U.S. president. Mandela has said his movement has no objections to a Bush-de Klerk meeting, but wants to United States to maintain its limited economic sanctions against South Africa to protest apartheid. A South African government source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said an official announcement of de Klerk's visit would be made this afternoon. No South African leader has visited the United States since the apartheid system of racial segregation was formally implemented in the late 1940s, officials said. De Klerk says he wants to end apartheid and negotiate a new constitution with opposition groups that would allow whites and blacks to share power. Under apartheid, the 5 million whites dominate politics and the economy and the 30 million blacks have no voice in national affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Crime Goes Up With New Freedoms
With PM-BRF--EGermany-Amnesty
DOC.TEXT: Crime in Czechoslovakia has risen by 41 percent so far this year, and part of the increase is due to the democratic changes that swept the Communists from power, the government news agency CTK reports. Speaking to parliamentary deputies, Interior Minister Jan Langos on Thursday confirmed has risen considerably, both due to the large number of prisoners amnestied in January and the newly gained freedoms of the population. ``The past period can be characterized by an increased activity of criminal elements and the broad tolerance (shown) by the population toward subjective interpretation of rights and freedoms of the individual,'' Langos was quoted as saying. Czechoslovakia is preparing for communal local) elections in November in an effort to strengthen the hold of pro-democracy forces on lower levels of the state administration. Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel freed some 20,000 convicts in January in an unprecedented amnesty, emptying two thirds of the country's jails. Shortly afterward the crime rate rose in some areas of the capital Prague by several hundred percent, police said. ``(The increase) is most visible in the attacks against the property and health of citizens, including tourists from Western states,'' the report said. While crime is on the rise, police work is made more difficult due to the fact that the police force is often identified with the dreaded STB secret police, one of the pillars of power of the past Communist regime. Prostitution and drug addiction are going up as well. The current estimate of prostitutes in Prague stands at 20,000. Two cases of heroin smuggling have been registered this year, indicating Czechoslovakia could soon become a transit country on the way from Asia to the wealthy countries of the West. Langos said a special department to combat drug trafficking was set up on August 1, with special links to Interpol, the international police organization.

DOC.HEAD: Showers in Midwest, Thunderstorms in East
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in the Midwest early today and haze covered the South. Thunderstorms rolled across northern Ohio late Thursday. A tornado was sighted in Geauga County but no injuries or damage were reported. Elsewhere in Michigan, driving rains, high winds and lightning tore down trees, damaged buildings and blacked out more than 115,000 power customers, officials said today. A Detroit Edison Co. spokesman Robert Dobkin said the company hoped to restore power to most customers today. Showers developed over the Northeast today, with a low pressure system extending from Illinois to northern Maine. High pressure was expected to bring continued sunny, hot weather to the Southeast and Deep South, with highs in the 90s. Thunderstorms were possible in Florida and the southern tip of Texas. Rain fell early today in Chicago, Cleveland and Buffalo, N.Y., and a thunderstorm broke out in Pittsburgh. Partly sunny skies were forecast for the nation's midsection, except for some showers in Nebraska, Oklahoma and Missouri. Arizona and New Mexico were in store for thunderstorms and showers were also possible in Wyoming and Utah. Sunshine was forecast for other Western states. The high temperature Thursday in the Lower 48 states was 106 degrees in Borrego Springs, Calif. Marie 57 fair; San Antonio 76 fair. _West: Albuquerque 65 cloudy; Anchorage 52 fair; Boise 69 fair; Casper 54 fair; Fairbanks 45 rain; Great Falls 61 fair; Honolulu 78 fair; Las Vegas 82 fair; Los Angeles 71 fair; Medford 63 fair; Pendleton 69 fair; Phoenix 85 fair; Portland, Ore., 65 cloudy; Reno 62 fair; Salt Lake City 64 fair; San Diego 71 fair; San Francisco 61 fair; Seattle 57 fair; Spokane 62 fair. _International: Montreal 66 showers; Ottawa 66 foggy; Regina 50 fair; Toronto 68 showers; Winnipeg 48 fair; Mexico City 59 partly cloudy; Merida 73 partly cloudy; San Juan 76 fair.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose today against most major foreign currencies in early, cautious European trading. Gold prices fell slightly. Trading was quiet ahead of the release of U.S. employment figures for August, dealers said. The financial markets are looking to the figures for indications that the U.S. economy is slowing perhaps toward a recession and the Federal Reserve Board will have to reduce interest rates to spur economic growth. The British pound fell after a statement by Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major quashed speculation that the pound will join the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System this weekend. There had been speculation that Britain would use a meeting in Rome of European Community finance ministers to announce the move. Major said in an interview this morning that an announcement will ``certainly not'' be made in Rome. Britain is committed in principle to join the exchange rate mechanism, which will stabilize the exchange rates of most major EC currencies. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 1.40 yen to a closing 140.25 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 140.57 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: _1.5605 German marks, up from 1.5590 _1.2990 Swiss francs, up from 1.2985 _5.2280 French francs, up from 5.2168 _1.7590 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7545 _1,163.75 Italian lire, up from 1,162.50 _1.1593 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1575 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8935, compared with $1.9075 late Thursday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $388.85 at mid-morning, down from $389.50 Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $388.80, unchanged from late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $0.64 to close at a bid $388.23. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.79 a troy ounce, down from Thursday's 4.80.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Gets New Liver After Apparently Eating Poisonous Mushrooms
DOC.TEXT: A woman who suffered liver failure, apparently from eating poisonous mushrooms, has received a donor liver in an emergency transplant. Roberta Rigali, 55, was in critical but stable condition early today at Bernard Mitchell Hospital at the University of Chicago after the eight-hour operation Thursday, said Nicole Muse, a hospital administrator. ``We expect she should have total or almost total recovery with very little in the way of deficits,'' Dr. Thomas Brastitus said. Mrs. Rigali likely would have died without the transplant, hospital spokesman John Easton said. Easton said he did not know where the donor liver came from. Mrs. Rigali prepared hamburgers with mushrooms picked last week while she and her husband, William, were at their cottage in Dewey Lake, Mich. She checked into a hospital Aug. 28 and went into a coma three days later. Her husband also got sick but recovered.

DOC.HEAD: Forum Head Criticizes U.S. Incineration Plans, Will Travel To Washington
DOC.TEXT: The head of the 15-nation South Pacific Forum today attacked U.S. plans to burn off chemical weapons at Johnston Atoll, accusing Washington of treating Pacific residents as ``coconuts and guava.'' Secretary-General Henry Naisali said four ministers from Forum countries, whose governments represent about 25 million people, will travel to Washington Sept. 17-19 for talks with U.S. officials on the issue. The trip comes shortly before a deadline to transfer U.S.-owned chemical weapon stocks from West Germany to Johnston, a remote atoll 700 miles southwest of Hawaii, for incineration at a specially built facility. ``I want the United States president and his advisers to please listen and try to accomodate the fears and concerns ... of the territories of the South Pacific and their peoples,'' Naisali told a news conference. He cast doubt on U.S. assurances that the incineration process at Johnston would be safe and shrugged off claims that similar plants would be built on the continental United States, where most American chemical weapons are stockpiled. ``Why bring them to our front yard in the Pacific?'' Mr Naisali asked, referring to chemical weapons. ``You know why? Because they don't class us as human beings in the Pacific. They class us as breadfruit, as coconuts and guava, tapiocas and taros.'' Washington had given ``no absolute guarantee'' that the incineration would be safe and the Forum had no way to monitor the burning, he said. He likened American safety claims to French assurances on their underground nuclear test site at Mururoa Atoll. An independent environmental report released last week said the atoll is leaking radioactivity. ``Are we going to believe the Americans when we now know that the French statement was wrong?'' he said. ``The same thing will happen at Johnston island. ``The Americans are playing cheap politics with the people of the South Pacific,'' he said. Some 100,000 rounds of nerve gas projectiles are to be shipped to Johnston Atoll over the next few months. The U.S. Army plans to store them at the facility and destroy them in an incinerator that is still being tested. The weapons from West Germany would add 100,000 rounds to the 300,000 rounds of nerve and mustard gas stored at Johnston Atoll since 1971. The tests on the incinerator are to be completed late next year, and full-scale destruction of the weapons is not expected to begin until 1992. The Army has said moving the weapons across the ocean and destroying them at Johnston Atoll would have minimal public health, safety and environmental effects.

DOC.HEAD: Slayings of Five Students Cast Pall on Football Festivities
With PM-Gainesville Slayings
DOC.TEXT: The slayings of five students by a killer who may still be on the loose have cast a pall over festivities for the University of Florida football opener, normally a high point of the new school year. The Gators play Oklahoma State on Saturday. A sellout crowd of more than 72,000 is expected, but football was secondary as the murder investigation continued. Canceled was the coming out party for Steve Spurrier, a former star player who returned to his alma mater as coach nine months ago. As the father of two daughters who attend the school, he is trying to keep the game in perspective and prepare the team to play. ``This has just been a sad, sad thing for the whole community,'' Spurrier said. ``But again, as (school) President (John) Lombardi said this week, we can't be held hostage by this situation. We've got to go on with university life,'' he said. Instead of joining hands at pep rallies and attending parties, some students are attending grief sessions with counselors to learn how to cope with a tragedy psychologists say could affect the campus for years. ``Usually there's excitement in the air with everybody talking about the first game. Now it's gloom and doom,'' senior tight end Kirk Kirkpatrick said. ``I'd be lying if I said it hadn't affected our concentration. We're football players, but we're students, also.'' Four women and a man, all students at the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College, were slain last month in three attacks. Norm Carlson, an assistant athletic director, has worked for the university for 27 years and can't remember a time when the mood before a game was as solemn. ``What's happened has really thrown everybody for a loss,'' he said. ``It's been downright depressing around here. The students seem to be doing a little better now. There's a lot of activity around the stadium and you can sense them getting excited again.'' There were other indications Thursday that students have regrouped and are eager to get on with normal campus life. Music blared from dormitory windows and long lines formed at the student ticket window outside the football stadium. A few blocks away, a huge banner advertised a post-game party at a fraternity house and campus bookstores prepared for the increased business football Saturdays bring. ``The mood is a little bit subdued, but I think it's picking up more and more each day,'' senior associate athletic director Jeremy Foley said.

DOC.HEAD: Jet Reportedly Came Close to Rooftops
DOC.TEXT: A United Airlines jetliner came within 300 feet of rooftops in a residential neighborhood where two small planes have crashed in little more than three years, a newspaper reported today. The wide-bodied Boeing 767 jet with 184 people on board was headed for Logan International Airport in bad weather when it flew about 800 feet lower that it should have over the Dorchester neighborhood, The Boston Globe reported, citing information from a flight data recorder. The newspaper said an air traffic controller ordered the pilot to abandon approach during the June 7, 1989 incident. The plane went around and landed safely. Last month, all three people on a twin-engine plane were killed when it went down Dorchester and set two houses on fire. In June 1987, the pilot of a small plane was killed when it crashed in Dorchester, destroying three homes and injuring three people on the ground. The Federal Aviation Administration said the United pilot made a bad approach. The FAA suspended the flight certificates of the pilot and first officer, whose names have not been released, but waived further penalties because they reported the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Judge: Hand Over Snake or Go to Jail
DOC.TEXT: Linda Mae Walker wasn't interested in the car, the house or the china during her divorce. She wanted her snake, and she got it after a judge threatened to jail her ex-husband. Walker, 42, was awarded Samson, a 14-foot Indian python, in a property settlement from her July 18 divorce. But her former husband, Terry D. Warren, wouldn't turn over the snake. On Wednesday, Circuit Judge Gene Schnelz told Warren to give Walker the snake or go to jail. Warren initially picked jail but reconsidered when Schnelz told him he'd stay there until the snake was returned to Walker. Walker picked up Samson later Wednesday. ``I just got my baby home,'' said Walker, who has two children and a another, smaller snake. ``I love him a lot. I missed him a lot.'' Samson appeared happy to be home, she said. ``He's crawling all over.''

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Batters Taiwan After Hitting Philippines
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Dot, packing 105-mile-an-hour winds, triggered landslides and cut of transportation in Taiwan today after flooding thousands of people from their homes in the Philippines. Police said a 65-year-old man in Taipei was killed by falling objects, and another man was reported to have been swept out to sea while fishing in northeast Taiwan. The Central Weather Bureau said Dot was off the coast about 75 miles east of Taitung in eastern Taiwan at 5:00 p.m. (5 a.m. EDT). It was moving northwest at 15 mph. Weathermen said the typhoon had winds of 105 mph and covered a large radius of about 220 miles. All domestic flights and most train services were canceled due to strong winds. Landslides also blocked highways in several eastern cities. Most schools and government agencies across the island closed this afternoon to prevent people from being stranded by strong winds and heavy rains. The typhoon was expected to sweep past send Taiwan Saturday and move toward toward China's Fujian province. Earlier today, Dot left the Philippines, where it hit Manila and central Luzon Island. No injuries were reported, but officials said about 8,000 people fled their homes because of flooding in suburban Quezon City and Pasig. Several schools and colleges sent students home early. The state-owned Philippines Airlines canceled flights to and from four towns on Luzon and Mindoro Islands. About one-third of traders and brokers with the Manila Stock Exchange were unable to reach the trading floor because of the flooding, officials said. that waters in the area would be dangerous to all types of sea craft. Floods from monsoon rains have killed at least 65 people and forced tens of thousands to flee their homes in Manila and northern Philippine provinces since Aug. 24.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Lives in House Made of Coal
DOC.TEXT: Forget wood and brick. Try a house built of coal _ 80 tons of it. When David Myles, a former coal operator, retired in 1961, he didn't want to leave behind the black mineral entirely. ``I just thought it would be pretty,'' Myles, 84, said of his coal house. Myles' wife, Quindora, and others weren't sure it could be done. ``Everybody thought he was crazy when he started,'' she said. ``But he put a white roof and white trim on it and it looked pretty good. Everybody loves it now.'' On the inside, the home looks like any other: drywalled and painted, with carpeting and windows. But the outside is made of eight-inch-thick blocks of coal, varnished every five years so it won't crumble from exposure to oxygen. Myles said he cut the blocks with an electric saw, which soon broke. Workers finally discovered that sharp hatchets did the trick, he said. The six-room house, started in 1961, took six months to build. Myles later added a three-room addition for an elderly uncle. At the time, the house cost less to build than it would to build a brick home. But today, it would be much too expensive, Myles said. There are benefits as there's no need for air conditioning or heating because, since the coal is so thick, Mrs. Myles said. Visitors frequently if the couple is afraid their house will ever catch fire. The Myles say it's highly unlikely because of coal's high-ignition temperatures.

DOC.HEAD: Pitched Battle as Army Tries to Rout Tamil Rebels in Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Government troops and Tamil rebels fought pitched battles in the northeast as the army tried to expand its control after breaking the rebel siege of a strategic garrison, military officials said today. They said 17 Tamil Tiger guerrillas and eight soldiers were killed in Thursday's fighting near Chilawatte in the Mullaitivu district on the seacoast south of the Jaffna Peninsula, the northern end of this island nation. The Tigers' 10-week siege of the army garrison at Mullaitivu town was broken Monday, officials have reported. Mullaitivu is 60 miles southeast of Jaffna town, where the government's efforts to break another Tamil siege, of a 17th century fort, have been at a standstill for two weeks. More than 200 policemen and soldiers have been trapped in Jaffna Fort for nearly three months, with air force helicopters managing to make occasional drops of food and blocks of ice that melt into drinking water. The military officials said on condition of anonymity the Tigers continued their attacks Thursday on Jaffna Fort, killing one policeman and one soldier. Officials say at least 13 government defenders in the fort have been killed since June 11 when the Tamil rebels broke a 13-month-old cease-fire and renewed their separatist war against the Sinhalese-controlled government. There was no independent confirmation of the reports. Communications with the region have been cut, and the Tigers issue only periodic battle reports, usually from offices in Europe. The Tamil war for a separate homeland started in 1983 when the Tigers and other militant groups embarked on a campaign of guerrilla attacks on the government and massacres of Sinhalese civilians. At least 14,000 people have been killed since then. The Tamils, who make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, accuse the Sinhalese of discriminating against them in jobs and education. The Sinhalese, who have dominated the government and military since the Indian Ocean island became independent from Britain in 1948, comprise 75 percent of the population.

DOC.HEAD: Emotional Pontiff Sees Dying AIDS Patients in Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II toured a Burundi hospital crowded with dying AIDS victims today and said he shared their suffering. ``I know the moment is difficult,'' he told 650 patients at the Prince-Regent Charles Hospital on the last day of his three-day visit to this central African nation. ``I think especially of those among you who are afflicted by AIDS, for which there is still no effective cure. But I want to tell you, in the name of faith, that you have reason for hope and you are not alone in your ordeal.'' The pontiff, who toured the hospital before flying to neighboring Rwanda on the third leg of his 10-day African tour, was told by doctors that 85 percent of patients in two wards suffered from AIDS. Most were in an advanced stage of the disease, the doctors said. John Paul, visibly moved, stopped at the bedsides of about 40 men and women, patting their heads and touching their foreheads in the sign of the cross. At the end of the visit, he instructed Archbishop Giovanbatista Re, the Vatican's undersecretary of state, to write out a check for $10,000 as a donation to the hospital. There are no reliable estimates of AIDS cases in this former Belgian colony of 6 million people. But health officials say up to 40 percent of young urban adults in some areas could be infected with the AIDS virus. The World Health Organization estimates that 5 million Africans are infected. It was the third time the pope has spoken about AIDS during his African pilgrimage. In Tanzania last week, he called for a global effort to combat the virus and reaffirmed the church's rejection of the use of condoms as a means to check the spread. Before leaving, the Roman Catholic leader ordained 22 priests from Burundi and three from neighboring Zaire during a Mass attended by tens of thousands of pilgrims in a sprawling meadow on the outskirts of the capital. The new priests, clad in green capes, knelt one by one at the pontiff's feet to receive his embrace. The ceremony marked a record number of ordinations in Burundi, a predominantly Catholic country that only three years ago emerged from a bitter conflict between church and state. Under the previous military regime that President Pierre Buyoya toppled in 1987, foreign missionaries were expelled, local priests were detained and some churches were closed. Buyoya, a Catholic, restored full freedom to the church in his efforts to unify a nation long scarred by ethnic bloodshed. After his visit to Rwanda, a former Belgian protectorate, the pope will travel Sunday to the Ivory Coast on the last leg of his seventh trip to Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Isidore Becomes a Hurricane, Turning to North Far From Land in Atlantic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with storm strengthening to 80 mph, turning toward the north. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Isidore's top sustained winds were up to 80 mph this morning, but an early turn toward the north could signal the storm will never threaten land, forecatserrs said. Isidore, which reached hurricane strength late Thursday, remained in the eastern Atlantic on a northeasterly heading at 13 mph, said Max Mayfield, a specialist at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. ``It's not a threat to any land mass at this time, and it has turned up towards the northwest much earlier than most storms do in that area,'' Mayfield said. ``That's really good news,'' he said. ``The farther north it gets out there, the less likely it is to affect the Caribbean and the United States.'' Isidore could stengthen slightly in the next day or so, but has shown no early signs of becoming a major hurricane, he said. At 6 a.m. EDT, Isidore's center was located near 17.6 degrees north latitude and 37.9 west longitude, or about 800 miles west of the Cape Verde Islands. The system was expecting to maintain its course and speed for the next 24 hours. Isidore is the ninth named storm of the 1990 Atlantic hurricane. Tropical storms are named when their maximum sustained winds reach 39 mph; they are ranked as hurricanes if their wind speed reaches 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Flood McDonald's Office
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Chinese have flooded a McDonald's office in southern China where the American fast-food giant is hiring employees for its first restaurant in this communist nation, a company official said today. McDonald's plans to open a 500-seat restaurant in the economic boomtown of Shenzhen, near Hong Kong, on Oct. 8, said company spokeswoman Angela Bassage in Hong Kong. Two Shenzhen newspaper ads this week drew more than 6,000 applicants for 240 part-time jobs, an official at the Shenzhen McDonald's said on condition of anonymity. Some applicants held university degrees, he said. ``It was pretty chaotic when the huge number of people raided our ... office. We're now busy deciding who to pick,'' he said. A second office had to be opened to accommodate the crowd, he said. The newspaper ads, displaying the traditional McDonald's striped shirts with matching caps, read: ``More than 200 youths in Shenzhen are going to put on this uniform, a symbol of a prosperous future. As an aggressive person, what are you waiting for?'' The new recruits must work 12 hours a week, the ads said. Wages were not given. The restaurant will be operated by McDonald's Shenzhen Ltd., a subsidiary of McDonald's Hong Kong, which is a 50-50 joint venture with McDonald's in the United States. It will be managed by a Chinese national, Ms. Bassage said. She said the restaurant hopes to serve 10 million burgers a year, far fewer than the popular Moscow McDonald's which makes 50,000 burgers daily, or more than 18 million in a year. Ingredients will be shipped in from Hong Kong initially, but Chinese potatoes eventually may be used, she said. McDonald's plans to open a restaurant in Beijing in 1992, she said. Beijing's only foreign fast-food restaurant is Kentucky Fried Chicken, which runs four popular restaurants. Pizza Hut will open a restaurant in Beijing on Monday, its first in China.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Phones Of Politicians, Journalists Tapped in Israel
DOC.TEXT: Israel's phone-tapping scandal widened today amid reports that private investigators illegally tapped phones of more than 20 journalists and possible witnesses in an investigation of a Cabinet official. Interior Minister Aryeh Deri is being questioned on suspicion of illegally funneling public funds to religious institutions that he controls. He is a member of the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party. Israel army radio said today that police would complete their investigation in about two weeks and were expected to recommend charges against Deri. The report did not name the possible charges. If Deri stands trial, it could rattle the government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. A coalition, led by Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc, has a 62-seat majority in the 120-seat Parliament and needs the five seats of Shas to govern. Police believe three private investigating firms tapped phone lines in municipal officials in Jerusalem and newspaper offices in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, according to today's media reports. But a Tel Aviv police official denied the stories, saying they were ``nonsense.'' She spoke on condition of anonymity. The bugging scandal surfaced last week with reports that five people had been arrested on suspicion of tapping the phone of Mordechai Gilat, an investigative reporter for the Yediot Ahronot newspaper. Gilat had written a series of exposes on Deri in June. A tape allegedly containing a recording of a conversation between Gilat and Police Commissioner Yaacov Turner was discovered earlier this week. Reports said Turner's phone may have been bugged as well. Deri, meanwhile, suggested the left-of-center Labor Party was responsible for the investigation. He indicated it could have started as an attempt to prevent the formation of Shamir's coalition on June 11. ``Somebody decided to torpedo the formation of a right-wing government,'' Deri told the weekly newspaper Kol Hair. ``Only six days before the formation of the new right-wing government did police start to investigate accusations against me. Only one day before the new government was presented, investigators confiscated material from the Interior Ministry,'' Deri said. Shas was responsible for toppling the previous Likud-Labor coalition on March 15. During the subsequent wrangling for power, both Labor and Likud tried to lure Shas onto their sides.

DOC.HEAD: Precede SEOUL, South Korea
Brady Says U.S. Has Support From South Korea, Japan; No Specifics Given
With PM-Gulf-Baker
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 6 grafs Baker-Kaifu meeting; picks up 6th graf pvs, However, it...
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, winding up a global fund-raising mission, said today Japan and South Korea have given new assurances of support for the massive economic and military campaign against Iraq. But no specific dollar figures were provided following Brady's talks today with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, or in an earlier meeting in Seoul with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo. Brady met for an hour with Kaifu, after which he said, ``We have a very serious problem. It is gratifying to know of Japan's support.'' A Japanese official, briefing reporters after the Brady-Kaifu meeting, said ``Japan will make the utmost contribution. ... We have to do what we have to do.'' However, the official refused to provide any specifics of how that pledge would be translated into additional contributions. Japan earlier announced about $1 billion in support. Brady's meeting with Kaifu was the final stop on a four-day, 18,500 mile journey that took him from Paris to London to Seoul to Tokyo. However, in none of the cases did the world leaders provide any specifics about how much they would contribute, saying in most cases that they needed more time to review the requests. However, it appeared that a second fund raising mission headed by Secretary of State James A. Baker III was having more luck. While no figures were given, officials said that Saudi Arabia had committed several billion dollars with an offer to pick up all fuel, water and transportation costs associated with maintaining the 60,000 U.S. troops now stationed in Saudi Arabia. Brady, talking to reporters in Seoul after his meeting with Roh, said he had not expected an immediate answer to the American request for help in defraying the cost of the U.S. military buildup. Brady also was seeking aid for Jordan, Turkey and Egypt, whose economies have been severely hurt by the United Nations' supported trade embargo against Iraq. He said the United States was hoping to get funds flowing to the so-called front line states by the end of this month. There have been reports South Korea is reluctant to commit significant resources to the campaign against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein because of fear of jeopardizing construction contracts in both Iraq and Kuwait worth well over $1 billion. Brady said Roh raised these concerns in a ``tangential way'' during their meeting but he said he pointed out to the South Korean leader the huge stake his country has in keeping the price of oil from escalating. ``Every $10 increase in the price of a barrel of oil means a $2.5 billion cost to the Korean economy,'' Brady said. Brady insisted that he has received strong words of encouragement at every stop, and he questioned the accuracy of reports that various countries are balking at the American aid request. ``There are particular problems that every country has, but the logic is compelling. We want to make sure these sanctions work,'' he said. Still, Brady's high-level delegation appeared to be having a tougher selling job than the Baker mission to oil-rich Middle East countries. Officials traveling with Brady insisted that the aid will be forthcoming once the allies have time to study the specific requests presented to them. However, in their meetings with world leaders, the U.S. delegation has stressed that time is in short supply, especially in Jordan, Egypt and Turkey, which are facing massive costs connected to their support of the U.N.-sanctioned trade embargo against Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Miss Mississippi and Miss Illinois Win Preliminary Competitions
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen years of piano training and a degree in music were Miss Illinois Marjorie Judith Vincent's ticket to winning the last of three preliminary talent competitions in the Miss America Pageant. The classical pianist from Oak Park, Ill., impressed a panel of preliminary judges with ``Fantasy Impromptu'' by Frederic Chopin. ``I was surprised. I really was. There were so many good talents in my group,'' she said afterward. ``I am difficult on myself as an artist and I felt I could do better,'' said Miss Vincent, 25, this year's only black contestant. Despite an undergraduate degree in music, she has no plans to make it a career. Miss Vincent is in her third year at Duke University Law School and hopes to go into corporate law, with an emphasis on international relations. The final swimsuit preliminary competition was won by Miss Mississippi Beth Howell. Miss Howell, 21, a pharmacy student at the University of Mississippi and sometime model, said her modeling experience enhanced her self-confidence. ``I don't really feel any pressure being on stage,'' she said. ``There's nothing like feeling right up on the stage and that's important for swimsuit competition.'' The 50 Miss America hopefuls are divided into three groups, who compete in talent, swimsuit and evening gown divisions on three successive nights to qualify for Saturday's finals. At that time, the top 10 finishers will be announced and compete during a nationally televised final with Gary Collins and Miss America 1971 Phyllis George as co-hosts. The 50 contestants are vying to succeed Miss America 1990 Debbye Turner. Miss America 1991 wins a scholarship of $35,000. Thursday was the last of three preliminary competitions. On Tuesday, Miss Texas Suzanne Lawrence won the first talent competition and Miss Colorado Karrie Mitchell won the first swimsuit competition. On Wednesday, Miss North Carolina Scarlet Morgan won the second talent competition and Miss Florida Dana Rinehart Dalton won the second swimsuit competition. The winners of the three preliminary evening gown competitions are not announced until Saturday night's finals.
