DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 19 to CORRECT year of Soviet grain purchases to 1972, sted 1971.
DOC.HEAD: Commodity Markets Abuzz Over Possible Soviet Credits
DOC.TEXT: Commodity markets have been buzzing for days about the possibility of a credit arrangement for Moscow when President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet this weekend. The administration favors liberalized trade and would like to see the United States grant most-favored-nation, or low tariff, status to the Soviet Union. But this would depend on Moscow changing policies to allow free emigration of its citizens. For nearly two decades, the Soviet Union has been a major force in U.S. agriculture _ a lucrative but sometimes erratic customer. Japan is a larger buyer of total U.S. commodities, but the Soviets' annual grain orders stir excitement around the world. Farm exports to Japan last year were valued at nearly $8.2 billion, compared with $3.6 billion for the Soviet Union. Many farm leaders want most-favored-nation, or MFN, status for the Soviet Union and a solution to the hangup over immigration. New credit deals would sprout, helping sell more U.S. wheat, corn and soybeans. Whether this comes up between Bush and Gorbachev at their meeting in Helsinki, Finland on Sunday is conjecture at this point. The crisis in the Mideast is paramount. But just in case the recent bread shortages in Moscow prompt Gorbachev to ask about an emergency loan to buy U.S. grain, it would be warmly applauded by American wheat farmers who have seen prices plummet in the wake of a bumper harvest this summer. Don Lipton of the American Farm Bureau Federation's office here said Thursday the organization favors MFN status for the Soviet Union and realizes that emigration policies are a stumbling block. However, he said, if the White House works out a special arrangement for Bush to present in Helsinki, it would be ``something we would support'' conditionally if it met all the legal specifications. Leland Swenson, president of the National Farmers Union, said from his Denver office that his members support MFN for the Soviet Union. But Swenson added that many other factors come to bear over the longer pull, including the question of long-term credit, subsidized sales of grain and other issues that affect U.S.-Soviet relations. The United States has been selling millions of tons of grain to Moscow at cut-rate prices under the Agriculture Department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP, since it was authorized five years ago. As of Aug. 30, the Soviet Union had bought 21.3 million metric tons of wheat under the EEP subsidy arrangement. No dollar estimate was available, but the monthly report showed the Soviet wheat deals under the program accounted for 28 percent of the five-year total sold to all eligible foreign countries. The Soviet Union banged into the world grain market as a major importer in 1971 with a $150 million purchase of U.S. corn, barley and oats. Traditionally, except for a few times in the mid-1960s, the Soviet Union had been a net exporter of grain. Suddenly, Russia was on the loose as a major buyer. The conventional wisdom in USDA at the time proved correct. The Soviets indeed wanted to boost food production and needed to import more grain to do it. But the department grossly underestimated the magnitude of Moscow's needs. On July 8, 1972, then-President Nixon announced a $750 million credit arrangement for the Soviet Union to buy U.S. wheat and feed grains. It was only the tip of an export iceberg. Secretly, private grain traders sold millions of tons of U.S. grain, mostly wheat, to Moscow, for cash while the Nixon credit deal was being worked out. By August, it was apparent that the Russians had bought about 19 million tons of grain during the summer of 1972 _ and at subsidized prices in effect at the time. The transactions, carried out by large multinational grain companies, led to congressional investigations and accusations that USDA insiders had worked with the private trade in the dealings. Grain prices soared, contributing to higher food costs for American consumers. Eventually, Congress insisted on daily and weekly public reporting of larger commodity sales to foreign buyers, a system in effect today. Meanwhile, the Soviet Union used most of its $750 million line of credit announced on July 8, 1972, but the authorization ran out with about $200 million left on the books _ the equivalent of around $600 million at current prices. Since those beginnings almost 20 years ago, the Soviet Union has paid more than $25 billion for more than 231 million tons of U.S. wheat and corn. The total since the 1972 credit deal included 78.4 million tons of wheat and 152.8 million tons of corn. This year's entire U.S. wheat crop was about 73.6 million tons, and the corn crop is estimated by USDA at 199.4 million tons.

DOC.HEAD: Government Ordered To Pay Man Who Lost Arm to Gator
DOC.TEXT: The federal government has been ordered to pay more than $770,000 in damages to a man whose arm was bitten off by a 500-pound, 11{-foot alligator in a national forest. U.S. District Judge Robert E. Varner, in a ruling made public Thursday, awarded more than $650,000 to Kermit H. George Jr. for his pain and suffering, along with sums for medical costs and other damages. The award of damages followed an April 30 ruling in which Varner found that the U.S. Forest Service had received complaints about alligators in the Conecuh National Forest but had failed to post signs warning of the danger. On July 26, 1986, George was swimming in a public pond in the Conecuh forest, not far from his hometown of Florala, when the alligator attacked him. George, who was 42 at the time, was an experienced electronics engineer who also did land surveying and construction consulting part time. He had been riding his bicycle and had stopped at a roped-off swimming area to cool off. He was in chest-deep water at the time of the attack. George was with his dog, a part Doberman pinscher. The dog wasn't on a leash, and the government argued that George had attracted the alligator by letting the dog run free in violation of the park's leash law. Varner said it was unlikely the dog had attracted the alligator, even though alligators ``enjoy dog meat.'' ``The preponderance of the evidence shows that alligators are not discriminatory in their tastes and are well known to dine on whatever is convenient,'' the judge wrote in the April ruling.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Rate Climbs to 5.6 Percent in August
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads thruout to UPDATE with analysts comment, CORRECT in 4th graf pvs that private industries lost 12,000 jobs sted added; editing thruout; no pickup. ^By KAREN BALL
DOC.TEXT: The nation's unemployment rate rose in August for the second consecutive month, climbing to 5.6 percent for the highest jobless rate in two years, the government said today. Last month's rise in the civilian jobless rate, up from July's rate of 5.5 percent, brought unemployment to its highest level since the 5.7 percent rate posted in March 1988, the Labor Department said. The nation's jobless rate had also hit 5.6 percent in August 1988. Analysts said the report showed fresh evidence that the U.S. economy is either already in a recession or about to topple into one. ``It's becoming clear that we are sliding into a recession,'' said Martin Regalia, chief economist at the National Council of Savings Institutions. ``If it's not quite flatlined, it's time to get the jumper cables out and do something.'' The weak employment report would probably renew pressure on the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates to spur the economy, private economists said. The rise in unemployment was largely caused by the economy's failure to produce many new jobs last month, the government said. In fact, all business payrolls actually fell by a total of 75,000, but much of that was caused by the thousands of federal census workers who were laid off, the government said. Still, private industries overall lost 12,000 jobs as well, with the slump in the construction and manufacturing sectors continuing. Analysts had been bracing for weak payroll numbers in August, which they blamed in part on the Middle East crisis, saying it probably had unnerved businesses and kept them from hiring new workers. However, the U.S. economy has been sluggish for months. The Middle East conflict has not had time yet to fully impact the nation's economy, analysts said. ``It's really a question of whether the oil shock is going to tip it over,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. ``The economy had reached a virtual standstill. Will this now push it down into negative territory?'' Dederick asked. The nation's jobless rate is derived from a household survey, but most economists consider a separate survey of business establishments _ from which the government gets its figures on how many new jobs were created in a given month _ a better barometer of economic activity. The nation's manufacturing slump continued in August, as factory jobs posted a 45,000 loss. It was the 16th time out of 17 months that manufacturing jobs declined. Since reaching a post-recession peak in January 1989, the manufacturing sector has lost 455,000 jobs, the government said. Industries with the largest losses include electronic equipment, which has lost 100,000 jobs, motor vehicles, which has lost 80,000, and apparel, which has posted a 55,000 job loss. Meanwhile in August, the construction industry continued to suffer as well. Those payrolls fell by 40,000 jobs, after a seasonal adjustment, posting the sixth consecutive decline to reflect continued weakness in the housing market. The construction industry has lost nearly 100,000 jobs in the past three months alone. The service sector, which until a few months ago had been adding huge numbers of new jobs and virtually carrying the rest of the economy, continued on its recent trend of showing weakness. Service sector jobs increased by a relatively low 17,000 jobs. Health services, which had added an average of 50,000 jobs each month in the first half of this year, continued to show robust gains, posting a 44,000 jobs increase last month. Labor costs, which have been rising and are being blamed for worsening the nation's inflation problems, rose only moderately in August. Average hourly earnings posted a 0.2 percent rise last month to $10.09, up from the $10.07 the average worker earned per hour in July. The Labor Department's household survey showed that overall, total civilian employment was about 117.7 million in August, down from the 118 million employed in July. The jobless numbered 7 million, up from 6.8 million unemployed in July. The average manufacturing work week was 41 hours in August, up from the 40.9 hours in July. Manufacturing overtime was 3.9 hours in August, a slight increase over July's average of 3.8 overtime hours. Before July and August of this year, the jobless rate had held relatively stable for much of the past year, fluctuating within a narrow range of 5.3 percent. Many analysts have said the unemployment rate was able to stay relatively low, despite the sluggish economy, because fewer Americans are entering the labor force. The unemployment rate among major demographic groups last month were: _Adult white men, 4.3 percent, up from 4.1 percent in July. _Adult white women, 4.2 percent, up from 4.0 percent. _White teen-agers, 13.2 percent, up from 12.3 percent. _All blacks, 11.8 percent, up from 11.3 percent. _Adult black men, 10.6 percent, down from 10.7 percent. _Adult black women, 9.9 percent, up from 9.4 percent. _Black teen-agers, 35 percent, up from 31.2 percent. _Hispanics, 7.8 percent, down from 7.9 percent. In a separate calculation of unemployment that counts members of the armed services stationed in the United States, the August jobless rate was 5.5 percent, up from the 5.4 percent in July but still better than August's civilian rate of 5.6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: South African President to Meet with Bush
DOC.TEXT: South African President F.W. de Klerk will meet with President Bush in Washington on Sept. 24, the White House announced today. ``The meeting is at the invitation of President Bush and will allow the two leaders an opportunity to discuss the current negotiating process underway in South Africa and ways it may be encouraged,'' Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said in a statement. De Klerk's government has been negotiating with the black majority in South Africa to seek a way to allow power sharing in the strife-ridden nation. De Klerk has announced he wants to see a new constitution within five years. Bush had invited both de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela for separate visits to the White House some time ago. Mandela met with Bush in June, but de Klerk put off his visit.

DOC.HEAD: Engineer Who Helped Develop Radar Dies
DOC.TEXT: Edward Bowles, an electrical engineer who played an important role in developing radar in World War II, has died of Parkinson's disease after suffering a series of strokes. He was 92. His family said he died Wednesday in a Weston nursing home. As a consultant to the secretary of war, Bowles was asked to devise a way to combat German submarines that were sinking merchant ships in the North Atlantic. Having been a microwave specialist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, he set up a laboratory at Langley Field, Va., where Army Air Corps bombers were equipped with radar developed at the university. In 1945, he was awarded the Distinguished Service Medal for his wartime efforts. Bowles was born in Westphalia, Mo. He received his bachelor's degree from Washington University in St. Louis and a master's from MIT, where he began teaching in 1921. He became an expert in what was then the new field of radio. Bowles pioneered the development of the multivibrator, by which a tuning fork, and later a crystal, could be used to maintain a precise radio frequency. He began a division of electrical communications at MIT in the mid-1920s.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators Fail to Reach Full Agreement on German Unification Plan
DOC.TEXT: The United States, the Soviet Union and four other countries today failed to reach full agreement on the final plan for German unification, the East German news agency ADN said. While unification is bound to go forward as scheduled on Oct. 3, today's talks indicate there may be some hard bargaining before then. Negotiators said ``a few open questions'' will have to be resolved at next week's foreign ministers' meeting in Moscow, according to ADN. There was no immediate indication of what the sticking points might be. News reports have said there were disagreements over the timetable for withdrawing Soviet troops from what is now East Germany. The U.S., Soviet, British, French representatives _ who have been joined by negotiators from East and West Germany _ had hoped to have the final plan worked out before Wednesday's foreign ministers' session. It is to be the final session of the six-nation talks that began in May in the West German capital of Bonn.

DOC.HEAD: American Women and Children Fly Out From Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to CORRECT number on flight to 171 sted 170; pickup graf 8 `Hundreds of...'
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi Airways jetliner with 171 American women and children on board landed in Jordan today, the first U.S.-chartered airlift to arrive from conquered Kuwait. The Americans described conditions in Kuwait, which was taken over on Aug. 2 by Iraq, as appalling. They said foreigners are terrified of Iraq's occupation forces, who have been rounding up Westerners. ``It's terrible there. People are frightened, they're in hiding, running out of food,'' said Patricia Hammer of Denver, Colo. She said she was shot at by Iraqi troops when she tried to escape from Kuwait across the desert several weeks ago. She said she was abandoned by her escorts and later saved by Bedouins. ``We made our way back to Kuwait where I hid, moving from flat to flat,'' she said. Ms. Hammer said she registered with the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait for the special flight two days ago. ``This morning, I dressed up in a black veil like an Iranian Shiite woman and made my way to the pickup point. A Kuwaiti friend followed me to make sure I got there,'' she said. The flight made a stop in the Iraqi capital of Baghdad, where passengers picked up Iraqi exit permits. A U.S. Embassy source at the airport in Amman said 171 American women and children were aboard the charter. Earlier reports had put the number at 170. Hundreds of Western women and children held by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein have been allowed to leave, but men are being kept as human shields against attack. A woman who identified herself only as Ruthie, from Memphis, Tenn., said she had to leave her husband behind. She was traveling with her three children, ages eight, seven and three. ``Many people are still hiding in their homes and are very afraid,'' she said. Mary Willett, 35, of Chicago, said of the situation in Kuwait: ``It's a disaster.'' Another evacuee, Maureen Aldakheel of St. Louis, was asked what she thought President Bush should do. `Go for it. Do something. People are tired of waiting for something to happen,'' she said. ``People are tired of hoping every day for some news of a military strike.'' The evacuees were taken from the airport to a hotel to wait for the arrival of a charter that will fly them home. U.S. embassy officials at the airport would not disclose plans for the flight to the United States. A handful of Americans were evacuated by air from Kuwait last week at the intervention of U.S. civil rights leader Jesse Jackson. But most other Westerners leaving Kuwait have had to travel across the desert in scorching summer heat to catch planes out Baghdad. Earlier today, a British Airways flight arrived in London carrying 252 British women and children from Kuwait and Iraq. It was the biggest group of Britons yet to leave the Iraqi capital, Baghdad. There were an estimated 21,000 Westerners in Iraq and Kuwait when Baghdad invaded Kuwait. They included 3,000 Americans. On Thursday, Baghdad said foreigners caught trying to leave without permission could face life in prison. The State Department on Thursday blasted Iraq for its treatment of foreign nationals, including the shooting of an American in Kuwait who was trying to avoid capture. Department spokesman Mark Dillen called Iraq's behavior ``outrageous.'' ``We hold the Iraqi government responsible for the health and welfare of all American citizens held against their will in Kuwait and Iraq,'' Dillen said.

DOC.HEAD: Aid Grows for Evacuees; Kuwait Promises To Pay For U.S. Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 19 grafs to CORRECT number on U.S.-chartered plane to 171 sted 170; UPDATE with European Community to provide $2 billion; pickup graf 20 pvs `The Jordanian...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AMM1,NY4,6,11
DOC.TEXT: The global effort against Iraq strengthened today with promises of more aid for victims of the Persian Gulf crisis, and Kuwait's exiled leaders joined the Saudis in pledging funds for U.S. forces in the region. A planeload of 171 American women and children arrived in Amman, Jordan, today aboard an Iraqi Airways jet, the first U.S.-chartered airlift out of Kuwait. The arrivals described harrowing conditions in the emirate. ``It's terrible there. People are frightended, they're in hiding, running out of food,'' said Patricia Hammer of Denver, Colo. Moscow said it favored establishing a U.N. peacekeeping force in the gulf and might have its troops participate in the effort to rein in Iraq's Saddam Hussein, whose army overran Kuwait five weeks ago and massed near the Saudi Arabian border. Three British minehunters made their way through Egypt's Suez Canal today, heading for the Persian Gulf region, where scores of U.S. and other warships are enforcing a U.N.-sanctioned embargo against the Baghdad government. Despite the show of unity, some countries have begun suggesting they might circumvent the U.N. sanctions. Today, India expressed frustration that it had not been allowed to send food and medicine to its nationals stranded in Iraq and Kuwait. ``It is inhuman to expect that political objectives will be achieved through the process of starving people,'' said Indian Foreign Ministry spokesman Aftab Seth. China's Foreign Ministry said Thursday it does not believe the embargo applies to ``supplies intended strictly for medical purposes and foodstuffs for humanitarian purposes.'' And Iran's Tehran Times newspaper, which is close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani, said in an editorial Thursday that sanctions aside, providing food and medicine was a ``humanitarian question.'' In Kuwait, conditions grew intolerable in embassies ordered by the Iraqis to close two weeks ago. Norway said it would evacuate its Kuwait mission on Saturday and that its three diplomats would travel to Baghdad. A few embassies, including the U.S. mission, remained open, but they were surrounded by Iraqi troops, with water, power and telephone service cut off and food running out. Western women and children allowed out under Saddam's Aug. 28 promise they could go free were having an easier time getting home. Western men are being held as human shields at Iraqi installations to deter any attack by U.S-led multinational forces. In addition to the U.S.-chartered plane, a British Airways flight arrived in London today carrying 252 British women and children from Kuwait and Iraq. It was the biggest group of Britons to leave Baghdad so far. There were an estimated 21,000 Westerners in Iraq and Kuwait when Baghdad invaded and later annexed the neighboring emirate of Kuwait. They included 3,000 Americans. More promises of aid were made today for desperate Asian and Arab refugees from Iraq and Kuwait stranded in a no man's land at the Jordanian border. Japan said it would pay an additional $12 million to help evacuees. U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady also received assurances from Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu in Tokyo today that Japan would help pay the huge costs of the military campaign in the Persian Gulf. South Korean President Roh Tae-woo made similar pledges to Brady on the previous leg of his Asian tour. A day earlier, Britain earmarked $3.8 million more in refugee aid, bringing total British aid to $10 million. Sweden today decided to contribute $5.2 million to help repatriate refugees fleeing Iraq and Kuwait. The Swedish aid will include food and medical assistance. European Community foreign ministers meeting in Rome today agreed to give $2 billion in economic aid to Turkey, Jordan and Egypt to compensate them for lost trade with Iraq. They also granted more food and other emergency aid for the refugees from Iraq and Kuwait stranded at Iraq's borders. The Jordanian news agency Petra says more than 600,000 people have fled since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 in a dispute over oil, land and money. Most have managed to leave Jordan, but relief officials said more than 100,000 Bangladeshis, Pakistanis, Indians, Sri Lankans, Thais and Filipinos remain in squalid camps that are running low on food, water and medicines. Kuwait's exiled monarch, Jabir al-Sabah, told Secretary of State James A. Baker III today his government will help pay for the U.S. buildup in the gulf region ``in order to restore my country to what it was before.'' ``We will not spare any amount or any value. We will give whatever is necessary,'' he told Baker at the royal mountain retreat in Taif, Saudi Arabia, about 50 miles east of Mecca. The emir did not immediately give a specific figure. U.S. officials say the cost of the 100,000-strong American force in the region is about $1 billion a month. While Kuwait's royal family has lost control of its vast oil reserves it still has billions in assets worldwide. In Saudi Arabia Thursday, Baker was promised that at a minimum, the Saudi government will pick up all fuel, water and transportation costs for American troops protecting the kingdom's oil fields from possible Iraqi aggression. The aid has been estimated in the billions of dollars. On Thursday, members of a congressional delegation visiting U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia said they were dissatisfied with the lack of burden sharing and said international aid was essential to maintain American public support. The delegation was scheduled to meet with Saudi King Fahd today. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov today said Moscow would be willing to provide troops for a U.N. peacekeeping force in the Persian Gulf if they were under a joint command that included Soviet generals. U.S.-Soviet cooperation in the gulf crisis will be topic No. 1 on Sunday when Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev hold a hastily arranged summit in Helsinki, Finland, spokesman for both sides say. The Soviet announcement came a day after Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, told Gorbachev Iraq would not withdraw from Kuwait. Moscow and Baghdad are longtime allies, but Gorbachev has condemned the Kuwait invasion. There were, however, cautionary notes. In Tokyo, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze urged U.S. troops not to take unilateral action and said the superpower summit would seek ways to resolve the Middle East crisis peacefully. In other diplomatic efforts, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar will send an envoy to occupied Kuwait to meet with diplomats whose embassies are surrounded by Iraqi troops if he receives Baghdad's permission. The United Nations has sent more than 3,000 tons of food and supplies to Jordan and received $19 million in relief aid, mainly from Japan and Sweden, said Robert Souria, a U.N. relief official.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Helped Wife Die Ordered To Stand Trial On Murder, Conspiracy Charges
DOC.TEXT: A California man who said he came to Michigan to help his dying wife commit suicide was ordered to stand trial today on charges of murder and conspiracy to commit murder. Bertram Harper, 72, of Loomis, Calif., faces possible life imprisonment if convicted of the Aug. 19 death of his wife Virginia, 69. Romulus District Judge Henry Zaborowski, who presided over Harper's two-day preliminary hearing, said he agreed with prosecutors' claims that there was a conspiracy to end Mrs. Harper's life. He also ordered Harper tried on the murder charge because no evidence showed she consented to her death at the time Harper pulled a plastic bag over her head and secured it around her neck. ``Suicide is self-destruction,'' Zaborowski said. ``There is no law that gives a person a license to help another person in this destruction.'' Zaborowski allowed Harper to return to California, but scheduled arraignment for Sept. 21 in Wayne County Circuit Court. The Hemlock Society, a suicide rights group, is paying for Harper's defense. In his statement to Romulus police, Harper said his wife _ diagnosed with cancer of the breast and liver _ swallowed about a dozen pills, washed them down with coffee liqueur and lay on their motel-room bed while she pulled a clear plastic bag over her head. Afterward, Harper told reporters that he, his wife and stepdaughter, Shanda McGrew, would not have come to Michigan if the state had a law making it illegal to help someone else die. Wednesday's hearing included testimony from five witnesses. Four of the five related accounts of Mrs. Harper's death given them by McGrew, 40, who traveled with her mother and stepfather from California to Michigan. Ms. McGrew is an unindicted co-conspirator in her mother's death but has not been charged. Assisting in a suicide in California is a felony punishable by up to five years' imprisonment. Michigan has no specific law prohibiting people from assisted in suicides, but some prosecutors have contended that the practice is still illegal in the state under the general law against murder. Harper said their decision wasn't influenced by publicity over the so-called ``suicide machine'' case involving Dr. Jack Kevorkian, an outspoken advocate of death on demand for the terminally ill. The suburban Detroit pathologist is under investigation but has not been charged in the June 4 death of Janet Adkins, 54, of Portland, Ore. Adkins was said to have had Alzheimer's disease when she and her husband flew to Michigan, met Kevorkian and drove with him to a park about 40 miles north of Detroit. There, Kevorkian fitted Adkins with an intravenous tube and she pressed a button on a machine he invented and it delivered a fatal dose of heart-stopping drugs.

DOC.HEAD: An Early Thanksgiving? Almanac Suggests Giving It Some Thought
LaserPhoto AD1
DOC.TEXT: Not one to tamper lightly with tradition, the Farmers' Almanac suggests nonetheless that the date designated for Thanksgiving is a turkey. In its 1991 edition, just off the presses, the venerable publication says Americans should consider celebrating the holiday, the fourth Thursday in November, earlier in the fall. An earlier date would rid Thanksgiving of pre-Christmas overtones, allow for more favorable travel weather and line it up more closely with the harvest whose bounty it is meant to celebrate, the almanac says. The almanac says the second Monday in October, the date on which Canada celebrates Thanksgiving, might be an appropriate alternative. Almanac editor Ray Geiger invites readers to offer their own ideas. ``We're only suggesting that we examine this thing. We're not bold enough to say `do it!''' Geiger said in an interview. Thanksgiving, commemorating the feast held by members of the Plymouth Colony in Massachusetts in December 1621 to celebrate that year's harvest, has been observed at various dates over the years. It has remained at its current date since 1863, except for a brief period when President Franklin D. Roosevelt reset it for the third Thursday in November. ``Thanksgiving is a sacred holiday. What makes it sacrosanct is not that it is observed on a certain date each year, but rather what it means,'' the almanac says. ``When one ponders the real reason for Thanksgiving, the date of celebration seems immaterial.'' Geiger said the principal reason for change would be to separate Thanksgiving from the overlapping demands posed by the start of the Christmas season. ``You've got football, you've got Christmas pressing and you don't know whether you're celebrating Thanksgiving or Christmas,'' he said. An earlier holiday would reduce the chances that travelers would encounter ice or snow while heading to family gatherings, Geiger said. And it would shift the holiday to a time closer to the end of the harvest, when the woods still are ablaze with colorful foliage, he said. By contrast, fields and orchards are bare in late November and trees have lost their leaves. ``When we celebrate Thanksgiving under these conditions, we seem to have lost our sense of timing,'' the almanac said. The date change could mark the start of a new crusade by the 174-year-old almanac, which in years past has prodded the government to restore city names to postmarks and eliminate the nine-digit ZIP code. Geiger's almanac is not to be confused with the Old Farmers Almanac, the 198-year-old New Hampshire-based publication. Geiger claims a circulation of about 5 million for the 48-page publication, sold to banks, insurance companies and other businesses that distribute it to customers as a promotional tool. Last year's campaign promoting the introduction of a coin it calls the Columbus Dollar as a replacement for the $1 bill is making progress, Geiger said, and bills introduced in the House and Senate are enjoying increased support. That proposal, along with the shuffling of Thanksgiving, does not mean that the almanac is abandoning its longstanding profession of traditional values. ``Tradition is a must for us, but we're not blinded by it,'' Geiger said. Almanac traditions include calendar data, puzzles, household hints, inspirational messages, one-line jokes and ``flavorite recipes.'' Another tradition is weather data. This year's edition predicts a harsh winter _ chilling news to households concerned about rising energy prices brought on by the crisis in the Persian Gulf. ``It's going to be a rough winter, rougher than last year, with more snow and more cold weather in January and February,'' Geiger said. ``But it's not going to be a prolonged winter. It's going to ease off early in March,'' Geiger said. The almanac forecasts a mild spring and summer that won't be too hot. The forecasts are prepared by Caleb Weatherbee, who calculates them in accordance with a secret formula based on sunspots, the position of the planets and the tidal action of the moon, Geiger said. ``His track record has been excellent, getting better every year.''

DOC.HEAD: European Community to Provide $2 Billion for Embargo Losses
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
By MARY BETH SHERIDAN
DOC.TEXT: The nations of the European Community today agreed to give $2 billion in economic aid to Turkey, Jordan and Egypt to compensate them for trade lost as a result of the U.N. sanctions on Iraq. The European countries also granted more food and other emergency aid for the tens of thousands of refugees from Iraq and Kuwait stranded at Iraq's borders. However, the 12 EC states made no promises to contribute to the cost of deploying U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf. The buildup was launched to counter the Iraqi invasion of neighboring Kuwait on Aug. 2. After the meeting of the EC foreign ministers, the Italian minister, Gianni De Michelis, told reporters, ``We want to contribute to the burden-sharing in an independent and direct manner and not to the expenses of a separate country, even though it is an ally.'' He said the $2 billion that the EC will grant Turkey, Jordan and Egypt through 1991 ``relieves the United States of an effort in this area.'' There have been increasing demands in the U.S. Congress for America's allies to share the cost of deploying the thousands of U.S. troops in the gulf. Italy holds the EC's rotating presidency. Jordan, Turkey and Egypt are particularly hard hit by the U.N.-ordered embargo on Iraq. The EC executive Commission has estimated their losses in revenues through 1991 at roughly $10 billion. On food and other emergency aid for refugees, the EC countries agreed to donate another $39 million. That money would come in addition to the $27 million they already pledged. The European Community members are France, West Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, Belgium, Netherlands, Denmark, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, Spain, and Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Hyena Trapped in Bathroom Floods Home
DOC.TEXT: A hyena that accidentally locked itself in the bathroom at a game park got the last laugh _ it tore the room apart and opened the shower tap, flooding the house. The Star newspaper said Friday the hyena spent 24 hours in the bathroom last weekend at the house in Skukuza, a village in Kruger National Park in eastern South Africa. It apparently wandered into the house while the occupants were away. The hyena pulled down curtains, ripped the medicine chest from the wall, smashed the toilet seat, damaged a towel rail and bit into aerosal shaving cream and deodorant cans, the Star said. It also turned on the shower, causing overflowing water to seep under the door into the rest of the house, the newspaper said. Neighbors saw water coming out from under the front door and alerted game rangers, who shot the hyena with a tranquilizer dart through the bathroom window. Tests on the animal indicated no serious injuries, and the hyena was released.

DOC.HEAD: Osho Rajneesh's Dentist Says: Fix Saddam's Teeth, End Gulf Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The crisis in the Persian Gulf could be settled peacefully if Iraqi President Saddam Hussein got his teeth fixed, the personal dentist to the late guru Osho Rajneesh said Friday. Swami Devageet said Rajneesh, the mystic who was expelled from the United States in 1985 and died in January, discovered a year ago that ``man's animal past, including his aggressive instincts, are mysteriously stored in the human dental structure.'' In a telex from the commune that Rajneesh founded in Poona, Devageet said Saddam could become ``a blissful human being instead of a blistering warmonger'' if he submitted to tooth-centered character analysis. ``It may sound absurd, but it's a lot cheaper than a third World War,'' Devageet said.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Sentenced to Five Years For Hijacking
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager who hijacked an Aeroflot jet to Sweden in June has been convicted of air piracy and sentenced to five years in prison, Soviet media reported. Dmitry Semenov, 17, pretended he had a grenade and forced the Minsk-to-Murmansk flight to land in Stockholm on June 9. He told authorities he hijacked the jet for personal rather than political reasons. Airline hijackings carry a penalty of 5 to 20 years in jail in the Soviet Union, but because he is under 18, Semenov faced a maximum of 10 years. Prosecutor Ivan Sukhoverkh asked the judges at the trial in Minsk to sentence Semenov to six years, and on Thursday they sentenced him to five, the Tass news agency reported. The judges took into account the fact that Semenov came from a broken home and noted his ``high emotional excitability,'' Tass said. There were at least a dozen airline hijackings in the Soviet Union this summer. The youth will serve his sentence in a reformatory for juvenile delinquents, Tass said. Semenov was believed to be the first person to be extradited from Sweden to the Soviet Union since the end of World War II, when some Baltic refugees were sent back. The Soviet Union alleged they were Nazi sympathizers. Sweden's acting prime minister, Lena Hjelm-Wallen, said the decision to grant the extradition request was ``a signal to would-be hijackers.''

DOC.HEAD: Nudist Camp Owner Challenges GOP Incumbent; Three-Way Democratic Primary
DOC.TEXT: Three New Hampshire Democrats are trying to turn the state's financial woes into a political plus as they seek to end eight years of Republican domination in the governor's office. Gov. Judd Gregg faces token opposition from a nudist camp owner in Tuesday's primary. The three Democrats fighting for the chance to run against Gregg are counting on voter unrest to sway independents, who comprise just under one-third of registered voters, to vote Democratic in November. New Hampshire has a dismal economy and a budget deficit despite recent tax hikes. But most believe it will be an uphill climb for any Democrat to unseat Gregg. The governor already has more than twice the campaign contributions his opponents have raised collectively and leads comfortably in polls. Gregg, 43, a former four-term congressman, is seeking his second two-year term. In the GOP primary, he faces Robert Bonser, 69, who decided to run to protest having several mobile homes hauled out of his nudist park in a zoning dispute. Former state Democratic Chairman Joseph Grandmaison, 47, state Senate Democratic Leader Robert Preston, 61, and state Rep. Paul Blacketor, 63, have focused their campaigns for the Democratic nomination on Gregg, accusing him of mismanaging the economy. Grandmaison says Gregg's ``short-term fixes'' will result in a ``giant past due bill arriving next January.'' Adds Preston: ``I have never seen such chaos in state government. Our economy is floundering; the ship of state lacks a skipper at the helm.'' Gregg and legislators enacted a package of tax and fee hikes and spending cuts in February that weren't enough to prevent a deficit when the fiscal year ended June 30. A further decline in revenues prompted Gregg last month to make additional budget cuts. Gregg says he's acted decisively and that the $160 million fix in February means ``the budget concerns we now face are manageable.'' Preston and Blacketor also have attacked Grandmaison, who leads them in recent polls, as being too closely tied to Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, whose popularity has plunged since he ran for president. Grandmaison directed Dukakis' first gubernatorial campaign and has received contributions from more than 40 current or former Dukakis campaign workers as well as $100 from Dukakis. Preston, who says he represents a conservative wing of the party able to win in November, wants voters to link Grandmaison with Massachusetts, derisively called ``Taxachusetts'' by some New Hampshire residents. ``Frankly, I think Granite State citizens will resent the fact that Massachusetts politicians and their fat cat contributors will try and influence the outcome of a New Hampshire election,'' Preston says. ``Mike Dukakis is my friend. He gave my campaign $100,'' Grandmaison responds. ``I don't know why Bob (Preston) finds that so upsetting.'' Abortion is an important, but not pivotal, issue, partly because Gregg vetoed pro-choice legislation both this year and last. Preston and Bonser oppose abortion while Grandmaison and Blacketor are pro-choice. The National Abortion Rights Action League of New Hampshire endorsed Grandmaison, believing he has a better chance of winning than Blacketor. However, taxes overshadowed abortion in a poll of 900 potential voters in July by the Becker Institute Inc. of Sudbury, Mass. New Hampshire voters traditionally reject candidates who refuse to take ``The Pledge'' to veto general sales or income tax proposals. But both Grandmaison and Blacketor advocate tax reform, which has growing appeal to voters disenchanted that property taxes have doubled, on average, since 1983. Blacketor proposes an income tax earmarked for property tax relief, while Grandmaison has called for tax reform without being specific. Gregg has promised to veto broad-based taxes. In the Becker poll, Gregg topped Grandmaison among pro-choice voters, 47 percent to 37 percent, with 16 percent undecided. Grandmaison led Gregg among those who favor enacting a state sales or income tax, 45 percent to 38 percent, with 17 percent undecided. Gregg held a wide lead over Grandmaison among tax- and abortion-opponents, and among those satisfied with the economy. Overall, 52 percent picked Gregg to 32 percent for Grandmaison with 16 percent undecided. Gregg led Preston by a similar margin. The margin of error was about 5 percentage points. An August poll conducted by the University of New Hampshire for WMUR-TV had Grandmaison leading his opponents almost 3-1, but more than half of those polled said they hadn't made up their minds.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Vow Beirut Slaughter Won't Happen Again
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The last large deployment of U.S. Marines in the Middle East ended with more than 240 of them killed by a suicide car bomber in Beirut in 1983. Risks of such an attack are extremely low in a controlled society like Saudi Arabia, but the U.S. military says it is taking no chances. ``The lesson we learned from Beirut was a very hard one,'' said spokesman Lt. Col. John Olsen. ``We're taking a lot of care not to repeat that.'' He would not comment on specific security measures, but some are obvious. Journalists are barred from photographing sleeping areas, for example. The suicide bomber in Lebanon's capital, believed to be a member of an extremist Shiite Moslem faction, drove a truck crammed with explosives into a Marines barracks building. Commanders were criticized for inadequate precautions that allowed the truck driver to make it through the gates. Marines in Saudi Arabia said Beirut crosses their minds occasionally. ``You always think nothing's going to happen, but you never know,'' said Sgt. Thomas Hixson, 23, of Kingston, Tenn. ``Just like Beirut. It helps keep people's morale up to ask them what they would do in a case like that.'' The 2nd Battalion's commanding officer was more blunt. ``We're not going to allow terrorists to come in here and kill Marines,'' said Col. Carl Fulford, of Twentynine Palms, Calif. ``We're not going to stack them up in one hotel waiting for someone to come blow them up.''

Blunt talk by commanders makes good newspaper quotes and excellent television or radio sound bites. The more it sounds like the movies, the faster reporters try to get every nugget. Fulford is a particular favorite for sentences like: ``If the Iraqi were to come south, we'd give him all he can handle.'' Said one Australian reporter after a Fulford briefing: ``They got that guy from central casting.''

U.S. troops headed into the Saudi Arabian desert are given strict lectures about Islamic customs that demand fairly puritanical behavior by American standards, such as the separation of men and women in public. A song booming over the loudspeaker on a bus shuttling around one staging area seemed inappropriate. The refrain was: ``Take Me Dancing Naked in The Rain.''

The new diplomatic quarter in the Saudi capital, Riyadh, is a stunning enclave of parks and embassies executed by modern architects. The shopping centers and apartment buildings were designed to resemble old Saudi mud brick forts. The landscaped park around the quarter consists basically of a high earthern wall with just a few entrances cut through for roads. The idea was to allow up to 25,000 foreigners living there some privacy for outdoor activities like jogging that the Saudi public might frown on. But in this time of crisis, the Iraqi siege of the foreign embassies in Kuwait is more on everbody's mind than the careful design. ``They'll have no difficulty sealing off this quarter,'' joked one visitor.

The question: ``What should be done about Iraqi President Saddam Hussein?'' elicits a standard array of responses like ``Hit him hard'' or ``Knock him down'' or just plain ``Kill him!'' But once in a while the question draws a more vivid answer. Like one from an elderly Omani herdsman: ``I'd like to take out his eyes and heart and boil them.''
