DOC.HEAD: White House Panel on Owls Unlikely to Change Endangered Species Act
DOC.TEXT: Faced with opposition from environmentalists and key lawmakers, the Bush administration isn't likely to weaken the Endangered Species Act to save logging jobs in Northwest forests where the threatened northern spotted owl lives, congressional aides said Friday. Bill Calder, press secretary for Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., said a White House task force hasn't ruled out changing the act to soften the economic blow of protecting the owl. But, he said, leaders of the Cabinet-level task force have indicated they're moving away from that option. ``The senator has always believed we should not be tinkering with the act,'' Calder said. An aide to Rep. Bob Smith, R-Ore., also said Friday it appears unlikely there is enough support in Congress to change the act. ``There are too many powerful committee chairmen, subcommittee chairman, indeed the rank-and-file members, who say they are not going to change the act,'' said press secretary Dave Redmond. Hatfield and Assistant Agriculture Secretary Jim Moseley, who works on the task force for Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, denied reports the panel backs a version of a controversial plan offered by government scientists in April. That plan would ban logging on millions of old-growth forests in Washington, Oregon and Northern California. ``It's not the information we have received,'' Hatfield said. Moseley said in a statement that the task force has not completed its deliberations. He said reports that the task force has concluded owl protection will cost 20,000 jobs are ``speculative and conjectural.'' ``The task force is working toward recommendations which will balance the economic and environmental concerns of the Northwest,'' Moseley said. Hatfield said the recommendations made by the scientific committee are ``totally unacceptable.'' Job loss in the region under that proposal would range from 25,000 to 50,000 and revenue loss could total $600 million to $2 billion, he said. ``I can tell you that would be like sending a missile into the economy of the Northwest,'' Hatfield said. Steve Goldstein, a spokesman for Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan, denied a report in Friday's Washington Post that the task force had tentatively agreed to back the April report. Lujan is a member of the task force, along with the heads of the Environmental Protection Agency, the Office of Management and Budget and the Council of Economic Advisers. Goldstein said late Thursday that the task force leaders told the panel's working members this week ``to begin exploring new options.'' ``Clearly the principals are not satisfied that they have come up with the best solution,'' Goldstein said. ``Secretary Lujan believes there are better options.'' Goldstein declined to elaborate on those options. A congressional aide who spoke on the condition of anonymity said White House Chief of Staff John Sununu told Yeutter on Wednesday that the April report is ``simply unacceptable'' because of its economic impact. An administration source who asked not to be identified said the task force had concluded it will be more difficult to save timber jobs than the task force originally had hoped, but that no plan has been backed. The Fish and Wildlife Service declared the owl a threatened species in June.

DOC.HEAD: Birds of a (Different) Feather Flock Together
DOC.TEXT: Officials at Will Rogers World Airport would like to know how a parrot got in with a flock of ducks living at a pond on airport property. But the bird isn't talking. Airport spokesman Tom Morton said field maintenance workers first noticed the gaudy green bird Aug. 31 and called animal control. But animal control officers were unable to catch it. A call to the Oklahoma City Zoo also proved worthless. ``They didn't want the parrot,'' Morton said. Morton and a photographer went looking and found the bird perched in a tree. ``We couldn't coax him down, but he didn't seem to mind our taking his picture,'' Morton said. The bird is not wanting for company in the grassy area known as Coleman Plaza at the airport entrance. ``There are rabbits, ducks, doves, raccoons and other animals living there,'' Morton said. He said the parrot has taken up with the ducks, apparently because the fowl get fed regularly.

DOC.HEAD: Advice to GOP: Call Democrats `Sick,' `Pathetic,' `Liberal'
DOC.TEXT: Attention Republicans: mention ``strength,'' ``vision'' and ``hard work'' when talking about yourself. Use ``pathetic,'' ``liberal'' and ``criminal rights'' when talking about Democrats. GOPAC, a conservative political action committee, this week is distributing scores of suggested words and phrases that can help GOP candidates burnish their own images and revile their opponents. The Washington-based group, whose general chairman is Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia, sent the list and a few helpful hints to some 6,000 Republican officeholders and candidates across the country. Gingrich is not one to ignore his own advice. In an August speech to the Heritage Foundation, Gingrich packed four words from the GOPAC list into just two sentences. The loaded words are indicated in capital letters: ``Congress is a broken system. It is increasingly a system of CORRUPTION in which money politics is defeating and driving out CITIZEN politics. Congress is a SICKer and sicker institution in an imperial capital that wallows in the American people's TAX money.'' Democratic National Committee spokeswoman Ginny Terzano used few words in responding to the GOPAC circular. ``While the Democrats are dealing with issues, Republicans are playing Scrabble,'' she said. The recipients of the GOP list aren't yet running for Congress. But GOPAC hopes they will. ``This list is prepared so that you might have a directory of words to use in writing literature and mail, in preparing speeches, and in producing electronic media,'' GOPAC tells its members in introducing the key words. ``The words and phrases are powerful. Read them. Memorize as many as possible. And remember that, like any tool, these words will not help if they are not used.'' In all, there are 131 selections to choose from. Half are called ``positive governing words'' that candidates can use to outline their vision of the future and of their own philosophy. They include ``flag,'' ``prosperity,'' ``common sense,'' and ``reform.'' The others are called ``contrasting words'' that attempt to identify and label the Democratic enemy in terms voters can understand. They include ``waste,'' ``corruption,'' ``traitor,'' and ``decay.'' GOPAC offers a whole host of ``anti-'' words handy for use against opponents _ ``anti-flag,'' ``anti-family,'' ``anti-child,'' ``anti-jobs.'' The word list is the product of months of research by GOPAC staffers in focus groups across the country, according to Gingrich. GOPAC Chairman Howard ``Bo'' Callaway said the group hopes the vocabulary list, instructional speaking tapes, forums and other programs it offers will help correct a flaw in the political system. Conservatism, he said, is popular, but that isn't being reflected in the results of local elections. Sometimes conservatives lose because they don't use the right buzz words. ``Language really does matter _ how you say things and the semantics,'' Callaway said.

DOC.HEAD: Utilities Invest in Electrical Car for L.A. Commuters
DOC.TEXT: Two utilities have agreed to develop a mass-production electric car and put 1,000 of them on the streets of the nation's smoggiest city by late 1992. The $7 million project would produce as many as 10,000 electric vehicles for car-crazy Los Angeles by 1995, the city Department of Water and Power and Southern California Edison Co. announced Thursday. ``It is essential that we move ahead on clean air,'' said City Councilman Marvin Braude, an advocate of electric car development. ``We must find alternative fuels to oil _ and electric power is the fuel of choice.'' The car will be designed by Clean Air Transport, a 2-year-old firm based in Sweden that beat 18 American and foreign bidders for the contract. Dubbed the ``LA 301,'' the clean machine would carry four passengers, have a range of 150 miles between charges and a top speed of 70 mph. Designers say it will accelerate from zero to 30 mph in nine seconds. In passenger sedan and quarter-ton minivan models, the vehicles initially would cost $25,000 each, a price officials said would drop with large scale production. ``They're fun to ride. It's exciting and they are vibrationless,'' Braude said after test driving a prototype. The first cars will be produced in England. Henry Munkevik, managing director of Clean Air Transport, said production eventually could be transferred to Los Angeles. Jerry Enzenauer, the DWP's electric transportation program manager, acknowledged the utilities hoped the plan would help persuade air quality officials to ease pollution restrictions on power plants.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Louisiana Oil Field Waste Contaminating Wetlands
DOC.TEXT: Toxic and radioactive discharges from oil fields are contaminating southeast Louisiana wetlands, possibly upsetting the delicate ecological balance and disrupting the food chain, says a state report. The Department of Environmental Quality study released Thursday said high levels of volatile organic compounds and radium are accumulating in estuaries and wetland sediment. The contamination could spread if the sediment was disburbed by dredging, a storm or even a passing tugboat, state officials said. And the pollutants threaten to diminish the seafood supply, they said. ``The more land we lose to coastal erosion, the less we have left and the more we have to protect it,'' said Maureen O'Neill, assistant secretary of the department. ``There's a very serious amount of contamination going into the wetlands through these discharges and we have to get rid of it.'' The sediment is being contaminated by ``produced water,'' a virtual chemical stew that flows from oil wells. Companies separate the produced water from petroleum and release it into the wetlands. Such discharges, amounting to 84 million gallons a day, are allowed in southeastern Louisiana but are prohibited in the northern part of the state, O'Neill said. Only Texas and Louisiana allow the discharge of produced water, the department said. The report appears to add momentum to the campaign to ban such discharges. The department has circulated proposed regulations to phase out the discharge of produced water in four years. Oil and gas companies have complained that the deadline is too short; environmentalists have objected that it is too long, O'Neill said. Industry could drill new wells and inject the contaminants into them, but that's much more expensive than dumping them into the water. ``It's always cheaper to release contaminants into the waterways,'' said O'Neill said. ``But this won't put the oil industry out of business.'' Mid-Continent Oil and Gas Association, the lobbying organization for the state's oil and gas companies, said in 40 years of drilling, produced water has not harmed the environment or human health. The threat has been limited to some bottom-dwelling organisms in certain wetlands, said spokesman Larry Wall. He said a ban on such discharges could force the capping of less profitable wells. The association has asked for eight years to end the discharges.

DOC.HEAD: Island Dispute Still Hampers Improved Relations
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's planned visit to Japan is another step to ease tensions between the nations, but rival claims over an island chain keep relations cool, officials said Friday following four days of meetings. It was unclear if the talks made progress toward resolving the 45-year-old territorial dispute over the islands seized by the Soviets at the end of World War II. The issue has blocked closer relations with the Soviet Union while many other nations break down Cold War barriers with Moscow. ``One thing I can confidently say is that the ... atmosphere has changed significantly during this visit,'' said Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze before returning to Moscow Friday. ``It was an extremely meaningful visit for both sides,'' said Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama. The agreement for the April 1991 visit by Gorbachev highlighted the meetings between Nakayama and Shevardnadze. Japanese officials, however, stressed they will continue to push for the return of the Kuril Islands, a sparsely populated archipelago north of the Japanese island of Hokkaido. The islands, in waters rich with salmon and other marine resources, were claimed as historically Russian territory. Japan contends they were ceded by a 19th-century agreement. The two countries have yet to sign a post-World War II peace treaty because of the Kuril dispute. ``I could not find any practical change in the attitude of the Soviet Union on the territorial issue,'' Nakayama said. But some analysts say they expect the Soviets to seek a resolution to the territorial issue in order to gain access to Japanese economic aid and investment. ``I think the time is ripe to take a big political step forward. It is time to discuss fundamental issues between the two countries,'' said Shevardnadze. ``Our basic policy remains unchanged,'' said Kazuhiko Togo, director of the Foreign Ministry's Soviet Union Division. ``We have asked the Soviet side to consider the question seriously, squarely and straightforwardly.'' It is not clear whether Japanese officials will discuss the Kuril dispute with Gorbachev, who earlier threatened to refuse a Japanese trip if the issue would be raised. Shevardnadze also met with Emperor Akihito and invited him to Moscow. Akihito declined to reply immediately, saying ``it is for the two governments to decide,'' according to an Imperial Household Agency official. On Wednesday, the two governments issued their first joint statement on an international issue. The declaration condemned the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and demanded an immediate withdrawal of its troops.

DOC.HEAD: Government Puts Soldiers at State Telephone Company; Strikers Angry
DOC.TEXT: The government of President Carlos Menem, signaling it will not bow to pressure by organized labor, has sent soldiers to the state telephone company to replace striking employees. It was the harshest action yet by the government against the unions that helped put it in office 14 months ago. A crew of about 20 officials from the army, navy and air force went to work Thursday at the telephone company's center for international communications in downtown Buenos Aires. The director of the state company, ENTel, said it was necessary to protect company property and restore service after 350 strikers were fired. The boycott by the 25,000 union members in the capital threatened to spread nationwide. ``The jobs not covered by normal operators ... are going to be covered, as of today, by personnel of the armed forces,'' Maria Julia Alsogaray told reporters after meeting with Menem. The Menem government has been plagued by strikes in recent months, many brought on by salary demands as real wages have been shrunk by inflation. Bus drivers walked off the job Monday just before the evening rush hour. The next day, 40,000 doctors and nurses at public hospitals stayed off the job to protest the layoffs of 2,000 colleagues. Most were rehired. Train crews were to strike beginning Thursday, but the government ordered mandatory conciliation for 20 days. University professors have not given end-of-semester exams since July; grade school teachers are threatening to revive classroom boycotts held months ago. The government claims some of the strikes are political statements against its policies of budget austerity and a reduced role for the state in the economy. Unions that represent ENTel and state airline employees admit they fear job and wage cutbacks when the companies are sold. Formal transfers of ownership are set for Oct. 8. Privatizations and deregulation as well as budget austerity have been policy centerpieces since Menem took office in July 1989 amid hyperinflation, recession and a nearly bankrupt treasury. He lifted controls on foreign exchange and prices, allowed foreign companies access to state oil fields, reduced import tariffs and export taxes, cut back subsidies to private businesses and provincial governments, seized bank deposits to throttle speculation, and hiked public service rates to what it costs to provide them. Midway through this year, monthly inflation neared single digits, Central Bank reserves topped $2.3 billion, and the austral regained stability. However, inflation in July crept up to 10.8 percent and last month reached 15.3 percent. The austral began to devalue. Menem's response was to announce the layoffs of 130,000 contract employees and civil servants, close down the money-losing National Mortgage Bank, and pay state suppliers owed $8 billion with bonds that come due over 10 years. ``The party's over,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Special Trip to Mark `Chattanooga Choo-Choo's' Golden Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Tourism officials hope a train ride following the route of Glenn Miller's ``Chattanooga Choo-Choo'' will boost recognition for the city that inspired the tune. The Chattanooga Convention and Visitors Bureau is planning a special rail excursion from New York to Chattanooga next September on what will be the song's 50th anniversary. Bureau officials plan to use the 18-car train to bring about 400 convention planners, travel writers, tour operators and business executives to Chattanooga. ``It's not just a train ride. It'll have lasting impact. Someone may book a meeting three years down the road as a result of taking this trip,'' Carl Little, executive director of the bureau, said Thursday. If all goes as planned, the train will arrive in Chattanooga in time for the city's annual Choo-Choo festival. Harry Warren and Mack Gordon wrote the song ``Chattanooga Choo-Choo,'' about a fictional New York-to-Chattanooga rail route. It made its debut in the 1941 movie ``Sun Valley Serenade'' and won a gold record for Miller. ``We're known worldwide for that song,'' said Little. ``I've traveled quite a few places, and in most parts they don't even know that Chattanooga's in Tennessee. But they know the Chattanooga Choo-Choo.'' The tourism bureau is still working out details with Amtrak, but the train is expected to leave from New York's Pennsylvania Station, just as in the song, Little said. ``I don't know that we'll leave right at a quarter of four, because that's the time the Crescent leaves,'' Little said, chuckling. ``But we will make promotional stops in Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington, Lynchburg, Virginia, Charlottesville, Virginia, Charlotte, North Carolina, and Atlanta.''

DOC.HEAD: North Korean Soldier Defects in Boat
DOC.TEXT: A North Korean soldier on a sea training exercise broke away from his unit Friday and used a rubber boat to defect to South Korea, military officials said. Lee Kyong Nam, 24, a master sergeant, surrendered to a South Korean military outpost on Paeknyongdo Island shortly after 2 p.m., the officials said. The island, 120 miles northwest of Seoul, is only six miles from the North Korean coast. The defection came a few hours after North Korean Premier Yon Hyong Muk returned home following after four days of historic talks with South Korea on easing tensions between the rival states. Several North Korean soldiers and civilians have defected to South Korea by sea and land in recent years. The Korean peninsula was divided into the communist North and the capitalist South in 1945. Their border is the most heavily armed in the world with more than 1.6 million troops deployed on both sides.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Favored in His First Non-Presidential Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: retransmitting to correct cycle designator to AMs.
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson is campaigning to become the District of Columbia's unpaid ``shadow senator'' using the same personal salesmanship skills that earned him 7 million votes for president in 1988. Jackson is favored to win one of two ``shadow senator'' nominations in Tuesday's Democratic primary after spending months preaching the gospel of statehood for the district. The two ``senators'' will serve as lobbyists pressing Congress for D.C. statehood. District voters also will elect a ``shadow representative'' this year to advance the district's uphill effort to become a state. It is Jackson's first bid for an office other than president, and he is using the same articulate, personal campaign style that he employed in his 1984 and 1988 presidential campaigns. While four years ago he was stumping in Iowa wheat fields and East Los Angeles soup kitchens, Jackson now works coffee klatches and neighborhood meetings around the nation's capital. ``Jackson in person is very persuasive _ in that sense it is the same as his presidential campaigns,'' said longtime Jackson aide Frank Watkins. ``Statehood was dead, buried and had a couple shovel loads of earth on it when he started talking about it, and now, all the mayoral candidates say it is one of their top priorities.'' If Jackson wins one of the ``senator'' nominations on Tuesday, a victory in November's general election is a near-certainty, given that Democrats outnumber Republicans by an eight-to-one margin in the district. Jackson moved from Chicago to Washington last year, and speculation that he would run for mayor increased with Mayor Marion Barry's much-publicized legal problems linked to drug and perjury charges. Barry, who was convicted of a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge, decided not to seek re-election. But Jackson declined to run for mayor, prompting a new round of criticism from those who have maintained he is unqualified to be president because he never has served in elective office. Jackson says he chose to seek the shadow senator's job because ``my quest is not employment. It's empowerment.'' ``Why D.C. statehood? Why not mayor? Because my life commitment is to expand democracy,'' he told a group of Democratic women this summer. Some critics have faulted Jackson for a weak understanding of local issues, and questioned whether the world traveller will commit himself fully to the goal of statehood. ``Freeing D.C. residents from colonial bondage will require more commitment than his three-day rescue mission to Damascus or Baghdad,'' the local ``City Paper'' said in a recent article on Jackson's campaign. Aides say statehood remains Jackson's top priority even as he continues to be involved in a host of foreign policy and civil rights issues. Last week he traveled to the Middle East, where he interviewed Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for a syndicated television show. A week earlier, he stood before microphones and television cameras to urge minorities to boycott Nike products because the athletic wear giant has no blacks on its board of directors. ``The commitment is there,'' said Bernard Demczuk, a labor liaison with Jackson's National Rainbow Coalition. ``Whether it is (in) the Middle East or Mississippi, he is saying that the number one civil rights priority is statehood for the district.'' ``Don't forget, he can travel the country, getting the people who voted for him (in 1988) to pressure their elected representatives to support statehood,'' Watkins said. The shadow senator concept first was employed by the Tennessee territory prior to its admission to the union in 1796. The district's shadow delegation will have no voting rights and only one official mission _ to encourage Congress to make the nation's capital the 51st state. The city council originally wanted to spend $1.3 million for the delegation's salaries and expenses, but dropped that plan because of budget problems. The lack of voting authority and a salary hasn't diminished Jackson's enthusiasm for statehood _ or his penchant for relentless campaigning. ``He's been to forums, ward events, quite a few house parties, just like last time around,'' Watkins said. ``The only difference here is, the travel is a lot easier _ any stop we have to make here can be done in 20 minutes or less, without getting on a plane.''

DOC.HEAD: Female Impersonator, Zen Abbot, Hospice Founder Dies of AIDS
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st two grafs to move Thursday to second graf
DOC.TEXT: Issan Tommy Dorsey, abbot of the San Francisco Zen Center, has died of AIDS. He was 57. Dorsey died Thursday at the Maitri Hospice, which he founded in 1987 when a fellow student at the Zen Center became ill with AIDS. A year later, the hospice merged with the Zen Center. Dorsey came to San Francisco in 1953 after being discharged from the Navy. During the Beat era, he worked as a female impersonator on Broadway and toured the country in drag as ``Tommy Dee.''

DOC.HEAD: Summit Could Lead to Joint Statement on Iraq, Maybe More
DOC.TEXT: For President Bush, the Helsinki summit offers a chance to demonstrate truly global support for his Persian Gulf policy. For Mikhail Gorbachev, it presents an opportunity to remind his people the Soviet Union remains a major player in world affairs. As for specific actions, there are a number of possible steps Bush and Gorbachev could take to signal united disapproval of Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait. Administration officials sought to lower expectations for any major initiatives from either side. But, even a joint statement reiterating the call for an Iraqi rollback from Kuwait would be significant. It would mark the first time the Cold War rivals have spoken in tandem on a major international issue other than arms control in more than four decades _ a strong message U.S. officials say they assume would not be lost on Saddam. The two leaders will also use their Sunday summit to attempt to prod arms-control negotiations in hopes of nailing down a treaty on conventional force reductions in Europe by year's end, administration officials say. And they could announce at summit's end whether they will accept invitations to attend German reunification ceremonies in Berlin on Oct. 3. The White House expectation-lowering effort followed a familiar pattern in advance of superpower summits. ``As the president has indicated, it is an unstructured agenda,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Still, at last December's summit at Malta, the White House said essentially the same thing _ and Bush proceeded to lay out in careful detail a full 16-point program. Here are some steps that could be taken at Helsinki if the leaders decide to go beyond a simple statement on Iraq. _ Although it seems unlikely, Moscow could agree to send forces to bolster the U.N. military operation. A senior administration official, briefing reporters at the White House on Friday on the condition of anonymity, said it would ``be useful if the Soviets would send ground forces.'' Bush seems likely to convey this message to the Soviet leader at Sunday's session. _ Gorbachev could announce the withdrawal of all or some Soviet advisers from Iraq, as pressed by the United States. However, such a step would mark a major concession on the Soviet side _ and U.S. official say they do not really except it to happen. Still, ``you can be sure the issue will be discussed,'' the senior official said. _ The Soviet Union could agree to develop, with outside help, its vast oil supplies to help offset losses from the gulf. Fitzwater said energy supplies will be discussed ``and probably oil reserves in the Soviet Union.'' However, Soviet oil production has been down in recent months. _ Some long range peace plan for the region could be proposed, or at least an agreement to study the possibility. It would have to be a common ground between the NATO-like military alliance proposed by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and the conference suggested by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze to settle both the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. _ The Soviets could be invited to play some mediation role in negotiating the withdrawal of Iraq from occupied Kuwait and U.S. forces from Saudi Arabia. U.S. officials have played down these suggestions, however. The summit will give a Bush a chance to respond to Soviet misgivings about the U.S. military buildup less than 1,000 miles from the Soviet border. Gorbachev has said ``the building up of military confrontation might lead to unpredictable consequences'' in the tense Persian Gulf. Also, if Bush is planning military action against Iraq, he would no doubt want to tell Gorbachev of his intentions in advance, U.S. officials agree. Lost in the discussions, says one administration official involved in the summit preparations, is the fact that ``there is obviously a special relationship that the Soviet Union enjoys with Iraq.'' Moscow had been Baghdad's prime arms supplier. The Soviets ``still have their advisers there. They still have influence,'' the official said. ``The fact of the (Helsinki) meeting itself sends a very strong signal to Saddam,'' the official said. Thus far, despite its lukewarm support for the U.S. military presence in the Middle East, the Soviet Union has tolerated it. The summit will also give Bush a chance to sound out Gorbachev on ``what the Iraq position is,'' particularly in light of this week's meeting between the Soviet leader and the Iraqi foreign minister, the official said. ``We will pass on what our intentions are and our goals are,'' the official added. Many analysts say they doubt that any new initiatives will result from the summit _ if only because all sides seem to want to wait to see if the international sanctions are taking hold.

DOC.HEAD: Police: `Promising Evidence' Found In College Slayings
With PM-Gainesville-Football Season
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with spokeswoman saying evidence found in searches `promising.' Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Budnick ruled...'.
DOC.TEXT: Investigators found ``promising evidence'' in the slayings of five college students when they searched the lodgings and car of a suspect, a spokeswoman said today. On Thursday, investigators searched the apartment of the suspect, 18-year-old part-time student Edward Lewis Humphrey, as well as the home of his grandmother and his car. They also took blood and hair samples from Humphrey. ``We did not leave empty-handed,'' Lt. Sadie Darnell, Gainesville police spokeswoman, told a news briefing today. Besides calling the evidence promising, she declined to elaborate. On Thursday, she had said that while she was not prepared to label Humphrey a prime suspect, ``it is obvious we have a lot of information on Mr. Humphrey.'' Humphrey, whom police describe as one of eight suspects in last month's grisly slayings, has not been charged in the deaths. He remained jailed today on $1 million bond in connection with an assault on his grandmother shortly after the killings. And Thursday, University of Florida police announced they issued a warrant charging Humphrey with two counts of aggravated assault in another incident Aug. 25, a day before the first two bodies were found. Police would not give details of the incident, but The Miami Herald reported today that two freshmen, both 18-year-old male fraternity pledges, were threatened with a knife at the Pi Lambda Phi house. Also Thursday, a judge in Sharpes cited Humphrey's bizarre behavior when he upheld a $1 million bond on the charge that Humphrey assaulted his 79-year-old grandmother. ``I see before me a very disturbed individual,'' Circuit Judge Martin Budnick said. ``I see a great deal of acting out ... neurotic or psychotic behavior.'' Budnick ruled that Humphrey is a danger to the community. But he indicated he would consider another request for bond reduction and wanted to hear medical testimony about Humphrey's mental condition. Humphrey's grandmother testified she didn't want to press charges and would welcome Humphrey back into her home, where Humphrey's mother also lives. ``I want it dropped ... definitely,'' Elna Hlavaty, her right cheek and right eye badly bruised, said as Humphrey looked on. She said she didn't fear her grandson, although she had called police repeatedly. Ms. Hlavaty said she couldn't remember details of the night she was hurt, other than that she bruised her right side when she fell on a concrete floor. Sheriff's Deputy Douglas Hammack testified she told him the night of the arrest that she feared Humphrey would beat her again. Warrants also have been issued for Humphrey in Indian River County for attempted sexual battery and armed burglary in an attack on a woman two years ago. Four women and a man, all students at the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College, were slain last month in three attacks. Three victims were mutilated; one was decapitated, police said. Humphrey and Stephen Michael Bates, a 30-year-old Lakeland short-order cook, have been mentioned publicly as suspects. Bates has been held in the Polk County Jail on $100,500 bail since his Aug. 29 arrest in an unrelated assault. In Colorado, meanwhile, authorities disclosed Thursday that Humphrey was arrested two weeks before the Gainesville killings began on charges of theft and disorderly conduct for failing to pay for $12 worth of gasoline at a convenience store near Ordway, a town about 160 miles southeast of Denver. When he was booked into the county jail, Humphrey began ``hollering, yelling and flipping out,'' Sgt. Allan Turner of the Crowley County sheriff's department said. Humphrey also threatened suicide but didn't threaten anyone else, Turner said.

DOC.HEAD: ``Today'' Drops in Ratings, ``Good Morning America'' Gains
DOC.TEXT: NBC's ``Today,'' which is trying to rebound against ABC's front-running ``Good Morning America,'' was the only network morning show that failed to increase its ratings last week, the A.C. Nielsen Co. said Friday. ``Today'' actually lost sixth-tenths of a ratings point as it came in second to ``Good Morning America'' for the 35th consecutive week, Nielsen said. ``Today,'' which rose to a 3.7 rating two weeks ago when anchor Bryant Gumbel was reporting from the Middle East, slipped to a 3.1 last week. ABC's morning show showed a 10 percent increase in audience, averaging a 4.3 rating, and ``CBS This Morning'' showed a slight increase, getting a 2.5 rating. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. On Monday, the ``Today'' studio will inaugurate a new set. The show's ratings woes began before the departure of co-anchor Jane Pauley and the January appointment of Deborah Norville as her successor. On Tuesday, Norville announced that she is pregnant and expects to give birth in March, but she did not say how long she would be away from the show. Former ``Today'' co-host Joe Garagiola, 64, who rejoined the show as a third co-anchor in June, left the show for four weeks on Aug. 31 to undergo elective surgery for an undisclosed medical problem.

DOC.HEAD: Steroid Use Among Teen-agers Said to be Growing
DOC.TEXT: Teen-agers appear to be using more body-building steroids despite the health risks of the illegal drugs, federal health officials said Friday. What's more, the officials said that coaches, teachers, parents and other adults may subtly be encouraging the trend. The assessment was contained in a report, by the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services, that estimated more than 250,000 adolescents, mostly boys, have used steroids. Health Secretary Louis Sullivan called the finding ``disturbing'' and said he was ``concerned that some adults who are charged with our young people's welfare might be passively accepting or even tacitly approving'' use of the drugs that build up muscles and strength.'' Dick Stickle, executive director of a substance abuse program of the National Federation of State High School Associations, said coaches can appear to condone steroid use with off-the-cuff comments such as, ``Everybody uses steroids now in sports,'' or by telling a young athlete, ``If you were a little larger, a little stronger, you could be a starter next year.'' Sullivan said an interagency task force has been formed to look into new approaches to stemming illegal steroid use. Also, the Food and Drug Administration is conducting an educational campaign targeted at young athletes and their coaches, he said, and the department is launching a public affairs campaign on the issue. In the best-known case of steroid use by an athlete, Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson lost his gold medal in the 1988 Olympics in when he tested positive. He was disqualified and barred from competing for two years. The report by Inspector General Richard Kusserow estimated that 262,000 students in grades 7 through 12 are using or have used steroids, based on a 1989 survey by the National Institute on Drug Abuse. The report estimated 5 percent to 11 percent of teen-age boys use steroids. Among girls, the estimated range was 0.5 percent to 2.5 percent. The report, based on interviews with 30 knowledgeable professionals and 72 current or former steroid users, as well as a review of recent studies, said steroid use among the young appears to be rising. More than half the users questioned said they had started using steroids by age 16; 85 percent said they had started by age 17. All but one said they used injectable steroids. The effects of steroids can be physical as well as psychological. Users exhibit addictive behavior, although it has not been proven that these drugs are habit-forming, the experts said. Other possible psychological effects are increased irritability, violent behavior, depression, mania, psychosis and suicide. Among the physical effects are acne, fluid retention, breast development in males, masculinization in females, reversible sterility in males, increased cholesterol levels and high blood pressure, the report said. Also, because adolescents' bodies are still developing, they are at special risk for some adverse effects, including stunted growth and long-term dependence on steroids, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: More Mail, Radios on the Way to Troops
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon is trying to increase the ``creature comfort'' quotient for troops in the Mideast by lifting weight restrictions on mail and telling service men and women to pack an FM radio. Fighting boredom in the far-flung fields of potential battle could become a major problem for troops deployed in Operation Desert Shield as long as a military stalemate continues. ``There's nothing there but desert _ no women, no liquor, no fun,'' one military officer said of his colleagues' deployment on the front lines of the Saudi Arabian-Kuwait border. So on Friday, the 12-ounce restriction on military mail to APO and FPO addresses in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf was lifted. And an all-points message went out to those units still deploying that the troops should be encouraged to bring a personal portable FM radio now that the Armed Forces radio network has begun broadcasting in Saudi Arabia. Officials also said they were trying to increase shipments of movies, newspapers, and library books. Shipments of films from bases in the United States and Western European will arrive within 48 hours. Boxes of assorted books from military libraries are expected to be in Saudi Arabia within six to eight days, officials said. ``They have a thirst to know what's going on,'' Army spokesman Col. Bill Mulvey said of the troops. ``They want to know not only about the current crisis situation, but also about who's leading in the American League East, or what's going on with the pre-season NFL.'' The military radio and television network known as AFRTS ``has begun broadcasting an FM radio service in Saudi Arabia,'' the Pentagon told commanders. The change in mail distribution became possible because the military postal system in Saudi Arabia has become more organized and ``sufficient airlift capabilities are now in place to handle the increased volume of mail,'' a Pentagon statement said. ``All classes of mail up to the maximum weights allowed will now be accepted,'' the statement said. Those who want to send packages or mail to particular service members should check with his or her unit to determine whether an Army Post Office or Fleet Post Office designation has been established, a spokesman said. It is taking an average of seven days for first class mail to reach Saudi Arabia, the statement said. Tobacco products and U.S. stamps depicting the American flag may be sent, the statement said. Erroneous reports that such products were not allowed have resulted in ``some isolated cases'' in which letters or packages have been returned, the statement said.

The address for people who want to express their support to any member of the Army, Air Force and Marine Corps is: Any Servicemember Operation Desert Shield APO New York 09848-0006
The address for any member in the Navy and Marine Corps is: Any Servicemember Operation Desert Shield FPO New York 09866-0006
Those addresses are not meant for mail to particular service members by name.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Begins Preparing For Pump Removal
DOC.TEXT: NASA workers entered Columbia's rear compartment Friday and began preparing the area for this weekend's removal of a fuel pump that is believed to be the source of an elusive hydrogen leak. The space agency's third attempt to send the shuttle on an astronomy mission was halted Wednesday after hydrogen flooded the compartment. Engineers suspect the fuel is coming from one of three recirculation pumps. Workers planned to remove insulation around the pumps on Saturday and replace a package containing all three pumps on Sunday. A series of tests will follow. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is aiming for a fourth launch attempt early in the week of Sept. 17. Columbia's first countdown was stopped in late May because of leaking hydrogen. The second was halted last week due to communications problems with one of four telescopes inside the cargo bay. The telescopes constitute the $150 million Astro observatory, which will probe ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted from stars, galaxies, a supernova and a comet during Columbia's nine- to 10-day flight.

DOC.HEAD: Rooftop Sniper Holds Off Police in Pittsburgh; No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: A sniper fired 20 random shots from an apartment-house rooftop Friday and held off police, who blocked off streets in the area and evacuated two schools near the University of Pittsburgh campus. No injuries were reported in the stand-off. Residents saw the sniper, wearing an orange hunting cap, sitting on the edge of the 15th-story roof with his legs dangling over the edge. Police sharpshooters took up positions on rooftops nearby, radio station KQV reported. About 50 police officers were on the scene. Students at the grade school and high school at nearby St. Paul's Cathedral were evacuated.

DOC.HEAD: Court Asked to Break Attorney-Client Privilege in Stuart Case
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors trying to crack the troubling case of Charles Stuart, who allegedly shot his pregnant wife and later killed himself, asked the state's highest court Friday to force his lawyer to talk. Suffolk County Assistant District Attorney Thomas Mundy argued before the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court that a grand jury will be deprived of ``potentially relevant information'' if attorney John Dawley is not compelled to testify about his final conversation with Stuart. But attorneys representing the Stuart family argued that the court will be setting a dangerous precedent by tampering with the ages-old attorney-client privilege. Chief Justice Paul Liacos agreed that it would be difficult to make an exception to the attorney-client privilege. Dawley met with Charles Stuart as his attorney on Jan. 3, the day before Stuart drove to Boston's Tobin Bridge and apparently committed suicide. He apparently had learned that his 24-year-old brother, Matthew, had gone to police and implicated him in his wife's murder. Carol Stuart, 30, was shot to death Oct. 23, during what her husband had claimed was a robbery attempt by a lone black gunman after the couple had attended a childbirth class. The Stuarts' prematurely-born son, Christopher, died 17 days later. Public interest in the crime was heightened by a dramatic, tape-recorded telephone conversation between Stuart and an emergency dispatcher who tracked down the Stuarts' location in order to send an ambulance. The crime shocked Bostonians and aggravated racial tensions, particularly after a black man was prominently named as a suspect. The crime's hold on the public imagination grew greater still when it became clear that the prime suspect was Stuart himself. Prosecutors are most interested in learning the extent of Matthew Stuart's involvement in the slaying. In their arguments before the court, prosecutors gave the first details in open court about Matthew Stuart's testimony before the grand jury. Mundy told the court that Matthew Stuart has told the grand jury that he was solicited by his brother to participate in an insurance scam. Matthew testified that he drove his car alongside his brother's the night of the shooting and was only 5 to 6 feet away from him when he was handed a bag of items including the murder weapon, Mundy said. But Matthew testified that he neither saw Carol Stuart inside the car nor noticed that his brother was injured, Mundy said. The grand jury, Mundy said, ``is faced with a question: Was Matthew Stuart a naive thief who was nearsighted or was he a willing participant in murder?'' Mundy argued that the sanctity of the attorney-client privilege is designed to ``ensure the administration of justice'' and asked the court to consider making an exception in the Stuart case to avoid a miscarriage of justice. Nancy Gertner, the attorney representing Matthew Stuart, told the court that overriding the attorney-client privilege would mean that attorneys could no longer be trusted with confidences. ``If Charles Stuart and others had the slightest idea that their conversations would be disclosed down the line, they would never want to talk,'' said Gertner. Attorney Richard Clayman, who represents the rest of the Stuart family, said the attorney-client privilege is ``sacred, fundamental and never waived.'' The court did not say when it will rule.

DOC.HEAD: Nature Parks, Endangered Wildlife on Land Seized in S&L Scandal
With AM-Preserve or Develop-List
DOC.TEXT: The government must strike a delicate balance between its duty to clean up the savings and loan crisis and the need to protect S&L assets that have environmental value, federal officials told a congressional panel Friday. The Resolution Trust Corp., the agency set up last year to take over and dispose of failed thrift institutions, has under its control 1,853 S&L properties believed to have important environmental, historical, recreational or scientific value. The properties have a total value of about $340 million, the agency says. The agency ``must engage in a balancing act between (environmental) concerns and the obligation to resolve the savings and loan crisis at the least cost to the taxpayer,'' said Peter H. Monroe, president of the RTC's oversight board. Monroe appeared as a witness before the House Task Force on the RTC. The panel's chairman, Rep. Bruce F. Vento, D-Minn., accused the Interior Department of delaying its effort to help the RTC evaluate the environmentally sensitive properties. The RTC is charged with protecting taxpayers by getting as much money as it can for the thrift assets it sells. Restrictions against commercial development on land tend to reduce its market value sharply. Some environmental activists see the government's control of those lands as a rare opportunity for promoting conservation. The lands range from natural habitats of endangered wildlife to ``pocket parks'' in cities to condominium developments located near scenic sites. A group of properties, for example, lies in the Balcones Canyonlands, an area west of Austin, Texas, that is home to several endangered songbirds and other species. The 1,853 parcels, many of them situated in Texas, Arizona, California and Florida, are a small proportion of the 36,000 or so S&L properties under the RTC's control _ but they have stirred interest in Congress and the environmental community. ``It's plain old common sense for a landowner to learn the value of a property before it is sold,'' Vento told the hearing. ``Let's make sure the seller is beware, too.'' The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the RTC have drafted an agreement under which the service, part of the Interior Department, would review the RTC's inventory of properties. The service then would recommend conservation restrictions on the use of properties that are considered environmentally sensitive. The agreement was scheduled to be signed by officials from both agencies on Aug. 3, but it was put on hold indefinitely. ``What we don't need with regard to the S&L bailout is more delay,'' Vento said, addressing Interior Department official Scott Sewell, another witness. ``You've been dillydallying with it for the last five weeks.'' Sewell said the agreement has been held up by reviews within the Interior Department, the need for computer software and the fact that ``the information we're dealing with at this point is still not specific.'' ``I know it seems like a snail's pace,'' he said. ``We are proceeding with all due haste to work through the process.'' Rep. Stan Parris of Virginia, the panel's ranking Republican, cautioned that the environmental issue should be kept in perspective. The special properties should be protected, he said, ``but we must be careful to balance that very desirable goal with the primary purpose of the RTC.'' Burdensome requirements on the thrift agency could slow the S&L bailout and scare off potential buyers of assets, Parris said. Some of the properties were commercially developed when they were in private hands, since the laws governing land use are relatively lenient when assets are privately owned. Now that they are under government control and subject to stricter regulations, environmentalists and historic preservationists want to seize the chance to protect them and to attach some conditions to their future sale. ``It's the greatest opportunity of the century to protect important environmental lands,'' Richard Lowerre, a project director at the Texas Center for Policy Studies in Austin, said in an interview. Vento has said he is seeking ``compatible use'' of the RTC properties. Some could be sold to state and local governments, he said, while others could be bought by private developers, with some protective conservation measures included as a condition of sale.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The state Capitol will be closed this weekend for a display of violence and vulgarity: Hollywood has come to Little Rock. Secretary of State Bill McCuen said the Capitol would be off-limits to the public during filming of ``The Brotherhood,'' an adventure starring former football star Brian Bosworth. If all goes well, the filming could be wrapped up by Monday, McCuen said. The secretary of state said he didn't mean to offend anyone by closing the Capitol. On the contrary, he meant to save them from offensive dialogue. ``This is not a G or a PG-13 type of movie,'' he said. ``They don't want to be involved with the public when some of their lines and scenes are being shot that have violence and vulgarity. I agreed to do that and it's no big deal. It's a violent movie and they say things that they don't want people to hear while walking down the halls of the state Capitol.''

Veteran singer Webb Pierce says being elected to the Country Music Hall of Fame would cap his career. Pierce, 69, is among five finalists for this year's induction. Others are Tennessee Ernie Ford, Don Gibson, George Jones and the Louvin Brothers. The inductee will be announced Oct. 8 during the nationally televised Country Music Association awards show. ``It's important to me,'' Pierce said in an interview. ``I want 'em all, all the awards. When I win this one, that'll be all of them.'' Pierce, who underwent abdominal surgery for cancer in April, said he is getting stronger every day. ``I still have a little trouble walking,'' Pierce said. ``I can walk, but I kind of wobble. I take exercise each day. I go over to the bowling alley and walk up and down.'' His biggest hit was ``In the Jailhouse Now'' in 1955. He has been semiretired for several years.

John Sasso, who left as manager of the Dukakis presidential campaign after a flap over his aggressive tactics, pulled a switch on a car rental company that left employees thinking he'd stolen a car. Sasso, renting a car on the island of Nantucket as the Labor Day weekend began, said he was given a key that didn't fit the car he was given. He went behind the counter to find the right keys because nobody was there to help. ``I certainly didn't think I did anything wrong under the circumstances,'' Sasso said. He added that he'd had to wait 25 minutes with two small children and had gotten fed up, leaving his credit card and a note. Hertz workers, though, didn't know him, saw a man leaving with a car they'd rented to someone else, and told police the Ford Tempo was stolen. Police recovered the car at 2 a.m. Saturday, the next morning. ``It was not a major crime, but it was wrong. He annoyed me,'' said Dave Murphy, who runs the Hertz agency. He said he won't press charges. ``I don't want to spend a lot of time with John Sasso about a set of keys.'' Murphy said he did not know it was Sasso who had taken the car until Sasso called him on Saturday. Sasso resigned as Michael Dukakis' campaign manager in September 1987 after it was disclosed he had distributed a videotape showing rival Sen. Joseph Biden Jr., D-Del., had copied speeches by British Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock.

Brigitte Bardot intervened Friday in an Anglo-French conflict over meat prices, condemning French farmers for slaughtering hundreds of imported British sheep. The former actress, a militant campaigner for animal rights, released the text of a letter she had sent to President Francois Mitterrand accusing the farmers of illegal acts of cruelty. She cited incidents Thursday and in late August in which French farmers slaughtered more than 700 British sheep and lambs, burning some alive. She demanded an immediate halt to ``this revolting, insolent and demented waste.'' Farmers protesting lower-priced imported lamb have beaten British truck drivers, hijacked lamb trucks, blocked roads and burned a consignment of sheep. On Friday, more than 200 farmers protested meat imports outside the main slaughterhouses of Bordeaux.

Prince Alexander Karadjordjevic, whose father served as Regent before the royal family was forced to flee Yugoslavia in 1941, was feted by hundreds of supporters Friday on his first visit home in 49 years. He is the first male member of the banished Karadjordjevic dynasty to visit Yugoslavia since the communists assumed power after World War II. Like all the other members of Yugoslavia's former ruling family, the prince is still legally banned from the country on the basis of a 1945 communist law that is still on the books. But hundreds of people greeted him with tumultuous applause when he appeared at Belgrade's National Museum to promote a British biography about his father, Prince Pavle. The prince became Regent after King Alexander was assassinated in 1934 and served until shortly before the family fled the invading Nazis in 1941. Alexander's sister, Elizaveta, was the first member of the Karadjordjevic family to defy the legal ban on coming to Yugoslavia during a visit last year and accompanied him Friday. Alexander, who is now in his 60s, was quoted by the state news agency Tanjug as saying he was delighted to be in his homeland. He plans to stay a week and tour Serbia.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Li Peng Dismissed From Government Economic Post
DOC.TEXT: A little-known political and business figure was named Friday to replace Premier Li Peng as shepherd of China's stumbling economy. It was not immediately known how the loss of the economic post could affect Li, 61, who faced criticism for his strict fiscal policies and his role in the 1989 crackdown on the nation's pro-democracy movement. The China News Service said Li asked to be relieved as minister of the State Commission for Restructuring the Economy so he could concentrate on his duties as premier. Li took charge of the commission in 1988, the same year he became premier. Li remains one of China's top leaders and the main person in charge of government policy on a day-to-day basis. Radio Beijing and China Central Broadcasting said Li's replacement was Chen Jinhua, 61. The China News Service said Chen was a ``longtime leader in economic work'' who had been president of the China National Petrochemical Corp. since 1983 and held several political posts in Shanghai. Li's austerity program has reduced inflation, which peaked at about 40 percent in 1988, but it brought the nation to the brink of recession and forced millions of small factories to close. The program also halted many market-oriented reforms and returned much of the economic decision-making power to the central government. Local and provincial goverments had gained a greater say in economic affairs during the past decade. Li was in the forefront of officials advocating a hard line against last year's student-led pro-democracy efforts, which ended when tanks and riot troops were ordered into Beijing's Tiananmen Square. He was an opponent of former Communist Party General Secretary Zhao Ziyang, who pushed rapid economic reform but was ousted for allegedly supporting the pro-democracy protests. Li spent many years as an engineer in various ministries before being elevated to full membership in the party Central Committee in 1978. In 1987, Li became a member of the power-wielding standing committee of the Politburo. The National People's Congress standing committee, whose 135 members meet between annual sessions of the full congress, concluded an 11-day session Friday. From 1977 to 1979, Chen was a deputy chairman of Shanghai's Revolutionary Committee, which replaced the city government during the tumultuous Cultural Revolution. He was deputy mayor of Shanghai from 1979 to 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev, Troubled at Home, Heads for Summit of Hope
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev carries a bag full of troubles to Helsinki. He's attending a summit full of hope, with the United States and the Soviet Union united in opposition to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. It is the first time they have been on the same side of a global crisis since World War II. But at home, Gorbachev's popularity is plummeting, the Soviet economy is defying predictions it couldn't get worse, and most of the 15 Soviet republics, including Mother Russia, have declared sovereignty or independence from the Communist government that Gorbachev heads. After the summit, Gorbachev is expected to rush back to Moscow to present economic reforms that are likely to strip central authorities of much of their domestic power and largely dismember the state planning apparatus that Josef Stalin assembled at the cost of millions of lives. Despite the tumult on the home front, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze has hailed the Sunday summit in Helsinki as a ``landmark.'' Soviet media are describing it as a new phase in superpower cooperation. History could well be made in Helsinki. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said in an interview Friday that the Soviet Union would be willing to send military forces to the Middle East under a military staff committee that included officers from the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council: the United States, Soviet Union, France, Britain and China. The aim, he said, was not only to help the United States enforce Security Council sanctions against Iraq, but also to impose Soviet controls on any unilateral military actions against Iraq by the United States. The implication is that despite the collapse of the Soviet empire in Eastern Europe and the malaise at home, the Soviet Union retains its superpower status. But that view is not universally held. Andrei Kortunov, a young Soviet scholar at the USA-Canada Institute, publicly classified his nation as a regular rather than a super power last June. His analysis has been embraced by a number of respected American sovietologists. ``The Soviet Union is not still a superpower, at least as pertains to its capability of projecting global power in a low-violence conflict. Of course, it still has vast nuclear arsenals,'' said Marshall Shulman, a Columbia University professor who is visiting Moscow. A senior Western diplomat was more cautious, simply saying, ``It has been a multipower world for quite some time now.'' The diplomat, who spoke on condition that he not be further identified, noted that even the United States generally seeks accord with its allies before exerting military muscle. Bush, at least, in requesting the meeting with Gorbachev, appears inclined not only to acknowledge the Soviet Union as a once and future superpower, but to recognize Gorbachev as the de facto leader of the reform movement in the Soviet Union. Gorbachev faces the threat of eclipse by Boris Yeltsin, who last May 29 was elected to the newly created post of president of the Russian Federation, the largest Soviet republic. The Russian Congress of People's Deputies quickly declared ``sovereignty,'' asserting that its laws take precedence over Soviet laws on Russian territory, and that the Russian _ rather than the central Soviet _ government controlled the republic's vast natural resources. The declaration stopped short of the independence proclaimed earlier by the three Baltic republics, but it paved the way for radical sovereignty decrees by other republics, including the Ukraine. The independence and sovereignty movements promise to transform the shape of the Soviet Union's borders and government structure. Yeltsin is also having his way with economic reforms, beating the Gorbachev team in preparing a radical package to transfer economic decision-making powers away from central authorities to the republics. Yeltsin introduced his reforms to the Russian parliament last Monday, whereas Gorbachev is due to propose his to the national legislature next week, Monday at the earliest. Public pressure appears to have forced Gorbachev to jettison a moderate reform package advocated by his ally, Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, in favor of a more radical version drafted by economist Stanislav Shatalin _ who is also credited with writing the reforms proposed by Yeltsin. Gorbachev's spokesman, Vitaly Ignatenko, said the two programs would be very similar. Widespread consumer shortages, five years into the Gorbachev administration, are fueling public anger against the Soviet leader and his allies. Reformist Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov, who quit the Communist Party in July, renewed calls on Friday for the resignation of Ryzhkov. Gorbachev, who in the West is considered a reformer, is viewed increasingly in the Soviet Union as a moderate, or even conservative. Yeltsin hs overtaken Gorbachev in popularity, according to some polls.

DOC.HEAD: Girlfriend Testifies in Teen-ager's Murder Trial
DOC.TEXT: The 19-year-old son of a state legislator talked for hours about his hatred for his parents only weeks before he shot his mother with a hunting arrow, his girlfriend testified Friday. ``He told me about how his parents had been cruel to him,'' Jennifer Bolstad told the jury in Dodge County Court. Ms. Bolstad, a student at Mount Mary College in Milwaukee, testified in the second day of Chad Goetsch's trial. Goetsch is accused of first degree intentional homicide for fatally shooting his mother, Carolyn, 51, with an arrow. He also is accused of reckless endangerment during a violent struggle with his father, state Rep. Robert Goetsch, seconds after his mother was shot Nov. 8 at their home in the town of Oak Grove. Ms. Bolstad said she spoke to Goetsch on the telephone about his parents at least twice last October. ``He told me that she (his mother) treated him badly, that she would be nice to him and then really mean to him,'' Ms. Bolstad said. Ms. Bolstad said she suggested he get away if he didn't want to be around his parents. She said Goetsch responded that he couldn't escape his parents' control and that he loved them, ``at least his mother.'' District Attorney Kevin Schram reminded Ms. Bolstad that she testified at a preliminary hearing last December that Goetsch told her he couldn't go on with his life unless his parents were dead. She said that testimony was correct.

DOC.HEAD: Three Leftists Plead Guilty to Bombing the U.S. Capitol
DOC.TEXT: Three leftist radicals pleaded guilty Friday to bombing the U.S. Capitol and conspiring to set off explosions at eight locations in a two-year campaign of ``armed propaganda'' to protest government policies. Marilyn J. Buck, Linda S. Evans and Laura J. Whitehorn each pleaded guilty to maliciously damaging the U.S. Capitol by setting off a bomb on Nov. 7, 1983 that blew a hole in the wall outside the Senate chamber. Evans, 43, told U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene that the bomb was exploded to protest the American invasion of Grenada. Five paintings were damaged and the door to Democratic leader Robert Byrd's office was blown off its hinges. The three women also pleaded guilty to conspiring to bomb the Capitol and seven other buildings in Washington and New York between 1983 and 1985 in what Whitehorn called an effort ``to resist and protest the unjust policies of the U.S. government.'' The charges carry a maximum sentence of 15 years in prison plus fines totaling $20,000. Greene scheduled sentencing for Nov. 28. As part of the plea agreement, charges will be dropped against three co-defendants. Whitehorn, 45, also pleaded guilty to possession of equipment to make fake identification documents stemming from an FBI raid in 1985 on a Baltimore apartment she shared with Evans and Buck. That charge carries a five-year sentence. In addition to fake identification documents, authorities also found typewritten bomb-making instructions bearing Evans' fingerprints plus 15 pocket watches similar to the type used to detonate the Capitol bomb. Nine watches were altered to be timing devices, according to a statement of evidence from prosecutors. All eight bombs ``bore marked similarities'' to each other and were triggered by altered pocket watches made by the same manufacturer, the statement said. The group, variously identifying itself as the Armed Resistance Unit, the Revolutionary Fighting Group and the Red Guerrilla Resistance, claimed responsibility for each of the bombings in communiques to news organizations. Evans, Buck and Whitehorn have participated in radical activities since the 1960s when they were members of the Students for a Democratic Society, according to their spokeswoman, Judy Greenspan. None of the eight bombings caused any injuries. After the proceedings were recessed, about 50 supporters stood up in the courtroom and applauded the defendants, who saluted them with raised fists. Outside the courthouse, demonstrators chanted ``Free All Political Prisoners'' as prosecutors held a news conference. But U.S Attorney Jay B. Stephens told reporters that law enforcement agencies ``will not tolerate terrorism to direct the policies of our government.'' Prosecutors said that after the defendants are sentenced, they will drop bombing charges against Susan Rosenberg, Timothy A. Blunk and Alan Berkman. The government had legal problems with those cases because of a Supreme Court decision last May on the issue of double jeopardy, according to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. The three defendants claimed prosecutors could not use evidence that was the basis of earlier convictions to prove they participated in the four Washington bombings. All six defendants, except Whitehorn, are serving lengthy prison terms for possession of explosives or firearms. Buck, 42, is serving a 50-year prison term for participating in a string of armed robberies, including a 1981 holdup of a armored car near Nyack, N.Y., in which two policemen and a guard were killed. She also was convicted of helping convicted murderer Joanne Chesimard escape from a New Jersey prison in 1979. Evans is serving a 40-year prison for illegally purchasing firearms. Rosenberg and Blunk are serving 58-year terms for possessing an arsenal of explosives they were caught loading into a rented storage bin in Cherry Hill, N.J. in 1984. Berkman, who suffers from Hodgkins disease, is serving a 10-year prison term for possession of explosives and munitions authorities found in a garage in Doylestown, Pa., that is also linked to the bombings, authorities said. A seventh defendant in the case, Elizabeth Duke, is a fugitive.

DOC.HEAD: Seattle School Board Approves Plan to Ease Racial Balance Guidelines
DOC.TEXT: The School Board has approved a plan to relax racial balance guidelines despite opposition from civil rights activists who said it would re-segregate schools. School busing was a major issue in last year's city elections, when voters passed an initiative asking the School Board to ban busing to achieve racial balance. The new plan, approved 4-3 Tuesday night, allows 75 percent of a school's racial makeup to consist of any one racial group, including whites. The plan replaces a requirement that no more than 50 percent of a school's enrollment be from one minority group, 70 percent from all minority groups, or 65 percent white. The new plan means a school could be 100 percent minority. For example, enrollment could be 75 percent black and 25 percent Asian. ``The NAACP will do whatever is necessary, including lawsuits, to prevent the re-segregation of Seattle public schools,'' said Larry Steele, president of the Seattle chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Supporters of the plan said it would reduce mandatory busing by allowing more minorities, who are bused in greater numbers than are whites, to attend their neighborhood schools. It would also give whites more school choices. ``I never have and never will favor re-segregating the school district,'' said board member Ken Eastlack, who wrote the proposal. ``All I want is equity. It's interesting that people feel more choice will result in segregation. I don't think that will happen.'' The new plan takes effect immediately but would not allow students to switch schools immediately. An estimated 3,000 students on a waiting list will have a chance of attending their preferred schools this fall after officials review the attendance at each school.

DOC.HEAD: Four Anchormen to Converge on Helsinki Summit
DOC.TEXT: CBS anchorman Dan Rather, in the Middle East since the Persian Gulf crisis began Aug. 2, will help cover the Bush-Gorbachev summit in Helsinki this weekend, then may return home, CBS said Thursday. He will be one of four U.S. network anchormen at the Helsinki summit. The others are Cable News Network's Bernard Shaw, ABC's Peter Jennings, and NBC's Tom Brokaw. Brokaw, who spent a week in Saudi Arabia reporting on the Gulf crisis, will do part of ``NBC Nightly News'' Friday from Moscow as part of the network's preview of the Helsinki summit, NBC News said. Rather, anchoring his newscast for the rest of this week from Saudi Arabia, ``is tentatively scheduled to come home'' after the Helsinki summit, ``barring another serious development in the Gulf,'' CBS spokeswoman Donna Dees said.

DOC.HEAD: Increasing Number of Unmarried Couples Buy Homes Together
DOC.TEXT: More unmarried couples are buying homes together than at any time in the past, according to a survey of major lenders conducted by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. ``Eighty-nine percent of those surveyed reported more `mingles' purchasing homes as compared to five years ago,'' said James W. Nelson, president-elect of the trade association. ``I suspect it's the result of greater social acceptance, on the one hand ... and recognition of the economic benefits both in terms of mortgage interest deductibility'' and home ownership, he told a news conference. Nelson, president of Eberhardt Co. in Minneapolis, added that growth in sales to unmarried couples also is recognition by lenders that many are qualified and capable of handling the financial aspects of buying a home. Nelson also said the Persian Gulf crisis has pushed mortgage interest rates up one-half of a percentage point since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ``This translates into about $40 more per month on a mortgage of $100,000,'' he said, adding that the rate increase and tighter mortgage underwriting will exacerbate affordability problems for many first-time homebuyers. Sixty percent of the 20 mortgage companies in the survey reported more stringent lending standards because of government requirements, economic downturns in some markets and increased loan delinquencies. ``It is likely that mortgage rates will stabilize at currently higher levels over the next few months and, in the short-term, adjustable rate mortgage rates will look more attractive,'' Nelson said. ``However, we expect long-term rates to come back down somewhat ... once the outcome of the Persian Gulf crisis is resolved,'' he continued, adding: ``If the shooting starts, all bets are off.''

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Protest Imported Agricultural Products
DOC.TEXT: Farmers and students opposed to imports of agricultural products fought riot police in provincial cities Friday, police and news reports said. More than 20,000 police and government officials were reportedly mobilized across the country. Police said hundreds of protesters were arrested, but no injuries were reported. Scuffles and violent clashes broke out in the southern opposition stronghold of Kwangju and several other provincial cities when riot police blocked about 6,000 farmers from attending planned rallies. In Kwangju, about 1,500 riot troopers firing volleys of tear gas moved on to Chonnam University, where 3,000 farmers and students gathered, according to Yonhap, the South Korean news agency. About 500 students fought back with firebombs and rocks, Yonhap said. The demonstrators called for an end to imports of agricultural products and urged South Korean farmers to rise up and topple the government of President Roh Tae-woo. The United States and other advocates of free trade have asked South Korea to open its markets wider, reduce subsidies in exports and remove trade barriers. At a cathedral in Chonju, police allowed about 1,000 farmers to hold a peaceful indoor rally. In Andong, about 600 hundreds of farmers supported by radical students staged running protests inde of gasoline

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Meet with South African President
DOC.TEXT: South African President F.W. de Klerk, who this week invited representatives of all races to negotiate a new constitution, will meet with President Bush on Sept. 24, the White House announced Friday. The two leaders are to discuss ``the current negotiating process underway in South Africa and ways it may be encouraged,'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. De Klerk's government has been engaged in negotiations with the African National Congress on power sharing under a government that would do away with the apartheid system of racial separation. A June visit for de Klerk had been set up at Bush's invitation but the South African president canceled it indefinitely. African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela did visit with Bush at the White House in June and addressed a joint session of Congress during a U.S. tour in which he was greeted with accolades everywhere. Mandela, freed this year by de Klerk after 27 years as a political prisoner, has said his group does not object to the Bush-de Klerk meeting, as long as the United States maintains its economic sanctions against South Africa to protest apartheid. The White House announcement follows de Klerk's call for a new constitution and comes against a backdrop of tension stemming from the South African army's involvement in a township shooting that killed 11 people. No South African leader has visited the United States since apartheid was implemented formally in the late 1940s, officials there said. De Klerk recently called South Africa's anti-apartheid course ``irreversible.'' The government opened talks this year with the ANC, the main black opposition group, on halting anti-government violence and removing other obstacles toward negotiations on a new constitution.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Announces Grants to Boost Literacy Programs
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush on Friday honored 11 organizations for their programs to advance literacy and announced grants to the groups totaling $500,000. The grants were made by the non-profit Barbara Bush Foundation for Family Literacy, which has the first lady as its honorary chairman. The recipients included groups that promote reading among the homeless and mobile literacy programs that serve residents of mountainous areas. ``Today may well be the best day I have ever had at the White House,'' Mrs. Bush told a breakfast for honorees. Promoting literacy and reading has been Mrs. Bush's pet cause for many years. The recipients were chosen from among 500 applicants. Grants ranging from $25,000 to $50,000 were given to: _The New Haven Public Schools for Project HELP, which serves the literacy needs of families in a homeless shelter. It works with Yale University, Head Start and Literacy Volunteers and the Private Industry Council. _The Community Action Center of Pullman, Wash., which focuses on victims of child abuse and neglect. _The YWCA of Elgin, Ill., for its Family Literacy Project geared to low-income people with limited English ability. _The Center for Family Resources in Hempstead, N.Y., for its Starting Together program serving urban and rural families. _Whitley County Communities for Children of Williamsburg, Ky., which has a mobile literacy program serving five rural communities in Appalachia. _The Montana Office of Public Instruction for its Family Learning Center, which addresses the needs of Native Americans and welfare mothers and children. _Delmarva Rural Ministries, Inc. of Dover, Del., for its classes serving migrant workers and migrant workers. _Cohn Adult Learning Center for Future Directions, of Nashville, which offers computer instruction in a public housing project. _Lawrence Public Library in Massachusetts, for its Newcomer Family Literacy Project helping immigrants learn to read. _The Honolulu Community Action Program Inc. for its Waianae Family Literacy program for Head Start parents and children from diverse cultures. _Plantation Education Program, Inc., of New Iberia, La., for Project FREE, which uses computer-assisted instruction to teach Cajun and black residents living in bayou subsidized housing. The Barbara Bush Foundation for Family Literacy was founded in 1989 as part of the Community Foundation of Greater Washington, Inc., a non-profit organization. In addition to the grant program, funded through donations, the foundation supports training and professional development for teachers and has published ``First Teachers,'' a family literacy handbook.

DOC.HEAD: First Ladies To Visit In Helsinki
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev will visit over tea, look at old books and view Western art together as their husbands hold their superpower summit in Helsinki, Finland.
