With Finland's first lady, Tellervo Koivisto, the two wives will meet Sunday for coffee, lunch, and tea while President Bush and President Gorbachev are engaged in talks on the Persian Gulf and other matters. Mrs. Gorbachev and Mrs. Bush also will visit a university library. Mrs. Bush has a full schedule beginning with a visit Saturday afternoon to historical Porvoo in the countryside outside Helsinki, aides said. She will be accompanied by Virginia Weinman, wife of the U.S. ambassador to Finland, and Rebecca Matlock, wife of the U.S. ambassador to the Soviet Union. Their plans include a tour of the 14th century Lutheran church in Porvoo, a village of 20,000 people and Finland's second oldest town, founded in 1346. They also will visit the town museum and are likely to take a shopping tour on the town's picturesque cobblestone streets. ``She likes to see a little bit more of the countryside when she travels,'' said Mrs. Bush's press secretary, Anna Perez. Mrs. Bush probably will also have a private dinner with the two ambassadors' wives while the president has a working dinner with aides. On Sunday, Mrs. Koivisto will host Mrs. Gorbachev and Mrs. Bush at the presidential palace for morning coffee. Mrs. Bush and Mrs. Gorbachev then will go to the University of Helsinki Library to help mark its 350th birthday and view the first book ever printed in Finnish. The two first ladies will join their husbands at the palace for lunch, and then drop by the U.S. embassy to view a collection of Western art. Later Sunday afternoon, Mrs. Gorbachev will host a tea at the Soviet Embassy before the wives join their husbands at the send-off press conference that concludes the summit. The weather forecast in Helsinki was chilly and damp, but there is one item Mrs. Bush was not expected to pack in her baggage _ a fur coat. The first lady does not wear furs, considering it not in keeping with her style.

DOC.HEAD: Pontiff Visits AIDS Sufferers
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II, continuing his travels across AIDS-ravaged central Africa, comforted dying patients Friday and assured them ``you are not alone in your ordeal.'' Before arriving in Rwanda on the third stop of his 10-day African trip, the pope visited a hospital in neighboring Burundi for people with AIDS and other terminal illnesses. John Paul appeared moved as he stopped at the bedsides of about 40 men and women at the Prince-Regent Charles Hospital in Bujumbura. Doctors said 85 percent of the patients have acquired immune deficiency syndrome and most are in advanced stages of the disease. The pope patted the heads of the patients, touched their foreheads in the sign of the cross and offered his blessing. One of the patients, a woman in her 40s, was barely conscious while undergoing a blood transfusion. ``I know the moment is difficult,'' John Paul said. ``I think especially of those among you who are afflicted by AIDS, for which there is still no effective cure. ``But I want to tell you, in the name of faith, that you have reason for hope and you are not alone in your ordeal.'' The pope instructed the Vatican undersecretary of state, Archbishop Giovanbatista Re, to make a $10,000 donation to the hospital. The pope has spoken frequently on the problem of AIDS during the trip, which has also taken him to Tanzania. He has said AIDS is both a moral and medical issue but told followers use of condoms is not acceptable to check its spread. The World Health Organization estimates that 5 million people in sub-Saharan Africa have the virus that causes AIDS. In Burundi and Rwanda, two tiny countries in the heart of the central African AIDS belt, health officials estimate up to 40 percent of young urban adults in some areas could be infected by the virus. On his arrival in Kigali after a 45-minute flight, the pope was met by Maj. Gen. Juvenal Habyarimana, who seized power in a military coup in 1973. In a speech to diplomats, the pope said international aid was needed to help Rwanda and other developing countries boost their economies. ``We will not cease repeating that there is one humanity, and that poverty and suffering of a large part of its members cannot be ignored,'' he said. The pope will travel Sunday to Ivory Coast, the final stop on his trip.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Told of Korean Jet Sale
DOC.TEXT: Congress has been notified formally of South Korea's intention to purchase 120 F-A-18 jet fighters and components in a $4.7 billion deal crafted last year, the Pentagon said Friday. The program covers a triple-phased arrangement by which the South Koreans purchase 12 of the aircraft from U.S. production lines, are provided with kits for 36 aircraft that will be assembled in Korea, and have licensing agreements allowing 72 aircraft to be produced in Korea. The agreement had been a matter of dispute for some months in Congress, particularly among members who wanted more of the U.S.-produced aircraft to be included in the deal. But the arrangement also provides for modernizing South Korea's aging air fleet of F-4s and F-5s, and increases its military alignment with the U.S. forces. This may open the way for some of the more than 40,000 U.S. troops based there to return home, another goal for budget-cutters on Capitol Hill. The F-A-18 ``Hornet'' primary contractor is McDonnell-Douglas Corp. of St. Louis, Mo. The deal also includes 24 GE F-404 engines, produced by General Electric of Lynn, Mass.; test and support equipment, software support, spare and repair parts, personnel and technical training and maintenance support. Under the co-assembly and licensing program, commercial contracts will cover the technical assistance, production and assembly line equipment, a Pentagon statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Mayor Calls For Resignation of Soviet Premier
DOC.TEXT: Moscow's radical mayor blamed the central government Friday for shortages of bread and cigarettes in the capital and joined the calls for Soviet Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov to resign, press reports said. Ryzhkov said on Soviet television Friday night that the nation's economic problems were due in part to lack of discipline by workers and disruptive strikes. He said the government would take ``severe measures'' against disruptive workers. Moscow's bread shortage was the result of increased demand by returning vacationers and students, as well as panic-buying, Ryzhkov said, apparently trying to steer the blame away from the government. ``The political clock has speeded up sharply,'' Ryzhkov said. ``We are aware that the national economy is in a very serious situation and tensions are growing all the time.'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called together economic experts earlier Friday to work on combining a radical economic reform plan with the moderate one that Ryzhkov prepared, the Tass news agency reported. Gorbachev is expected to submit a reform plan after the Soviet parliament convenes Monday. The plan will be drafted in large part by Stanislav Shatalin, a reformer who sits on Gorbachev's Presidential Council, apparently bypassing the proposal by Ryzhkov. Reformers such as Russian Federation President Boris N. Yeltsin have been pushing Gorbachev to adopt a more radical plan than Ryzhkov's. Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov, at a session of the Russian parliament, sharply denounced the Soviet government and accused it of trying to retain full control over the country's economic life, Tass said. He called on Ryzhkov, and the rest of the Council of Ministers, or Cabinet, to resign. Popov said pressure for Ryzhkov's resignation was growing across the country and a similar call would be made at the Soviet parliament next week by a radical wing of legislators known as the Inter-Regional Group, Tass reported. During his televised talk, Ryzhkov did not address the calls for his resignation, but vowed to stand by his economic plan. ``If I believe in my decision, I am going to defend it,'' Ryzhkov said. Popov also blasted the Cabinet for barring the Moscow City Council from selling cigarettes at free-market prices. The introduction of commercial prices helped relieve the ``tobacco crisis'' in Moscow in recent days, Tass quoted Popov as saying. The official price of a premium pack of Soviet cigarettes rose this week to 3 rubles, about $4.80, and newspapers reported consumers grumbled about the increase. The old price for a premium pack of cigarettes was about 90 cents. The government later prohibited the increase. Popov said that intervention was a violation of the sovereign rights of the city as a part of Russia and that Moscow intends to disregard the ruling, the independent Interfax news agency quoted him as saying. The Soviet Union has been gripped all summer by the worst shortage of cigarettes in decades. Its causes range from the closure of factories for repairs to a lack of hard currency to buy usual quantities of cigarettes from Bulgaria. Angry smokers have taken to the streets in Moscow, Leningrad and elsewhere, staging strikes and venting their outrage at local officials like Popov, as well as the national government. In recent days, there has also been a shortage of bread in Moscow for the first time in more than 25 years. The press blamed it on the sudden rise in demand when Muscovites returned from their traditional August vacations. Popov said he believes the city needs to set up 500 to 600 small bakeries _ perhaps using the resources of some of the nation's defense plants _ to deal with the shortage, Interfax reported. The City Council suggested that these bakeries be privatized and turned into family enterprises.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Cancel Yoga Class Because of Devil-Worshiping Argument
DOC.TEXT: Yoga is a form of New Age mysticism that can lead to devil worship, says a man who led protests that forced officials to cancel a city-county sponsored yoga class. ``The people who are signed up for the class are just walking into it like cattle to a slaughter,'' said Philip Lawrence. ``Half of yoga is a branch of Eastern mysticism, and it has strong occult influences.'' Lawrence said he is opposing the yoga class as a Christian. He said other people opposing the classes are from Baptist, Lutheran and Church of God congregations. The class, sponsored by the Toccoa-Stephens County Recreation Department, was scheduled to begin Monday. It was canceled Aug. 31 after city and county commissioners received a number of complaints from church members in Toccoa. ``The different commissioners got together on the phone, and the majority decided the class should be canceled,'' Mayor Bill Harris said. ``Some felt that they were under too much pressure.'' Leonard Greenspoon, a Clemson University religion professor, said yoga has become a secularized form of exercise and relaxation. ``There's certainly no necessary connection between yoga and devil worship,'' he said. ``Anybody who's equating Eastern religion with devil worship has made a big mistake.'' Roger Terrell, program director for the recreation department, said he met with yoga teacher Carolyn Davis to make sure the class would involve only simple stretching and relaxation techniques. ``We can't be promoting religion or anything,'' he said. ``It's strictly for health reasons.'' Some of the 26 people who had signed up for the yoga class say they won't let the matter drop. ``This is not the end,'' said Deborah Hartley. ``This is just the beginning as far as I'm concerned.'' She and Katherine Hodges, another would-be yoga student, complained Tuesday to the county commissioners. She said she also plans to fight for the class at the next meetings of city-county commissioners and the recreation board.

DOC.HEAD: Army Readying Anti-Missile Test That Raises Treaty Questions
DOC.TEXT: Army scientists are readying a little-known Star Wars test in the South Pacific that critics say brings the anti-missile program close to violating a 1972 treaty outlawing major missile defenses. Monday morning, a Boeing 767 equipped with a 3-ton infrared sensor is scheduled to depart Boeing Field in Seattle for a two-day trip to Kwajalein Atoll, an Army missile test range in the Pacific. Near the middle of the month _ the Army won't give the exact date for security reasons _ the aircraft will make its first attempt to track a mock warhead on an intercontinental ballistic missile fired from Vandenberg Air Force Base, Calif. The ability to use sensors to track incoming missiles and to distinguish between warheads and decoys is a key element of Star Wars, which the Pentagon hopes will be ready for deployment within a few years. The government has spent about $20 billion on Star Wars since then-President Reagan launched the project in 1983. This month's Kwajalein test will be the start of an ``aggressive, intensive'' series of flight tests for the airborne sensor over the coming 12 months, Col. Gary M. Stewart, who manages the aircraft program at the Army's Strategic Defense Command headquarters at Huntsville, Ala., said in an interview Friday. A key question in the debate over the aircraft, known as the Airborne Optical Adjunct, is whether it could substitute for an anti-ballistic missile radar, which is prohibited by the 1972 ABM Treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union. The Pentagon says the aircraft is purely experimental and will not be deployed as part of a Star Wars system. John Pike, head of space policy at the Federation of American Scientists and a Star Wars critic, said, ``It appears to be the functional equivalent of an ABM radar.'' Pike said the Soviets may be justified in questioning whether the airborne sensor is a treaty violation. ``If we saw the Russians doing this kind of thing, we would be pretty bent out of shape about it, and if the Russians were giving the explanation we are, we wouldn't believe them,'' Pike said. Stewart said the Army is certain there is no treaty violation. ``We are totally treaty-compliant,'' he said. ``There are no open issues'' to debate. The Army says the airborne sensor is not a prototype for an anti-missile sensor system. It also argues that the aircraft could not substitute for an ABM radar because of technical limitations in its infrared sensor and its on-board computers. The aircraft's first flight was May 11, when it began a series of tests to observe stars and track satellites. Stewart said those tests, which were completed Aug. 28, went smoothly and set the stage for the missile-tracking test at Kwajalein.

DOC.HEAD: New Democrats Win Majority in Ontario Election
DOC.TEXT: The New Democratic Party ended a five-year Liberal Party rule in Ontario and gained its first legislative majority in elections in Canada's most populous province. The NDP stunned the Liberals by taking 74 of the 130 seats in the legislature, knocking off Premier David Peterson and prominent Cabinet members. ``We have an obligation to govern and provide people with leadership . . . this was not a sneak attack. It was an election, '' said NDP leader Bob Rae, who had an easy victory in his Toronto district of York South in the Thursday elections. The Yukon territory has the only other government led by the New Democratic Party, which supports a socialist platform. Ontario, which has about 6 million voters, has been ruled by the Liberals since 1985. Peterson was defeated by New Democrat challenger Marion Boyd, who runs a women's shelter in the district of London Center. Conservative leader Mike Harris held onto one of the few northern Ontario seats the NDP did not seize. The Liberals retained some pockets of support in eastern Ontario. Before the election, the Liberals held 93 seats; the New Democrats 18, and the Conservatives 17. Two seats were vacant. The Liberals now control four provinces. The national Parliament in Ottawa is dominated by the Conservatives. Public opinion polls released in the final week of the campaign suggested a dramatic shift away from the Liberals in Ontario. Rae made the Liberal government's integrity a main campaign issue, and the Liberals focused on constitutional reform.

DOC.HEAD: Tandy, Cronyn Are Among National Medal of Arts Winners
DOC.TEXT: Actress Jessica Tandy and her husband, actor Hume Cronyn, will be awarded the National Medal of Arts next week, along with 11 other people and a corporation, the White House said Friday. Blues guitarist B.B. King, opera singer Beverly Sills, painter Jasper Johns and choreographer Merce Cunningham are among those who are to receive the medal from President Bush at a luncheon Monday. The medal, established in 1984, is intended to honor those who have encouraged the arts and offered inspiration to others through distinguished achievement, support or patronage. The other recipients named Friday were: George Francis Abbott, actor and director, Forestville, N.Y. David Lloyd Kreeger, patron, Washington, D.C. Jacob Lawrence, painter, Seattle. Harris and Carroll Masterson, patrons, Houston. Ian McHarg, landscape architect, Unionville, Pa. Southwestern Bell Corp., corporate patron, St. Louis.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th item to CORRECT Parks' age to 75
DOC.TEXT: Bert Parks, fired by the Miss America Pageant in 1980 for being too old, got a standing ovation from this year's crowd when he was introduced during preliminary competition. Gary Collins, who has been co-host of the pageant for nine years, introduced Parks on Thursday. Parks, 75, stood and waved from his seat next to pageant director Leonard Horn, prompting a 25-second standing ovation. ``Every night, I feel that gentleman is here somewhere looking over my shoulder. Parks was invited back to sing his trademark ``There She Is'' to 26 former Miss Americas during the nati,'' Collins saidonally televised finals Saturday night. However, Collins will serenade the new Miss America with the pageant standard as she walks down the runway.

DOC.HEAD: Taxpayer Advocates Face Off With Western Mining Interests Over Proposed Bill
DOC.TEXT: A 118-year-old federal mining law being considered for an overhaul by Congress was criticized Thursday as a taxpayer giveaway to business. Mining interests defended it, however, as necessary to the discovery of new mineral resources. ``The law is obsolete,'' consumer advocate Ralph Nader told a House subcommittee. ``It shows disrespect for taxpayer assets.'' He called it a ``giveaway program.'' Representing the miner's point of view, Donald Fife, a geologist and chairman of the National Inholders Advisory Board, said ``a way of life for hundreds of thousands of citizens and a national asset for America would be destroyed by imprudent changes.'' An inholder is a property owner whose land is surrounded by government land. Cy Jamison, director of the Interior Department's Bureau of Land Management, acknowledged that parts of the law need changing, but said that in general it ``has worked well as an efficient and predictable basis for one of the world's most successful hard rock mining industries.'' The three men were among 41 witnesses presenting opinions about a bill introduced by Rep. Nick Rahall, D-W.Va., that would increase fees to the government from prospecting for minerals on federal land and make other changes. Rahall is chairman of the House Interior subcommittee on mining and natural resources. An even more extensive bill, introduced by Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., is pending in the Senate. However, congressional aides say work on the legislation will not be completed in either body this session. The 1872 law, frankly aimed at promoting mining, governs the extraction on public lands of minerals such as gold, silver, copper, lead and oil shale _ just about anything valuable except coal, natural gas and liquid petroleum, resources that fall under other laws and on which the government gets production royalties. The federal government is a major landholder throughout the West, in some states owning a majority of all land. When Rahall introduced his bill, he said he was trying to modernize ``some of the more archaic provisions of the law that thwart efficient mineral exploration and development.'' The proposed changes pit environmentalists and taxpayer interest groups against the mining industry. Under the law, anyone may prospect and file a claim. The claim gives the prospector exclusive rights to prospect and mine. To maintain the claim, the holder must perform $100 worth of work every year _ a figure unchanged since 1872. Miners who can show that they have found valuable minerals and have spent at least $500 on the claim may also _ but are not required to _ acquire title to the mine land by paying the government $2.50 or $5 per acre. The federal government has sold 3.2 million acres in this way since the law's enactment. Once the title is granted, the miner owns the land outright, and there is no requirement that a mine be worked. The General Accounting Office, which does investigations for Congress, found that 20 properties passing into private ownership since 1970 were estimated in 1988 to be worth between $13.8 million and $47.9 million. The federal government received less than $4,500 for the titles. Last week, the GAO reported that many holders were living rent-free on claims while participating in unauthorized activities, like storage of toxic chemicals and marijuana cultivation. Rahall's bill would require, among other things, that claim holders pay rent to the government each year of $1.50 per acre _ $5 after the filing of a mining plan. Existing claims _ some have been outstanding for decades _ would have to be converted to ownership or abandoned within three years. After mining is finished, the miner would have to restore the land.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Shipping Self-Stick Stamps to Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Self-adhesive stamps that don't curl and stick together in hot, humid weather are being shipped to the troops in the Persian Gulf, the U.S. Postal Service announced Friday. Some 400,000 of the 25-cent stamps are being dispatched to the U.S. forces there. The stamps, which have an eagle and shield insignia, were introduced last fall on a test basis. They are peeled off a backing sheet and can be applied to a letter without moisture. The stamps are sold in sheets of 16. They cost $4.50 per sheet in this country because of higher production costs, but will be sold at face value of $4.00 per sheet for the servicemen and women in the Gulf area, officials said. Officials said the stamps should be available by the middle of next week.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Must Pay Gator Bite Victim; Should Have Warned Him, Judge Says
DOC.TEXT: A man whose arm was bitten off by an alligator in a national forest has been awarded $772,870 in damages in his lawsuit against the federal government. U.S. District Judge Robert E. Varner of Montgomery ordered the Forest Service to pay the money to Kermit H. George Jr. of Florala. George's arm was bitten of by a 500-pound, 11{-foot alligator on July 26, 1986, while he was swimming in the Conecuh National Forest, not far from his home near the Florida-Alabama line. In a ruling released Thursday, the judge awarded $655,200 for George's pain and suffering. He was awarded $117,670 for medical needs and other damages. The decision followed an April 30 ruling in which Varner found that the Forest Service had failed to place signs warning of danger despite having received complaints about alligators in the national forest. He rejected government claims that George encouraged the attack by allowing his dog to run unleashed into the pond in violation of national forest rules. The judge acknowledged that alligators ``enjoy dog meat,'' but added that they ``are not discriminatory in their tastes and are well known to dine on whatever is convenient.'' George, who was 42 at the time, was an experienced electronics engineer who also did land surveying and construction consulting part time. He had been riding his bicycle and had stopped at a roped-off swimming area to cool off. He was in chest-deep water when he was attacked.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Two Juries for Next Bensonhurst Trial
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the Bensonhurst racial murder case ruled Friday that the two white defendants should stand trial together but with separate juries deciding their fates. Prosecutors wanted John Vento, 21, and Charles Stressler, 22, tried before a single panel, arguing that the cases were similar enough and would save time and money if tried before a single panel. Stressler's lawyer, Jacob B. Evseroff, asked Justice Thaddeus Owens of the trial-level state Supreme Court for two juries, arguing that Vento's earlier conviction in the case might prejudice the panel against Stressler. Owens overruled assistant District Attorney Douglas Nadjari and scheduled jury selection on Stressler's case for Sept. 17 and on Sept. 24 for Vento. Vento was acquitted in July of one second-degree murder charge in the case, but the jury deadlocked on a second murder count and a riot charge. He will be retried on those two charges and an added, second-degree manslaughter count. Vento was convicted on two counts of unlawful imprisonment and four counts of menacing and is serving a sentence of two and two-thirds to eight years. Stressler faces trial on numerous counts, including second-degree murder, first- and second-degree manslaughter, assault, riot and other crimes. Both face 25 years to life if convicted of murder. Vento and Stressler are charged in the Aug. 23, 1989, racially motivated slaying of Yusuf Hawkins, 16, who was fatally shot when he and three friends were attacked by a white mob in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst district. Two other whites accused of participating in the killing, Joseph Fama and Keith Mondello, were tried together before separate juries, convicted and are in jail. Fama, who fired the gun, was found guilty of second-degree murder and other crimes. Mondello, the ringleader, was acquitted of murder, but convicted of several lesser crimes, including riot and unlawful imprisonment. Four other young white men are to stand trial later.

DOC.HEAD: Precede SAUDI ARABIA
Kuwait's Ousted Rulers Pledge $5 Billion to Anti-Iraq Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Kuwaiti rulers pledging $5 billion dollars. No picksup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Finances, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait's ousted royal rulers pledged $5 billion Friday to support the U.S.-led campaign against Iraq, urging the United States to set a deadline for ending negotiations with Saddam Hussein. ``Kuwaitis inside Kuwait are living a nightmare,'' said Yahya al Sumait, the designated spokesman for the ousted royal family. He said peaceful measures were unlikely to resolve the crisis. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the United States would not ``foreclose any actions, but we are not going to put any deadline there.'' Emir Jabar al-Sabah offered the $5 billion to Baker at a meeting in Taif, Saudi Arabia, where the monarch has taken refuge. Half the money would help defray the $6 billion the United States anticipates spending on its military defense of the Saudi oilfields by year's end. The other half would go to countries such as Turkey and Egypt, which are suffering economic hardships because of the United Nations embargo of Iraq. Also Friday, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady won a pledges from Japan and South Korea to increase their support for the operation. However, no specifics were discussed. Baker, here for talks with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, said he was pleased with the Kuwaiti offer, which followed an unspecified pledge Thursday night of several billion dollars from King Fahd of Saudi Arabia. ``Their attitude was very, very forthcoming,'' Baker said of the Kuwaitis, whose rule of nearly 250 years was swept aside in Iraq's lightning Aug. 2 invasion of the Persian Gulf oil state. Baker also said Sheik Zayid bin Sultan al Nahyan, president of the United Arab Emirates, took ``a very positive and constructive attitude'' when the aid issue was raised at a meeting Friday in sun-baked Abu Dhabi. However, Baker told reporters he didn't receive ``a final number'' from the United Arab Emirates, a federation of seven emirates, which also is protected by U.S. warplanes. The Kuwaitis took an especially tough line toward Iraq, which seized the oil-rich country in a bitter dispute that challenges Kuwait's right to survive as a nation. Al Sumait, the Kuwaiti spokesman, said a deadline should be set for a negotiated settlement after which military action may be needed to expel the Iraqi invaders. ``We don't want to speak of any military action for the time being,'' he said. ``Knowing this man (Saddam) and knowing his actions and his intentions, I don't believe that peaceful actions will end in any result.'' Asked when the deadline should be imposed, al Sumait said: ``If it were up to me, I would like to see it tomorrow.'' Earlier Friday, Baker went to the Saudi desert to visit a hanger built to resist a chemical weapons attack and house part of the U.S. war machine. ``We have weapons, we have guns, we have our crew chiefs, we are ready to go,'' Lt. Col. Tommy Crawford, 41, of Roswell, N.M., said as he stood in front of the camouflaged F111 fighter plane that bombed Libya in 1986. The plane is being prepared to attack Baghdad should the Persian Gulf crisis come to that. Alongside was another version of the F111, equipped with jamming devices, from Home Air Force Base, Idaho. The location of the base is a matter of national security and reporters accompanying Baker were told to say only that it is somewhere in western Saudi Arabia. From the distance, the hangar looks somewhat like a sand dune, giving no hint of the firepower inside.

DOC.HEAD: No Charges for 65 Arrested in Store Melee
DOC.TEXT: Charges will be dropped against 65 Haitians arrested when riot police used nightsticks to disperse protesters demonstrating against a clothing store, the state attorney's office said Friday. ``The disputed facts and claims of self-defense make it impossible to prove a criminal charge against anyone beyond and to the exclusion of a reasonable doubt,'' Assistant State Attorney Jerald Bagley wrote in a memo. Charges also will be dropped against four other Haitians arrested outside the Rapid Transit Factory Outlet a week earlier, after a fight between a Haitian customer and the son of the store's owner. ``By dropping the charges, we are getting one step closer to reuniting the community,'' said Philippe Brutus, an attorney for several of those arrested. ``To prosecute would have added salt to the wounds.'' Haitians long have claimed they are discriminated against in immigration policy because their political asylum requests routinely are rejected and boatloads of refugees intercepted by the Coast Guard are returned to Haiti. Store owner Luis Reyes said State Attorney Janet Reno told him of the decision not to prosecute anyone in a telephone call Tuesday. The controversy began with a June 29 fistfight at the store between customer Abner Alezi and Joe Reyes, the 16-year-old son of the owner, Luis Reyes. After police arrested Alezi and three others on trespassing charges, 200 demonstrators clustered around the store in a six-hour standoff. More than 500 demonstrators showed up at the store the next day. On July 5, as television cameras rolled during a third protest, police beat several demonstrators and arrested 65 people to disperse the crowd that refused to leave the shopping center in Miami's Little Haiti neighborhood.

DOC.HEAD: Britain's Most Popular Historian, A.J.P. Taylor, Dead at 84
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Percivale, graf 17, is correct
DOC.TEXT: A.J.P. Taylor, Britain's most popular historian, died Friday after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. He was 84. Taylor, who pundits said was a historian who saw history as more muddle than ideology, wrote at least 30 books of history and biography. Taylor, given to humorous expressions and a bow tie, gained audiences of millions through plain-spoken journalism and riveting television lectures on the Russian Revolution and other modern conflicts. He often stood before the camera without notes or teleprompter, talking nonstop for up to an hour. Taylor's history stressed the importance of what he called ``the irrational, the unpredictable and the unique,'' and said his historical philosophy was ``things happen because they happen.'' Said Michael Foot, former leader of the opposition Labor Party, ``No one ever knew better how to spur the excitement of history.'' Taylor's study of history in a 60-year career convinced him that events are often shaped by accident. His argument that Adolf Hitler was an opportunist who did not plan World War II but blundered into it caused international controversy. Other historians denounced Taylor's stand, put forward in his 1961 book, ``The Origins of the Second World War,'' but Taylor said a historian must write without preconceptions and on the basis of events as they happened. ``I set out with the firm conviction inherited from my pre-war years, that Hitler planned the war,'' Taylor wrote later. ``I discovered, or thought I discovered, that Hitler, though no doubt resolved to make Germany a world power, had no clear-cut plan how to do it and moved forward with the changing situation. Some critics were shocked by this and attributed to me all kinds of wickedness _ apologizing for Hitler or justifying the later appeasement of Soviet Russia. ``I had no such aims. My historian's conscience simply carried me in an unexpected direction. I do not think any historian is worth his salt who has not had a similar experience.'' Taylor participated in events as well as writing about them. A lifelong radical, he was briefly a Communist Party member in 1926 but then joined the Labor Party. He marched for the campaign for nuclear disarmament. In his 1983 autobiography, ``A Personal History,'' he defined his politics as ``extreme views weakly held.'' His most enduring book is ``English History 1914-1945'' in the Oxford History of England series. Taylor put in his 600-page account often curious footnotes describing actors on the political stage, including: ``King George V, 1865-1936, second son of Edward VII: married Princess Mary of Teck, 1893; king, 1910-36; changed name of royal family from Saxe-Coburg to Windsor, 1917; his trousers were creased at the sides, not front and back.'' Taylor wrote that the abdication of King Edward VIII in 1936 was ``an event of no historical importance'' and described Sir Winston Churchill as the ``savior of his country, the first Englishman to be so hailed since Alfred the Great,'' the Anglo-Saxon ruler who died 1,000 years ago. Historian David Marquand said Taylor's English history was ``a story of muddle, folly and incompetence in high places, redeemed only by the patience, courage and decency of ordinary people.'' Alan John Percivale Taylor was born March 25, 1906, in Birkdale, Lancashire, the son of a cotton manufacturer. He studied at Oxford University and became a lecturer there in international history and modern and English history. Taylor's lively skill in turning history books into bestsellers won the favor of Canadian newspaper magnate Lord Beaverbrook, who gave him a platform in his mass-circulation Sunday Express. That and the popularity of Taylor's books, such as ``Struggle for Mastery in Europe,'' aroused the antipathy of academics, particularly J.C. Masterman, warden of New College, Oxford. In the 1950s, Masterman and others blocked Taylor from receiving an Oxford Chair of Modern History and then prevented him from becoming Regius Professor of Modern History at Oxford. Taylor is survived by four sons and two daughters from two marriages, and by his third wife, Hungarian historian Eva Haraszti. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Roundups Net Almost 90 Americans, US Says
With AM-Gulf-Americans
DOC.TEXT: While allowing American women and children to leave, Iraqi authorities are continuing to round up American men and now have almost 90 in detention, the State Department said Friday. Spokesman Mark Dillen said the latest addition to the list was an American man picked up Thursday in Kuwait with his non-American wife. He was subsequently taken to Baghdad. ``We have not been told where our citizens have been taken, and we have not been granted, with a small number of exceptions to the contrary, any consular access,'' Dillen said. Many of the Americans are believed to have been taken to military or industrial installations as ``human shields'' to deter against a potential American military attack on Iraq. Some 165 Americans, virtually all women and children, flew out of Kuwait on Friday and an additional evacuation is scheduled for Saturday. After the Saturday charter, the number of stranded Americans in Iraq and Kuwait will have fallen below 2,200, U.S. officials estimate. Dillen said the Iraqis have provided no additional information about an American who was shot by an Iraqi soldier earlier this week while trying to evade capture, the first incident of its kind since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iraqi authorities told U.S. envoys on Thursday the man was not wounded seriously and was expected to be released shortly from a hospital.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Blast on Air Base Kills One, Leaves One Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf with nine grafs to UPDATE with no evacuations ordered, background on Titan 4
DOC.TEXT: A Titan 4 missile blew up at a rocket test site Friday, killing one person, leaving one missing and sending up a huge mushroom cloud over the desert, authorities said. The Titan 4 booster rocket exploded at the testing laboratory at about 10:45 a.m., said Staff Sgt. Thomas Morgan. The blast left one person dead and one missing, said Lt. Col. Rick Oborn, a spokesman at the Pentagon. Oborn said an initial report from the scene indicated that the blast was due to the explosion of ``one of the stages of a Titan missile booster.'' The spokesman said one of the rocket's stages was being moved, was somehow dislodged or dropped, and exploded upon impact. ``It appears to have been one of the solid fuel sections'' of the booster, Oborn said. The resulting plume was moving away from populated areas at an altitude that posed no immediate threat to residents, Morgan said. ``There was a big cloud of smoke. It was really bright,'' said Roberta Martinson, clerk at a convenience store in Boron. Base officials contacted the California Highway Patrol, which closed a 30-mile stretch of Highway 58. The road, which runs across the north side of the base, was reopened a short time later. There were no evacuations of the area, 70 miles northeast of Los Angeles, said Capt. Chris Angelo of the Kern County Fire Department's Boron station. ``It was high enough that we felt it wouldn't come down,'' Angelo said. Titan 4s, built by Martin Marietta Corp., are considered the Air Force's primary booster for launching its heavy payloads into space. The second Titan 4 built, worth $173 million, was launched June 8 from Cape Canaveral, Fla., carrying a secret surveillance satellite into orbit. The first was launched on June 14, 1989, boosting what analysts said was either a missile-warning satellite or an electronic eavesdropping satellite. Ten launches had been planned during 1990-91, but six were postponed because of delays in preparing launch sites and taking delivery of the rockets. As of June, the Air Force said it planned two more Titan 4 launches this year. The Pentagon also has said it plans to launch 10 Titan 4s annually by 1995. The Air Force initially planned to build only 10 Titan 4s to complement the space shuttle as a way to launch heavy payloads. But the 1986 explosion that destroyed the shuttle Challenger and killed seven crew members prompted the Pentagon to decide to obtain many more. The shuttle can put a 52,000-pound payload into orbit. The Titan 4, which stands 20 stories tall, can lift a 39,000-pound cargo into low Earth orbit or a 10,000-pound payload to a fixed orbit 22,300 miles high. As of June, the Air Force had let contracts for construction of 41 Titan 4s, and had funds available for nine more. The service planned to procure 100 Titan 4s by the year 2000.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt's Foreign Ministers Suffers Minor Injuries in Car Accident
With AM-Gulf-Baker
DOC.TEXT: Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid failed to show up Friday at Cairo International Airport to greet Secretary of State James Baker because of a car accident. Abdel-Meguid was briefly hospitalized for treatment of minor ear and shoulder injuries caused by the explosion of a tire of the car that was transporting him from the Mediterranean resort of Alexandria to Cairo. He was set to meet with Baker later Friday in Cairo.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say They've Caught `Sexual Sadist' Who Killed 4 Women
DOC.TEXT: Police said Friday they arrested a man they believe is the ``sexual sadist'' who raped eight women, killing four of them, in a series of attacks that terrorized Moscow's northern neighborhoods. Deputy Police Chief Maj. Gen. A. Bugayev told the Soviet evening television news program ``Vremya'' the man was captured after being identified by a woman who survived an attack. Bugayev refused to identify the suspect, but said he had a long criminal record, including six previous convictions, and lived in Moscow after being recently released from prison. The Moscow City Council had offered a reward of 10,000 rubles _ about $16,000 _ for help in apprehending the man who stalked the Timiryazevsky district of northern Moscow since July 13, the newspaper Moskovskaya Pravda reported. Police said the killer would surprise his victims by jumping from behind bushes brandishing a knife. Four of the rape victims were stabbed to death. It was not disclosed how the four survivors managed to escape. ``He was a sexual sadist. He never stole anything,'' Bugayev said. ``He left all their jewelry and only removed rings from some of them.''

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Meets Iraqi Ambassador, Calls For Diplomatic Initiative
With AM-Gulf-Americans Bjt
LaserPhoto WX16
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson met the Iraqi ambassador Friday and said the stage was set for an ``airlift of significant proportions'' of American citizens from Iraq and occupied Kuwait. In addition, Jackson urged the United States to honor humanitarian requests that milk and food for Iraqi children be exempted from economic sanctions, and he called for more communication with Baghdad. ``If the diplomatic initiative now begins to match the military initiative, just maybe we can be spared of the ugliest scenario,'' Jackson said. ``We must give honorable peace every possible chance,'' said the civil rights activist and former Democratic presidential contender. Jackson acknowledged after an 80-minute meeting with Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat that he had received no promises that American men could join women and children now being allowed to return home. American and other Western men are being seized by Iraqi authorities and moved to strategic installations to discourage military attacks. Jackson met Iraq's President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad last week and won his approval to escort home 47 American hostages. ``What was a trickle is now beginning to look like an airlift of significant proportions,'' he said. A U.S.-chartered Iraqi airliner Friday carried 165 Americans stranded in Kuwait to Amman, Jordan. State Department spokesman Mark Dillen said a second flight of Americans will reach Amman from Kuwait on Saturday, and that additional charters are being planned. Asked if Iraq would allow the flights to continue, Jackson said, ``That was the impression. I didn't get the impression there was `a' flight.'' Al-Mashat said Iraq had taken the initiative to ``show the world our good will,'' but complained that the United States had failed to reciprocate with a similar act to ease tensions.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois GOPers Criticize National GOP Fund-Raising Plan
DOC.TEXT: Republican U.S. Senate candidate Lynn Martin is willing to dip into her campaign funds to reimburse people confused by a national GOP group's fund-raising appeal, her campaign says. Martin, a five-term House member who is challenging Democratic Sen. Paul Simon, joined other top Illinois Republicans in questioning a recent mailing of $25 ``checks'' by the National Republican Senatorial Committee. The committee helps elect Republicans to the Senate. Cashing one of the checks authorizes the committee to withdraw $12.50 a month from the recipient's checking account. Fine print on the back of each check says the person endorsing it also is authorizing the automatic electronic transfer of funds. The fund-raising letter was mailed to 700,000 people nationwide. Martin campaign spokeswoman Kathy Lydon said Thursday that Martin sent the GOP committee a letter encouraging it to use a larger disclaimer and to live up to its pledge of a money-back guarantee to dissatisfied donors. Ms. Lydon said the Martin campaign fund would reimburse anyone who does not quickly obtain a refund sought from the national senatorial committee. GOP gubernatorial candidate Jim Edgar said he disagreed with the way the committee solicited funds and said it should have made a more direct appeal for contributions. Republican Gov. James R. Thompson also criticized the letter, saying: ``If you want to ask people for money, simply ask them for money.'' Wendy Burnley, a spokeswoman for the Republican senatorial committee in Washington, defended the appeal for funds as ``fairly straightforward.''
DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Poll Gives Sen. Johnston 48 Percent Support
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Sen. Bennett Johnston was supported by 48 percent of those surveyed on Louisiana's U.S. Senate race, just shy of the 50 percent share needed to avoid a runoff after the Oct. 6 primary. The survey found maverick Republican David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader, was supported by 28 percent and state Sen. Ben Bagert, the GOP's endorsed candidate, by 11 percent. Thirteen percent were undecided. The telephone poll of 823 registered voters was conducted Sunday through Wednesday by Mason-Dixon Opinion Research of Columbia, Md., for Gannett News Service and a consortium of television stations. The margin of error was plus or minus 3.5 percentage points. Among white voters, Duke was supported by 37 percent of those surveyed, compared to 36 percent for Johnston and 14 percent for Bagert. Four out of every five black voters favored Johnston, according to the poll. J. Brad Coker, president of Mason-Dixon, said Duke's support had risen from a May poll when he was supported by 21 percent of those surveyed. ``The conventional wisdom has been that Duke has started to slip, but he is up to 28 percent now,'' Coker said. ``I don't know if people are necessarily voting for him or voting for him to show their discontent.''

Less than two days after recapturing his party's nomination, Republican Gov. Bob Martinez launched a television commercial tweaking his Democratic rival for retiring from the U.S. Senate. ``Bob Martinez never quits and walks away,'' the ad says, a reference to Lawton Chiles' decision in 1987 not to seek re-election to the Senate. Julie Fletcher, a spokeswoman for the Chiles campaign, said Martinez was picking up on a negative theme that backfired on U.S. Rep. Bill Nelson in his attempt to defeat Chiles in the Democratic primary. ``I think it's also (a) not-so-thinly veiled slap at Lawton for walking away from the Senate,'' she said. The 30-second commercial, touting Martinez as offering ``leadership you can count on,'' debuted statewide Thursday. It portrays the governor as a fighter and leader who can be counted on, although it acknowledges that he hasn't won all his fights. ``To the extent his endurance and his being a fighter contrasts favorably with Lawton having quit the Senate, that's a plus, but not the purpose of the ad,'' said J.M. ``Mac'' Stipanovich, campaign manager for Martinez.
DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Pell Widening Lead Over Schneider in RI Senate Race
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell leads his GOP challenger, Rep. Claudine Schneider, by 12 percentage points, according to a survey of likely voters in Rhode Island's U.S. Senate race. The survey by Alpha Research Associates showed Pell leading Ms. Schneider 52 percent to 40 percent, with 6 percent unsure. Both had picked up support since an Alpha poll in May, when Pell led Schneider 49 percent to 38 percent. The latest random survey of 511 likely general-election voters, released Thursday, was conducted by telephone Aug. 22-29 and had a margin of error of 4 percentage points. Schneider's camp said it was encouraged that Pell's lead wasn't larger, given his long tenure in Congress. ``He is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee and has a high profile in this (Middle East) crisis, and barely at 50 percent is a good sign,'' said Schneider campaign spokesman Robert Rendine. Pell campaign spokesman Richard Gureghian said the survey was conducted before Pell's trip to the Middle East and he stressed that Schneider herself was an incumbent member of Congress. ``This is an incumbent senator running against a congresswoman of 10 years with statewide recognition,'' Gureghian said.

DOC.HEAD: Engineer Who Helped Develop Radar Dies
DOC.TEXT: Edward Bowles, an electrical engineer and microwave specialist who played a key role in spurring Allied development of radar technology in World War II, has died at age 92. Bowles, who died Wednesday, had suffered from Parkinson's diease and a series of strokes, his family said. During the war, Bowles worked as a consultant to Secretary of War Henry Stimson and became a liaison between Washington and radar scientists working at the Radiation Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Bowles, who specialized in microwave technology at MIT, set up a laboratory at Langley Field, Va., where Army Air Corps bombers were equipped with MIT-developed radar. British scientists were first to develop radar, based on the theories of James Clerk Maxwell, a British mathematician and physicist, who predicted the existence of electromagnetic waves that travel at the speed of light. In 1935, the British has developed pulse techniques to locate aircraft up to 17 miles away. By 1940, England's ground-based radar stations were a decisive element in winning the Battle of Britain. But in 1944, Germany began attacking London with its jet-powered ``buzz bombs'' _ the first cruise missile _ and the British asked for U.S. help. Langley had developed ground-based systems that could ``track an airplane or buzz bomb by radar, plot its course and then tell the guns where to point and shoot, in order to have the best chance of hitting the target,'' said Albert Hill, 80, a former Radiation Lab scientist and MIT professor. Bowles then bypassed regulations that would have delayed the shipment of necessary equipment. ``We were loading the requisite materials on ships the next morning,'' Bowles recalled in an interview with the Washington University Magazine a decade ago. ``The result was that thereafter we destroyed above 90 percent of the buzz bombs.'' A native of Westphalia, Mo., Bowles received his bachelor's degree from Washington University in St. Louis and a master's from MIT, where he began teaching in 1921. Bowles pioneered the development of a method for maintaining a precise radio frequency, using a tuning fork. He began a division of electrical communications at MIT in the mid-1920s. In 1945, he was awarded the Distinguished Service Medal for his wartime service, an honor usually reserved for military personnel.

DOC.HEAD: Japan, South Korea Promise to Help Pay for Military Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Kuwait saying it will give $5 billion to Mideast military campaign; U.S. officials saying Japan is being asked for more than $2 billion; comments from administration officials. Edits throughout. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Japan and South Korea joined Kuwait on Friday in pledging to contribute to the massive costs of the economic and military campaign in the Persian Gulf. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and Secretary of State James A. Baker III solicited the promises on separate global fund-raising expeditions. They were seeking support for an American plan that needs more than $25 billion to defray the costs of the U.S. troop buildup and to provide emergency economic relief to countries hurt by the U.N.-sponsored trade sanctions against Iraq. Administration officials returning to the United States after Brady's four-day whirlwind trip were upbeat about the chances of ultimate success, although one conceded that full acceptance of the plan ``might take a little longer than we had hoped.'' In Saudi Arabia, Kuwait's ousted royal rulers pledged $5 billion, while one U.S. official said Japan was being asked for ``billions of dollars.'' None of the other world leaders Brady lobbied this week provided any specifics on what they would pledge, saying in most cases that they needed more time to review the request. ``Our principal message throughout this trip has been that there is a cost which all must share in maintaining a freely flowing source of oil at a price determined by market forces,'' Brady said. The United States estimates it will cost about $1 billion a month to keep American troops in the Mideast, with $10.5 billion urgently needed to alleviate serious hardships in Jordan, Egypt and Turkey. Brady met for about an hour with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu as he tried to persuade Japan to contribute more than the $1 billion package of military support it already has pledged. ``I think Japan will not disappoint you,'' Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman Yukio Okamoto said after the meeting, but offered no specifics. In Saudi Arabia, Kuwait's exiled monarch, Jabir al-Sabah, said: ``We will not spare any amount or any value. We will give whatever is necessary.'' Al-Sabah's regime already has pledged to compensate Turkey for losses of up to $2 billion from the shutdown of an Iraqi oil pipeline and the exiled leader also said his government would contribute to the cost of the American military buildup. But a spokesman for the Kuwaiti royal family also urged the United States to set a deadline for ending negotiations with Saddam Hussein. Baker said the United States would not ``foreclose any actions, but we are not going to put any deadline there.'' On Thursday, Saudi Arabia promised several billion dollars toward the operation protecting the kingdom's oil fields from Iraqi aggression. Al-Sabah, Kaifu and South Korean President Roh Tae-woo joined French officials and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in promising to help pay the costs of the military operation. Brady said he was pleased with the endorsements from Japan and South Korea. Before Brady arrived, Japan announced it would provide an additional $12 million to assist the thousands of refugees fleeing the Middle East and repeated a pledge to provide direct economic assistance to countries hard hit by the trade embargo. Officials traveling with Brady, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the total being sought from Japan was higher than $2 billion, with one official saying the request was for ``billions of dollars.'' A third American official said the Japanese had a lot of questions about how the money would be used, but added he ``wouldn't be surprised if we got very close'' to the figure being sought. Brady met earlier Friday with Roh in Seoul, South Korea, amid reports that country is reluctant to commit significant resources against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein because officials fear jeopardizing construction contracts in Iraq and Kuwait worth more than $1 billion. At a news conference in Seoul, Brady said Roh raised those concerns in a ``tangential way.'' Brady said he pointed out the huge stake South Korea has in keeping the price of oil from escalating. ``Every $10 increase in the price of a barrel of oil means a $2.5 billion cost to the Korean economy,'' Brady said. He said a similar increase would cost the Japanese economy nearly $20 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Northern Ireland Man Shot to Death in Bed
DOC.TEXT: Intruders shot and killed a man Friday while he was in bed, police said. The Royal Ulster Constabulary said the 34-year-old Catholic man died soon after he was shot five times in the head and body by at least two assailants. His girlfriend was in bed with him at the time of the shooting, police said. The man's companion, her two children and a friend spending the night at the south Belfast house were unharmed, police said. Police detectives said the dead man, identified as Emmanuel Shields, had no connection to the security forces, and they were afraid the killing was a random attack by Protestant loyalists. On Wednesday, the outlawed Ulster Freedom Fighters threatened to kill Catholic workers after the Irish Republican Army shot and wounded two men on their way to work in County Tyrone. The Apprentice Boys of Derry, meanwhile, said the Rev. Ian Paisley and four others had been expelled from the group, a major Northern Ireland Protestant organization, because they publicly opposed asking for money from a fund set up under the Anglo-Irish agreement, to build a heritage center. The 1985 Anglo-Irish accord angered some of the leaders of Northern Ireland's Protestant majority by giving the Roman Catholic Irish Republic a consultative role in the administration of the British province. Derek Miller, general secretary of the Apprentice Boys, said the five men had broken the rules of the 9,000-member loyalist organization of clubs, which commemorate Protestants shutting the gates of Londonderry to the advancing Catholic King James in 1688. Paisley, a Democratic Unionist Party member of Parliament, was unavailable for comment though an appeal was expected.

DOC.HEAD: Sherburne Says Humphrey Splitting GOP For Personal Gain
DOC.TEXT: The little-known state representative battling political giant Gordon Humphrey for a state Senate nomination charged Friday that Humphrey is splitting the party for personal political gain. Jack Sherburne said Humphrey, who is retiring from the U.S. Senate and running for the New Hampshire Senate, has fragmented the party with his ultraconservative views and call for a tax revolt. ``He is the would-be head of a maverick Republican wing with little or no social conscience,'' Sherburne said at a news conference. ``He is so conservative that he has held himself aloof from the Republicans in Congress and been largely ineffective as a U.S. senator.'' Humphrey, 49, is known as a maverick. During his 12 years in Washington, he has often clashed with Republican congressional leaders because of his strong views. He gave up almost certain re-election to stick to a campaign promise that he would serve no more than two terms in Washington. Sherburne said he believes Humphrey wants to use the state Senate as a springboard to run for governor and, eventually, president. ``He's got a national agenda in mind,'' Sherburne said. ``He's the darling of the ultraconservatives and that's the role he's playing. He's staying in government to become governor and then run for president.'' Humphrey has said he is interested in becoming governor, but that he wouldn't challenge his friend, Gov. Judd Gregg. He hasn't mentioned presidential aspirations. A call to Humphrey's Washington office for comment was not immediately returned Friday. Due in large part to his greater name recognition, Humphrey is favored in Tuesday's primary. But observers say an upset is possible, in part because the candidates differ sharply on abortion. Humphrey is one of the Senate's staunchest opponents of legal abortion, while Sherburne is pro-choice. Sherburne said Humphrey's call for a tax revolt in New Hampshire is ridiculous. He said New Hampshire already ranks among the lowest states in per capita taxation, while its personal income is among the highest. ``Here comes Gordon Humphrey, the former Virginia Democrat, a converted extremist from Washington who wants a tax revolt. A revolt against what?'' Sherburne asked.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Campaigners Sentenced to 15 Months Jail
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Friday sentenced two peace campaigners to 15 months in jail for damaging a U.S. Air Force fighter bomber. The campaigners were found guilty Tuesday of causing $475,000 damage when they hammered an F-111 with mallets at the Upper Heyford air base. Former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark wrote to Judge Francis Allen opposing a prison sentence. ``The law cannot punish conscience and only hurts itself when it tries,'' he said. ``We must hope there will always be people with the courage and selflessness to risk their very freedom to warn society when they believe it is endangering itself.'' Stephen Hancock, a 24-year-old poet and publisher, and Michael Hutchinson, a 35-year-old musician, are members of the Swords Into Ploughshares anti-nuclear peace group. They said they were acting on behalf of the survival of the human race. The men were wearing large Mickey Mouse ears and T-shirts when they were arrested hammering the plane March 21. Allen said everyone hated the thought of using nuclear weapons. ``Since they first darkened the world, men and women have debated whether they should be permissible. As a matter of conscience you argue they should not and many agree, but many, no doubt reluctantly, do not agree. ``We live in a democracy, as do the Americans, and in a democracy the right way to deal with matters of conscience as law abides is through argument and the ballot box and not by causing damage to property.''

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Blast Midwest, Parts of East; Nome Freezes
DOC.TEXT: Powerful thunderstorms pounded large parts of the Midwest and East on Friday, swelling rivers and causing flooding in several states. Nome, Alaska, recorded its first freezing temperatures of the season. The thunderstorms developed during the afternoon along and ahead of a cold front curving through the Ohio Valley. Showers and thunderstorms extended from eastern Kansas through central Illinois to the upper Ohio Valley. There also were thunderstorms in Pennsylvania, New York and parts of New England. Ohio was particularly hard hit by the flooding, with many communities receiving more than 3 inches of rain in 24 hours. At Steubenville, where more than 5 inches of rain sent the Ohio River over its banks, floodwaters were as deep as 10 feet in places. Flooding was also reported in Michigan, Pennsylvania and West Virginia. Nearly 2 inches of rain fell in Pittsburgh, breaking the record for the date. Thunderstorms in central Indiana produced hail an inch in diameter at Thorntown, northwest of Indianapolis. A few showers and thunderstorms also were reported in Missouri, Arkansas, Oklahoma, New Mexico and Colorado. Isolated showers and thunderstorms dotted the Gulf Coast. A few light showers fell in western Washington state, western Oregon and northeastern Nevada. Sunny, dry weather prevailed across most of the rest of the nation, with haze in the Southeast and along the Middle Atlantic Coast. Temperatures warmed into the 90s across much of the area from the southern and central Plains to the southern half of the Atlantic Coast. Readings were only in the 60s from northern Minnesota through much of Michigan and northern New England. In the West, temperatures ranged from the upper 60s to lower 80s in the Pacific Northwest, and into the 90s in the desert Southwest. The nation's low Friday was 37 degrees at West Yellowstone, Mont. At Nome, summery weather came to an end when the mercury dipped to freezing for the first time since June 11. The first freeze in Nome typically occurs by Aug. 18, although last year it didn't occur until Oct. 5.

DOC.HEAD: Storms Pound Midwest; Five Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with National Weather Service saying floodwaters as deep as 10 feet, quotes from Steubenville woman; INSERTS 3 grafs after 12th graf pvs, `Up to ...,' to UPDATE with more quotes, details. Pick up 13th graf pvs: `In Western ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CD3
DOC.TEXT: A band of thunderstorms from Michigan to Pennsylvania unleashed high winds and driving rains, flooding Ohio River communities with as much as 10 feet of water Friday and disrupting flights from the nation's busiest airport. The storms were blamed for the deaths of five people. Hundreds of residents fled their homes in Steubenville, Ohio, and across the Ohio River in Follansbee, W.Va., because of flooding Thursday night and Friday. The North Ohio Valley Air Authority reported 5.71 inches of rain fell in 24 hours in Steubenville in eastern Ohio. Schools were closed Friday. ``I lived down here 15 years, and I've never seen anything like this before,'' Jessica Keifer of Steubenville said. Ms. Keifer said she lost a washer and dryer, a motorcycle, pool table, a friend's furniture she had been storing, her television and all of her winter clothes. United Airlines said it canceled 50 percent of its Friday afternoon flights out of Chicago's O'Hare International Airport. Three Chicago-bound flights were canceled out of Washington's National Airport, and three others delayed earlier in the day, a United spokesman said. One Chicago-bound flight was delayed 4{ hours. Some southbound flights out of O'Hare had to be diverted as far east as Iowa City before they could start turning south, in order to get around the storms, said Don Zochert, a Federal Aviation Administration spokesman in Chicago. A sailboat caught in the storm Thursday on Lake Erie crashed into a breakwater near Cleveland harbor and broke into pieces. Three women aboard were killed; three men were rescued. The boaters were whipped so hard by 36 mph winds and 6-foot waves that their clothes had been torn off, Coast Guard Lt. Vincent Weber said. In eastern Ohio, a 50-year-old woman was struck by lightning and killed as she ran for shelter through a farm field near Wilmot, and another woman died in a two-car accident in Warren blamed on a power outage caused by the storm. Power outages were also reported in southern Michigan and West Virginia. The Allegheny Creek in West Virginia ran out of its banks, flooding about a dozen businesses with up to 6 feet of water and submerging cars in Follansbee. About 40 homes were evacuated in the town of about 4,000. ``I can't believe it actually floated cars,'' said Fire Chief Larry Rea. Up to 300 residents left their homes in Steubenville, said George Starliper, Jefferson County Emergency Services Director. Steubenville Mayor Dave Hindman gave lower figures, saying about 30 people went to an emergency shelter during the night and an equal number stayed with relatives. About one-third of the evacuees would be allowed to return home Friday, but others will have to wait, said Jim Ferris, the city building inspector. At least 20 of the most heavily damaged homes would need inspections, he said. The National Weather Service said floodwaters in Steubenville were as high as 10 feet. In western Pennsylvania, Plum Creek overflowed about 20 miles southwest of Pittsburgh, flooding the business district in Houston with up to 10 feet of water. One hundred residents of Avella were evacuated, said Washington County Emergency Services Director Bracken Burns. Tornadoes knocked down trees in Pennsylvania's Butler County and Westmoreland County, the weather service said. Other unconfirmed tornado sightings were reported in Michigan and Ohio. Winds knocked over a tarp at a softball complex in Rochester Hills, north of Detroit, injuring seven people, one critically. Winds ripped the roof off a feed store in Chesterfield Township, north of Detroit. ``The power went off, there was a loud whistling noise, then _ blam! It took the roof off,'' said employee Jerry Scopas, the only person in the store at the time. ``It only lasted about 15 seconds, then the roof was gone. It's all laying out front in the parking lot.'' The body of the third victim of the Ohio boating accident was found in Lake Erie on Friday morning. The 26-foot boat had radioed the Coast Guard for an escort into a Cleveland marina because of the high water and strong winds, said Coast Guard spokesman Phillip Franklin. ``By the time our boat arrived on the scene, the sailboat had broken in two, and the mast had collapsed,'' Franklin said. One of the rescued crew members, William Alston, said the boat got pushed up on the rocky breakwall before it broke apart. ``Like any accident, some people were in the wrong place at the wrong time. The boat broke up really fast,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dentist With AIDS Dies; Former Patient Pursues Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A 22-year-old woman apparently infected with AIDS while getting a tooth pulled urged stricter control of the health care industry Friday, the same day her dentist's death was revealed. David Johnson Acer, 40, of Stuart, died Monday of acquire immune deficiency syndrome, but his family ``waited to make this announcement so they could privately grieve,'' lawyer Deborah Sawyer said. She refused to elaborate. On Tuesday, the state Health Department released a letter Acer wrote to former patients urging them to be tested for the deadly virus. Meanwhile, the patient Acer is accused of infecting came forward Friday to urge stricter regulation of the health care industry. Kimberly Bergalis, 22, of Fort Pierce, said she would sue the late dentist's estate and her own insurance company for malpractice. ``What we've gone through is an injustice,'' said Ms. Bergalis, who in earlier court papers revealed only her initials. ``If this can be prevented, if new guidelines can be established to prevent this from happening again, then I think that's what needs to be done.'' The national Centers for Disease Control reported last month that Ms. Bergalis' case marked the first time a health professional had passed AIDS to a patient. She was apparently infected while having a tooth pulled in 1987. Ms. Bergalis was diagnosed in December 1989 with the virus that causes AIDS. The illness forced her withdrawal from the University of Florida and documents filed in state court in Palm Beach described her as being in the disease's advanced stages. Ms. Bergalis criticized the CDC, saying she never heard back from the three officials who investigated her case. ``I was watching the news,'' she said. ``I didn't know what to think. I assumed either that they had dropped my case, or they had found something and just never did disclose what they had found with me.'' CDC officials in Atlanta refused to comment, citing confidentiality rules. Acer acknowledged in a letter _ dated Aug. 31 and made public Tuesday _ that he was the dentist involved, but said he had followed CDC safety guidelines, including consulting his doctor before continuing his practice and wearing gloves and a mask while treating patients. He said he doubted he was the source of Bergalis' infection. But Ms. Bergalis' lawyer, Robert Montgomery, questioned the late dentist's ethics. ``I would like to know who his peers were that he consulted prior to continuing to treat patients with HIV positive,'' Montgomery said. Montgomery said he planned to sue Acer's estate and CIGNA Dental Health of Florida on Ms. Bergalis' behalf. He did not say when the suit would be filed. CIGNA referred Bergalis to Acer, who treated about 370 patients belonging to the dental plan. Health officials received more than 100 telephone calls after the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services released Acer's letter Tuesday. It was unclear how many he sent to former patients. ``I am a gentle man, and I would never intentionally expose anyone to this disease,'' he wrote. The letter did not say how long Acer practiced after being diagnosed with AIDS. The Cleveland native graduated from the Ohio State University dental school in 1973 and served as an Air Force dentist, leaving as a captain in 1976, state records show. He was certified to practice in Florida in August 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Forces Crush Nidal Fighters, Dozens Killed
DOC.TEXT: PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat's forces crushed dissident guerrillas of terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal in savage fighting Friday that killed at least 25 people and wounded 70, police said. They said Arafat's loyalists from the PLO mainstream faction, Fatah, overran all bases of Abu Nidal's Fatah-Revolutionary Council breakaway faction in a five-hour battle in the Ein el-Hilweh camp near Sidon, provincial capital of southern Lebanon. Among the dead were seven civilians, members of a Palestinian family killed by a mortar shell that hit their home. The rest were mostly from Abu Nidal's group, said a police spokesman. He could not be identified under standing rules. The fighting died down at 8 p.m. after Arafat's men wrested control of all offices and bases of Abu Nidal's group, the spokesman said. That left about 100 fighters of Abu Nidal's group holed up in the tiny village of Majdalyoun, five miles east of Sidon, their only remaining base in southern Lebanon, the spokesman said. ``We think it's only a matter of days before the PLO moves to take Majdalyoun,'' he said. Arafat and Abu Nidal, whose real name is Aabri al-Banna, have been at odds since Nidal broke away from Fatah in 1973. Abu Nidal tops the wanted lists in the United States and Europe for a series of terrorist attacks the past 15 years. Arafat's men routed about 200 of Abu Nidal's loyalists from the Rashidiyeh refugee camp near Lebanon's southernmost port of Tyre in fighting June 17-18. Police had said five Abu Nidal guerrillas were killed, 16 wounded and 40 taken prisoner in the two-day crackdown at Rashidiyeh, home of nearly 20,000 Palestinian refugees 40 miles south of Beirut. Ein el-hilweh, 25 miles south of Beirut, has a population of 31,750 refugees registered with the United Nations.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Foreign Minister Says He's Willing to Go to Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Friday he is willing to go to Iraq to help settle the Persian Gulf crisis, Tass reported. In an interview with Soviet journalists while flying home from an official visit to Japan, he said he expected Presidents Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev would discuss at the Helsinki summit Sunday how to influence events in the gulf by working with other Arab countries. ``We expect that a substantial discussion will be held in the capital of Finland relating to ways to stimulate the Arab factor in order to overcome the crisis,'' Shevardnadze was quoted as saying by the official news agency. ``We shall seek to combine the efforts of those with whom we have good relations and those with whom the United States has good relations in order to find a way out of the crisis,'' he said. Shevardnadze again proposed an international conference on the gulf that also would take up the Arab-Israeli conflict and Lebanon. ``If the need arises, I am ready to travel to Iraq,'' Tass quoted him as saying. Shevardnadze first proposed the conference Tuesday in Vladivostok. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said he would consider participating in such a conference but emphasized his refusal to discuss the Palestinian question at such a forum. Shevardnadze on Friday again raised the possibility of such a meeting, and suggested convening it in three stages, Tass said. ``If only we succeeded in convoking such a conference _ with the participation of the conflicting sides, U.N. Security Council member-countries and, maybe, some others _ it would become possible to consider the Persian Gulf situation already at its first stage, while devoting the second stage to the consideration of the situation on the occupied Arab territories, i.e., the whole set of problems relating to the Arab-Israeli conflict,'' Tass quoted him as saying. The third stage of the conference would discuss Lebanon, and ``this conference would undoubtedly stress the role of the Arab factor,'' he said. He said he knew Secretary of State James A. Baker III views his plan ``without much enthusiasm. But I think one should not be scared by this idea.'' Israel has vehemently opposed Soviet ideas to hold an international conference to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict, and Shevardnadze acknowledged this. ``It will probably be necessary to do some work with Israel at the ministerial level,'' he added. ``But I want to reiterate, there is no need to fear such a conference. ``What needs to be feared is the consequences of an exacerbated conflict,'' Shevardnadze said, according to Tass. Shevardnadze said settling the crisis via the U.N. Security Council is a top priority, but he added, ``If a more resolute action is needed, the U.N. military staff committee should be used,'' according to Tass. Earlier Friday, Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said the Soviet Union would be willing to provide troops for a U.N. peacekeeping force in the gulf if they were under a joint command that included Soviet generals. Although Iraq is a longtime ally of the Soviet Union, Gorbachev halted the flow of Soviet arms to Iraq after Moscow condemned Baghdad's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Says Mali May Have Prisoners of Conscience
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International said Friday it believes that leading members of the Tuareg community in northeastern Mali may be prisoners of conscience. The London-based human rights group said a number of Tuaregs have been arrested since armed uprisings by the ethnic group began in May, following the arrest of members of their tribe. Amnesty called on the government of the sub-Saharan country either to press charges or release the Tuaregs immediately. The organization said some Tauregs were being held in poor conditions, perhaps solely on account of their ethnic origin. It identified two as Oefane ag Souleymane, a Gao businessman in his 60s, and Sikaye ag Ekawel, director of a government-sponsored food aid project in Kidal. ``Prison conditions in Mali are generally harsh, with inadequate food and medical care, and a high level of resulting ill health,'' Amnesty said. The group had said 29 Tuaregs were executed in August, apparently without trial. But Mali's Minister-Delegate for Defense, Gen. Mamadou Coulibaly, said Aug. 21 that no Tuaregs had been executed, Amnesty said.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Secretary Meets State Representatives
DOC.TEXT: Energy Secretary James Watkins met representatives from oil producing states Friday to discuss ways that domestic oil production might be increased, department officials said. The meeting was attended by officials from states belonging to the 29-member Interstate Oil Compact Commission, which is chaired by Wyoming Gov. Mike Sullivan. Bob Porter, a department spokesman, said the meeting was one of several that Watkins is holding with both oil producers and consumers in connection with the development of an interim strategy to ease U.S. reliance on foreign oil and offset any supply shortfall brought on by the Middle East crisis. Watkins previously has met with oil company executives and planned meetings with other energy industry representatives and consummer groups in the coming weeks, officials said. The Energy Department wants states to temporarily relax oil production limits. Texas recently agreed to do so with the expectation that an additional 20,000 barrles per day may be produced in the state. Porter described Friday's meeting an ``an extremely candid exchange'' but said he could provide no details on what suggestions the state officials offered.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Accuses France of Mistreating Iraqis
With Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Friday accused the French government of mistreating Iraqis in France, saying some have been deported and others illegally interrogated.
