An unidentified Foreign Ministry spokesman told the official Iraqi News Agency that ``deportations, unlawful interrogation and turning back Iraqis with valid entry visas are practices taking place at airports in Paris in particular.'' ``Even children have been subjected to these measures,'' INA, monitored in Nicosia, quoted him as saying. ``Also, the movement of 14 students at an educational institution has been restricted and they have been prevented from traveling,'' he said. He said a senior French Foreign Minitry official justified these actions as ``necessary for France's national security.'' ``Iraq never threatened France's security and the measures can only be understood as unjustified acts that serve aggressive purposes of the U.S. hostile policies toward Iraq,'' the spokesman said. France last week announced that some Iraqis were under police surveillance and that it had restricted the movement of 29 who had received military training. France, a major arms supplier to Iraq during the 1980-88 war with Iran, is contributing to naval fleets imposing the blockade on Iraq to force it to withdraw from Kuwait. A large number of French expatriates are among hundreds of thousands of foreigners who have been trapped in Iraq and Kuwait since the Aug. 2 invasion. Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein has sent some to military installations as part of human shield to avert an attack by U.S.-led foreign forces assembled in Saudi Arabia. The Iraqi spokesman was quoted as saying Iraq was treating the French expatriates ``normally, except for hosting some of them to prevent war from breaking out.'' He added: ``This measure was dictated by the open threats of military aggressesion made by the United States and its allies.''

DOC.HEAD: Sinead O'Connor Tops Madonna in MTV Awards
DOC.TEXT: The MTV Music Video Awards, not noted for their cultural significance, produced a curious mixture of censorship protests and upset victories at their seventh annual ceremony. Irish pop singer Sinead O'Connor breezed past American bombshell Madonna during Thursday night's three-hour show and took top video, best female video and the postmodern awards for her stark ``Nothing Compares 2 U.'' Madonna, who performed a racy version of her ``Vogue'' video dressed in an 18th century French costume bursting at the bust, won for direction, cinematography and editing _ none of which go to her. O'Connor created a flap last month when she threatened to walk out on an audience of 9,000 at the Garden State Arts Center in New Jersey if the state-owned arena played the national anthem before her show. ``I'd like to say I had a great respect for people of all countries, including American people,'' she told the sellout crowd at the Universal Amphitheatre, which gave her a standing ovation. ``My attitude over the national anthem was in order to draw attention to the censorship issue,'' she added. ``When it's racism disguised as censorship it's even worse.'' The group 2 Live Crew performed ``Banned in the USA,'' a rap version of Bruce Springsteen's ``Born in the USA,'' which sparked a dancefest by audience members waving bumper stickers reading, ``Censorship is UnAmerican.'' The rappers, whose ``As Nasty as They Want To Be'' album has been banned by some record stores, called the reaction to their explicit music racist. ``It's a damn shame. It's racist,'' said lead singer Luther Campbell. Ex-Eagle Don Henley beat Billy Idol and M.C. Hammer in the best male video category for ``End of the Innocence.'' But M.C. Hammer's ``U Can't Touch This'' won in rap and dance categories. Janet Jackson won the 1990 Video Vanguard award, MTV's highest honor. The sister of pop icon Michael Jackson is the first woman to have the five highest spots on the Billboard charts with cuts from a single album. Aerosmith, which won the metal-hard rock award, also won an unofficial ``viewer's choice'' honor, in which members of the TV audience telephoned a 900-number to declare their favorite group. Here's a list of the winners of the 1990 MTV Video Music Awards: VIDEO OF THE YEAR: ``Nothing Compares 2 U,'' Sinead O'Connor. MALE VIDEO: ``The End of the Innocence,'' Don Henley. FEMALE VIDEO: ``Nothing Compares 2 U,'' Sinead O'Connor. GROUP VIDEO: ``Love Shack,'' B-52's. METAL-HARD ROCK VIDEO: ``Janie's Got a Gun,'' Aerosmith. NEW ARTIST IN A VIDEO: Michael Penn, ``No Myth''. VIDEO FROM A FILM: ``Cradle of Love,'' Billy Idol. RAP: ``U Can't Touch This,'' M.C. Hammer. DANCE: ``U Can't Touch This,'' M.C. Hammer. POST-MODERN: ``Nothing Compares 2 U,'' Sinead O'Connor. BREAKTHROUGH VIDEO: ``Sowing the Seeds of Love,'' Tears for Fears. DIRECTION: ``Vogue,'' David Fincher. CHOREOGRAPHY: ``Rhythm Nation,'' Anthony Thomas, Janet Jackson. SPECIAL EFFECTS: ``Sowing the Seeds of Love,'' Jim Blashfield. ART DIRECTION: ``Love Shack,'' Martin Lasowitz. EDITING: ``Vogue,'' Jim Haygood. CINEMATOGRAPHY: ``Vogue,'' Pascal Lebeque.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say Stasi Knew of Plans for 1983 West Berlin Attack
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's now-disbanded secret police knew of plans for a 1983 bombing in West Berlin that may have been the work of the world's most notorious terrorist, officials said Friday. The bomb exploded on Aug. 25, 1983, in West Berlin in the French cultural center known as Maison de France, killing one person and injuring 23. In a letter to West German officials, the terrorist known as ``Carlos'' claimed responsibility. The name is the alias for top terrorist Illich Ramirez-Sanchez, a Venezuelan. Carlos is believed to have been behind several attacks, including the June 27, 1975, killing of two French secret agents and an attack on a gathering of Arab oil ministers in Vienna six months later. The East German Interior Ministry on Friday said officials with the now disbanded Stasi secret police had personal contacts with a international terrorist group calling itself ``Carlos'' up until last year. Stasi officials also knew of preparations for the Maison de France bombing in West Berlin, the ministry said in a statement. According to the statement, Stasi officials had even arranged a villa for the bombers outside East Berlin. The Maison de France housed the French consulate general, the French Trade Council, a movie theater and a bookstore. There have been previous reports of links between East Germany's secret police and Carlos. The West German newspaper Bild reported in July that former East German security chief Erich Mielke had personal contacts with Carlos and other top international terrorists.

DOC.HEAD: Chilean Police Seize 130 Pounds of Cocaine in Drug Bust
DOC.TEXT: Police on Friday seized 130 pounds of cocaine from a Colombian man at Santiago's international airport. Police said the drugs were worth $4 million and that it was the largest bust ever made at the Pudahuel airport. An unidentified Colombian man and several ``accomplices'' were arrested, police said. Police refused to give any further details, saying it could damage an investigation still in progress.

DOC.HEAD: Biggest Heroin Cash Seizure Claimed
DOC.TEXT: The Drug Enforcement Administration claimed its largest cash seizure from a heroin investigation Friday after the arrest of four men and the dismantling of an operation that distributed Asian heroin. The DEA displayed the haul, estimated to be worth up to $6 million, at a news conference attended by Mayor David Dinkins, who has been criticized as failing to deal with crime in the city. The total recovered in 28 bags, some too heavy for one person to carry, was ``in the $4-, $5-, $6-million range,'' said Robert A. Bryden, the federal agency's New York chief. Bryden said it would take four or five days to count all the money, piled like bricks on conference tables and guarded by two agents carrying submachine guns. About a dozen agents of the East Asian Task Force, drawn from federal, state and city agencies, raided three sites in Brooklyn Thursday night. Agents arrested four men, seized the cash and a submachine gun, two large-caliber pistols and a .25-caliber pistol with silencer, Bryden said. They also found two heroin presses, about three-quarters of a pound of heroin and 13 cylinders in which they believed as much as 3,000 pounds of heroin could have been smuggled into the country, Bryden said. Rep. Charles Rangel, a Democrat from Harlem in New York, lauded the multi-agency operation. ``It's very easy for us in Washington to declare the war,'' he said. ``It's the people on the federal, state and local level that are in the trenches.'' Dinkins, accompanied by his police commissioner, Lee Brown, praised the operation and participation of city police. ``When that police department does well, I claim the credit,'' the mayor said. ``When that police department does not do well, I clearly get the blame.'' Brown said the number of heroin arrests in the city had doubled over the past 18 months. He called the high number of heroin users and dealers especially disturbing because it coincides with a continued high level of crack use. Rangel said the heroin came from Burma. Bryden said the agency did not know where it entered the United States. Those arrested, held for arraignment in Brooklyn on charges of conspiring to distribute heroin, were identified as Ken Lee Sak, 32; Siu Chuen Chung, 32, and Kam-Far Lee, 45, all of Brooklyn, and Tak Chew Chiu, 30, of Glendale, Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor: No Plea Bargain for Eight Indicted In Tourist's Death
DOC.TEXT: Eight men were indicted Friday on murder and robbery charges in the stabbing of a Utah tourist who died trying to protect his mother during a holdup. Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau said he promised the victim's father, Sherwin Watkins, that the defendants would not be offered plea bargains. ``I expressed my condolences to him, and told him there was nothing we could do to bring his son back,'' said Morgenthau, who said seven of the defendants made incriminating videotaped statements. Each was indicted on one count of second-degree murder, two counts of first-degree robbery, and two counts of second-degree robbery, said Assistant District Attorney Thomas Shiels. State Supreme Court Justice Thomas Straus ordered the suspects jailed pending a Sept. 24 bail hearing. The gang of young men is accused of killing Brian Watkins, 22, of Provo, Utah, Sunday night after robbing his father of $200 and some credit cards as the family waited for a subway train. Police said the gang wanted the money to pay for a night of drinking and dancing at a nightclub where several suspects were arrested. Watkins was stabbed in the chest as he tried to defend his mother, who was punched during the attack. A youth using a box cutter slashed his father's pants and took the cash. The family was in New York for its annual trip to the U.S. Open tennis tournament. After spending the day at the tournament in the borough of Queens, the victim, his mother, father, brother and sister-in-law returned to Manhattan and were heading to Tavern on the Green in Central Park for dinner. The stabbing occurred in the Seventh Avenue subway stop at 53rd Street. Charged were Anthony Anderson, Pascal Carpenter, Emiliano Fernandez, Ricardo Lopez, Johnny Hincapie, Ricardo Nova and Yull Gary Morales, all 18, and Luis Fernando Montero, 22. All live in Queens and all but Montero made a videotaped police statement. Police said Morales stabbed Watkins with a butterfly knife. Two other suspects were being sought, Morgenthau said. Watkins' funeral is scheduled for Saturday in Provo.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Violence Claims Four Victims in Peruvian Andes
DOC.TEXT: Maoist Shining Path guerrillas killed four people, including a teen-age student, in attacks outside the central Andean city of Huancayo, police said Friday. In the first incident, rebels shortly after midnight shot to death two brothers in Orcotuna, 9 miles north of Huancayo, police said. Huancayo is 120 miles east of Lima. Police said eight masked insurgents with machine guns dragged the brothers from a party out into the street. There the guerrillas tortured the brothers before shooting them repeatedly. The guerrillas left their trademark sign on the bodies, ``This is how police informers die,'' according to police. Guerrillas also killed a schoolteacher and a student in Chupaca, 5 miles west of Huancayo, police said. Police said four masked guerrillas, one of them a woman, raided the town school looking for the pre-military academy instructor. The insurgents shot the instructor 10 times and also fired at students who tried to protect him. One 18-year-old student was killed and another was seriously injured, police said. The guerrillas left a sign on the instructor's body threatening a similar fate for others connected to the military. Meanwhile, police were searching Friday for 30 heavily armed pro-Castro Tupac Amaru guerrillas spotted near Satipo, 70 miles northeast of Huancayo. Police said the rebels held meetings this week with local farmers to hear their grievances. Huancayo, a major commercial city, and other towns in the fertile Mantaro Valley, have been the targets of a growing guerrilla offensive in recent weeks. The guerrillas plan to cut off Lima's main food supply. Clashes between guerrillas and the armed forces have claimed over 19,500 lives since the Shining Path took up arms in 1980. The majority of victims have been civilans. The guerrillas aim to overthrow the government and set up a worker-peasant state. After 10 years of insurgency, over half the country's 22 million inhabitants live in government-declared emergency zones under military control.

DOC.HEAD: Hard, Hungry Days Face Those Stranded in Jordan
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 225,000 Egyptians waited Friday at the Iraqi border to cross into Jordan, but they were held back because Jordan cannot cope with the 100,000 refugees already stranded in its desert, a border official said. A U.N. relief official warned the refugee problem could explode into a ``human tragedy.'' Four tons of canned beef from the Netherlands were sent to laboratories for testing Friday after tons of cookies, powdered milk and dates sent to hungry refugees were deemed unfit for human consumption. The worthless food was the latest in a series problems confronting the people trying to ease the misery of 45,000 Asian refugees packed into the makeshift Shaalan I camp here. Fights have broken out in this and other camps jam-packed with hungry refugees who fled Iraq and Kuwait after Iraq invaded Aug 2. They scramble and jostle for a meager daily ration of a piece of bread, a tomato and a cucumber. Red Cross officials and others say some refugees have gone for up to three days with little water, food or shelter. The Jordanian border official, who requested anonymity, said the Egyptians were stranded in a huge camp just inside the Iraqi border. ``They are waiting under terrible conditions for permission to cross into Jordan to continue their journey home,'' the official said, who cannot be named under regulations. ``But we cannot cope with such huge numbers before the Asian evacuees already inside Jordan waiting for transportation to their homes are shifted,'' he added. He said 18,325 crossed through this post during the day. James N. Purcell, director of the U.N. International Organization for Migration, appealed urgently for ships and aircraft to repatriate the Asians squatting in hot and dirty camps ``before human suffering becomes a human tragedy.'' Jordanian officials are doing their best to stretch meager resources while awaiting international help to care for the nearly 100,000 refugees already in the country. On Wednesday, Jordan ordered 10 tons of dates returned to Egypt after they were tested and found to be too old and hard to eat. Forty more tons were on the way to Jordan, and authorities said they, too, probably would be sent back. Rahib Moussa, an official with Jordan's Ministry of Supply, said Friday it would take at least a day for a laboratory to inspect the canned beef, only the second shipment of outside aid received at Shaalan I near the Iraqi border. India earlier donated 10,000 sandwiches and 5,000 barrels of water, he said. Most of the refugees crammed into tents at the Shaalan I camp are Bangladeshi, Pakistani, Indian and Sri Lankan men. Many of the women and children are being sent to refugee camps in Amman, Moussa said. On Friday, at least 2,000 people stood in a seemingly endless line that snaked through the hot sand. Those patient enough waited for hours under the scorching sun for a piece of bread, slice of cheese and tomato provided by the government. Moussa said the government plans to speed up the distribution at the camp by creating seven feeding stations instead of just one. On Friday, a nun from Mother Teresa's order stood by offering words of encouragement and sympathy. At a tent hospital set up by the Red Cross-Red Crescent, Dr. Khaled Issa said 2,000 people a day come in for treatment. Most are suffering dehydration, colds and other minor illnesses. But in the harsh camp conditions, minor ailments can rapidly become life-threatening. Issa said those who are sick should drink 5 gallons of water a day, much more than is available. A five-member delegation from the European Parliament toured Jordan's camps and said Friday they were appalled by the conditions. One member of the delegation called on European nations to provide military transport planes to airlift the refugees home. France's minister for humanitarian aid, Bernard Kouchner, speaking to reporters in Amman, said 10,000 more people arrive every day in Jordan from Kuwait and Iraq. Jordanian officials estimate the number of new arrivals at about 18,000. Nobody really knows. Official estimates say more than 250,000 foreigners, mostly Asians, have crossed the desert border post at Reweishid since Aug. 2 following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Regardless of the precise number, one thing is clear. For those stranded in Kuwait, Kouchner said: ``these are very, very hard days.''

DOC.HEAD: Hartfort Courant Publisher to Succeed Reg Murphy at The Sun
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf, ```He has ...' to UPDATE with appointments of those who will succeed Davies at Hartford newspaper. Picks up 5th graf pvs: `In seven . . .' Also moving on financial news wire.
DOC.TEXT: Michael J. Davies, the editor, publisher and chief executive officer of The Hartford Courant, was named Thursday to replace Reg Murphy as publisher and chief executive officer of The Sun newspapers. Murphy, 56, will become chairman of The Sun newspapers, said David Laventhol, president of Times Mirror Co., which owns the morning and evening papers in Baltimore and the morning daily in Hartfort, Conn. ``Reg Murphy has been an outstanding leader of the Baltimore Sun for the past decade, both before and after Times Mirror's acquisition of the paper in 1986 from the A.S. Abell Co.,'' Laventhol said. ``He has been a journalistic innovator, leading the paper to two Pulitzer prizes, to record-breaking circulation gains and to substantially improved business operations during his tenure.'' Raymond A. Jansen will succeed Davies as publisher and chief executive officer of the Courant, newspaper spokesman Dennis Schain said. The newspaper's senior vice president and general manager since 1986, the 51-year-old Jansen held numerous advertising and sales positions during a 22-year career at Newsday in on New York's Long Island before going to the Courant in 1982. Michael E. Waller, the Courant's executive editor since 1986, was named the newspaper's editor and vice president. Waller went to Hartford from Kansas City, Mo., where he served as editor of The Kansas City Star and Times. In seven years as publisher of the Courant, Davies ``was an industry leader, launching a major new zoning effort last year and improving customer service at every level of the newspaper,'' Laventhol said. Zoning is the practice giving different geographic areas their own newspaper sections. Murphy joined the Sun papers in 1981 after serving as editor and publisher of the San Francisco Examiner since 1975. From 1961 to 1975, he was with the Atlanta Constitution. He started there as a political reporter and was named editor of the newspaper in 1968. He began his newspaper career with the Macon (Ga.) Telegraph and News in 1956. He attended Mercer University and Harvard University. Davies, 46, came to the Courant in 1983 from The Kansas City Star and Times, where he had been president and editor since 1978. Before that, he spent two years as managing editor of The Courier-Journal in Louisville, Ky., and was managing editor of the Louisville Times from 1971 to 1976. He began his journalism career in 1961 as a reporter for the Savannah (Ga.) Morning News. He has a bachelor's degree from Georgia State University and a master's in journalism from Northwestern University. Murphy will continue to represent Times Mirror as the chairman of the board of directors of Newspapers First, a national advertising sales organization. He also will be involved in the management of the Sun's weeklies and its audiotex service. Times Mirror, a Los Angeles-based company, publishes the Los Angeles Times, Newsday, New York Newsday, The Sun newspapers, the Courant, The Morning Call in Allentown, Pa., The (Stamford) Advocate and Greenwich (Conn.) Time. The company also has interests in broadcast and cable television and book, magazine and other publishing.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Brando's Lawyer Asks for Reduced Charge of Manslaughter
DOC.TEXT: Christian Brando's defense lawyer has asked a court to reduce the murder charge against him to manslaughter. Another motion, filed Wednesday in Superior Court, seeks to suppress a tape-recorded police interview of Brando, the son of actor Marlon Brando. Attorney Robert Shapiro will argue the motions before Superior Court Judge Robert Thomas on Sept. 14, said Sandi Gibbons, spokeswoman for the district attorney's office. Brando, 32, pleaded innocent to first-degree murder in the May 16 shooting of Dag Drollet, 26, the boyfriend of Christian's half-sister, Cheyenne. He was found dead in Marlon Brando's hilltop Bel Air estate. Trial is set for Oct. 1. Shapiro argued unsuccessfully during a preliminary hearing that the murder charge should be reduced to manslaughter because there was no evidence Brando intended to kill Drollet. The attorney cited statements Christian Brando made to police that the shooting occurred accidentally while he and Drollet struggled for a gun. Prosecutors have cited reports that Drollet was clutching a TV remote control device and other items when his body was discovered. Shapiro filed the motion seeking to suppress the recorded interview even though a judge has ruled the statements cannot be used because a police detective failed to advise Brando of his right to a court-appointed attorney. Brando was released from jail last month after his father met $2 million bail by posting the deed to his estate.

DOC.HEAD: State Issues Unusual Warning
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS penultimate graf: ``The department said,'' to CORRECT typo; ``said it'' sted ``said if''
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Friday night the United States would ``view with utmost seriousness'' any Iraqi-sponsored terrorism. Terrorist attacks would be more likely if fighting breaks out in the Persian Gulf, the department said. The department offered no explanation why it issued such a statement at the unusual hour of 8:30 p.m. In the language of diplomacy, ``view with utmost seriousness'' is considered a grave warning of severe consequences. Spokesman Mark Dillen, when asked, would say only that the statement ``simply updates and further draws attention to the phenomena described in the statement.'' He said the department did not know of any ``specific, credible'' terrorist threat. Asked if it knew of any general, credible threat, he replied, ``No.'' The statement said Iraq had expanded support for several terrorist groups, particularly radical Palestinian elements, in recent months. Groups supported by Iraq could attack at ``almost any time'' throughout Europe and the Middle East, with Americans and American interests among the targets, the statement said. ``Iraq support for terrorist groups also endangers U.S. interests in other regions, although to a lesser extent,'' the department said. ``Such attacks would become more likely if hostilities were to occur in the Persian Gulf region. The United States would view with utmost seriousness any Iraqi-sponsored terrorist attack.'' The department said it would ``provide additional information to overseas travelers or other concerned parties'' if it received ``specific, credible'' information on a threat to overseas American interests. The department restored Iraq to its list of governments sponsoring terrorism on Sept. 1. It had been removed several years ago when the United States was cooperating with Iraq in opposing Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Armed Teen Takes Classmates Hostage, Later Releases Them Without Injury
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th and 5th grafs to CLARIFY how teen brought guns into school and where he pulled the weapons.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AX3
DOC.TEXT: An armed high school sophomore held nine classmates hostage for more than five hours Thursday, releasing some for candy and soda before growing dizzy and surrendering, officials said. No one was injured during the hostage ordeal at the combined South Forsyth high school and middle school in Forsyth County, about 40 miles north of Atlanta. Most of the school's 1,200 students were evacuated, and hundreds of worried parents flocked to the campus as word of the incident spread. The episode began about 8:30 a.m., shortly after classes began. Forsyth County Sheriff Wesley Walraven said the youth, identified as 10th-grader Randy Addis, carried a small duffel bag holding three weapons into the school, pulled out a rifle in Don Hutchins' civics class and fired it over the students' heads. Johnny Tallant, who was teaching in the next room, struggled with Addis and got the rifle away from him, but not before another shot was fired, the sheriff said. Addis then ran, Hutchins tackled him and the youth pulled a shotgun from his bag, he said. The youth, armed with the shotgun and a pistol, ordered Hutchins' students into Tallant's classroom and held both classes _ about 40 students _ at gunpoint, Walraven said. Most of the students were released gradually during the morning, including all the girls but one, who chose to stay because she knew Addis, he said. Some hostages were freed in exchange for candy and soda, said Joyce Shadburn, a spokeswoman for the county's school superintendent. The only other demand was for a school bus, she said, adding that a bus had been taken to the scene. Student Shelly Dixon said the boy told ``us to stand up and put our hands on our heads. He started cussing at us. He said if we said anything, he'd shoot us.'' Walraven said the youth demanded the bus to take him to Savannah and $3,000 cash. About 1:45 p.m., Addis began to get dizzy and two of the hostages ran out, the sheriff said. Officers moved in to take his weapons and he did not resist. ``From our information, he was wearing down. He was starting to get dizzy. His reaction time was slow,'' said Walraven. Addis was being held without bond at the Forsyth County Jail and was charged with kidnapping and weapons violations, officials said. Seventh-grader Shawn Abercrombie, whose older brother was among the final hostages, described Addis as ``a quiet guy. He has problems and has seizures and takes pills for them.'' The youth had a seizure last week, Abercrombie said, and another student made fun of him. But police would not speculate on the reasons for the hostage-taking.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Activists Protest Harassment by Cuban Officials
DOC.TEXT: A United Nations conference on crime-fighting ended in Cuba on Friday with a human rights watchdog group saying its representatives were harassed and threatened by President Fidel Castro's communist regime. The International League for Human Rights said three of its U.N.-approved delegation of five were prevented from taking part in the weeklong Seventh Congress on Crime in Havana, Cuba's capital. All three are prominent anti-Castro human rights activists and Havana residents. Yndamiro Restano is a member of the Cuban Commission for Human Rights and National Reconciliation. Antonio de Varona Batlle served as defense counsel for commission leader Elizardo Sanchez when Sanchez was recently tried for ``disseminating false news against international peace.'' Jorge Bacallao is a legal adviser to the Cuban Human Rights Committee, another non-government group. The league said in a news release from its base in New York City that the three Cubans were ``threatened and followed by security officials, and may suffer reprisals after the conference concludes.'' It quoted league board member Robert Cox, another of its delegates in Havana, as saying the five ``were harassed, intimidated and threatened throughout the meeting'' and that ``state security groups appear to be out of control.'' ``Security guards challenged the delegates on the grounds that the three, two of whom are lawyers and all of whom are experts on criminal justice in Cuba, were connected to human rights organizations in Cuba that are not officially recognized by the government,'' the league said. It said one of the Cubans ``was physically pushed out of the conference hall'' and all three ``were physically detained temporarily by security police in a hall off the conference site.'' The league quoted Cox as saying that security official Felipe Zilla ``intimated to him that Mrs. Restano was in danger.'' Cuban acting Foreign Minister Rolando Lopes del Amo threatened both Cox and the league, saying ``his government would oppose the league's continued consultative status at the United Nations,'' the league said. Cox, a Briton, was awarded the United Kingdom's Order of the British Empire for denouncing rights abuses by right-wing military regimes during Argentina's ``dirty war'' against suspected leftist subversives in the 1970s. Cox was editor of the Buenos Aires Herald at the time. He is now associate editor of the Charleston, S.C., Courier and Post. Dianne Orentlicher, the fifth delegate and another league board member, is a lawyer who taught at Yale, Harvard and Columbia universities. The league, founded in 1942, has been accredited to the U.N. for more than a half-century and works to combat rights abuses worldwide. Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov was its honorary president until he died last year. The congress is held by the U.N. every five years to formulate guidelines on crime-fighting, protecting prisoners from abuse and protecting their lawyers from reprisals in countries under authoritarian governments. Dispatches on the conference by the official Cuban news agency Prensa Latina from Havana, monitored here, made no mention of the incidents between the Castro government and the league's representatives. A Prensa Latina dispatch Friday said the conference closed after holding 14 plenary sessions and approving about 30 resolutions, one of them praising the Castro government and the Cuban people for their hospitality. It said 1,700 delegates from 129 nations attended the meeting.

DOC.HEAD: `Camille' and `Money Talks' Open Off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: That cough of Camille's has been a siren song for some of the world's best-known actresses and singers. From Sarah Bernhardt to Eleanora Duse to Greta Garbo to Maria Callas, the consumptive courtesan who dies for love has been a staple on stage, on screen and in the opera house. But move over, ladies. Everett Quinton has made the role his own in Charles Ludlam's giddy, giggly adaptation of ``Camille'' that resurfaced Thursday at off-Broadway's Ridiculous Theatrical Company. Ludlum, who died in 1987, originally starred as Camille 17 years ago in the troupe's tiny Sheridan Square theater. By all accounts, his performance was definitive, but Quinton, Ludlum's successor as head of the Ridiculous Theater, is a worthy and very funny replacement. In fact, with this role, Quinton moves out from Ludlum's shadow and into the spotlight as a first-rate clown, an expressive lead performer who knows when to go for pathos or a pratfall. The actor has a quizzical comic face, highlighted by a Grand Canyon-size mouth. As Camille, he can be haughty, even slighty malevolent, but you know it's all in fun. Here, dressed in Elizabeth Fried's outlandish costumes and sporting a dark wig of what appears to be tightly coiled mattress springs, he resembles Agnes Moorehead crossed with Martha Raye. Ludlum's version of the Alexandre Dumas tearjerker veers all over the map _ from high camp to poignant melodrama. But the adapter never lost sight of the basic story of a woman sacrificing herself for the man she loved. And Quinton, who also doubles as director, doesn't either. He keeps a firm hand on the production, not letting the play get too moist or too wild. A menagerie of distinctive character actors offer some memorable portraits, particularly Stephen Pell as Nanine, the ever-loyal maid; H.M. Koutoukas as a lascivious baron; and Georg Osterman as Camille's true love. ``Camille'' ranks as one of Ludlam's best efforts, and Quinton has managed to preserve the laughter and a bit of the tears. And much of the fun comes from his own splendid performance.

There is a certain grim fascination in watching ``Money Talks,'' a fascination not unlike driving by an auto accident on the interstate and wondering how _ and why _ it happened. This dumb comedy by Edwin Schloss, which arrived Thursday at off-Broadway's Promenade Theater, is something the New York theater hasn't seen in a while _ a vanity production that seems to have been produced more for the benefit of the playwright than for the audience. It never should have opened. ``Money Talks,'' which reportedly cost $500,000, has an elaborate, yet ugly, set and a cast of 11 actors. Most prominent among them are Dolores Gray and Helen Gallagher, two formidable musical comedy stars. The plot revolves around several wealthy Manhattan matrons who invest in the stock market. The jokes died before vaudeville: ``Nature abhors a vacuum.'' ``So does my cleaning lady.'' The direction is nonexistent and the acting, except for the unsinkable Miss Gallagher, hard to watch. The evening strings together a series of low points that reach Death Valley level in the second act when the matrons, dressed in black for a funeral, parade across the stage to Ravel's ``Bolero.'' Where is Bo Derek when you really need her? Miss Gray gets to sing a bit of an old Irving Berlin song, ``Marrying for Love,'' at the end of the show. The diversion doesn't help, but does remind audiences that the woman should be back in the musical theater instead of appearing in such disasters as ``Money Talks.''

DOC.HEAD: Sharpton Calls Truce With Miss America Pageant; Last of Preliminaries Held
LaserPhoto XACC10
DOC.TEXT: A militant black activist said Thursday he's calling off a protest of the Miss America Pageant after reaching an agreement with its director. The Rev. Al Sharpton and the city's black youths will not disrupt Friday's parade or the Saturday night finals with their demand for a recreational center in Atlantic City, he and pageant Director Leonard Horn said at a Boardwalk news conference. But the protesters will stage a peaceful Boardwalk march Saturday, Sharpton said. Sharpton and 22 others were arrested Monday after about 200 protesters blocked the inbound lanes of the casino city's main thoroughfare, the Atlantic City Expressway. Sharpton promised after his arrest to disrupt the pageant. The group had 100 tickets for the televised extravaganza Saturday, he said. But Sharpton said Thursday the group's quarrel was not with the pageant. ``As we confront the issue, let's not confuse the issue,'' Sharpton said. ``We feel it would be unfair to do anything contrary against other youth who are trying to develop themselves.'' Horn said Sharpton contacted him Wednesday. The men agreed Thursday afternoon that a demonstration was useless, Horn said. Youth leader Jason Sales, 16, said the protesters wanted only to dramatize the city's lack of a recreational center. The group refers to itself as the Forgotten Youth of Atlantic City. After the news conference, Horn and Sharpton closed the deal with a handshake. Horn then presented Sharpton with a handful of cigars, saying he had heard the New York City activist was an avid cigar smoker. Meanwhile, Miss Illinois Marjorie Judith Vincent won the last of three talent competitions and Miss Mississippi Beth Howell the last of three swimsuit competitions in the Thursday night preliminaries of the Miss America Pageant. The 50 Miss America hopefuls are divided into three groups, who compete in talent, swimsuit and evening gown divisions on three successive nights to qualify for Saturday's finals. Thursday was the last of the three preliminary competitions. The winner of the evening gown competition is kept secret to heighten the suspense for Saturday night's finals. Miss Texas Suzanne Lawrence won the first talent competition and Miss Colorado Karrie Mitchell won the first swimsuit competition in the Tuesday night preliminary. Miss North Carolina Scarlet Morgan won the second talent competition and Miss Florida Dana Rinehart Dalton won the second swimsuit competition in the Wednesday night preliminary.

Irish pop singer Sinead O'Connor breezed past American bombshell Madonna for top honors at the seventh annual MTV Music Video Awards, in a ceremony marked by a protest against censorship. The outspoken O'Connor took video of the year, best female video and best postmodern video for her stark ``Nothing Compares 2 U'' during the three-hour ceremony broadcast live Thursday night. Madonna's ``Vogue'' video won for direction, cinematography and editing. Madonna, dressed in an 18th century French costume bursting at the bust, performed a racy version of the video during the awards show. Ex-Eagle Don Henley beat Billy Idol and M.C. Hammer in the best male video category for ``End of the Innocence.'' But Hammer's ``U Can't Touch This'' won in rap and dance categories.

A judge's ruling has made it more difficult for an art gallery and its director to fight obscenity charges for displaying Robert Mapplethorpe's sexually graphic photographs, a defense lawyer says. Hamilton County Municipal Judge David J. Albanese on Thursday ordered the Contemporary Arts Center and director Dennis Barrie to stand trial Sept. 24 on one misdemeanor count each of pandering obscenity. Defense lawyers contend the 175-picture Mapplethorpe exhibition _ mostly portraits and pictures of flowers _ isn't obscene when viewed as a whole. But Albanese granted a prosecution request to let a jury see only the five pictures that depict sex acts. ``I'm disappointed but I'm not surprised,'' Barrie's lawyer, H. Louis Sirkin, said after the hearing. ``It certainly doesn't help us.''

The financial performance of banks in the Midwest, South and West showed improvement in the second quarter, while loan problems continued to grow in the Northeast and Southeast, government figures show. Nationwide, commercial banks earned $5.3 billion from April through June of this year, down 24 percent from the same period in 1989, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. reported Thursday. The FDIC said banks in the Northeast dragged down profits for the entire industry, which had earned a record $7 billion in the second quarter of 1989. ``It's not great, but it's not terrible,'' said Robert Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, a Washington research group. ``It's continued sogginess, basically.''

The leader of the nation's largest black church says racism in America is worse now than it was during the civil rights struggles of the 1950s and '60s. Former President Reagan and his appointments to the Supreme Court are a large part of the problem, the Rev. T.J. Jemison said Thursday at the 110th annual meeting of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A. Inc. ``He (Reagan) will be remembered not because he didn't have a memory, but he will be remembered because he gave respectability to racism,'' he said. Jemison, who led one of the first successful boycotts of segregated busing in Baton Rouge, La., in 1953, said race relations stand at a criticial point in the nation's history. He said he thought the battle to condemn racism had been won during the civil rights struggle, but ``it's worse now than it's ever been.''

Gun control supporters are calling for a nationwide ban on bringing firearms within 1,000 feet of schools, but federal officials say it would be virtually impossible to enforce. ``Passage of this bill will enable our children and their teachers to travel to and from ... schools without an overriding fear for their personal safety,'' Cleveland police Chief Edward P. Kovacic said Thursday. He urged the House Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on crime to approve the bill, which is similar to provisions included in an omnibus crime package already approved by the Senate. Bringing a gun within 1,000 yards of a schoolyard would be punishable by a maximum five-year sentence under the measure. The bill reflects growing concern over gun incidents on school grounds in recent years, including multiple slayings of youngsters by deranged individuals in Stockton, Calif., and Winnetka, Ill.

DOC.HEAD: Priesthood Continues to Attract in the New Poland
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: It is peaceful in the seminary, as it was through times of partition, before the communists and after they fell, and when rigid economics was left behind on the bumpy road to a free market. The only sounds reaching the office are the gentle swish of long black robes as priests glide across the marble floor in sandals, and the chirping of swallows that inhabit lush inner courtyards thick with ferns, red petunias and lavender geraniums. Priestly routine in Poland, one of only five countries where the number of Roman Catholic seminary students has risen steadily the last decade, bears little resemblance to the difficult, uncertain life on the outside. While the church generally faces a chronic shortage of priests, the number in this country rose from 20,234 in 1980 to 24,678 in 1989, according to the Polish Episcopate Office. That works out to one priest for 1,280 church members, compared with 1,650 members per priest in the United States. Burundi, Rwanda, Zaire and India are the only other countries with net increases in recent years. Church officials give many reasons young men are attracted to the priesthood in Poland, where more than 90 percent of the people are Catholics. Most obvious is a desire to follow the path of the Polish pope, John Paul II, whose image is displayed over shop doors, in cars, even on key chains. ``John Paul is beloved everywhere, but especially here,'' said the Rev. Szymon Stefanowicz of the Jasna Gora monastery in Czestochowa, site of Poland's holiest shrine. ``Is it any wonder young men want to be like him? He is such a good force in this world.'' Being a priest is a mark of prestige in Poland. Enrollment of a son in the seminary is as much a cause for celebration as an American child's acceptance into law or medical school. Although church officials stress the compulsion to answer God's call, some acknowledge the attraction also may be practical. Since World War II, families have had to wait decades for apartments, telephones and cars. Until the economic reforms of January, they had to spend hours in line for such essentials as milk and eggs. In contrast, seminaries offered secure housing, intellectual opportunities and a chance to travel outside the Soviet bloc. Several priests, who spoke on condtion of anonymity, said semimaries were havens of safety and comparative comfort through the bad times. Outside, the dangers of communist rule now have been replaced by painful aspects of the ``shock therapy'' economic plan. Inflation is more than 170 percent so far this year and unemployment, unknown under the communists, has reached 4 percent. ``In the West, children are born with everything: television, computers and cars,'' said Brother Marian Laskowski, a 24-year-old monk from Elblag in northern Poland. ``In Poland, we are born with very little.'' Laskowski said he chose the seminary because he is drawn to God, but admitted to occasional doubts. ``I see people come here wearing short sleeves and short pants, and I am spending the best years of my life between these cold marble walls,'' he said. The monk, dressed in a heavy robe, was tending a stand at St. John's Cathedral in Warsaw that sells icons and religious postcards. Brother Maciek Gaup, also 24, said his decision was made at an early age. ``Poland is a very spiritual country,'' he said. ``Our religion is very, very strong and old.'' Even when the communists were in power, Poland moved to the rhythms of the Roman Catholic Church. In the Soviet Union, those who worshiped openly faced persecution and the Orthodox Church was strictly controlled. In Poland, the church withstood the repression and becoming a powerful rival of the regime. During martial law in 1981-83, the pulpit was a bastion of dissent. The Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, the ``Solidarity priest'' murdered by secret policemen in 1984, is revered as a martyr. Worshipers fill churches each Sunday. Construction of religious buildings in many predominantly Catholic countries has all but stopped, but nearly 1,000 churches and other religious buildings have been erected in Poland since 1985. The Rev. Henryk Kietlinski, deputy superior of the Pallotines, one of the country's most popular religious orders, interviews hundreds of young men who apply for adminission to its seminary each year. ``Many of them are very excited about passing on the pastoral word in today's world,'' he said. ``Others want to give service to the world, and others are excited about the possibility of missionary work in other countries. ``Those who become missionaries are able to live abroad and learn other languages, promote culture in places like Brazil, Central Africa and Asia.'' Poland is one of the few countries with enough priests to send some of them abroad. Travel by priests was almost unrestricted under the communists, but they made it extremely difficult for most other Poles to venture outside the Soviet bloc. Now that Poland is democratic, a goal the church helped achieve, some Catholic officials fear growing Western influence will deter young men from the priesthood. Records and videos of Madonna, whose Catholic allusions the church calls blasphemous, are best sellers. Sex shops and pornography, once taboo, are cropping up in all but the smallest villages. ``More and more of today's youth is intellectually weak,'' Kietlinski said. ``This comes from thoughtless television shows, bad videos, poorly organized free time and bad family attitudes.'' The church, he said, intends to reverse the trend with a series of ``positive'' television programs developed by young priests. In August, the government announced the return of voluntary religious classes to primary and secondary schools, a move largely prompted by church officials.

DOC.HEAD: He Seeks Tomorrow's Blue Chips
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Lanyi and his researchers study as many as 30,000 earnings reports a year seeking what they hope will become blue-chip investments, but you won't find a single blue chip in their portfolio. The reason: Lanyi tries to detect the faint hue of blue before it deepens, to search out small, growing companies that seem destined to become high-quality stocks, to discover tomorrow's blue chips today. Somewhere out there are the new McDonald's or H&R Blocks or Automatic Data Processings _ companies that developed repeat businesses, that perfected repetitous production of products. Cookie-cutters products, he calls them. By the time Lanyi's choices are true blue and highly visible they might have been removed from his portfolio, sold for a very good price to the more traditional investors such as mutual funds. Replacing them will be other emerging companies, young outfits with good products, repeat business, good management and good profits. Some of these too will become A-one investments. Inevitably, others will fade. It's a lot of work for Lanyi, seven days a week, reading, talking with management, querying suppliers, and all to discover perhaps eight prospects a year. Hard work is part of the job, he says, explaining that as an immigrant Hungarian philosopher he was lucky even to get into the business. Sequent Computers, the biggest holding in the portfolio, was purchased in January 1988 at about $7.25, rose to as much as $34 and sold this week at about $24. Care Plus, bought at year ago at about $8.25, sold this week at about $18. Occupational Urgent-Care Health Systems, bought in March 1989 at $6.12{, sold this week at more than $20 after having reached a high of $27.25. Wide price swings are in the nature of such stocks, and it takes patience, information and nerves to stay with them. Lanyi has stayed with all these stocks, even though some are off sharply in recent weeks. After a one-day decline of $3, Pharmacy Management Services sold this week at about $8. Lanyi checked it out, found that growth rather than sales problems had cut profits, and decided to stick with it. He's an investor, he said, not a trader. The decline made him more aggressive, he said. That sort of confidence is based on knowledge of the company, he said, and Lanyi sometimes knows more about a company than some of its officers. Most of this research is done before he buys, but some is done afterward, too. To even consider a stock it must have a dominant position in its market; be undiscovered by Wall Street; be recession resistant; occupy a niche, such as home infusion therapy; and have earnings growth of 30 percent a year. Perhaps 300 of them meet the critieria. Lanyi and his researchers then telephone the company president, who might be invited to New York to discuss prospects over the next five or six months. About 100 get the invitation. At least five of the company's suppliers and 10 of its clients are then interviewed. Lanyi himself might even talk to the company's printer, asking how many boxes or brochures were being prepared, compared with an earlier period. If the printer says he is required to print more and more boxes Lanyi is pleased. He isn't pleased if the printer states, even enthusiastically, ``Yes, the company's giving us the same big order as they gave us last month.'' Hearing a response like that, Lanyi grows wary, and his research team is put to work even harder. Conceivably, it could be a sign that growth is topping out, a very early warning signal to sell. Why wait for the earnings report? Lanyi always tries to sell into strength, to sell before a stock levels off to just normal growth. Selling is the art, he says, even more so than buying. ``Take 1,000 brokers, 999 of them are poor sellers,'' he says. Operating as a division of Landenburg, Thalmann & Co., Lanyi and his staff handle more than 400 accounts, most of which began with an initial investment of $50,000. Lanyi makes the recommendations, the customers make the decisions.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Friday, Sept. 7.

DOC.HEAD: New ``Dracula'' Series To Make Transylvania Necker Family Fare
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Geordie in 5th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: For reasons known only to students of a full moon, vampire movies have Hollywood flapping these days _ at least five are planned. But TV also has a new Dracula in the wings. The syndicated ``DRACULA _ The Series,'' however, arriving Sept. 24 on 113 U.S. stations, is a little different from most versions of the Transylvania Necker. Its half-hour tales are being shot in the tiny duchy of Luxembourg _ yes, Luxembourg. And this Dracula is not quite like the pioneering Bela Lugosi movie model of 1931 that still keeps impressionists telling their children, ``Drrrrinnk your soooop beforrre it congealllssss.'' This Dracula, played by Geordie Johnson, is a ruthless European mogul who seeks global domination through his conglomerate empire. He's sort of like Gordon Gekko of ``Wall Street'' with a taste for type A positive. Perhaps he's the modern sort of vampire-businessman, hunting for a corporate takeover or a bare neck nearly 24 hours a day? ``Well, in our bible of vampirology, we've decided that he's found ways through modern technology _ sun block or whatever _ to operate during the day,'' said David Patterson, the show's executive producer. ``So he doesn't have to go off and hide in the crypt during the day. On the other hand, he has no vampire-like powers until the sun sets.'' Although Patterson's Dracula does wear a black cape now and then and develops the customary upper fangs when it's time to go for the gusto, traditionalists who see this mod version may say ``Oh, drat.'' They may say worse when they learn the other regulars in this ``Dracula'' include two American teen-agers who get caught up in things while visiting Europe with their mother. The lads team up with another regular, their Uncle Gustav, to battle the show's Dracula, who goes by the name Alexander Lucard. It helps that Uncle Gustav (Benard Behrens) proves to be from a long line of Dracula-chasers and has some inherited wisdom in this matter. Dracula, by Patterson's estimate, has been undead since the 1400s. The show specifies no European country as its setting. That it's filmed in Luxembourg _ the sort of duchy where occasionally you may hear Flemish spoken _ is due as much to lower costs as to Transylvania-like scenery that includes medieval castles, dungeons and caverns. ``The Luxembourg government has been going to great lengths to attract film and television production recently,'' said Patterson, whose production company is based in Toronto. The U.S. networks have no vampire efforts this season. Indeed, the last memorable network series about vampires, zombies and weirdos who howl in the night was in the halcyon season of 1974-75, when ABC aired the magnificent ``Kolchak: The Night Stalker.'' That series starred Darren McGavin as a wisecracking wire service reporter whose bureau chief kept spiking his amazing stories of life in the undead lane. ``That was an extremely well-done show, and one that we certainly were aware of during the course of developing this one,'' Patterson said. ``That's because we didn't want to be emulating anything that had been done.'' His ``Dracula,'' which has an order for 21 episodes, will be different in yet another way. It's intended for family viewing. That means no lingering shots of punctured aortas or a bloody-mouthed prince of darkness saying ``Fangs for the the memory,'' or whatever it is such princes say these days. There will be Dracula-caused departures, Patterson said. But ``we are sensitive to the fact that we can't allow the show to boil down to only blood-sucking and our heroes holding up a cross at the end of each episode.'' When the show's modern Dracula sips from his talking cup of life, he said, that will be alluded to ``but not graphically portrayed.'' ``We're talking family drama here. We hope we've got a show that parents will be happy to see, along with their 9- and 10-year-olds. . . . We want it to be a family drama, and we think it is.''

Elsewhere in television ... PUT ON A HAPPY FACE...OR THIGH: Shy, retiring talk show host Joan Rivers is starting the second season of ``The Joan Rivers Show'' today with the perfect contest for those who suspect they're not perfect. It is the ``Rivers Re-Do,'' a chance for viewers unhappy with their faces or bodies to win a free plastic surgery operation. To enter the contest, you must submit by Oct. 1 a videotape of yourself in which you address the vital topic, ``Why I'd like to look better.'' A panel that includes Rivers and a plastic surgeon will judge the tapes; five finalists will be chosen and the winner announced later next month. The show does not say what happens to the four losers. But maybe they will be allowed to appear in the new series, ``The Ugly Family.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Fri PMs, Sept. 10

For Release Tuesday AMs, Sept. 11, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Sir Bob Picks Up His Guitar and Plays
DOC.TEXT: Bob Geldof, musician, is back. Not St. Bob, the humanitarian of British tabloid headlines. Not Sir Bob, knighted by Queen Elizabeth in 1986, nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize that same year. Not author Bob, who's already written a best-selling autobiography, ``Is That It?'' And not businessman Bob, who oversaw millions and millions of dollars in contributions for the starving Third World. Geldof remains chairman of the board of trustees for Band Aid, although he says the organization will cease to exist fairly soon. But his main focus these days is ``The Vegetarians of Love,'' his critically acclaimed second solo album. This is no Boomtown Rats rock 'n' roll extravaganza; Geldof has instead assembled a mostly acoustic band featuring accordion, violins, flute, tin whistle, mandolin and ukulele. ``For me, I suppose, it's simply a reaction to stuff I hear on the radio which I don't like _ basically, house music and New Kids on the Block or Kylie Minogue,'' Geldof said in a recent interview. For the new album, Geldof enlisted an old friend _ ex-Rats bassist Pete Briquette _ and four traditional musicians he'd never met. They recorded 28 songs in five days; any song that didn't click after three takes was thrown out. Geldof improvised many of the lyrics on the spot. ``I came in on Monday morning, said hello to four guys I didn't know ... I'd bash out a song and say, `Right! OK, let's go,' '' Geldof recalled of the session. ``They'd say, `What do you want me to play?' I'd say, `Whatever you want to play.' They'd say, `Where do you want me to play it?' I'd say, `Wherever you feel its right.' And `When does the song finish?' And I'd say, `When it stops, it's over.' '' The spontaneity shows. On ``A Gospel Song,'' Geldof tells the band ``middle eight coming up'' during an instrumental break. Geldof asks at the start of another cut, ``Are we rolling?'' And at the end of ``The Great Song of Indifference,'' the entire band is heard laughing loudly. ``Indifference'' is already a Top 40 hit in Britain. ``The last thing everybody expected was this Irish pub song. And it became a big dance hit, you know? Thirteenth-century dance music,'' says Geldof, laughing. After almost a decade as front man for the New Wave-era Boomtown Rats, Geldof became a household name in 1984 _ by organizing the cream of British musicians to record ``Do They Know It's Christmas?'' and raise money for African famine victims. That was followed by USA for Africa's ``We Are the World'' and the internationally televised Live Aid benefit. For two years, Geldof met with heads of state and political power brokers; the scruffy Irishman was photographed with everyone from Nobelist Mother Theresa to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Geldof looks back on those days with pride tempered by the realization there was only so much that could be done. ``I mean, I never said we were going to stop world poverty or world hunger. I said it was a Band-Aid. `You don't put a Band-Aid on a gaping wound,' if I remember, was the quote at the time,'' said Geldof. ``That wasn't the function, to stop world hunger. It was to raise the issue to the top of the political agenda, and we did that.'' Geldof is still the nominal head of the organization: ``I'm the chairman of the board of trustees, which requires me to go to a meeting once every two months. In reality, the buck still stops here.'' But he says projects are winding down, and the end of Band Aid could come in 1992. ``We have a million pounds left, which is contingency, which we don't touch, in case there's an emergency or a shortfall on a project,'' said Geldof. ``When all that's finished, about two years, then we just close.'' So Geldof is back with his first love, music. He's not sure if ``Vegetarians'' will be his long-awaited commercial breakthrough, and he's aware that there's no immediate market for his songs on U.S. radio. ``So what if it doesn't fit? It's still music,'' says Geldof. ``For every 3 million people who love Bon Jovi, there's a quarter of a million who can't stand it. I'm not at all bitter. I'm sort of philosophical.'' The philosopher looks much the same as he did at Live Aid, except for the bit of gray in his unruly mop of hair. Geldof considers the music scene today, and he sees many of the same things flourishing which led to the punk scene. ``I feel a real sort of betrayal now when I listen to the radio. I understand that this is now a giant, monolithic industry, and I understand so many millions of people depend on their livelihoods for it, and they play it safe,'' said Geldof.

DOC.HEAD: Cheers for Saddam Widen Gap Between Arabs and Jewish Majority
DOC.TEXT: Children in this biblical Arab town used to copy stone-throwing Palestinians of the occupied territories in a game called ``Intefadeh.'' Now they play ``Burn the American flag.'' They are responding to what many adults in Kufr Kanna and other Arab towns in Israel have said since the U.S.-Iraqi showdown began: Saddam Hussein is a hero who will unite Arabs against the United States and its ally, Israel. Most Israeli Jews have been startled by such wide support for the Iraqi president among Israel's 800,000 Arab citizens. Liberals are disappointed and hard-liners cry ``treason,'' some even urging that Arab citizens be expelled. ``The Arabs in Israel are crossing a red line, support for an enemy who is threatening to annihilate half of Israel with chemical weapons,'' said Eliezer Tsafrir, Arab affairs adviser to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. ``We used to say the majority of our Arab citizens are loyal to the state. We must go on saying that, but I'm not sure any longer how accurate it is.'' Tsafrir said ``Saddamania'' was further weakening Jewish-Arab coexistence already hurt by Israeli Arab support for the 33-month-old Palestinian intefadeh, or uprising, in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Support for Saddam among Israeli Arabs springs partly from anger about their treatment by the Jewish majority. They were under military government until 1966 and, today, their communities get only about one-quarter the government funds given to similar Jewish towns. Moslem fundamentalism also plays a role. The fundamentalists are angry that American ``infidels'' have been sent into Saudi Arabia near Moslem holy places. A study by Givat Haviva, a left-wing Israeli think tank, found that Israeli Arab intellectuals initially condemned the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, but rallied behind Saddam when U.S. troops entered Arab lands. Outspoken support for Saddam is the rule in Kufr Kanna, a hillside farming town of 12,000 north of Nazareth that is believed to be where Jesus changed water into wine. Two weeks after Iraq's invasion, about 2,000 people marched through town, carrying banners with such slogans as ``Saddam, hit the Americans and Israel with chemical weapons.'' The marchers burned an American flag and pictures of Hosni Mubarak, president of Egypt, who has cooperated with the U.S. defense of Saudi Arabia. Omar Saeed, a leader of the nationalist Sons of the Village movement, said the demonstration inspired the children's game of pretending to burn makeshift American flags. Saeed, a self-proclaimed socialist, sees Saddam as a fellow revolutionary because he ousted Kuwait's oil-rich royal family. ``Saddam is leading the revolution of the poor; he is the Arabs' Robin Hood,'' Saeed, 30, said in the living room of his father's two-story home overlooking the town. He has an apartment in Haifa, where he is studying for a doctorate in pharmacology at an Israeli university, and said most of his Jewish neighbors call him a traitor. ``They are saying, `If you are with Saddam, you are against us,' but my professor said he would fight for my right to speak my mind,'' said Saeed, who spent four years under house arrest and six months in prison for nationalist activities. His 65-year-old father, Radwan, described Saddam as a savior fighting to unite Arabs, in the tradition of the late Egyptian president, Gamal Abdel Nasser. Radwan Saeed, who been under town arrest for 10 years because of nationalist activities, pointed to a picture of Nasser on the wall and said: ``Tomorrow, we'll have a picture of Saddam up there as well.'' Jews are shocked by such sentiments from Arab countrymen, who remained silent during Israel's wars with its Arab neighbors. ``I didn't expect to find them on friendly terms with such a dictator,'' said Yossi Sarid of the left-wing Citizens Rights Movement. ``Maybe they haven't digested deeply the democratic rules of the game.'' Conservative Israeli newspapers suggested the government crack down on Arabs supporting Saddam. ``No one asks that they identify with Israeli policy, but no state that values its existence can accept the identification of its citizens with an enemy,'' said an editorial in the daily Maariv. ``One does not play with fire.'' On the extremist fringe, U.S.-born Rabbi Meir Kahane of the anti-Arab Kach movement said Israeli Arabs should be expelled. ``I saw on television, how the Arabs of Kufr Kanna . . . our Arabs, good Arabs, faithful Arabs, marched in support of this dictator,'' Kahane said at a rally. ``Friends, if we want a common policy, it is `Throw the Arabs out'.'' Tsafrir said there were no plans for action against Israeli Arabs unless they broke the law, but noted that growing resentment by Jews would make it more difficult to redress the imbalance in funding for Arab towns. In Kufr Kanna, Mayor Aref Hamdan said Arabs were angry over ``separate and unequal'' policies under which a permit for building a factory had been denied. The town's unemployment rate is about 25 percent, more than twice the Jewish rate. Mohammed Abbas, unemployed after losing jobs in his field of biology and as a waiter, said: ``The Jews think we are weak, inferior people. We have to explain ourselves to them all the time, say that we are loyal to the state. They never explain themselves to us.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, Sept. 18

DOC.HEAD: Caribbean Back in Business, but Problems Persist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf `Two insurance' to include government guarantee, and 9th `The Education' to CORRECT figure to $43 million
DOC.TEXT: Purple and red bougainvillea are back in bloom, seaside resorts are open and cruise ships call again at most of the dozen Caribbean islands battered by Hurricane Hugo. St. Croix in the U.S. Virgin Islands and the British colony of Montserrat still are rebuilding, but elsewhere there is little remaining evidence of the worst storm in a decade, which killed at least 56 people and caused more than $2 billion in damage on Sept. 17-18, 1989. ``I think we've recovered better than expected,'' said Carl Mitchell, director of the Economic Secretariat of the seven-member Organization of Eastern Caribbean States in St. John's, Antigua. ``Initially, we had looked at the possible long-term effects and had indicated it was going to take three years before there would be full recovery,'' he said. ``But I think this may apply just to Montserrat. The recovery in the other islands has been quite startling.'' Nevertheless, Mitchell said, the hurricane caused a drop in economic growth rates and a sharp rise in the cost of living in Montserrat and the neighboring islands of Antigua, Dominica and St. Kitts-Nevis. On St. Croix, where one-third of the homes were demolished or heavily damaged by winds of up to 200 mph, life is returning to normal gradually. Two insurance companies went out of business, leaving more than $55 million in claims to 1,000 homeowners and 200 businesses unpaid. The territorial government has agreed to cover policyholder losses of up to $100,000 each, but hundreds of families are still waiting to have their homes rebuilt. One million cubic yards of debris has been cleared from the island and restaurants and stores in Christiansted, the main town, are operating. The landscape, once brown from defoliation, is greener now. The Education Department said all but one of the island's 10 schools were reopening for the fall term after repairs made with a $43 million federal grant. Thirty-three cruise ships are to resume port calls in October. Betty Sperber, president of the Hotel and Tourism Association on St. Croix, said 10 of the 15 major hotels would be open by then, but the other five were closing permanently. St. Croix's image as an American paradise suffered both from the hurricane's destruction and four days of looting that followed. President Bush sent 1,100 military police to restore order. They stayed for two months and the island was under curfew. Residents still have angry memories of news reports at the time about marauding gangs of blacks attacking wealthy whites with machetes. Police Chief Delroy Richards says more than 100 people, including some prominent residents, were arrested on theft charges but ``none of the cases can I say were racially motivated.'' ``I feel the looting is behind us,'' he said. ``People have condemned those persons who took items that were not needed.'' St. Croix, population 56,000, was by far the hardest hit of the three main U.S. Virgin Islands. It has received the bulk of $750 million provided to the territory by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, known as FEMA. Hugo also heavily damaged St. Thomas, whose population is about the same; sparsely populated St. John, and the neighboring British Virgin Islands, but all of them recuperated quickly. Puerto Rico, a U.S. commonwealth of 3.6 million people 70 miles west of St. Croix, returned to normal within weeks of the hurricane despite an estimated $1.3 billion in damage and lost production. Jose Bravo, the FEMA coordinator in San Juan, said 900 families still were living in temporary modular housing, mostly in northeastern Puerto Rico and on the offshore islands of Culebra and Vieques. He said FEMA provided $72 million to the commonwealth government for new housing but construction has been delayed by permits, contracts and land development. Only $1.1 million of $14.2 million raised for hurricane victims by a 12-hour simultaneous telethon in San Juan, New York and Miami had been distributed by the end of August, 11 months later. Luis Davila, administrator of the telethon fund, said all applicants should have their money within three months. She said the fund also would build 330 homes, all expected to be ready by Christmas. Montserrat, a small, pear-shaped island with only 12,500 residents 200 miles south of Puerto Rico, was all but flattened by the hurricane and remains far from completely recovered. Reuben Meade, the government's director of development, said about 90 percent of the island's 4,000 homes had been rebuilt and businesses had reopened in Plymouth, the capital. Electricity, water and telephone services have been restored and the two major hotels have reopened, he said, but roads need repairs, the port still uses a barge as its main jetty and little work has been done on government buildings. In Guadeloupe, which has 340,000 inhabitants and was the first island in Hugo's path, wood and corrugated iron is heaped in places and schools and houses still are being rebuilt. Franklin McDonald, director of the Pan-Caribbean Disaster Preparedness and Prevention Project in Antigua, said the French government responded quickly. ``There are still housing repairs being done, but to a great extent Guadeloupe is back to normal,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Sept. 17

DOC.HEAD: Without the Cold War Guidelines, East and West Test New Alliance
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In the chronic crises of the Middle East, the Cold War and its remnants always have shaped the moves and countermoves of the superpowers _ until now. In this crisis, the rules have changed. That shows in the sudden summit meeting between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. The framework of East-West struggle is gone. U.S. and Soviet leaders, whose predecessors bristled and charged aggression when one side or the other made or backed military moves in the Middle East, now are allied against the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Bush stressed the joint effort, not the limits and points of friction, as he headed to Helsinki for the brief summit he suggested about two weeks ago. Bush said there was no specific agenda for five hours of meetings on Sunday but, rather, a need for free-flowing, personal consultation on a wide array of questions, with the Middle East chief among them. European security, negotiations to limit conventional weapons there, and other issues are due for discussion, too, as are the economic strains facing Gorbachev at home. The Helsinki conference is a symbol of the basic changes wrought by the breakup of the Soviet bloc and the passing of the Cold War. That remodeling of the world political map outweighs and will outlast the current crisis and others that certainly will follow in the Middle East. It has been a cockpit of East-West struggle for the better part of 50 years and in a way, the Moscow-Washington rivalry disciplined the recurring conflicts. Each side backed client states to counter the other, and each side was able to rein its allies before their clashes escalated into a risk of superpower confrontation. ``There is no more East-West game,'' said Judith Kipper, a Middle East scholar at the Brookings Institution. ``It will make some people yearn for the Cold War, when there were rules ... '' Secretary of State James A. Baker III is proposing a new regional security system to seek stability and order in the Middle East, suggesting that there could be a long-term U.S. presence in the area as part of such a system. At the White House, Bush's spokesman said there was no way to know whether such an alliance might include the Soviet Union. In another era, the Soviet Union, Iraq's chief arms supplier, might have been able to restrain Saddam Hussein short of the invasion of Kuwait, another Middle East expert said. ``This is the first Middle East crisis in which the Soviet Union is essentially a secondary player,'' said Robert E. Hunter of the Center for Strategic and International Studies. Hunter, an aide and adviser to Democratic administrations and to a congressional delegation just back from the crisis zone, said Moscow is preoccupied with internal economic and political problems. But the administration has played up the Soviet role and even suggested that it might now reconsider economic aid to Moscow. The White House was conciliatory on other points, too. While the Soviet Union has cut off arms shipments to Iraq and joined the U.N. trade embargo, it still has about 193 military advisers there, among about 1,000 Soviet citizens involved in training and maintenance. Baker has called their role inappropriate and there have been congressional demands that the advisers be withdrawn. But White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater called it a marginal matter, since the embargo is working. ``There's no sense getting argumentative with the Soviets on this issue,'' he said. On such points, the rule is accommodation. ``A new foundation for world order is being built, and the spadework begins in Helsinki,'' Fitzwater said. The accommodating words are mutual. After a Soviet military leader complained that the U.S. buildup in the Gulf could get impede negotiations for weapons cuts in Europe, a foreign ministry spokesman disputed the idea. Gennadi Gerasimov said the U.S. deployment in Saudi Arabia was at the invitation of that government, in a legitimate response to the invasion of Kuwait. Only three years ago, Moscow was denouncing the U.S. naval operation to protect Persian Gulf tanker traffic as a move that threatened war. But that was the old order.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Sept. 9
