DOC.HEAD: A Look at the New Television Series on Saturday Nights
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf of ``American Chronicles'' review to CORRECT ``Contender'' to ``Chronicles''
DOC.TEXT: Here are capsule reviews of the networks' new prime-time television series on Saturdays:
DOC.HEAD: ABC
DOC.TEXT: No new series.
DOC.HEAD: CBS
DOC.TEXT:
``FAMILY MAN'' (premieres Sept. 22): Battling NBC's ``Parenthood'' for viewers, this wholesome new arrival could be called ``My Three Sons, One Daughter and No Laughs.'' It stars Gregory Harrison, late of ``Trapper John, M.D.'' Now he essays a harried, freshly widowed fire department captain left with three sons, two of whom are teen-agers, and a kindergarten-age daughter. He also has a kindly father-in law (Al Molinaro) in from New York to help him. This Southern California clan lives in a two-story Spanish-style home that appears to be the kind that costs maybe $300,000 more than a fire captain's salary could afford. But heck, maybe this smoke-eater works in Beverly Hills. But the fireman's writers appear to have burnt down, leaving this motherless family facing such emergencies as burnt pancakes, still-wet socks and absolutely no funny lines whatsover. Sure, there's a lot of warmth, and also a sad moment that leads to a release of pent-up grief by the youngest son. But ``Family Man'' is one of the season's most feeble entries. All you can say of it is that the actress playing the tiny daughter has a great deal of peewee charm and appeal. Said actress, Ashleigh Blair Sterling (why don't they call girls Julie any more?), is not yet double-digit in years. But she has a fine sense of timing and will probably do well in later years. She should not include ``Family Man'' on her dossier.
``E.A.R.T.H. FORCE'' (premieres Sept. 22, with Sept. 16 preview): Billed by its makers as network TV's first action-ecological series, this one proves why environmentally concerned Hollywood writers and producers should be banned as hazardous: They threaten the world with deadly clouds of earnest dialogue. The series is about a sort of ecological A-Team, funded by the spare-no-expense Earth Alert Foundation. The team is led by sturdy Gil Gerard. He plays a brilliant surgeon whose background includes Vietnam. The team has five members, one of them a beautiful woman. Four hold advanced degrees in such things as marine biology and anthropology. One even has a double major, nuclear physics and radical protest. The fifth, a raffish Australian, is a counter-terrorism expert who also owns a C-130 cargo plane, a helicopter, a cigar and a pair of driving gloves with the fingertips cut off. The modest goal of the team is to Save The Earth. In the show's preview, they're brought together _ by force in some cases _ by a wicked conglomerate president whose troubled nuclear power plant is approaching meltdown. No government intervention, no press, the mogul says. You guys take care of it and I'll fund your projects forever. The team discovers double trouble: The plant is missing two kilograms of deadly plutonium stolen during the approaching meltdown, and the meltdown was programmed by an insider but wasn't supposed to be for real. It is, though. And as for the plutonium, it to be sold to a mysterious Middle East country. This is bad enough, but the dialogue is even worse. Try this, about the potential effect of a nuclear meltdown: ``You won't see a deer or rabbit around here for the next 500 years.'' Or this, in which the industrialist's lovely aide describes a member of the planet-saving team: ``He's the one who threw sheep's blood on your limo in New York last summer ... even Greenpeace finds him too radical.'' At the finale, Gerard reports that ``we've lived on this planet for 50,000 years, and in the last 200 we've damned near killed it.'' Whereupon the team's staff radical comes right out and says: ``We've got to go after the slime that are dumping and polluting.'' He may be right. But if the two-hour preview written by Bill Corcoran is any indication, he'd show more real concern for the TV environment if he'd put ``E.A.R.T.H. Force'' inside a TV producer's heart.
DOC.HEAD: NBC
DOC.TEXT:
``PARENTHOOD'' (premieres Sept. 22): Based on the movie comedy of the same name, this one stars Ed Begley Jr. as a financial analyst who, with his college-educated wife (Jayne Atkinson), is raising a family of four. This effort is not a one-family adventure, though. There are three other families running loose here, all related. One includes a great-grandmother, the mother-in-law of Begley's dad, well-acted by William Windom. You'll probably like Begley's gruff old dad the best, if only because he often gives the impression there is nothing more he'd like to do than take a baseball bat and restore order in his gruff old way. The show's point seems to be that there's much warmth, heartache and confusion in family life. This is not hot news, and the monster cast tends to resemble a human gridlock that occasionally sits down to dinner. Matters could improve. The cast is good. But with less than 25 minutes to play with each week, the writers should be constantly advised of the excellent principle of K.I.S.S. _ Keep It Simple, Stupid.
``AMERICAN DREAMER'' _ (premieres Sept. 22; preview not available).
DOC.HEAD: FOX
DOC.TEXT:
``HAYWIRE'' (premiered Sept. 1): This follows ``Totally Hidden Video,'' and can be called ``Totally Dumb Television.'' It's full of the sort of stupid silly things people do when they get their first video camera _ only worse. Among other things, the opening show dispatched a staffer to Seattle to see what people would give him for free if he was from a TV show. The take included handcuffs, a monkfish and two blondes. Fox seems confused by ``Haywire.'' The premiere was hosted by Matthew Perry, a new graduate of the Bob Saget School of Home Video Show Hosting. But Perry is out now, Fox says, and Alan Hunter is getting a tryout. Hunter is identified as a former MTV veejay. If he is still around by next week, we will alert you by shouting ``Bingo!''
``AMERICAN CHRONICLES'' (premieres Sept. 8): This is a unique show by ``Twin Peaks'' makers Mark Frost and David Lynch, the good kind that appeals to ears and eyeballs alike. A beautifully photographed, impressionistic look at the sights and sounds of America, the first show, narrated by Richard Dreyfuss, examines Mardi Gras in New Orleans, from its humble beginnings in 1699 to the gaudy present. (The gaudy present here includes the baring of female bosoms 14 times in this year's French Quarter frolic. The baring is electronically blurred, but it's the thought that counts.) The video impressionism is nicely scored by Billy Barber, usually with a sort-of-classical music that goes from a whisper to a Wagnerian roar, with the morning-after finale done only with a wistful clarinet and banjo rendition of ``Till I Had You.'' True, the first video maestro of Americana was Jean Shepherd. His sardonic ``Jean Shepherd's America'' series on PBS in the '70s remains one of the best TV looks at the nation ever to come down the airwaves. But ``American Chronicles'' may prove a very close contender for second place.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Release Anytime

DOC.HEAD: Number of Black Farmers Dwindling; Farm Bill Would Address Their Needs
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of freed slaves were wooed to farming after the Civil War with political promises of ``40 acres and a mule.'' The pledge went the way of so many campaign come-ons. Still farming was a trade that many of the newly freed blacks knew. By the end of the century, minorities had acquired 15 million acres for farming. ``We never were given the 40 acres and the mule, but a lot of people were allowed to buy,'' said Ralph Paige, executive director of the Federation of Southern Cooperatives-Land Assistance Fund. But now the number of minority-owned farms is dwindling drastically, and members of Congress are trying to stop the decline. The 1990 farm bill includes provisions inserted by Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga., and Rep. Mike Espy, D-Miss., that give special attention to the needs of the minority farmer. ``I think the government should be concerned about all small farmers. They're the backbone of this country,'' said Paige, who lobbied for the minority farming language in the farm bill. ``Minority farms are a different breed. These are farmers who have the historical problem of discrimination.'' Only 4.5 million acres _ out 988 million _ are now farmed by minorities, Paige said. He attributed the losses among minority farmers to discrimination in credit, lack of access to markets and lack of knowledge about wills and other paperwork necessary to retain ownership of land. Years ago, the severe losses of minority farms were blamed on an outmoded sharecropping system. But in the 1960s, the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights found systematic racial discrimination in the Agriculture Department. In 1982, after noting that minority-owned farms were disappearing at 2.5 times the rate of white-owned farms, the commission recommended federal and state action to remedy the situation. The farm bill passed by the Senate includes more remedies for the decline in minority-owned farms than the House measure. A congressional conference committee will begin work this month to resolve the differences on these and other provisions of the farm bill. ``Minority farmers traditionally have received less federal assistance than their white counterparts, and have been more vulnerable to changes in agriculture,'' said Fowler. ``When they hurt, the communities around them hurt.'' From 1978 to 1987, the number of minority-owned farms declined 23 percent, while white-owned farms declined 7.1 percent, said Fowler. ``That means nearly one in four minority farms disappeared in just one decade,'' he said. Virtually all of this loss came from the ranks of black farmers, though minority farmers include Asians, Hispanics and American Indians, said the Rural Coalition in a report based on the 1987 Census of Agriculture. Nine out of 10 of the failed black farms were in the South, the coalition said. The coalition reported that while a third of the white farms receive direct government payments, less than half that percentage of minority farms do. ``A white farm is four times more likely to obtain a loan from the federal government's Commodity Credit Corp. than a minority farm,'' it said. Half of all white farms have sales above $10,000, but just 30 percent of minority farms have sales at this level, according to the coalition's findings. The House bill would expand outreach and education to increase minority participation in Agriculture Department programs. The Senate includes a similar provision, and also would: _Establish a national registry of minority farmers to monitor ownership. _Assign extension agents to areas with high population of minority farmers to involve them in existing USDA programs. _Create demonstration programs for minority youth and beginning farmers. _Direct the agriculture secretary to review the effectiveness of the current appeals process for discrimination complaints and affirmative action policies. _Review the impact of the Agriculture Department's purchasing and contracting policies on minority businesses. Espy has offered a separate, more far-reaching minority farm bill. It is unlikely to be acted upon this year.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Sept. 9, and Thereafter

DOC.HEAD: A Look at the New Television Series on Sunday Nights
DOC.TEXT: Here are capsule reviews of the networks' new prime-time television series on Sundays:
DOC.HEAD: ABC
DOC.TEXT: ``AMERICA'S FUNNIEST PEOPLE'' (premieres Sept. 16): This is the second half of ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' To understand this show, first you must watch Part I with host Bob Saget, a standup comedian who stars on ABC's ``Full House,'' the top-rated sitcom among children ages 2 to 11. The host of ``America's Funniest People'' is Dave Coulier, a standup comedian who also stars on the ABC sitcom ``Full House.'' Do you enjoy ``America's Funniest Home Videos''? Is it funny? Do you laugh at home videos of other peoples' pratfalls, misfortunes and stupidity _ even if a bit nervously? Maybe a bit guiltily? Don't feel bad. That's the appeal of these shows. It's a coarse, sometimes cruel brand of homemade slapstick. Call it the frontier humor of the Electronic Age. If you dislike ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' you probably will feel the same way about ``America's Funniest People,'' which features people doing Rodney Dangerfield impressions, making rude noises and performing strange stunts on demand. If you really dislike ``America's Funniest People,'' take solace that NBC's Brandon Tartikoff believes it will shorten the life of home video programming. If you really love ``America's Funniest People'' and can play ``God Bless America'' with your armpit, please contact the show's producers.
DOC.HEAD: CBS
DOC.TEXT: No new shows.
DOC.HEAD: NBC
DOC.TEXT:
``HULL HIGH'' (premieres Sept. 30, preview aired Aug. 20): ``Hull High'' threatened to be another empty-headed knockoff of the pretentious teen musical ``Fame,'' but turns out to be a bright, funny, musical comedy about a California high school that's beguiling from its first scene. In addition to superior production values and an excellent cast, ``Hull High'' is well-written and tightly edited. It's directed by Kenny Ortega, who choreographed ``Dirty Dancing'' and keeps things moving. ``Hull High'' opens with a house-dancing production number and introduces the four rappers, lads who function as a kind of Greek chorus to the action. Adults will enjoy a bilious teacher's jaundiced reaction to them. There's a lovely teacher (Nancy Valen) who can't understand why her male students don't seem to comprehend the material. The popular teacher (Will Lyman) sits in on her class, and his fantasy becomes a production number on the figures of speech. Simile and metaphor were never so well-danced. Then there's the student (Mark Ballou) who falls for the wistfully beautiful transfer student (Cheryl Pollak). Will the course of true teen love run smooth? Nah. Will they get back together? Go figure. ``Hull High'' is beautifully photographed, its music is melodic, and it keeps the teen-age angst at an acceptable level. It's fun to watch, filled with throwaway bits that are grace notes to the longer scenes. Its humor is suprisingly sophisticated and sometimes even subtle. ``Hull High,'' celebrates people who are young and alive and about 16 years old with nary a thought in their heads. It even admires the people who teach them.
``LIFESTORIES'' (premieres Sept. 30, preview aired Aug. 20): NBC has great hopes for this medical series, which looks at life-threatening illnesses from the patient's perspective. It's a clever idea for a drama and, given current American attitudes toward the medical industry, it's probably all for the best that this is not a doctor show. Judging from its pilot episode, however, the patient is in trouble. The episode is about colorectal cancer, America's second-most common cancer after lung cancer. Last year, colorectal cancer killed 61,000 Americans. It is preventable and, if detected early, has surprisingly high recovery rates. Introducing patients and their illnesses gives ``Lifestories'' an inherently difficult exposition. But writer Jeffrey Lewis resorts to a narrator, Robert Prosky, in the persona of an omniscient clinic founder. Prosky's know-all narration gives us the facts on colon cancer, explains peoples' motivations and generally intrudes on the story. It's so sentimental and superfluous that it actually ruins the story and the acting. In the first scene, the narrator introduces us to Don, a real estate developer who makes the putt of his life and raises his arms in triumph. Freeze frame. Cut to Don's gut, special effect, a sectional view, where a single cell has started its perverse multiplication. ``Lifestories'' promises more freeze-frame, cutaway views of central characters and their innards. TV characters walking about like medical textbook illustrations is not something to look forward to. The very talented Richard Masur plays Don. Lisa Barnes plays his wife, and Kieran Mulroney his son. The three create a real sense of how a family's dynamics are altered when cancer strikes it. Yet when these people create a mood, the narrator steps in and ruins it. As information, ``Lifestories'' is good. As entertainment, it is not.

``TRUE COLORS'' (premieres Sept. 9): It's difficult to believe groundbreaking can be done so tamely, or that the weblet which brought us the Bundys and the Simpsons would buy into this very mild sitcom about a biracial marriage. ``True Colors'' features Nancy Walker, fresh from the paper towel races, portraying an old-fashioned, domineering, wise-cracking mother-in-law. Is this a stretch for her as an actress, or what? Frankie Faison plays a dentist, the widowed father of two sons; his new wife is played by Stephanie Faracy (late of CBS' ``His and Hers''), a bubbly-sweet kindergarten teacher and mother of a teen-age daughter. The offspring are played by Claude Brooks as the elder son, a Joe Cool materialist; Brigid Conley Walsh as a naive, cause-minded liberal; and Adam Jeffries as a hip-hop-talking 14-year-old. This is the most well-adjusted group of human beings since the Huxtables of ``The Cosby Show.'' There's no real tension between the kids, the parents are wonderful role models and consequently nobody is particularly funny. Only once does ``True Colors'' obliquely refer to the tragedy that is its central theme, when the police come to the family home on a mistaken burglary call. Miraculously, nobody gets shot. It would be wonderful if racism would just go away. It won't, though, and there's no point in ignoring it simply because you're trying to do comedy.
``PARKER LEWIS CAN'T LOSE'' (preview aired Sept. 1, premieres Sept. 9): Well, maybe he can, but it won't be his fault. ``Not a problem,'' Parker says, repeatedly, in this winning high-school farce. Its writers, Lon Diamond and producer Clyde Phillips, have done their homework. Corin Nemec plays Parker, a bright, wholesome, basically decent teen-age lad you might trust with your sister _ until you found him promoting her for the minimalist page in Sports Illustrated's swimsuit edition. Parker's pastime, joy and full-time hustle is to exploit his fellow students, maximize profits and minimize the tedium of getting a high school diploma. Inevitably, these traits put him at odds with the principal, Ms. Musso (Melanie Chartoff), a dragon lady determined to get Parker expelled and yet helplessly unable to thwart his outlandish excuses, scams and schemes. The style of ``Parker Lewis Can't Lose'' is one of its most endearing qualities. People don't just move quickly, they WHOOSH. The school bully doesn't just stand, he looms like a mountain to the faint buzzing of flies. As it stands, ``Parker Lewis Can't Lose'' is a droll, delightful fantasy. If writers Diamond and Phillips put their minds to it, they could make this show the greatest high school sitcom since ``The Many Loves of Dobie Gillis.''
``GET A LIFE'' (premieres Sept. 23): What's the matter with a 30-year-old man who still lives with his parents and has a paper route? Absolutely nothing, provided the aging adolescent is played by Chris Elliot. One of the blither spirits to hit television, Elliott rose from the writing staff of ``Late Night with David Letterman'' to portray The Guy Under the Seats, The Fugitive Guy and other very skewed '80s-kinds-of-guys. His first venture into series comedy is pretty good stuff. He plays Chris Peterson, a guy who simply chose not to have a career and a full-time job. He just kept his old paper route and lived in his old room. His long-suffering parents are wonderfully played by Chris' real father, the comedian Bob Elliott, and the lovely June Lockhart. They rejoiced when their son said he wanted to move out. Then he moved into an apartment over their garage. Chris' best friend, Larry, is played by Sam Robards. Larry bought into the rat race and his frequent second thoughts about being a grownup make him easy prey to Chris' schemes and adventures. Robin Riker plays Larry's wife who has less than no use for Chris. ``Get a Life'' is about an immature, selfish, narcissistic Peter Pan who refuses to grow up and take life seriously. The frightening thing is that he may be right.
``GOOD GRIEF'' _ (premiere date to be announced; preview not available).
``AGAINST THE LAW'' _ (premieres Sept. 23; preview not available).

``FRESH PRINCE OF BEL AIR'' (premieres Sept. 10): An amiable but not memorable exercise. This sitcom has rap music star Will Smith as a street-wise teen-ager from a tough black section of Philadelphia sent to live with wealthy relatives in the posh Bel Air section of Los Angeles. His new family consists of his sympathetic aunt, her stuffy lawyer husband, three kids _ two of 'em teen-age twits _ and a butler who insists on calling the newcomer Master William. This clash of cultures has promise. But its opening round is tame, mainly because it lacks comic tension. Instead of being suspicious of his new surroundings and the inmates thereof, Master William is ceaselessly good-natured, impish and decent. The only time a point of view peeps out is when, in an angry exchange with his stuffy uncle (James Avery), he says: ``I remind you of where you came from and where you used to be. But you got soft. You forgot who you are and where you came from.'' There are a few funny moments in this look at the black upper crust in a predominantly white enclave. Example: Smith tells his preppy cousin Carlton (Alfonso Ribeiro) that Malcolm X is his hero, then asks the lad who he admires. ``My dad,'' the preppie says. ``And Bryant Gumbel. He's darned good.'' There also is a small surprise now and then, as in a closing scene, when Smith quietly picks out a passage of classical music on the piano. But they'd best put some more punch in this series, or ``Fresh Prince'' will quickly become stale sitcom.
``FERRIS BUELLER'' (premieres Sept. 17): This is a half-hour tribute to the proposition that anybody can write a realllllllly dumb sitcom. Based on the movie ``Ferris Bueller's Day Off,'' it mostly occurs in a Southern California high school, just like NBC's new ``Hull High'' and Fox's new ``Class of Beverly Hills'' and ``Parker Lewis Can't Lose.'' Like ``Parker Lewis,'' a distant sitcom cousin of ``Ferris Bueller,'' NBC's show is about a glib, charming student who aims to get through school with little work and much fun. He's much like, say, a network comedy development executive. Charlie Schlatter plays Ferris, a junior so cool he can computer-hack false attendance records, change the school menu or get a stretch limo for a ride to school. With the push of a remote-control button, he even can send his nemesis _ surprise, surprise, it's the forever-fuming high school principal _ plunging through a trap door on the opening day of school. The only thing Ferris Bueller can't do is get a funny script. Let us join hands now and pray for an end to sitcoms set in Southern California high schools. Or at least an end to sitcom writers who attended Southern California high schools.

``LAW & ORDER'' (premieres in October, date to be announced): Critics of longtime television producer Dick Wolf say he presided over the decline of ``Miami Vice'' as its producer and the demise of ``Hill Street Blues'' as its ``executive story consultant.'' He created ``H.E.L.P.,'' an action-adventure about a fictitious New York City fire-police-rescue unit, and it was last year's lowest-rated series. His ``Nasty Boys,'' a ninja-narco-SWAT action show, sank without a trace. Still, he persists, and may have found a winning formula with his latest creation, ``Law & Order.'' It's a police procedural for its first half-hour, starring the venerable George Dzunda and Christopher Noth as a couple of New York City detectives. They are patient, dogged, unglamorous and utterly believable. The second half-hour stars the distinguished Michael Moriarty as a hard-working assistant district attorney; Richard Brooks plays his colleague and Stephen Hill is the district attorney. The pilot episode has teads to a release of pent-up grief by the youngest son. But ``Family Man'' is one of the season's most feeble entries. All you can say of it is that the actress playing the tiny daughter has a great deal of peewee charm and appeal. Said actress, Ashleigh Blair Sterling (why don't they call girls Julie any more?), is not yet double-digit in years. But she has a fine sense of timing and will probably do well in later years. She should not include ``Family Man'' on her dossier.
``E.A.R.T.H. FORCE'' (premieres Sept. 22, with Sept. 16 preview): Billed by its makers as network TV's first action-ecological series, this one proves why environmentally concerned Hollywood writers and producers should be banned as hazardous: They threaten the world with deadly clouds of earnest dialogue. The series is about a sort of ecological A-Team, funded by the spare-no-expense Earth Alert Foundation. The team is led by sturdy Gil Gerard. He plays a brilliant surgeon whose background includes Vietnam. The team has five members, one of them a beautiful woman. Four hold advanced degrees in such things as marine biology and anthropology. One even has a double major, nuclear physics and radical protest. The fifth, a raffish Australian, is a counter-terrorism expert who also owns a C-130 cargo plane, a helicopter, a cigar and a pair of driving gloves with the fingertips cut off. The modest goal of the team is to Save The Earth. In the show's preview, they're brought together _ by force in some cases _ by a wicked conglomerate president whose troubled nuclear power plant is approaching meltdown. No government intervention, no press, the mogul says. You guys take care of it and I'll fund your projects forever. The team discovers double trouble: The plant is missing two kilograms of deadly plutonium stolen during the approaching meltdown, and the meltdown was programmed by an insider but wasn't supposed to be for real. It is, though. And as for the plutonium, it to be sold to a mysterious Middle East country. This is bad enough, but the dialogue is even worse. Try this, about the potential effect of a nuclear meltdown: ``You won't see a deer or rabbit around here for the next 500 years.'' Or this, in which the industrialist's lovely aide describes a member of the planet-saving team: ``He's the one who threw sheep's blood on your limo in New York last summer ... even Greenpeace finds him too radical.'' At the finale, Gerard reports that ``we've lived on this planet for 50,000 years, and in the last 200 we've damned near killed it.'' Whereupon the team's staff radical comes right out and says: ``We've got to go after the slime that are dumping and polluting.'' He may be right. But if the two-hour preview written by Bill Corcoran is any indication, he'd show more real concern for the TV environment if he'd put ``E.A.R.T.H. Force'' inside a TV producer's heart.
DOC.HEAD: NBC
DOC.TEXT:
``PARENTHOOD'' (premieres Sept. 22): Based on the movie comedy of the same name, this one stars Ed Begley Jr. as a financial analyst who, with his college-educated wife (Jayne Atkinson), is raising a family of four. This effort is not a one-family adventure, though. There are three other families running loose here, all related. One includes a great-grandmother, the mother-in-law of Begley's dad, well-acted by William Windom. You'll probably like Begley's gruff old dad the best, if only because he often gives the impression there is nothing more he'd like to do than take a baseball bat and restore order in his gruff old way. The show's point seems to be that there's much warmth, heartache and confusion in family life. This is not hot news, and the monster cast tends to resemble a human gridlock that occasionally sits down to dinner. Matters could improve. The cast is good. But with less than 25 minutes to play with each week, the writers should be constantly advised of the excellent principle of K.I.S.S. _ Keep It Simpltupid.
``AMERICAN DREAMER'' _ (premieres Sept. 22; preview not available).
DOC.HEAD: FOX
DOC.TEXT:
``HAYWIRE'' (premiered Sept. 1): This follows ``Totally Hidden Video,'' and can be called ``Totally Dumb Television.'' It's full of the sort of stupid silly things people do when they get their first video camera _ only worse. Among other things, the opening show dispatched a staffer to Seattle to see what people would give him for free if he was from a TV show. The take included handcuffs, a monkfish and two blondes. Fox seems confused by ``Haywire.'' The premiere was hosted by Matthew Perry, a new graduate of the Bob Saget School of Home Video Show Hosting. But Perry is out now, Fox says, and Alan Hunter is getting a tryout. Hunter is identified as a former MTV veejay. If he is still around by next week, we will alert you by shouting ``Bingo!''
``AMERICAN CHRONICLES'' (premieres Sept. 8): This is a unique show by ``Twin Peaks'' makers Mark Frost and David Lynch, the good kind that appeals to ears and eyeballs alike. A beautifully photographed, impressionistic look at the sights and sounds of America, the first show, narrated by Richard Dreyfuss, examines Mardi Gras in New Orleans, from its humble beginnings in 1699 to the gaudy present. (The gaudy present here includes the baring of female bosoms 14 times in this year's French Quarter frolic. The baring is electronically blurred, but it's the thought that counts.) The video impressionism is nicely scored by Billy Barber, usually with a sort-of-classical music that goes from a whisper to a Wagnerian roar, with the morning-after finale done only with a wistful clarinet and banjo rendition of ``Till I Had You.'' True, the first video maestro of Americana was Jean Shepherd. His sardonic ``Jean Shepherd's America'' series on PBS in the '70s remains one of the best TV looks at the nation ever to come down the airwaves. But ``American Contender'' may prove a very close contender for second place.

DOC.TEXT: Oil prices soared over $30 a barrel, reaching that plateau for the second time during the Persian Gulf crisis as traders bet that supply shortages will develop. Light sweet crude rose throughout a hectic day of trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, closing up $1.66 at $31.43 per barrel for October contracts on Thursday. Analysts attributed the surge to reports that supplies could be short this winter as well as a lack of any signs that the Middle East crisis could be resolved soon.

Commercial banks earned $5.3 billion from April through June of this year, down 24 percent from the same period a year ago, the government said. Banks in the Northeast dragged down profits for the entire industry, which had posted a record $7 billion in profits in the second quarter of 1989, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said Thursday. The financial performance of banks in the Midwest, South and West showed improvement in the second quarter, while loan problems continued to grow in the Northeast and Southeast, according to the FDIC report.

Contract talks between the United Auto Workers and General Motors Corp. are moving faster than past talks, a union executive said roughly a week before the pact expires. UAW Vice President Stephen Yokich told reporters Thursday that about half of the non-economic issues before negotiators have been resolved in tentative agreements. He declined to elaborate. UAW contracts with GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. cover more than 450,000 active workers and expire Sept. 14. A new UAW-GM contract, which would cover more than 300,000 of the employees, is expected to be used as a pattern for talks with Ford and Chrysler.

A federal appeals panel ordered government regulators to retake control of Franklin Savings Association on Thursday _ just hours after the thrift's managers had moved back into their offices. Operators of the largest thrift in Kansas were allowed back in the offices in the morning, after U.S. District Judge Dale E. Saffels ruled Wednesday that regulators had improperly seized the company. But the government obtained a stay Thursday afternoon from the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver. In response, Saffels ordered the Resolution Trust Corp. to retake control of the thrift.

A new corporation backed by the oil industry plans to spend $800 million over the next five years on a nationwide system designed to clean up the worst oil spills. The cost is three times the original estimate for setting up the Marine Spill Response Corp., but President John D. Costello said Thursday the increases were necessary to do the job. The company plans to construct five regional centers in areas where major oil spills are most likely to occur: the New York-New Jersey area; Port Everglades, Fla., north of Miami; Lake Charles, La., near the Texas border; Port Hureneme, Calif., north of Los Angeles; and Seattle.

American businesses plan to increase spending for new plants and equipment just 5.1 percent over 1989, the smallest growth in three years, the government said. Analysts said the Commerce Department survey, released Thursday, shows that businesses remain leery of a softening economy and worried about falling profits. The survey found businesses planning to spend $526.9 billion for expansion and modernization this year.

Atlantic Richfield Co. introduced its second less-polluting gasoline, a premium unleaded it said would burn cleaner and cost less than any competitor's. Arco Chairman Lodwrick M. Cook said Thursday the fuel will help prove his contention that cleaner gasolines, not fuels such as methanol or natural gas, are the best way to meet increasingly tough smog-control laws. The gasoline will cost a few cents more per gallon, but Arco plans to absorb the costs rather than passing them on to dealers, Cook said.

The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. said it will eliminate 1,180 jobs in Europe by mid-1992 in an ongoing restructuring effort that has cut jobs in the United States and Canada. The company also announced Thursday it expects to incur an estimated $51 million in after-tax charges in the third quarter to cover restructuring and environmental cleanup costs linked to production sites closed in 1986.

American oilmen heading to the Soviet Union at the behest of President Bush are prepared to share new technology that might immediately help the Soviets pump more oil, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher said. Fifteen chiefs of U.S. corporations and Mosbacher leave Saturday for a six-day round of meetings with Soviet officials about what kind of technical assistance the United States can give the Soviets on oil production, housing, transportation, food processing and telecommunications.

The stock market staged a broad retreat Thursday under renewed pressure from rising oil prices and intensified recession worries. The Dow Jones average dropped 31.93 to 2,596.29. The dollar finished mostly lower. Gold prices were higher. Grains and soybeans advanced. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher. Bonds were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Stock Exchange? U.S. Experts See Other Needs First
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: As the Soviet economy tries to switch from state-run to market-driven, the New York Stock Exchange is offering help in reviving an institution that flourished in St. Petersburg until the 1917 revolution. A trip to Moscow next month by NYSE Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. and other Wall Street leaders could help reshape the Soviet economy, but U.S. experts say it will be years before profit-taking and program trading become Soviet lingo. Before creating a place to swap stocks and bonds, the rigid central economy must be dismantled, economists said. State-owned firms must be turned into private companies and a banking system installed. The Soviets also must decide why they want a stock exchange: For worker ownership of newly privatized enterprises? To raise capital for moribund factories? For trading, speculation and profit-making? No matter what, it would be a long way from Lenin, who after the October revolution denounced the ``grasping, malicious, frenzied, filthy avidity of the moneybags'' inhabiting banks and exchanges. ``The minute you allow the stock of Soviet companies to be sold you have affected the way in which income will be distributed throughout society,'' said Paul Gregory, a Soviet expert at the University of Houston. ``You're dipping into very fundamental issues.'' As in other Eastern European countries, Soviet officials are pressing ahead. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, recently agreed on a plan for free markets within 500 days. Laws expanding private ownership rights and creating a banking system and stock market would be readied in the first 100 days. At Soviet invitation, the NYSE, the largest U.S. stock exchange, is holding a seminar in Moscow Oct. 8-10 on creating a Soviet exchange. Sessions will touch on operations, regulation and other issues. ``What we're going over to do is answer questions they have and share the experiences we've had the last 200 years in the evolution of our exchange,'' NYSE spokesman Richard Torrenzano said. The Soviets have history of their own on which to draw. A ``fondovaia birzha'' thrived in St. Petersburg, now Leningrad, from the early 1800s until Lenin seized all private assets in December 1917. The stock exchange building on Vasilii Island in the Neva River, now a naval museum, could be returned to its former use. Trading there occurred in many of the more than 2,000 Russian companies existing in 1914, as well as government and corporate bonds and foreign stocks. Russia was the world's largest debtor at the time, and bonds of its companies traded actively in Paris. Commodity exchanges abounded, with 82 in 1914, according to Thomas C. Owen, a Louisiana State University historian writing a book about companies in czarist Russia. The first was formed in St. Petersburg in 1703. Odessa had a grain exchange, Kiev a sugar exchange and Kharkov an iron and coal exchange. Economic need forced a brief and tightly controlled revival of commodity houses and companies in the 1920s before a total abolition by Stalin in 1928. The gap has made returning to a market system more difficult, scholars said. ``There is no culture of capitalism from which this generation can draw,'' Owen said Thursday. ``There is no cultural background for these European and American institutions.'' Hungary has the only functioning stock exchange in Eastern Europe, but activity there is slight. Poland has approved legislation creating an exchange and Czechoslovakia has said one will follow many other reforms. David Kemme, an economist at the Institute for East-West Security Study in New York, said a stock exchange ``is not the most important component. It's not even the most important part of capital markets.'' Before state-owned enterprises issue stock, their assets have to be fairly valued, presumably by commercial banks that could approve loans. Czechoslovak and Polish reform plans, possible models for the Soviet Union, called first for prices to be liberalized, allowing fluctuations and, therefore, markets for goods and services. State-owned enterprises then could be converted into joint-stock companies. The state could own 51 percent of shares, with the rest distributed to workers, the population at large or foreign investors. The ruble would have to be made convertible to attract foreigners, experts said, allowing its rate to fluctuate in relation to foreign currencies. Once commercial banks are able to assess companies' creditworthiness, the value of physical and intangible assets can be established and shares issued. ``For an investor, it's going to be very tricky,'' Kemme said. ``No one's going to have any clue what they're buying.'' There are other questions, such as whether the new economy would produce the kind of power elite the revolution sought to crush. ``They have to permit the possibility that some individuals will accumulate vast capital holdings in the means of production that were formerly owned by the government,'' said Judy Shelton, a research fellow at Stanford University's Hoover Institution and author of ``The Coming Soviet Crash.'' Tomasz Telma, an economist with PlanEcon Research Associates Inc. in Washington, said the sale of shares outside a company could be limited initially to stop foreigners or domestic parties from gaining too much control. ``The bottom line is to allow workers to purchase stocks in the company they work for but not sell too many to prevent effective management,'' Telma said. Shelton said Soviet leaders and citizens also must overcome the communist belief that a society of capitalists and workers is ``a recipe for exploitation.'' ``In the back of their minds I think the Russians will be receptive to the idea once they get over the stigma that this is capitalist,'' she said, adding that stocks may prove appealing because ``the people own the means of production.''

DOC.HEAD: Ho-Hum August for Retailers Prompts Predictions of Worse to Come
With PM-Retail Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: The specter of a sluggish Christmas season has retailers thinking conservatively and shoppers may find abundant holiday bargains as stores try to boost business during the industry's most important time of year. Major retailers on Thursday posted generally mediocre to poor August results. Analysts said retail sales could go into an extended slump for the rest of the year because concerns about U.S. involvement in the Middle East have made consumers, who already had economic worries, even more nervous about spending. ``I think that the retail environment faces a challenging Christmas season,'' predicted Jeffrey P. Luker of the Andersen Consulting division of Arthur Andersen & Co. Several national chains did adequately during the start of the traditional back-to-school period but overall the retail industry rang up sluggish revenue. ``I would say that the list of retailers reporting disappointing sales is growing,'' said analyst Jeffrey Edelman of Barclays de Zoete Wedd. ``We are in a consumer slowdown. And before it's over we're going to have more disappointments and that list is going to grow.'' He added: ``The bottom line is we are heading into a recession if we're not there already.'' Mindful of the economy's weakness and the negative impact that the Persian Gulf conflict has had on consumer confidence, retailers are planning to keep inventories as trim as possible in the months ahead. Most are cautious about how business will be during the Christmas season _ when they typically look to make 50 percent to 60 percent of their annual profits. ``Retailers are already cutting back on merchandise commitments as well as reducing expenses in order to protect profitability,'' said analyst Jeffrey Feiner of Merrill Lynch & Co. ``This will be another difficult Christmas for most retailers, marking the first time in awhile that we've had two poor Christmases back to back.'' The grim outlook for retailers could be good for customers. Shoppers may find merchandise marked down earlier than normal. A season of brisk promotional activity is expected as retailers pour on the hype to boost sales. But with inventories being kept lean, retailers may not need to be quite as aggressive in moving merchandise as they were last year, when financial problems at some chains triggered rampant price cutting. In any event, Feiner said Merrill Lynch has reduced its earnings projections for retailers and now expects average growth this year of 5 percent to 7 percent rather than 6 percent to 8 percent forecast previously. A few retailers bucked the trend in August. One of the exceptions was Wal-Mart Stores Inc., a rapidly expanding discounter widely believed to be on the brink of unseating the industry's two highest ranking retailers in size, Sears, Roebuck and Co. and K mart Corp. Wal-Mart posted a double digit gain in sales of stores open a year or longer, as it usually does each month. Called comparable or same-store sales, these results are considered the best guide to a retailer's health. They exclude the revenue that comes from opening new outlets. Total August sales for Wal-Mart jumped 30 percent from a year earlier while sales at stores operating at least a year were up 13 percent. Sears, the industry leader in terms of annual sales volume last year, experienced a modest improvement in August from recent past months but sales still were only so-so. Total sales rose 4.7 percent from August of last year while same-store sales were up 4.1 percent. Discounter K mart Corp., the second largest U.S. retailer, said parents shopping for clothing and merchandise for the new school year helped offset softness in electronics and other categories of expensive goods. On a comparable store basis, K mart's sales edged up 1.6 percent. Total K mart sales, including stores opened in the past year, grew 11.1 percent. Sales this year looked particularly poor for some retailers because they were compared to robust levels in August 1989. J.C. Penney Co., for instance, said its store and catalog sales for the four weeks ended Sept. 1 slid 1.2 percent from a record amount in the corresponding 1989 period. Sales at stores open a year or longer slumped 2.4 percent. Penney Chairman William R. Howell said the retailer was up against a strong 1989 performance when Penney led all department store chains with a 14.4 percent increase in same-store sales, the largest monthly gain for all of 1989. There was evidence in the numbers Thursday that new fall fashions haven't captivated shoppers. A leading specialty apparel chain, Limited Inc., often regarded as a barometer of the response to styles in women's clothing, said its same-store sales inched up just 1 percent. Total August sales at Limited rose 14 percent. By contrast, specialty apparel chain Gap Inc. had brisk August business. Total sales grew 24 percent while comparable-store sales gained 14 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Prodigy, the Sears-IBM Home Computer Venture, Goes Nationwide
DOC.TEXT: Prodigy, the home computer information service owned by IBM and Sears, says it hopes to gain a million subscribers by the end of 1991 and start turning a profit in a few years. But some industry analysts are skeptical. Similar computer-based home shopping and information services with nearly as powerful backers failed to catch on and were closed in recent years. On Thursday, Prodigy announced it was available nationwide except Alaska. The service says it already has about 465,000 members in 42 major cities, and now will be available in most areas. Prodigy is losing money, but it should turn a profit in ``the early 1990s,'' said its president, Theodore Papes. He declined to discuss specific financial figures. Analysts estimate the 50-50 investment in Prodigy by International Business Machines Corp. and Sears, Roebuck and Co. at $500 million to $800 million. Among Prodigy's 900 services are news, sports scores, weather reports, children's stories and other features, as well as commercial services such as discount stock trading, airline ticket purchasing and home shopping through Sears, J.C. Penney Co. and other retailers. Prodigy also offers a messaging service between members, and on Thursday added several new services, including an encyclopedia. Nearly every Prodigy ``page'' has an ad at the bottom, making it the only advertiser-supported computer service. Papes said ad revenue helps limit subscription costs and eliminates the need for the per-minute charges levied by some competitors. Prodigy costs $9.95 a month on an annual subscription basis and $12.95 on a month-to-month basis. Subscribers also need Prodigy software, at $49.95; the right kind of computer, such as an Apple Macintosh or IBM or compatible models; and a modem, the device that connects a computer to the telephone. Prodigy sells a modem and software package for $179.95. Prodigy says it has about 200 advertisers, including the retailers and banking services available on the system. Prodigy was launched two years ago. By that time, CBS Inc., one of the original partners, had pulled out. Since then, it says it has been the fastest-growing computer information service. Prodigy's chief competitors are CompuServe Information Services, which is owned by H&R Block Inc., General Electric Co.'s GEnie, and Quantum Computer Services, said Joshua Harris, president of Jupiter Communications Co., a New York research firm that follows the database industry. Harris said both CompuServe and GEnie are highly profitable, in part because they have invested much less and have fewer employees than Prodigy, which employs about 1,300 workers. CompuServe, the largest computer service at over 600,000 members, is aimed more at computer buffs than Prodigy, Harris said. That could work in Prodigy's favor since it is attracting more female users that CompuServe, and women do more shopping than men, he added. Harris said it would be difficult for IBM and Sears to win back their investment. As to Prodigy's growth prospects, he said, ``There's a finite pool of people with PCs and modems.'' He also said that with current personal computer technology, it takes more time to get at certain data in Prodigy, such as weather reports, than it would to turn on the TV to an all-weather cable channel. Prodigy executives say one of the biggest hurdles they face is getting customers to try the service. There is a lack of knowledge of what it provides among the 20 million U.S. homes with computers. IBM is helping boost Prodigy awareness by packaging it with its new home computer line, the PS-1, which it launched in June. Similar so-called videotex services offered by two newspaper companies, Knight-Ridder Inc. and Times Mirror Co., were closed in the past few years after their parent companies grew discouraged with their prospects. While Prodigy is an information service, its success may lie in its value to advertisers, analysts say. ``Prodigy is an extremely powerful marketing tool,'' says a report from Yankee Group, a Boston-based research firm, because it allows advertisers to know exactly how many people are reading their ads and, in many cases, provides demographic information on the viewers.

DOC.HEAD: OTS Expands Charges Against Spiegel, Opens Hearings to Public
DOC.TEXT: Regulators have expanded their charges against Thomas Spiegel, a former thrift executive who had ``survival chamber'' bathrooms with bullet-proof glass installed in the company's new headquarters. The Office of Thrift Supervision announced Thursday that it added a new charge to its accusations against Spiegel, who had earlier been accused of squandering $19 million. The thrift agency's latest accusation says Spiegel caused a $29.2 million loss to Columbia Savings & Loan Association from the construction of a new headquarters ``without any attempt to limit costs.'' The new building included a large multi-level gymnasium and the ``survival chamber'' bathrooms that also had an independent air and food supply, the OTS said. Columbia, which is trying to sell the building, has removed the gymnasium and the survival chambers. The building cost Columbia more than $54.7 and has a market value of around $24 million, according to the OTS. It was not possible to remove the top-quality limestone and marble, stainless steel floors and ceiling tiles, leather wall coverings and other accoutrements ordered by Spiegel, according to the regulators' latest catalog of S&L excesses. In a related development, the OTS said it has decided to open to the public hearings on the charges against Spiegel and Charles H. Keating Jr., a key figure in the savings and loan crisis. Nearly all the documents related to those two proceedings also will be made public, the agency said. ``The American taxpayer will be best served by open hearings in these cases,'' OTS Director Timothy Ryan said in a statement. ``With accurate reporting by the news media, Americans will have the opportunity to understand the importance of both of these enforcement actions by the agency.'' Spiegel was the chief executive officer of Columbia, a troubled thrift based in Beverly Hills, Calif. In late July, Columbia agreed to sell its high-risk junk bonds for $3 billion to a Canadian-led investment group. Regulators had allowed Columbia to continue operating even though it was insolvent while its managers tried to find a buyer for the bonds. The new charge has been added to the regulators' previous allegations that Spiegel breached his duty to Columbia's shareholders and showed a ``reckless disregard'' for the law that resulted in excessive personal enrichment. The OTS alleges that Spiegel used Columbia's funds to pay for trips he took with members of his family to, among other places, London; Rome, Milan and Bologna, Italy; Frankfurt and Munich, West Germany; and Zurich, Switzerland. On four trips alone, Spiegel charged to the thrift around $70,000 in hotel bills and other expenses that were unrelated to business, according to an OTS document. Spiegel also spent at least $91,000 of Columbia's money to buy about 80 guns, including Uzi submachine guns, rifles, revolvers, automatic pistols and shotguns, as well as ammunition and accessories. The OTS has been seeking to bar Spiegel from the financial institutions industry, and to recover $19 million from him for restitution and a civil penalty of $5 million. The $19 million in restitution would go to Columbia, while the $5 million penalty would be paid to the Treasury. The total of $24 million represents the largest civil case ever brought against an individual by thrift regulators. The regulators accused Spiegel in July of squandering $19 million on various ventures, some in partnership with his friend and financial ally, junk bond pioneer Michael Milken. Spiegel angrily denied the charges, which the OTS made in a civil lawsuit. Under Spiegel's direction, Columbia had the thrift industry's largest portfolio of junk bonds. On Wednesday, the Justice Department announced that Keating had agreed to give notice of any large transactions and not to transfer assets out of the country. Those terms had previously been imposed on Keating by the U.S. District Court in Los Angeles. Keating recently provided financial disclosure statements to the regulators, but they will not be made public as part of the move announced Thursday, an OTS spokesman said. The government's case against Keating stems from the collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., which Keating controlled and has been accused of looting. Regulators estimate the failure may cost taxpayers $2 billion, ranking with Miami's CenTrust Bank as the costliest S&L failures. The OTS has partially frozen Keating's assets in connection with its efforts to recover $41 million from him and five associates. Keating denies any wrongdoing. His case has attracted particular attention because of his $1.3 million in contributions to the campaigns of five senators: Republican John McCain of Arizona and Democrats Alan Cranston of California, Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and John Glenn of Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: GM-UAW Talks Progressing Well with a Week Left
DOC.TEXT: National contracts between the United Auto Workers union and the Big Three automakers expire a week from today, and talks are going well at the largest of the automakers, union and company officials say. UAW Vice President Stephen Yokich, directing the union's bargaining team with GM, said Thursday that talks with GM are progressing faster than past contracts. He said negotiators would begin ``burning the midnight oil'' today and that weekend bargaining sessions were likely. Late last month, the union chose GM as its bargaining target in talks with GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. UAW contracts with the three automakers cover more than 450,000 active workers. Each expires at midnight Sept. 14 _ one week from today. If things go as the union plans, a contract ratified by GM workers will be used as a pattern for agreements with Ford and Chrysler. ``I think we are right down to the hard stuff now,'' Yokich told reporters Thursday. ``I think we're way ahead of any past schedules.'' He said company and union negotiators have reached tentative agreements on about half of the non-economic issues before them. Typically, economic issues, including wages, time off and job security, are left for last. GM spokesman John Maciarz declined to estimate how far bargaining on non-economic issues has progressed other than to say: ``We're still making good progress. ``The members of the (GM negotiating) committee like where they are at this point of negotiations.'' There has been a calm air surrounding the UAW-GM negotiations this year. The only evidence of contention has come from bargaining on contracts at the 155 UAW locals at GM factories. Last month, the UAW staged a six-day strike at a parts plant in Flint that resulted in shutdowns at seven assembly plants and partial or complete shutdowns at more than a dozen component plants. The walkout was settled when union members ratified a contract guaranteeing more than 2,500 jobs for six years.

DOC.HEAD: Fifteen in Four States Charged in Penny Stocks Scams
DOC.TEXT: Two defunct penny stock brokerages and 15 individuals in four states have been charged by federal regulators with a series of schemes that netted $20.7 million from investors in high risk securities. The Securities and Exchange Commission brought charges Thursday against Power Securities Corp., a Las Vegas-based brokerage that went out of business in February 1989, and seven of its officers and employees. The SEC civil action, filed at federal court in Denver, also charged Allied Capital Group Inc., an Englewood, Colo. firm that ceased operations in November 1989, and six officers and employees. The SEC charged that the two firms had a secret working relationship in violation of federal securities law. Meanwhile, two other former Power employees have settled civil charges with the SEC _ one of them agreeing to a 15-month suspension from the securities industry. Penny stocks are low-cost, high-risk securities that are usually not traded on any stock exchange. Information about their price and performance is often sketchy and difficult to come by, making them ripe for fraud schemes. State securities regulators have estimated that American investors lose up to $1 billion a year on penny stock fraud. The SEC charged that between late 1987 and the fall of 1988, various defendants excessively marked-up the price of stocks sold through dealers, engaged in insider trading, manipulated the market for securities of New York-based Star Publications Inc. and Denver-based Art Cards Inc. Not all of the individual defendants were charged in each alleged scam. The SEC lawsuit seeks a total of $1 million in restitution and $3 million in fines from Power, Allied and three individuals: Power's board chairman, Richard T. Marchese, 30, of Las Vegas; Allied's former president, Barry H. Freedman, 38, Parker, Colo.; and Joseph V. Pignatiello, 43, Englewood, Colo., the head of a financial consulting company. The SEC lawsuit also seeks a court order requiring all defendants to pay back all illegal profits and losses avoided through their alleged illegal activities. The SEC announced that Toni S. Allen, 40, of Las Vegas, a former Power account executive and Joseph M. McDonough, of Denver, the firm's former vice president of finance and compliance, settled civil charges without admitting or denying wrongdoing. McDonough agreed to be barred from the industry for at least 18 months.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: $2.6 million in lede is CQ
DOC.HEAD: Ex-ABB Board Member Linked to Insider Trading Scheme
DOC.TEXT: U.S. securities regulators have charged a former director of ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. with making $2.6 million in illegal trading profits on inside information about the Swedish-Swiss company's acquisition of Combustion Engineering. Christian Norgren was accused in a civil complaint Thursday of illegal insider trading in Combustion Engineering securities through his company, Finacor Anstalt, a Liechtenstein-based financial services company. Norgren, a Swedish citizen living in Liechtenstein, allegedly used confidential information about the then-upcoming $1.6 billion deal to buy Combustion Engineering common stock and call options contracts. A call option contract is an agreement to buy 100 shares of a stock at a later datt price. It is a trading strategy used by investors betting a stock's price will rise sharply. The Nov. 13, 1989 announcement of ABB's takeover offer for Combustion Engineering at $40 per share drove the Stamford, Conn.-based company's stock up more than $13 per share. Thursday's charges were the latest in a Securities and Exchange Commission crackdown on alleged insider trading by foreign companies and individuals. Thursday's complaint, filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission at federal court in New York, amended earlier charges brought late last year against Finacor Anstalt. Last December, a federal judge froze about $3 million of Finacor Anstalt's U.S. assets. A New York attorney representing Finacor Anstalt called the amended complaint ``an unwarranted effort to expand the charges in this case.'' ``This case should have been settled long ago and could have been, had not the commission adopted a rigid agenda unrelated to the merits of this action,'' said Finacor attorney Thomas E. Engel, adding that Finacor has tried to resolve the matter without loss to Combustion Engineering share and options holders. In addition to Norgren and Finacor Anstalt, the SEC action also charges unidentified persons or entities who bought Combustion Engineering call options contracts through an account in the Grand Cayman Islands of the Caribbean and an account with an unidentified Luxembourg bank. In a related case, a Rancho Mirage, Calif. agri-businessman settled SEC charges that he aided Norgren's alleged illegal trading. Howard P. Marguleas, head of a private agricultural concern, settled _ without admitting or denying wrongdoing _ a separate civil complaint that he bought 200 call option contracts for Norgen in November 1989. The SEC said Marguleas tried to reverse the transaction and refused to pay for the securities after the tender offer was publicly announced. The $229,000 in trading profits reverted to a brokerage error account and as part of the settlement, Marguleas asked that the firm release the funds to the court, said his attorney, Alexia Morrison. ``There was never any intent that Howard going to benefit from this. It was a trade made as a favor to Christian (Norgren),'' she said, adding ``Howard was a victim here.''

DOC.HEAD: Financial Company Chairman Fellheimer Quitting
DOC.TEXT: The chairman and chief executive of Equimark Corp., Alan S. Fellheimer, is resigning from those posts. The troubled bank holding company announced Thursday that Fellheimer, 47, will return the practice of law. He will continue to serve as a director after his resignation becomes effective. ``I am leaving because Equimark now needs steady, day-to-day management and I find more personal satisfaction in crisis and turnaround management and the problem solving associated with the practice of law,'' Fellheimer said in the statement. The announcement follows the May 29 resignation of Fellheimer's wife, Judith, as Equimark vice chairman. Shortly after that move, Claire Gargalli resigned as company president. Equimark has reported losses of $31 million in the first half of this year, and the company announced Tuesday it was suspending dividend payments on its common stock. But a company official said Thursday that Fellheimer's resignation was not connected to the company's financial situation. ``It was very much a personal choice on Alan's part,'' said Libby Fishman, Equimark's executive vice president and general counsel. ``He will remain available during an orderly transition period.'' Fellheimer was named to lead Equimark in 1985 after joining the $3.5 billion company as a director the previous year. At the time, federal regulators were threatening to shut down the bank. ``Equimark now has in place marketing, operating, credit quality and expense-containment plans necessary, which will serve as the basis for the company's new strategy, and return to profitability,'' Fellheimer said. Part of the bank's recovery is due to a personal investment by Fellheimer and his wife of $9.5 million in Equimark. The purchase gave the Fellheimers a 10 percent stake in the company. Equimark said Fellheimer has no plans to make a ``significant change in his equity position'' in the company. The Equimark board of directors has established a committee to find a successor for Fellheimer. David Gardner, a director, will chair the committee. Equimark's principal subsidiaries include Equibank, Liberty Financial Group Inc., EquiManagement Inc. and Treasure Valley Bancorp Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Government Regains Control of Franklin
DOC.TEXT: The federal government again has control of Franklin Savings Association. Just six hours after the thrift's managers moved back into their offices Thursday, a federal appeals court temporarily set aside a court order issued Wednesday that had returned Franklin to its owners. U.S. District Judge Dale E. Saffels had ruled Wednesday that regulators improperly seized the thrift, the largest in Kansas. The appeals court's stay does not overturn Saffels' order, but sets it aside for an undetermined length of time. In response to the order issued by the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver, Saffels ordered the Office of Thrift Supervision to reinstate the Resolution Trust Corp. as conservator in charge of Franklin. The court made no comment on Saffels' decision. ``The reaction is this is an order of the court and obviously we'll comply,'' said Roger Stanton, an attorney for Franklin. ``Ernie (Franklin Chairman Ernest Fleischer) had a nice day seeing employees and customers. They were all happy to see him back.'' The OTS seized control of Franklin, based in Ottawa, Kan., last February in a dispute over whether it was being managed prudently. It placed Franklin under management of the RTC, the agency formed to sell or liquidate insolvent thrifts. Franklin's officers sued to regain control of the thrift, and Saffels held in a 93-page opinion made public Wednesday that the government seizure was arbitrary and capricious and had no basis in law. OTS attorney Harris Weinstein in Washington reiterated Wednesday after the ruling that the federal agency believes Franklin had insufficient capital and was being operated unsafely before it was seized. Fleischer was talking to an employee in the thrift's Overland Park office when he received word of the stay on Thursday. He said it was not a setback. ``The important steps are the district court decision and the appellate court decision,'' he said. ``You might want to think of this in terms of the reverse. Let's suppose the OTS had won this case. I would much rather have a district court victory and allow the appellate court whatever time it needs.'' But he said he thought the sudden shift in control hurt several groups. ``We do not believe that the change of control from the government to the management and back again to the government is good for the employees, the public or for anyone,'' Fleischer said. Steven Dimmick, an OTS attorney, said the stay did not mean the fight between Franklin and the government agency was over. The government filed a notice of appeal with the appeals court Thursday but has not yet presented its case to overturn Saffels' decision. Stanton said he anticipated it would take the court a week to two weeks to review the case. An OTS statement said its director, T. Timothy Ryan, reinstated the RTC as a conservator to retake control of Franklin on Thursday night. Fleischer and other board members had met with officials from the RTC Thursday morning, the deadline Saffels had given regulators to return the thrift. ``We waited for a couple minutes and then the order came in from Timothy Ryan to return the thrift to us, and that's what they did,'' said John Scowcroft, president of Franklin's holding company. Government attorneys filed a motion with the appeals panel shortly after the deadline asking for a stay. Earlier Thursday morning, Saffels had denied a similar request for a stay.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Departs, Leaves State to Insurgent Lieutenant Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Dukakis arriving in Germany. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `I think...'. SUBS 16th graf, `Now the...', to add today's unemployment rate. Minor editing throughout. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BX1, BX2
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis arrived in Germany today on a trade mission, leaving Massachusetts to an insurgent lieutenant governor who threatened to seize control of the state's ailing finances while he's gone. Dukakis allies doubted that Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, lagging in the Democratic primary to succeed her boss, can do anything in her week as acting governor to solve a fiscal crisis more than 2 years old. ``She's elevated Murphy's Law to an art form,'' said Stephen Crawford, a Dukakis spokesman. ``Whatever can go wrong, she'll make sure goes wrong.'' Murphy said Dukakis and his aides are overreacting. ``I don't understand what he's afraid of,'' she said Thursday. Dukakis delayed his trip after Murphy said she intended to take over state government and push secret financial plans once he left. He eventually decided to go. He arrived in Berlin this morning, his office said. ``I think the episode of the past 24 hours is really kind of pathetic,'' Dukakis told reporters before boarding his plane. Dukakis is scheduled to return Sept. 14, four days before the primary election. He said he could cut short his trip if anything happened that affected the government's stability. In Massachusetts, the lieutenant governor is elected independently of the governor. Murphy was a strong supporter of Dukakis in his 1988 bid for the presidency but has been at odds with him before. ``There's no good will here and certainly no mutual respect,'' Murphy said. She said she was treated with disrespect Wednesday in telephone conversations with Dukakis and his chief of staff, S. Stephen Rosenfeld, who demanded that she disclose her plans. She said she would disclose the plans today. ``To see the kind of overreaction by him and by his staff, this kind of wildness, I don't understand,'' Murphy said. Dukakis bitterly denounced Murphy, saying she was using a political maneuver designed to gain favor with voters in her gubernatorial bid. Murphy is well behind her two opponents in the Sept. 18 Democratic primary, according to recent polls. Before this week, she tried gently to dissociate herself from Dukakis, claiming she warned him in writing in the spring of 1988 that the state was headed for trouble. The state had one of the nation's strongest economies during much of the 1980s, a fact Dukakis touted in his presidential bid. But by the time he returned after losing to George Bush, the economy had begun slipping. Now the state has the lowest bond ratings in the country. And just today, the federal Labor Department announced that the state's unemployment rate in August soared to 6.7 percent, up from only 4.1 percent a year ago. The national rate stands at 5.6 percent. The Legislature has approved three tax increases, including one this year that is the largest in state history. Lawmakers this year also ordered $265 million cut from the state's $13.4 billion budget; Dukakis, learning that tax revenues were below expectations, on Tuesday ordered his Cabinet to make an additional $150 million in cuts. Murphy insisted quicker action was needed, but she didn't immediately give specifics. Murphy's actions caused a defection within her ranks. William Currier, a campaign coordinator, resigned this week because of her moves against Dukakis. Currier dismissed Murphy's maneuver as ``show bizzy.'' ``It's almost an attempted bloodless coup,'' he said.

Stock prices drifted lower today, registering some disappointment over the latest news on employment. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 8.91 to 2,587.38 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 8 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 311 up, 486 down and 482 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 15.45 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said the Labor Department's report for August on the employment situation suggested continuing weakness in the economy _ but not enough evidence of trouble to warrant action by the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy. Thus, the data seemed to provide little encouragement for traders on the outlook for either interest rates or corporate profits. The civilian unemployment rate increased from 5.5 percent in July to 5.6 percent last month. Nonfarm payroll employment dropped by 75,000 jobs, after a revised decline of 89,000 in July. Interest rates rose in the government bond market after the report was issued. Among actively traded blue chips, Boeing slipped | to 46|; American Telephone & Telegraph \ to 31\, and Eastman Kodak [ to 40|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell .29 to 175.72. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 1.00 at 323.50. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average fell 31.93 to 2,596.29. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 9 to 5 on the NYSE, with 507 up, 951 down and 489 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 125.62 million shares, against 120.61 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Former Director of Wall Street Brokerage Firm Indicted
DOC.TEXT: A former director of a defunct Wall Street brokerage firm has been accused of obstructing an insider trading inquiry and lying to Securities and Exchange Commission investigators. A federal grand jury returned a three-count indictment Thursday against Charles Howard, 45, of Bedford, N.H., former director and first vice president of Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc., U.S. Attorney Wayne Budd said. The indictment charged Howard with conspiracy to obstruct an SEC investigation, obstructing an SEC investigation and perjury in the SEC's 1987 inquiry of alleged insider trading. The 1987 SEC investigation followed the announcement that Suffield Savings Bank of Suffield, Conn., and Coastal Savings Bank of Portland, Maine, planned to merge. Howard was a key figure in a four-state investigation of the New York-based Thomson McKinnon that led last March to $320,000 penalties against the brokerage firm to be paid to Connecticut, New Hampshire, Vermont and Maine. Howard was accused of conspiring with others to conceal from the SEC the names of investors with inside information who had bought Coastal stock before the July 9, 1986 announcement of the merger plans. The indictment also alleged that Howard tried to influence, obstruct and impede the SEC's investigation of the trading of Coastal stock and that he committed perjury before the SEC. If convicted of all the charges, Howard faces a maximum 15 years in prison and a $750,000 fine, Budd said. He said arraignment had not been scheduled. Howard's attorney, Steven M. Gordon of Concord, said Thursday that Howard has known for several years that federal investigators were probing his dealings. ``He is in some respects relieved that he will now be provided with the specifics of the allegations against him and be permitted to fully contest the charges in a court of law,'' Gordon said in a statement. Howard will not comment on the case until he sees the evidence against him, Gordon said. Investigations into suspicious trading of stock in at least 10 New England banks revolved around Howard, who had close ties to the Suffield Bank and a former executive, Robert DiGennaro. DiGennaro, former chief executive of the Suffield Financial Corp., was convicted on insider trading and obstruction charges last year. Investigators traced a lead of privileged information from DiGennaro through a Simsbury developer to a Hartford stockbroker. Days before its chairman was indicted, Suffield filed a $24 million lawsuit against Howard for the losses the company sustained buying back stock under the broker's direction.
