DOC.HEAD: Upjohn Healthcare Unit Sold to Olsten
DOC.TEXT: Olsten Corp. plans to buy a health services subsidiary from Upjohn Co. for an undisclosed amount, the two companies announced Friday. The purchase of Upjohn HealthCare Services Inc., which had about $182 million in sales last year and accounted for 6 percent of Upjohn's total sales, will expand Olsten's presence in the home health care field. Upjohn HealthCare provides home health care and supplemental staffing to hospitals, nursing homes and in other settings. The sale, which must receive regulatory clearance and legal approval, includes operations in both the United States and Canada. Olsten's health care network will grow by more than 200 offices, giving it the capability to supply trained temporary help to patients in homes and elsewhere in more parts of North America. ``Acquiring the Upjohn HealthCare Services network is part of Olsten's strategic plan and will save us years of internal growth and development in health care services,'' said Frank N. Liguori, vice chairman and chief executive officer of Olsten Corp. Olsten, based in Westbury, N.Y., is the third largest temporary help provider. Last year it employed 325,000 temporary workers in business, industry, government and health care throughout a network of 550 owned, franchised and licensed offices. By divesting the unit, Upjohn will shed a subsidiary that no longer fits into its corporate fold. ``As we position the company for the decade of the nineties we realize that Upjohn HealthCare Services does not provide an acceptable fit to our strategic plan,'' said Upjohn's Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer Theodore Cooper. Upjohn, based in Kalamazoo, Mich., is a major worldwide provider of human health care products, animal health products, specialty chemicals and some agricultural items. The joint announcement of the sale was made available here.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He's Committed to $50 Billion Deficit Reduction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout with Bush remarks. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush arrived at budget negotiations with congressional leaders today saying he is committed to working out a $50 billion deficit-reduction program for next year. ``Nothing has transpired anywhere that makes me less interested in getting this budget deficit under control once and for all,'' Bush said as he arrived at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington, the site of the talks. Some lawmakers have said that with the weakening economy and the uncertain situation in the Persian Gulf, a smaller deficit-reduction plan could avoid pushing the economy into a recession. Asked if the figure of $50 billion in savings is carved in stone, the president responded, ``Yes.'' Bush said he was ``somewhat optimistic'' that a budget deal could be worked out quickly. ``I am pleased with ... the cooperative attitude that exists up there now (on Capitol Hill),'' Bush told reporters on leaving the White House. ``I am hopeful that this spirit of cooperation ... will be the catalyst in getting the budget agreement that's long overdue.'' Bush remained at the negotiations for about a half-hour. The budget negotiators, ending a five-week break for Congress' August recess, hoped to work out a deal by Monday. But the president acknowledged that Democrats and Republicans have a large gap to bridge before finalizing a compromise. ``Big differences remain,'' he said. ``It's going to take compromise.'' Congressional negotiators said foreign payments for American military forces in the Persian Gulf would help their efforts to reduce the deficit. ``I think the fact that some allies are being helpful will help us,'' Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., said as bargainers gathered at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland outside Washington. ``Obviously we have to take into account the cost of the Desert Shield operation,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., referring to the U.S. operations in the Middle East. ``To the extent those costs can be offset by our allies around the world that makes our job easier.'' Officials announced that Saudi Arabia, the ousted Kuwaiti government, Japan and South Korea have pledged to help the United States bear the cost of the economic and military campaign against Iraq. ``We'll put a plan on the table,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M. ``From what I understand the Democrats will put their plan on some time this morning, and then we'll start negotiating.'' Democratic and Republican negotiators said they agree on the amount of deficit reductions they need, but disagree strongly over how far to cut military spending. The new fiscal year begins Oct. 1. Without some combination of spending cuts and tax increases, the administration estimates the budget gap will approach a record $250 billion, Republican officials said. Unless a budget deal is enacted by then, the Gramm-Rudman law will impose about $100 billion in spending cuts in most domestic and defense programs. As a result, the bargainers hope to wrap up a deal by Monday to give Congress time to enact it. Leaders of both sides said they want to aim for packages cutting red ink by $50 billion next year and $500 billion over five years. Since Iraq's Aug. 2 conquest of Kuwait and the resulting oil price increases, some lawmakers have cautioned that the first-year figure should be lower for fear of driving the weakening economy into a recession. GOP officials, speaking on condition they not be identified, said their first offer would be similar to the $53 billion deficit-cutting measure the administration drew up in July. It would include new taxes on alcoholic products and defense cuts of about $7 billion _ several billion dollars less than Democrats prefer. ``I suspect the defense figure will fare better than it otherwise would have had there not been a crisis in the Middle East,'' said House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. Democrats talked of a package that would take a deeper slice out of the Pentagon, more akin to their earlier proposals of $9 billion to $16 billion cuts. They said they were reluctant to add the costs of the U.S. Middle East military buildup _ about $1 billion monthly _ into the long-range spending plan. ``It comes more under the head of emergency conditions than of regular planning for the future,'' said House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash. Foley, House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., and Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said they wanted a budget plan that also encouraged economic growth, protected social programs, contained progressive taxes and pushed the United States toward energy security. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said he favored energy production incentives. Domenici, ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, said new taxes and tax incentives on energy were a possibility. Divisions remained within GOP ranks. Gingrich, the No. 2 House Republican, continued to call for tax cuts to spur the economy.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Slip As Traders Take Profits
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices dipped this morning but stayed above $30 per barrel as traders sold futures to pocket their profits from Thursday's price surge. ``I don't really think there's anything in terms of hard news,'' said William Byers, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Co. ``I think there's simply some profit taking after the market ran up yesterday.'' In late morning trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude was down 70 cents to $30.74 per barrel on October contracts. On Thursday, oil had shot above $30 per barrel on the Merc for the second time during the Middle East crisis that began Aug. 2. The Merc had previously not seen $30 oil since November 1985. Unleaded gasoline was down .22 cent to 94.85 cents per gallon this morning for October delivery, while home heating oil was down 1.84 cents to 86.40 cents for October delivery. Natural gas was down to $1.501 per 1,000 cubic feet after closing Thursday at $1.530. Other contract months for petroleum futures were also trading lower today. A broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. said today's selling was partially attributable to a report that the Saudis would be able to vastly increase their crude production by the end of the year. A multinational military force has assembled in Saudi Arabia to protect it in the wake of Iraq's invasion and occupation of neighboring Kuwait. Anticipation that President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would issue a joint statement on the Persian Gulf after their summit Sunday in Helsinki, Finland, also depressed prices, the Shearson broker said. The Soviet Union has been an ally of Iraq, so a joint U.S.-Soviet statement would show ``it's not the United States versus Iraq, but it's more the world versus Iraq,'' said the broker, who did not want his name used. The continued airlifting of hostages out of territory controlled by Iraq was also calming traders this morning, the broker said.

DOC.HEAD: Mack Signs Merger Plan With Renault
DOC.TEXT: Renault Vehicules Industriels SA has sweetened its offer and agreed to buy all outstanding shares of Mack Trucks Inc. that it does not already own in an $81 million deal, the truck company said. Mack said Thursday it had agreed to be sold to the Paris-based Renault for $6.25 per share. Renault had previously offered $6 a share. Renault owned 44.5 percent of Mack's 29 million shares prior to the merger agreement. As of late Wednesday, Renault had received an additional 4.5 percent of Mack's shares under terms of its initial bid. The tender offer has been extended until Sept. 20, said Renault spokesman Bill Catacosinos Thursday. The French car company has been trying to buy the Allentown-based truck company for several months, saying it was making the offer ``because of the continuing deterioration of the financial condition of Mack'' and the need to restructure the company's debt. Mack lost a record $185.4 million last year and $97.2 million for the six months ending June 30, 1990. Net sales for the first half of 1990 were down 22 percent to $793.9 million from just over $1 billion in 1989. The company's five-year financial plan in July projected a net loss of about $130 million for the year ending Dec. 31, 1990. At the time, Mack officials said they did not expect the company to show a profit before 1992. In the past year, Mack had tried to reduce business costs and conserve cash amidst a slowing market for heavy trucks and negotiated an agreement with the United Auto Workers for employees at Mack's Winnsboro, S.C., truck plant. Mack is one of North America's largest producers of heavy-duty diesel trucks.

DOC.HEAD: IBM, Metaphor Announce Software Venture
DOC.TEXT: IBM Corp. and Metaphor Computer Systems plan to ease a bottleneck in the computer industry by developing software that could be used to write other software. The new venture, Patriot Partners, will start work immediately on software that would allow most applications programs to work with major operating systems, including multiple versions of Unix and OS@2. IBM and Metaphor said Thursday the project probably would take two or three years. The venture, to be based in Mountain View, will be jointly staffed and financed and is expected to employ up to 200 people. The personal computer-software industry has been hampered by the cost and difficulty of writing new programs and converting them to different formats. But IBM and Metaphor predicted their new venture will help ease that problem and make it easier to include such sophisticated features as stereo sound and full-motion video and let the programs work together on networks of different kinds of computers. ``We think a whole lot of brand-new thinking will come out of this,'' said Joseph Guglielmi, president of IBM's applications-solution division. Analysts said the effort could have a major impact on the software industry provided that Patriot Partners can do what it promises. ``There's a lot of questions as to whether they can pull it off,'' said Nancy McSharry, an analyst with International Data Corp., a market research company in Mountain View. Several years ago, software pioneer Mitch Kapor founded a company for a similar project, but his firm, On Technology, has become a developer of applications for the Macintosh computer. ``It was Mitch Kapor's initial thought and then he realized how huge the task was and he came up with much less ambitions plans,'' said Bruce Lupatkin, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco. He called the new project ``a bit like searching for the Holy Grail.'' But Metaphor's president, David Little, said the new venture differed from Kapor's plans. ``(He) had four guys and a little venture capital,'' Liddle said. ``We have a battle-hardened organization. We have IBM as a partner and accept that it's a big activity we're going to have to do.'' Metaphor was founded in 1982 by Liddle, chief executive and president of the new venture, and other former Xerox Corp. executives who worked with Star computer. That project pioneered the idea of controlling personal computers with a mouse pointing device and set of visual prompts, technology that helped popularize Apple's Macintosh. Metaphor originally sold its own computers but now chiefly sells data-analysis software that incorporates its graphical user interface. In 1988 IBM paid $10 million for an 8 percent stake in Metaphor, and the two companies jointly market Metaphor's data-analysis software.

DOC.HEAD: Reynolds Introduces Cheaper Cigarette
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) _ R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. is using an old name to introduce a new low-cost premium cigarette. Company spokesmen say they think there's a niche for their Sterling cigarette, which will sell about $3 a carton below the price of premium brands and $1 to $2 above savings blends. But industry analysts say it's a tricky move for the tobacco company, which also sells such premium brands as Camel and Winston. ``It's a very tricky piece of marketing,'' said David Goldman, an analyst at Nomura Research Institute in New York. ``If you're so successful with this brand, ... then you've created a conception in the consumer's mind that high-quality brands can be had at a lower price.'' Despite that risk, Goldman says he thinks the cigarette will be successful. ``It's innovative,'' he said. ``My feeling is it's going to be a very successful brand. More importantly, it might be the beginning of a brand-new cigarette segment.'' Some smokers may remember the old Sterling, a luxury smoke touted as a cigarette for ``a growing segment of the population who appreciate the finer things in life,'' as a news release stated. But similarities end at the name, said Reynolds Tobacco spokeswoman Peggy C. Carter. The tobacco blend and the packaging are different, she said. Sterling, to go on sale Oct. 1, will have a metallic-gray package with burgundy and diagonal stripes _ teal and gold on menthol packages. Cartons will have coupons that consumers can peel off at the checkout counter and get $3 off the price. ``We do believe Sterling will enhance our portfolio because it's a whole new dimension in our pricing structure here,'' Ms. Carter said. ``It is targeted to people who are looking for a premium-quality cigarette with a price advantage. There is a niche of people looking for this type of cigarette as a midpoint price.''

DOC.HEAD: Bethlehem Steel Plans $100 Million in Improvements
DOC.TEXT: Bethlehem Steel Corp. said Friday it will make $100 million in improvements at its Johnstown production plant if it obtains concessions from the United Steelworkers of America. Sufficient concessions would allow the company to make major improvements, including a new continuous caster and modernization of an existing bar mill to permit rod production, said Bethlehem Chairman Walter Williams. The Bar, Rod and Wire Division headquarters plant in Johnstown employs about 2,000 workers, while plants in Lackawanna, N.Y., and Sparrows Point, Md., each employ 350 workers. The current labor contract, which expires July 31, 1993, calls for modifications to the agreement for plants having financial difficulties, ``and the Bar, Rod and Wire Division is one of them,'' said company spokesman Henry Von Spreckelsen. He would not indicate what form of concessions the company is seeking and would only say the division has lost ``millions of dollars since its formation in 1983.'' ``It must be competitive on its own terms,'' he said. ``In this case we're saying for an unprofitable operation to survive requires a reduction in production costs, through a reduction in labor costs, and more efficient facilities. ``We've made some progress, but it hasn't been sufficient,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: New England Monthly To Cease Publication
DOC.TEXT: Facing a debt of $5 million, New England Monthly magazine will cease publication this month, its editors announced. Richard Todd, editor of the 6-year-old publication, told the magazine's 30 employees Thursday that the September issue will be the last. ``It's been a tough year for everyone in the magazine business,'' Todd said. ``For us, it proved fatal.'' Consumer magazine ad pages are down overall this year, and the tough ad climate has already led to the demise of Woman magazine and the regional magazines Southpoint and 7 Days. Earlier this week, France's Hachette SA said it would end regular publication of its Memories magazine with the October issue and publish only two issues of it in 1991 because of the weak ad climate. The news nostalgia magazine had been published every other month and had planned to go monthly this fall. According MagazineWeek's Ad Monitor, ad revenues for the first seven months of 1990 at New England Monthly were down 7.5 percent from 1989. From its first issue in April 1984, the magazine attracted a base of 120,000 subscribers. But it was unable to turn a profit. Industry observers said the magazine and the target audience were not specific enough to draw large amounts of advertising in several critical categories, such as home furnishings, food and retailing. ``I think what it did best weren't always sexy issues,'' said Geoffrey Wolff, a Rhode Island-based writer who was a regular contributor to New England Monthly. New England Monthly twice won the National Magazine Award for general excellence. It won the same award from the American Society of Magazine Editors. New England Monthly was founded by Texas Monthly veteran Robert Nylen and editor Daniel Okrent. Todd succeeded Okrent as editor last October. The magazine was threatened with closing 18 months ago, but given a new lease on life when it was bought by Telemedia Inc., Canada's largest publisher of consumer magazines. The new owner pledged to pour working capital into New England Monthly. But Todd said the magazine faced an outstanding debt of about $5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Saatchi Omits Dividend
DOC.TEXT: The beleagured advertising giant Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC announced Friday it does not have enough reserves at hand to pay a dividend. The shortage follows Saatchi's sale of two consultancy businesses for less than the expected amount. Saatchi is in the process of selling all its consulting businesses as it tries to focus on its advertising and marketing businesses. Saatchi grew rapidly in the 1980s and owns the New York-based ad agencies Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising and Backer Spielvogel Bates. In June, Saatchi sold Peterson & Co., a litigation support management company, to Peterson's management for about $2.2 million. Saatchi paid $79 million for the unit in September 1987. Atchi sold the Hay Co. consultancy to a group of investors and management for $90 million in cash and notes. It bought that company in 1985 for an undisclosed sum. The London-based advertising agency took a writeoff of about $76 milllso in June, Saaion on the sales, and cited them for its inability to pay the dividend. A Saatchi spokesman said that although there are funds to pay a dividend, it would involve getting the permission of bond holders and paying a high price to obtain that permission. ``We didn't think it was prudent to squander the funds at the moment,'' said the spokesman, who requested anonymity. The spokesman also said that the problem was ``largely technical'' and that payments would yment was a ``reflection of the fact that they have a balance sheet which is in a fragile state.'' ``It saves them 6 million pounds (about $11 million) a year which is a sensible move at this point in time,'' Sheppard said. Losses are also expected from the sale of the Gartner Group Inc., a Stamford, Conn.-based consultancy being sold to an investment management group for $55 million in cash and $15 million in notes and other obligations. Saatchi bought the group in June 1988 for $86 million.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Rise
DOC.TEXT: Share prices rose Friday on London's stock exchange. DOC.HEAD: Mortgage Rates Down
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.19 percent this week, down from 10.24 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.29 percent, down from 8.30 percent last week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Preserve or Develop
DOC.TEXT: The Resolution Trust Corp., the agency set up last year to take over and dispose of failed savings and loans, now controls about 1,850 properties believed to have important environmental, historical, recreational or scientific value. Many of the properties, which range from natural habitats of endangered wildlife to ``pocket parks'' in cities and towns, are in Texas, Arizona, California and Florida. Here are some examples compiled by the Texas Center for Policy Studies in Austin.

Nags Head Woods _ A coastal forest in North Carolina that has been declared a National Natural Monument. Some 390 of the 1,400-acre area is held by the RTC after a development plan and its financing thrift failed.

Balcones Canyonlands Habitat Conservation Plan Lands _ The west side of Austin and Travis County, Texas. A habitat for seven endangered species and an aquifer recharge zone. The RTC and Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. own as many as 100 tracts of the 15-acre area.

Playa del Rio _ 14,000 acres at the southern tip of Texas running inland from the Gulf of Mexico along the Rio Grande river. It includes 8,000 acres of wetlands, wetland buffer zones and habitat for endangered species. The FDIC is now a partner in the application to fill the wetlands, something the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service has opposed.

Friedrich Wilderness Park _ A 1,400-acre tract adjacent to a wilderness park north of San Antonio, Texas. The area is a recharge zone for the city's drinking water aquifer and the home of two endangered songbirds. The tract, originally slated for development, is now owned by the FDIC.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Fall on Profit-Taking, Fading Export Hopes
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices fell moderately Friday amid profit-taking and fading expectations that the United States will grant agricultural export credits to the Soviet Union soon. Forecasts for rain this weekend in the Mississippi Delta region, where soybeans have been stressed by dry, hot conditions, also weighed on the soybean complex, said Pat O'Connell, grains analyst with Refco Inc. in Chicago. ``It's kind of a wait-and-see attitude,'' he said. ``If it rains a little less than expected, we'll be back up on Monday. If it's a little more than expected, we'll go another leg down.'' The soybean, soybean meal and wheat markets posted strong gains earlier this week on hopes that President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev would strike a deal on export credits during their summit meeting Sunday. But talk circulated Friday that the State Department was opposed to granting credit to the Soviets unless Moscow lifts emigration restrictions that have prevented the United States from designating the Soviet Union a most-favored trading partner. At the close, wheat futures were 1} cents to 4{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.62 a bushel; corn was 1{ cents to 4{ cents lower with September at $2.38{ a bushel; oats were } cent to 2{ cents lower with September at $1.08} a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 5} cents lower with September at $6.12{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Executives, Analysts Fear Gulf Crisis Could Cause Gasoline Shortages
DOC.TEXT: Even minor disruptions of gasoline supply channels could cause shortages at gas pumps this winter because of the Persian Gulf crisis, oil industry leaders and analysts warned Friday. The problem isn't just that the cutoff of Iraqi and Kuwaiti supplies has reduced flow by nearly 2 million barrels a day. It's that the replacement oil, mainly from stepped-up Saudi Arabian production, is heavier and contains more sulfur. That means less of the lighter petroleum products like gasoline, jet fuel, diesel and home heating oil can be extracted from each barrel. And the coking and cracking units that break down the heavier oil are already running at near capacity, the experts said in a series of interviews this week. ``We are really on the razor's edge with no margin for error,'' said George Baker, an energy analyst with Merrill Lynch Research in New York. ``As we go into the fourth quarter, there's a potential for it getting tight,'' said Lodwrick M. Cook, the chief executive of Los Angeles-based Atlantic Richfield Co. Their worries followed warnings by Bush administration officials and other private analysts this week that oil shortages could develop out of the Mideast crisis. Baker said shortages at the pumps might be caused this winter by something as minor as the fire that recently knocked out part of Shell's refinery in Deer Park, Texas. He noted that during last year's fourth quarter, at least two such events occurred: A fire at an Exxon refinery in Baton Rouge, La., and Hurricane Hugo's assault on an Amerada Hess facility in St. Croix, Virgin Islands. ``Any prolonged outages would change it from the razor's edge of balance to a situation where people actually might not be able to get gas,'' Baker said. He and Cook shied away from using shock words from the '70s, like ``gas lines.'' But Baker suggested that some form of rationing, such as shorter hours of operation or 10-gallon limits, might be seen at gas pumps during the fourth and first quarters. Cook said it was too early to make predictions, but he finds the situation worrisome. Although gasoline use drops as winter approaches, use of heating oil rises, he noted in an interview. Home heating oil also is one of the lighter products made from crude oil. ``If you look at purely the arithmetic, we ought to be able to get through. But there's a lot of other factors,'' Cook said. The unknowns include whether suppliers at any stage hold back, hoping for higher prices later. Panic buying by drivers could also could cause problems, he said. ``If people decide to hoard supplies, if people decide to top off their tanks, there could be problems,'' Cook said. Another chief executive, Robert McClements Jr. of Sun Co. in Radnor, Pa., rearranged his agenda at a meeting with analysts in New York last week to address the problems caused by the heavier crude. He'd been scheduled to talk about the clean-air legislation making its way through Congress. McClements estimated the cutoff of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude oil and refined products may produce a shortfall equivalent to 1.95 million barrels of crude a day. Even if higher prices cut demand, the shortfall is likely to remain at 1.5 million barrels per day. The heavier oil on average will yield 8 percent or 9 percent less of the light-end products such as gasoline than the light sweet crude oil it is replacing, McClements told the analysts. With refineries already operating at near capacity, it will be hard to compensate for that, he said. ``The message was the tight market's out there already. Refiners are at very high levels of utilization,'' said Timothy R. Hughes, Sun Co.'s director of investor relations. ``Products like gasoline and distillates (such as home heating oil) are going to be very tight,'' he said. ``It's possible that we'd get back to gas lines or rationing in some form if this keeps up,'' Hughes said.

DOC.HEAD: ``Designer'' Water Quenching the Japanese Thirst
LaserPhoto TOK2
DOC.TEXT: With its dim lights, glittering chrome and glass-polishing bartenders, Aqua Bar Genryu looks like many other Tokyo watering holes. But at this cozy bar, water is the hardest thing on the menu. In fact, it's the only thing on the menu. Designer water, in dozens and dozens of brands, has flooded the Japanese market, with imports expected to more than double this year. And at Aqua Bar they drink it straight. The bar, on the sixth floor of an upscale Seibu department store, is near boutiques for designer brands Chanel and Piaget. ``We get maybe 100 or 120 customers in here a day,'' said bartender Masamitsu Matsumoto. ``They may not know their water very well, but they know this is the fashion.'' According to Yoshio Yamamoto, executive director of the Japan Mineral Water Association, the market this year is expected to be about $103.4 million, with imports forecast to go up 137 percent from last year. Sales of domestic brands, which make up about 85 percent of the Japanese market, are expected to increase roughly 20 percent, he said. ``Sales tooink something clean.'' Kazuhiro Uda, head of the Tokyo Waterworks Department's Water Quality Section, disagreed. ``Mineral water is just a fad.'' But he acknowledged that legal requirements for chlorine tend to create ``somewhat smelly water.'' ``Each summer we also have some problems with mold, and I suppose some people have begun to lose confidence in us,'' he said. ``But what's important is that wherever you go in Japan you can turn on the tap and get clean, drinkable water.''

DOC.HEAD: British Government Wants Coffee, Cocoa Bodies to Remain in London
DOC.TEXT: The British government is preparing to fight off any overseas bid to attract the international coffee and cocoa organizations, officials said Thursday. ``The U.K. government wishes to keep the organizations in London and is doing everything possible to get the best deal possible (on rents),'' said an official from the Ministry of Agriculture, speaking anonymously. Her comment followed a statement by Dutch officials attending the first day of International Cocoa Organization talks here that their government was considering offering the 41-nation body a new home in the Netherlands. In June, the West German government said it was likely to support a bid being drawn up by the state of Hamburg to attract the 73-nation International Coffee Organization away from London. Neither government has yet made formal bids for the two organizations, which provide a forum for producing and consuming countries to discuss matters of mutual concern. In the past the organizations have also operated price-stabilization treaties for both commodities. The lease on their present shared headquarters in central London, which is held by the British Agriculture Ministry, expires in May 1991. The landlords are seeking a rent increase. Both organizations are eager to keep down costs to member governments. The Ministry of Agriculture has appointed agents to negotiate the rent and look at cheaper alternative headquarters in the capital. Last year the British government guaranteed rent subsidies to the international wheat and sugar organizations in a successful bid to persuade them to remain in London in the face of offers of alternative accommodation in Paris, Brussels, Belgium and Amsterdam, the Netherlands. Commodity industry sources said the departure of the coffee and cocoa organizations would damage London's prestige as the world's commodity center.

DOC.HEAD: USX Launches Investment at Historic Plant
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. returned to its roots Friday to launch a $250 million investment in a historic steel mill, saying the project will ensure the survival of steel in the industry's cradle. The company broke ground for a continuous slab caster at the 115-year-old Edgar Thomson mill, Andrew Carnegie's first steel plant, in the depressed Monongahela Valley region near Pittsburgh. In continuous casting, molten steel is poured into a caster that shapes it into slabs up to 36 feet long. The process eliminates several steps in making flat-rolled steel, saving time and money and improving quality. ``In marking the start of this construction project, we are also marking the beginning of a new era in steelmaking in the Mon Valley region,'' said USX Chairman Charles A. Corry. ``The company is undertaking this large investment on the premise that world-class, quality steel products can be produced at competitive costs in the Mon Valley,'' he said. The caster, which will be completed in mid-1992, will have an annual capacity of 2.6 million tons. The company is building the caster under terms of a labor agreement reached with the United Steelworkers of America in 1987. It plans to begin renovating the hot strip mill at its nearby Irvin plant later this year for another $250 million. Millions more are being spent to renovate the nearby Clairton coke ovens. Some years ago, Corry said, there were serious questions about whether the company's steel division would still be operating in the valley in 1990, ``let alone investing a quarter of a billion dollars for modernization.'' ``While this project is not without risks, we are confident that with the dedicated support and cooperation of our employees and the community we can succeed,'' he said. There aren't many steelworkers left in the Mon Valley, an area hit hard by plant closings in the 1980s. The caster will mean the loss of an unknown number of jobs, but union and business leaders agree the improvement means job security for most of the 4,000 people who work at Thomson and the two other USX plants in the valley. The project will create about 550 construction jobs, and civic leaders hope the casters will draw other industries to the area. Bethlehem Steel Corp. joined USX in hailing the improvements Friday. The company said it will invest $100 million in its Johnstown production facility if it obtains labor concessions from the steelworkers union. Sufficient concessions would allow the company to make major improvements, including another new continuous caster and modernization of an existing bar mill to permit rod production, said Bethlehem Chairman Walter Williams. The Bar, Rod and Wire Division headquarters plant in Johnstown employs about 2,000 workers, while the division's plants in Lackawanna, N.Y., and Sparrows Point, Md., employ 350 workers apiece. The current pact, which expires July 31, 1993, calls for modifications to the agreement for plants having financial difficulties, ``and the Bar, Rod and Wire Division is one of them,'' said company spokesman Henry Von Spreckelsen. He would not indicate what form of concessions the company is seeking and would only say the division has lost ``millions of dollars since its formation in 1983.'' ``It must be competitive on its own terms,'' he said. ``In this case we're saying for an unprofitable operation to survive requires a reduction in production costs, through a reduction in labor costs, and more efficient facilities. ``We've made some progress, but it hasn't been sufficient.''

Stock prices moved higher in quiet trading today, recovering some of Thursday's losses. Analysts said a drop in oil prices helped encourage some sporadic buying in a quiet session. But traders seemed unimpressed by the latest economic news. The Labor Department's report for August on the employment situation signaled continuing weakness in the economy _ but apparently not enough evidence of trouble to warrant action by the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy. Thus, the data seemed provided little encouragement for traders on the outlook for either interest rates or corporate profits. The civilian unemployment rate increased from 5.5 percent in July to 5.6 percent last month. Nonfarm payroll employment dropped by 75,000 jobs, after a revised decline of 89,000 in July.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Stays Out of Foreign Exchange Market For First Time Since 1986
DOC.TEXT: The government did not intervene in the foreign exchange markets to support the dollar's value from May through July, the first time in four years it has refrained from taking action during one of its quarterly reporting periods, officials said Friday. Federal Reserve System officials said the dollar's slide against the German mark, British pound and Japanese yen during the quarter was not seen as a threat. ``This does not mean we're out of the intervention business or a change in policy or a change in approach,'' said Sam Y. Cross, executive vice president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, which manages foreign-exchange operations for the Fed. During the three months ended July 31, the dollar's value declined 8 percent against the yen, 5{ percent against the mark and 12 percent against the pound, Cross said at a news conference. It was the first time since August-October 1986 that the nation's central bank refrained from selling or buying dollars to affect the value of the currency during a quarter, the Fed said. The Fed attempts to regulate the value of the dollar against other currencies either by selling or buying dollars in foreign exchange markets, where various currencies are bought and sold much like soybeans or barrels of oil. If the central bank believes the dollar is undervalued, it will buy dollars to limit their supply on world markets in the hope that will prop up their value. If it believes the dollar is too strong, it will sell dollars from its reserves to try to lower their value through the law of supply and demand. Such interventions are not always successful, but they can change the dollar's value over the short term, particularly when central banks of other nations join in. A strong dollar makes imported goods cheaper, but makes U.S. exports more expensive on world markets. A weak dollar, conversely, makes imports more expensive but benefits exporters. Cross said the Fed did not view the dollar's decline against other major currencies during May-July to be a major threat to the economy, or that the dollar was ``being pushed inappropriately one way or another.'' He also said there was no panic movement of the dollar in the markets that may have prompted the Fed to intervene. ``We certainly do not try to keep the dollar at a rigid level,'' he added. He said domestic issues in Japan, Germany and Great Britain were in large part responsible for the rise in those currencies against the dollar. However, the dollar also was weakened later in the three-month period by signs that the U.S. economy was deteriorating, he said. The Fed was not completely out of the foreign exchange market, however. On behalf of the Treasury, it sold 1 billion marks for dollars on the open market and sold another 1 billion marks for dollars directly to another central bank, Cross said. But these transactions were timed to have little or no impact on the dollar's value, he said. They were undertaken as part of the Treasury's Exchange Stabilization Fund to adjust balances and to enable the fund to eliminate some of the foreign currency it stores with the Fed. The Treasury earned a profit of about $330 million from the currency dealings, Cross said.

DOC.HEAD: Toyota Boosting '91 Prices by 2.3 Percent Over '90
DOC.TEXT: Toyota Motor Corp. announced Friday that prices for its 1991-model cars will rise an average of 2.3 percent over prices for comparably equipped 1990 cars. The 2.3 percent average works out to $318 per car. Base prices for 1991 cars will range from $8,998 for the Corolla to $27,290 for the Supra Turbo. Prices for the 1991 model Tercel will be announced later, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Radio, TV Audit Finds Overcharges for Political Ads
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 10 grafs to CLARIFY that there apparently were violations at most stations and that findings are not complete. SUBS grafs 21-22 with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Cincinnati station saying it did not sell ads. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A surprise audit of 30 radio and TV stations indicates most apparently were overcharging for political advertising, a Federal Communications Commission official said Friday. Roy J. Stewart, chief of the FCC's mass media bureau, said the charges were not necessarily deliberate and that the commission would not impose sanctions pending further investigation. ``I would prefer to think they (broadcasters) are not aware of their full range of responsibilities ... in carrying out the law,'' Stewart said. He said no more audits were planned and that no final determinations had been made regarding any violations by individual stations. Instead, the FCC will increase its efforts to educate station executives in the intricacies of political advertising laws, Stewart said. Broadcasters said they were making good-faith efforts to comply with complicated rules. ``Historically, the commission has not done a good job of educating broadcasters to the various nuances in this important area,'' said Edward O. Fritts, president of the National Association of Broadcasters. The FCC can impose sanctions ranging from a letter of admonition to fines totaling $250,000. In April the commission fined an Indianapolis television station, WXIN, $10,000 for violating the political ad rules. The July 16-17 audit indicated widespread overcharging at 16 of 20 TV stations and four of eight radio stations. Two other radio stations sold no political ads during the time audited. At one TV station, candidates paid $5,500 to run a 30-second ad in a time slot that cost commercial advertisers no more than $3,000, Stewart said. Stewart would not identify any of the stations that may have been in violation. He said they first would be given a chance to respond to the commission's inquiries before a final determination of any violations were made. The audit reviewed the stations' compliance with federal rules requiring that candidates have equal opportunities _ commonly referred to as equal time _ to appear on stations and that stations sell ads to candidates at the lowest rates fr specific time slots. Political advertising rates are a sore spot in Congress, where proposals are pending to guarantee that candidates get the lowest rates without fear of being preempted by commercial advertisers who later offer to pay higher prices. The bureau said broadcasters' ``sales techniques encouraged (candidates) to buy higher-priced classes of time.'' ``It appears from the audit that certain industry practices are not in compliance with the law, and that political candidates have paid higher prices than commercial advertisers at a majority of the stations,'' the bureau said. Besides the pricing problems, the audit found many stations weren't keeping adequate records to allow candidates to determine whether they should be getting equal time with opponents. One proponent of tougher political ad rules, Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., said the FCC's audit ``confirms what candidates have known for some time, that broadcasters routinely ignore the law'' on ad pricing. The inspections _ the first of their kind _ were carried out in Cincinnati; Dallas-Fort Worth; Philadelphia; Portland, Ore.; and San Francisco. The commission said the stations were chosen because of their diverse locations and because they serve large areas. Jeff Rosser, general manager at one of the stations, KDFW-TV in Dallas, said officials there thought they had been complying, but found problems when they conducted their own audit. ``One could argue that we did overcharge, not by design, but by not being totally aware of the small print and the intricacies of a very complicated rule,'' Rosser said Friday. Dirk Brinkerhoff, general manager of KTXA-TV in Dallas, and Charles D. Schwartz, general manager of WWDB-FM in Philadelphia, said their stations would be found in compliance. Jim Wood, general manager of WWNK-FM in Cincinnati, said his station did not sell political ads during the audit period. The other audited stations were: Cincinnati _ WCPO-TV, WKRC-TV, WLWT-TV, WIII-TV and WCKY-AM. Dallas-Fort Worth _ KXAS-TV, WFAA-TV, KRLD-AM and KPLX-FM. Philadelphia _ KYW-TV, WCAU-TV, WPVI-TV, WGBS-TV and WPEN-AM. Portland, Ore. _ KATU-TV, KGW-TV, KOIN-TV, KPTV, KWJJ-AM and KKSN-FM. San Francisco _ KGO-TV, KRON-TV, KTVU-TV, KOFY-TV, KNBR-AM and KABL-FM.

DOC.HEAD: Connell Named President, Chief Operating Officer at Media Concern
DOC.TEXT: Venture capitalist William Connell was named Friday as president and chief operating officer of Whittle Communications. Connell, 50, will be taking posts at the Knoxville, Tenn.-based media company that have been vacant since Nicholas Glover stepped down two years ago. Chairman Christopher Whittle said he has known Connell for most of a decade and found him to be a broad-gauged business leader. ``His presence will allow me to devote my time to development and marketing while he focuses internally on the needs and morale of our work force which makes all of our ideas work,'' Whittle said. Connell has operated a venture capital business called Peregrine Capital Partners of Cincinnati, specializing in securing financing for optical businesses and day care centers. He had previously worked for 25 years at Procter & Gamble, heading its $300 million bar soap and laundry products division in Canada at one point and later its $800 million U.S. beauty care division. Whittle Communications, a private company that is 50 percent owned by Time Warner Inc., specializes in creating media vehicles ranging from magazines, sponsored posters and video programs to sampling kits and books that are designed to appeal to narrowly defined audiences. Its Channel One TV news show with commercials is designed to run in high school classrooms. It has created magazines for beauty parlors and doctor's waiting rooms, wall media for school lobbies and sponsored books sent free to American opinion leaders. The company employs 1,000 people and expects to generate revenue of $230 million this year.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Dips, But Stays Above $30 a Barrel, as Traders Take Profits
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices fell Friday as traders sold futures to pocket their profits from Thursday's surge over $31 a barrel, but crude stayed higher for the week amid fears of supply shortages this winter. ``There was really no news to go on,'' said Ed Kevelson, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``It was a Friday, so people were more likely to take profits.'' Light sweet crude for October delivery fell $1.39 to $30.04 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later contract months also fell. For the four-day trading week, shortened by the Labor Day holiday, October crude was up $2.72 per barrel following speculation that the Persian Gulf crisis may drag on. Prices also gained in response to government statements that supply shortages could be on the way. Unleaded gasoline for October delivery dropped 2.01 cents to 93.06 cents per gallon on Friday. Later contract months were also down. Home heating oil fell 4.26 cents to 83.98 cents per gallon for October, while later months were also down. Gasoline was down 3.26 cents for the week, while heating oil was up 8.09 cents over the four-day period. Friday's fall in oil prices helped boost the stock market. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 23.26 to 2,619.55, finishing the week with a gain of 5.19 points. Kevelson said oil made a steadier rise above the $30-per-barrel threshold this week than it had two weeks earlier, when it hit that level for the first time in nearly five years. Although no major news or rumors were moving the markets Friday, the bits of news that traders were watching tended to help keep prices down. Friday's selling was partly attributable to a report that the Saudis would be able to increase vastly their crude production by the end of the year. Anticipations that President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would issue a joint statement on the Persian Gulf after their summit Sunday in Helsinki, Finland, were also helping to keep oil prices lower. Traders were also calmed by more airlifting of hostages out of territory controlled by Iraq. Among other energy futures traded Friday on the Merc, natural gas settled at $1.510 per 1,000 cubic feet, compared with $1.530 a day earlier and $1.500 a week earlier.
