DOC.HEAD: Budget Bargainers Voice Optimism As Talks Resume
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, `Their goal ...' with 7 grafs to UPDATE with details of GOP, Democratic plans. Picks up 4th graf pvs `Unless lawmakers ...' SUBS 14th graf pvs, `Republicans have...' with 1 graf to DELETE reference to $7 billion. make defense cut figure conform. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and congressional leaders resumed budget talks Friday as lawmakers said foreign payments for U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf would ease some _ but not all _ pressure on the deficit. After a five-week break for Congress' summer vacation, negotiators returned to work in the main bar of the base Officers' Club, 10 miles from the capitol. Their goal was to finish by Monday a $50 billion package of tax boosts and spending cuts for next year and $500 billion in savings over the next five years. Reporters were confined to another building on the base about two miles away in an effort to reduce interruptions. Democrats and Republicans swapped plans Friday afternoon as the bargaining began, said officials who asked to not be identified. The administration proposal calls for $52.5 billion in savings next year and $513.2 billion over the next five years, one official said. It is similar to the budget Bush proposed in January, and to a July administration plan never formally released but revealed by GOP bargainers. The proposal calls for $4 billion in defense cuts and $15.5 billion in reductions in benefit programs, including Medicare. It seeks $20.4 billion in new taxes, including levies on alcohol and limits on the deduction allowed for state and local income taxes. It also calls for a cut in the capital gains tax rate, which Bush says would raise money by encouraging the sale of real estate and other property. Fewer details of the Democratic proposal were known. An official said it relied heavily on defense cuts and taxes, including levies on energy. The plan took no account of the costs of U.S. military operations in the Persian Gulf, the official said. Democrats have argued that the costs of Operation Desert Shield are similar to a one-time emergency and should not be counted in the government's long-range budgeting. Unless lawmakers and the administration enact a deal by Oct. 1, the Gramm-Rudman law will impose about $100 billion in cuts to most defense and domestic programs. Most participants on both sides say slashes of that amount would be so harsh that they could not be allowed to stand very long. Bargainers want to finish their work at Andrews by Monday to give Congress a chance to write the plan into law. As the talks began, bargainers reaffirmed their goal of slicing $50 billion off of next year's federal deficit. ``Nothing has happened anywhere that makes me less interested in getting this budget deficit under control once and for all,'' Bush told reporters as he arrived at the base for a 30-minute visit to the talks. ``If we needed a budget agreement five weeks ago, we need one more today,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. Since the talks recessed in late July, the economy has shown signs of weakening and Iraq and the United States have faced off in what may be a long-term standoff in the Persian Gulf. Legislators welcomed the news that Saudi Arabia, the exiled government of Kuwait, Japan and South Korea would be paying the United States billions of dollars to defray the costs of American forces in the Middle East. ``It helps out a little,'' said Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass. But with U.S. military expenses in the gulf expected to run about $1 billion per month _ barring large-scale fighting _ Conte and others cautioned that there was no reason to expect that the foreign help would put a major dent in the federal deficit. The administration has estimated that unless some savings are found, next year's deficit would be a record $250 billion. Fiscal 1991 begins Oct. 1. Republicans have been optimistic that because of the confrontation with Iraq, cuts to the $290 billion defense budget will be limited. ``I think we'll have an orderly defense build-down now,'' said Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas. ``I think we're not going to have the defense meltdown some people thought.'' Democrats have sought defense cuts more in the $9 billion to $16 billion range. Other important differences remained between Democrats and Republicans. Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., said Republicans were hoping for a package that would rely slightly more on spending cuts than on tax increases in the first year. Democrats want the two components to be equal in size. Domenici, Gramm and Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. _ all from energy-producing states _ said they wanted a plan that encouraged energy production with enticements such as tax credits. Democrats said they want a package that encourages the United States to move toward energy independence, with some officials saying privately that they have discussed some sort of new taxes on energy. ``Big differences remain,'' Bush said. ``It's going to take compromise.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises Against Most Currencies
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained against most major currencies except the Japanese yen Friday in a session traders described as eventless. Gold prices were marginally mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold for September delivery fell 20 cents to close at $389.50. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $390.00 for an ounce, up 15 cents from Thursday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. The dollar firmed slightly in reaction to a government report showing the nation's jobless rate rose to 5.6 percent in August from 5.5 percent the month before, traders said. ``I think people were anticipating a far worse figure,'' said Harlan Matusow, an assistant vice president in currency trading at the New York office of Bank Julius Baer & Co. Analysts said a bad unemployment report could have persuaded the Federal Reserve to ease credit. Lower interest rates tend to weaken the dollar. Much of the dollar's advance the rest of the day appeared to stem from investors covering short positions by buying dollars, he said. Traders who anticipated a worse unemployement report, and had been selling dollars, decided to cover their positions, he said. In addition, since the start of the Iraqi crisis, investors have been afraid to hold short positions over weekends for fear the dollar's value could be adversely affected by events before the market reopens on Monday, he said. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 140.25 Japanese yen from 141.65 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 140.15 yen. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 140.05 yen at late afternoon, down from 140.65 late Thursday. The dollar rose against the British pound. The pound cost $1.8933 in London, cheaper than $1.9075 late Thursday. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.8930 at late afternoon, down from $1.9125 late Thursday. British Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major said sterling won't join the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System during a weekend meeting of European finance officials. Rumors that the pound will join the mechanism have suppported the currency in recent months. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5680 German marks, up from 1.5560; 1.3055 Swiss francs, up from 1.2975; 5.2530 French francs, up from 5.2135; 1,170.50 Italian lire, up from 1,161.50; and 1.1634 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1563. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.5665 German marks, up from 1.5590; 1.3055 Swiss francs, up from 1.2985; 5.2465 French francs, up from 5.2168; 1.7653 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7545; 1,168.50 Italian lire, up from 1,162.50; and 1.1633 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1575. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $386.75 a troy ounce from $389.50 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to $387.00 an ounce from $388.80 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 64 cents to close at $388.23 an ounce. Silver bullion closed at $4.800 per troy oz. on the Comex, up from $4.770 late Thursday. Silver was unchanged in London at a late bid of $4.80 an ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Closing Georgia, Ohio Plants for a Week Apiece
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. said Friday it would shut down a truck plant in Ohio and a car plant in Georgia next week because of high inventories and a shortage of dealer orders. The company said its Lorain, Ohio, plant, which makes Ford Econoline vans, and its Atlanta factory, which makes Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable cars, would be closed in the week of Sept. 10. About 2,500 hourly workers will be laid off in Atlanta and about 2,000 in Ohio. Ford spokesman Joel Pitcoff said there were 92 selling days worth of unsold Econolines on dealer lots at the end of last month. Inventories stood at 66 days for Taurus and 74 days for Sable. The closing didn't sit well with Bill Allen, president of United Auto Workers union Local 425 in Lorain. The union is involved in local contract negotiations with the automaker. He said workers weren't told of the layoffs until after they reported for work Friday. ``Ford agreed to let us know a week to 10 days in advance of a layoff. They have no regard for workers whatsoever. It just creates total chaos,'' he said. Pitcoff said under normal circumstances the company will inform workers a week to 10 days before a planned shutdown. He said this notification came later because the company was trying to find other orders to justify continuation of production.

DOC.HEAD: Dow Jones Announces Appointments
DOC.TEXT: Dow Jones & Co. Inc., publisher of The Wall Street Journal, announced Friday that Bernard T. Flanagan, vice president of marketing for the newspaper, has been named to the same job at the parent company, a new position. Flanagan will report to Peter R. Kahn, president of Dow Jones, and will assist Kahn and other Dow Jones executives on overall advertising and marketing strategy, the company said. Flanagan, 59, will continue to direct the Journal's advertising efforts, it said. In other appointments, Paul Atkinson, the Journal's advertising sales director, was named vice president of advertising at the paper; Robert D. Higgins, director of advertising services for Dow Jones, was named to the additional post of director of advertising administration at the Journal; and James Friedlich, circulation director of The Wall Street Journal Europe, will be director of international sales and marketing for Dow Jones publications. All the appointments are effective Oct. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Court Report: Company Faces Insolvency by End of 1992
With AM-Manville Trust, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. has been financially devastated by liability for asbestos disease claims and faces insolvency by the end of 1992, a court-ordered report released Friday said. The report by former federal judge Marvin E. Frankel marked a major step in implementing a national class action for thousands of lawsuits filed against companies with insufficient assets to pay asbestos claims. The 24-page document was a stark portrayal of a company struggling under the weight of asbestos claims, which form the biggest product liability matter in U.S. history. Eagle-Picher, based in Cincinnati, is a maker of industrial products that used asbestos widely for years. Frankel said Eagle-Picher has more than 64,000 asbestos claims pending with another 20,000 being filed annually. The company's 1988 forecast of $613 million in asbestos liability was too optimistic, he said, and it faces a cash shortfall of up to $75 million by 1992. ``There is, in a word, a clear danger for disaster for Eagle-Picher within the next two years,'' the report said. ``There is a strong prospect of insolvency by the end of 1992.'' Frankel also said there is a ``clear risk'' the company will not be able to pay future claimants seeking to recover for asbestos injuries or deaths. Inhaled asbestos fibers can cause lung cancer and other respiratory ailments many years after the fact. ``At this time Eagle-Picher's options appear limited,'' Frankel said. ``Aggressive settlement of claims and aggressive litigation both require cash flow beyond current expectations.'' Frankel was appointed as a special master in the case last month by U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein. Frankel said Eagle-Picher met legal requirements for its claims to be converted into a class action. Weinstein has said he plans to pool the resources of Eagle-Picher and up to five other companies that don't have the money to fight cases in court or pay present and future claims. Weinstein's effort is part of a three-tiered plan to resolve 20 years of contentious litigation and clear state and federal courts nationwide of some 90,000 asbestos lawsuits. The judge has said he expects to combine funds from Eagle-Picher and the other companies with money from the Manville trust to settle claims. The Manville trust, formed after Manville Corp. reorganized in bankruptcy court, is in the process of being overhauled. A plan for Manville Corp. to inject up to $520 million in new money into the trust was announced Friday. Frankel said Eagle-Picher has paid out $5,990 per claim to settle about 64,000 claims to date, sharply higher than 1988 estimates. It also doled out $35 million on legal expenses last year while generating $27 million less from operations than projected. Eagle-Picher has been forced to sell off businesses to meet its asbestos claims, but even the recent divestiture of three divisions fell short by $12.3 million. Also, its remaining insurance for fiscal 1990 and 1991 is just $8 million, $17 million less than anticipated. ``The result is a picture . . . that is fraught with risks going to the company's very survival, let alone its ability to meet its asbestos liabilities,'' Frankel said. In addition to the fund created by Eagle-Picher and the other companies, a second part of the national asbestos plan called for a group of healthy companies facing claims to form a settlement fund in Cleveland. But that attempt was struck down by the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati, which said federal Judge Thomas D. Lambros did not have the right to consolidate cases outside his jurisdiction. The third phase of the plan _ a class action of cases that would go to trial _ is proceeding before federal Judge Robert M. Parker in Beaumont, Texas, where a hearing is set for next Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Kansas Gas and Electric Asks Regulators to Defer Action
DOC.TEXT: Kansas Gas and Electric Co. asked the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission Friday to defer action on Kansas City Power & Light Co.'s bid to acquire KG&E. KCPL launched an $857 million, or $27 per share, takeover of Kansas Gas & Electric on July 23. Kansas Gas' motion Friday asked regulators to deny KCPL's request for expedited approval of its acquistion plans. Kansas Gas claims FERC should wait until a federal lawsuit challenging the legality of the tender offer is resolved. The motion filed with FERC said ``it would not be in the public interest for the commission or the parties to consider the application if the transaction forming its basis is illegal.'' A KCPL spokesman said the company's offer complies with all legal requirements.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Soar on Supply Concerns, Technicals
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices soared more than 7 cents a pound to their highest levels in nearly a year Friday, reflecting renewed concerns that labor and production problems will lead to further tightening of supplies. On other commodity markets, precious metals were mixed; oil futures fell sharply; grains and soybeans were lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Copper futures settled 3.9 cents to 7.25 cents higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for spot delivery up 7.25 cents at $1.3545 a pound, the highest settlement of a near-term copper contract since Sept. 22, 1989. The most heavily traded contract, for December delivery, finished 6.95 cents higher at $1.3035 a pound. The rally followed an advance of 2.05 cents in the September contract on Thursday, making for a two-day gain of 9.3 cents or about 7.4 percent. Analysts said the surge in buying interest was prompted in part by reports of production setbacks or labor problems in a number of copper-producing countries including Chile, Peru, Zambia and Zaire. Frederick Demler, metals analyst with PaineWebber Inc., said two key developments were the shutdown due to environmental problems of an Exxon Corp. copper smelter in Chile and the rejection of a contract offer by striking copper miners in Peru. ``There are a number of production problems around the world and there are still relatively low worldwide inventories,'' Demler said. Tom Blaney, metals specialist with Balfour Maclaine Corp., said Friday's stronger stock market and steep drop in oil prices bolstered confidence in the economy and contribued to copper's gains. The Japanese were heavy buyers of copper, analysts said. Speculative funds also bought large amounts after the December contract surpassed $1.26 a pound, previously a point of a resistance. Gold futures edged lower on the Commodity Exchange, ending a three-day rally, but silver futures continued to advance. Gold settled 20 cents to 30 cents lower with September at $389.50 a troy ounce; silver was 2.4 cents to 3 cents higher with September at $4.80 a troy ounce. Crude oil futures gave back nearly all of Thursday's gains on the New York Mercantile Exchange as the standoff in the Persian Gulf appeared to sway in the direction of a peaceful settlement. A U.S.-chartered airlift plucked 165 Americans from occupied Kuwait on Friday and carried them to safety in Jordan, raising hopes the pace of freedom flights might quicken. And as President Bush prepared to meet with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Sunday to try to break the desert deadlock, Japan, South Korea and Kuwait promised financial aid to defray the cost of keeping 100,000 American troops in the Gulf region. Light sweet crude oil futures settled 95 cents to $1.45 lower with October at $30.04 a barrel; heating oil was 3.51 cents to 4.26 cents lower with October at 83.98 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.01 cents to 3.99 cents lower with October at 93.06 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures prices fell moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade amid profit-taking and fading expectations that the United States will grant agricultural export credits to the Soviet Union soon. Forecasts for rain this weekend in the Mississippi Delta region, where soybeans have been stressed by dry, hot conditions, also weighed on the soybean complex, said Pat O'Connell, grains analyst with Refco Inc. in Chicago. Wheat futures settled 2} cents to 3{ cents lower with September at $2.62} a bushel; corn was 1{ cents to 4\ cents lower with September at $2.38} a bushel; oats were 2\ cents to 2} cents lower with September at $1.08{ a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 5\ cents lower with September at $6.12\ a bushel. Cattle futures rose modestly on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in line with stronger cash cattle prices. Pork futures ended narrowly mixed ahead of Sunday's U.S.-Soviet summit meeting, which some analysts believe could produce an agreement on food export credits for the Soviets. Live cattle futures settled unchanged to .48 cent higher with October at 77.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .53 cent higher with September at 87.37 cents a pound; hogs futures were .25 cent lower to .32 cent higher with October at 49.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .10 cent lower to .07 cent higher with February at 52.12 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Rise as Oil Falls
DOC.TEXT: Government bond prices rose Friday as an oil price drop dampened inflation fears and an employment report offered some signs of a weakening economy. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond gained ] point, or $3.75 per 1,000 face amount. Its yield declined to 8.91 percent from late Thursday's 8.95 percent. Prices fell in morning trading after the government said August employment data showed weakness in the labor market _ but not enough to induce the Fed to foster an economic revival by lowering interest rates. The report said the civilian unemployment rate increased to 5.6 percent in August from 5.5 percent in July. Non-farm payroll employment dropped by 75,000 jobs, after a revised decline of 89,000 in July. A slight upward revision in the July payroll figures suggested to credit market participants that conditions in the job market, while bad, weren't as severe as previously thought. That left an ambiguous impression about the economy's health, which led some bond traders to believe that the Fed will refrain from acting until a clearer picture emerges. But market sentiment later shifted, in large part because oil futures prices declined, reducing the fear of worsening inflation. Light sweet crude fell $1.39 to $30.04 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Inflation is bad for the bond market because it erodes the value of fixed-income securities. Scott Winningham, a market analyst at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc. in Princeton, N.J., said bond prices had been following the oil market in lockstep until focus shifted to the employment report earlier this week. After the report was released, the focus again returned to oil, he said. ``Fed policy issues apparently are on the back burner as market participants concluded they are not going to ease imminently,'' Winningham said. In the secondary market for Treasury securities, prices of short-term governments gained about 3-32 point, intermediate maturities rose about 5-32 point, and long-term issues were up about ] point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, gained 1.97 to 1,146.70. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.60 percent as the discount declined 1 basis point to 7.37 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 7.71 percent as the discount added 1 basis point to 7.33 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.72 percent as the discount dropped 1 basis point to 7.21 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 percent, down from 8[ percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 89 19-32, up 1-32 point. The average yield to maturity held at 7.61 percent from late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Industry Threatened, Study Concludes
DOC.TEXT: Subsidies by European governments to Airbus Industrie, maker of the Airbus models of large commercial jet aircraft, threaten the competitiveness of the U.S. aircraft industry, according to a study prepared for the Commerce Department released Friday. On the average, 74 percent of the cost of developing Airbus models has been provided by the governments of France, Britain, West Germany and Spain, Commerce said. Member companies in the Airbus consortium have received or have been pledged more than $13 billion in direct government suppport, and if they had been required to pay interest at commercial rates, the value of that support would be $25 billion today, the department said. By the year 2008, Airbus will have paid out $30 billion more than it will have received, the department's summary concluded. If the subsidies continue, competing U.S. manufacturers will suffer reduced profits, either through lost sales or lower prices, Commerce said. The study was prepared by the consulting firm of Gellman Research Associates. The U.S. office of the European Common Market said in a statement it had not had time to study the report, but it was released in the middle of negotiations on the subject between the United States and the Common Market and was ``therefore untimely and unhelpful.'' Commerce says the U.S. aircraft industry earned $12 billion last year in overseas sales, after deducting the value of imports. Airbus' principal competitors are Boeing Corp. of Seattle and McDonnell-Douglas Corp. of St. Louis, which makes planes at Long Beach, Calif.

The nation's civilian unemployment rate hit a two-year high of 5.6 percent last month, the government said, reviving worries that the economy is on the brink of a recession _ if not already sliding in. The 0.1 percentage point rise, which followed a 0.3 percentage point increase in July, showed widespread sluggishness. Over the last two months, the ranks of the jobless have swelled by 550,000, according to the report issued Friday. ``There's a little bit of life, but it looks like it's ebbing away and we'll probably tilt into recession by the fourth quarter,'' said David Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a dealer of government securities.

Oil prices fell as traders sold futures to pocket their profits from the surge over $31 a barrel, but crude stayed higher for the week amid fears of supply shortages this winter. Light sweet crude for October delivery fell $1.39 to $30.04 per barrel Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later contract months also fell. For the week, October crude was up $2.72 per barrel following speculation that the Persian Gulf crisis may drag on. Prices also rose after government statements that supply shortages could be on the way.

Even minor disruptions of gasoline supply channels could cause shortages at gas pumps this winter, industry leaders and analysts warn. The problem isn't just that the cutoff of Iraqi and Kuwaiti supplies has cut the flow of crude oil. It's that replacement oil, mainly from stepped-up Saudi Arabian production, is heavier and contains more sulfur, making it less usable in U.S. refineries, experts said Friday.

President Bush and congressional leaders resumed budget talks as lawmakers said foreign payments for U.S. troops in the Middle East would ease some _ but not all _ pressure on the deficit. After a five-week break for Congress' summer vacation, negotiators returned to work here Friday. Their goal was to finish by Monday with a $50 billion package of tax boosts and spending cuts for next year and $500 billion in savings over the next five years.

Manville Corp. agreed to inject up to $520 million over seven years into an asbestos trust fund to reverse a cash shortfall jeopardizing compensation payments to tens of thousands of victims. The agreement Friday is the first step toward meeting more than 130,000 pending and untolled future claims by people who contracted lung cancer and other respiratory ailments inhaling fibers from Manville-made asbestos. The cash infusion, which would not begin until at least late 1991, is part of an overhaul ordered by a federal judge after the trust ran out of cash.

Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. has been financially devastated by liability for asbestos disease claims and faces insolvency by the end of 1992, a court-ordered report said. The report by former federal judge Marvin E. Frankel was released Friday and marked a major step in implementing a national class action for thousands of lawsuits filed against companies with insufficient assets to pay asbestos claims. Eagle-Picher, based in Cincinnati, is a maker of industrial products that used asbetsos widely for years.

The government must strike a delicate balance between its duty to clean up the savings and loan crisis and the need to protect S&L assets that have environmental value, federal officials told a congressional panel. The Resolution Trust Corp., the agency set up last year to take over and dispose of failed thrift institutions, has under its control 1,853 S&L properties believed to have important environmental, historical, recreational or scientific value, officials said Friday. The properties are worth about $340 million, the agency said.

The government did not intervene in the foreign exchange markets to support the dollar's value from May through July, the first time in four years it has refrained from taking action during one of its quarterly reporting periods, officials said. Federal Reserve System officials said Friday the dollar's slide against the German mark, British pound and Japanese yen during the quarter was not seen as a threat. ``This does not mean we're out of the intervention business or a change in policy or a change in approach,'' said Sam Y. Cross, executive vice president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, which manages the Fed's foreign-exchange operations.

Commodity markets have been buzzing for days about the possibility of a credit arrangement for Moscow when President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet this weekend. The administration favors liberalized trade and would like to see the United States grant most-favored-nation, or low tariff, status to the Soviet Union. But this would depend on Moscow changing policies to allow free emigration of its citizens. For nearly two decades, the Soviet Union has been a major force in U.S. agriculture _ a lucrative but sometimes erratic customer.

Stock prices closed out a week of erratic swings with a moderate rally Friday as oil prices fell. The Dow Jones average rose 23.26 to 2,619.55, finishing the week with a net gain of 5.19 points. The dollar gained against most major currencies except the Japanese yen Friday. Gold prices were marginally mixed. Copper futures prices soared more than 7 cents a pound to their highest levels in nearly a year. Precious metals were mixed; oil futures fell sharply; grains and soybeans were lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Bond prices were higher.

DOC.HEAD: Mineworkers' Leader to be Charged over Accounts
DOC.TEXT: Two top British mineworkers' leaders will be charged with improper accounting following an inquiry into union finances during the 1984-85 miners' strike, a court official said Friday. John Richman, a Sheffield Magistrates' Court clerk, said he had issued nine summonses against Arthur Scargill, president of the National Union of Mineworkers, and union general secretary Peter Heathfield, as well as against the union itself. The charges were brought by Trade Union Certification Officer Matthew Wake, a union watchdog responsible to the Department of Employment following the inquiry. The charges are failure to keep proper accounting records, failure to maintain a satisfactory system of accounting control, and failure to submit true and fair accounts in the return for 1989. The two men face fines if convicted. ``We have done nothing wrong and we shall contest the action all the way,'' Scargill said in response. ``This is the latest in a long line of attacks on the national leadership of the miners' union from the establishment who have never forgiven us for what we did in the 1984-85 miners' strike,'' he said. Scargill led the bitter and futile showdown with the government over the closure of unproductive mines. The union, which had 235,000 members at the time, now has 50,000, and 98 mines have been closed. In July the union sued Scargill to recover 1.4 million pounds, or about $2.6 million, that had been donated by Soviet and other East Bloc miners to help the British miners during the strike. The court granted the union a delay while it sought to settle the issue by negotiation, and on Monday, a union delegation heads to the Paris headquarters of the International Miners' Organization to determine control of the funds.
